1500.summary: Portuguese navigator Pedro Álvares Cabral and his crew become the first Europeans to discover Brazil, anchoring at Monte Pascoal and naming the country Vera Cruz

1500.event: First guide to distilling liquor published
1500.summary: The first guide to distilling of liquor is published, which could influence future practices in the production of alcohol and subsequently cultural practices
Pope Alexander VI issues a papal bull calling on a Roman Catholic crusade against the Ottoman Empire, indicating a significant religious and military mobilization
Sultan Abu Sa'id Qansuh of Egypt is overthrown and exiled, marking a political change in the Mamluk Sultanate
The Muscovites defeat the Lithuanians and the Poles in the Battle of Vedrosha, affecting the power dynamics in Eastern Europe
Christopher Columbus is placed under arrest after a new governor arrives, highlighting issues with his governance in the New World
Louis XII of France and Ferdinand II of Aragon sign the Treaty of Granada, agreeing to divide the Kingdom of Naples, affecting territorial claims in Italy

1500.event: Columbus arrives in Spain after arrest
1500.summary: Christopher Columbus and his brothers arrive in Spain after being arrested in the New World, which draws significant attention to his controversial rule
The last incunable is printed in Venice, marking the end of a significant era in book production and dissemination of knowledge
All charges against Columbus for governing issues in Hispaniola are dismissed, allowing him to maintain his status despite controversies

1501.summary: The first printed collection of polyphonic music is published by Ottaviano Petrucci in Venice
Portuguese explorer Pedro Álvares Cabral returns to Lisbon from India with a profit of nine times the investment
Formal coronation of King Shwenankyawshin of Burma takes place at Inwa in the Mandalay Region
The Livonian Order defeats an army of the Grand Duchy of Moscow in the Second Muscovite–Lithuanian War

1501.event: Grand Duke of Lithuania becomes King of Poland
1501.summary: Grand Duke Aleksandras Jogailaitis becomes the King of Poland as Aleksander I Jagiellończyk

1501.event: Ismail I enthroned as Shah of Iran
1501.summary: Ismail I becomes the first Shah of Iran, founding the Safavid dynasty
Michelangelo returns to Florence to begin work on the statue David
Italic type is first used by Aldus Manutius at the Aldine Press in Venice
Copernicus is formally installed as canon of Frauenberg Cathedral
Martin Luther enters the University of Erfurt

1502.event: Portuguese explorers sail into Guanabara Bay
1502.summary: Portuguese explorers, led by Gonçalo Coelho, sail into Guanabara Bay, Brazil, mistaking it for the mouth of a river.

1502.event: Marriage agreement between Scotland and England
1502.summary: Commissioners from Scotland and England meet to finalize an agreement on the marriage between Scotland's King James IV and Princess Margaret Tudor.
Isabella I issues an edict outlawing Islam in the Crown of Castile, forcing virtually all Muslim subjects to convert to Christianity.
Christopher Columbus begins preparation for his fourth and final voyage, aiming to find a westward passage in the New World.

1502.event: Death of Arthur, Prince of Wales
1502.summary: Arthur, Prince of Wales, the heir to the English throne, dies, leading to Henry, Duke of York, becoming the new heir.
Portuguese navigator João da Nova discovers the uninhabited island of Saint Helena.
Christopher Columbus leaves Cadiz in Spain for his fourth trip to the New World, taking 147 men on his flagship.
A powerful hurricane sweeps through the Caribbean, causing an estimated 500 deaths and wrecking many ships.
The first encounter between Europeans and the Maya people of Central America occurs when the Columbus brothers anchor at Guanaja.
Ismail I founds the Safavid dynasty and proclaims himself the Shah of Iran after defeating tribes of the Aq Qoyunlu confederation.

1503.summary: Christopher Columbus discovers the Cayman Islands, which he names Las Tortugas, after the numerous sea turtles there.
Construction of the Henry VII Chapel at Westminster Abbey begins in the perpendicular style, the final stage of English Gothic art.

1503.event: Treaty for Marriage of Henry and Catherine
1503.summary: Representatives of King Henry VII of England and Queen Isabella of Spain sign a treaty for 12-year-old Henry, Prince of Wales to be married to Catherine of Aragon.
Spanish forces under Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba defeat the French in the first battle in history won by gunpowder small arms.
Naples is captured by the Spanish.
Cardinal Giuliano della Rovere is elected as the 216th Roman Catholic Pontiff and takes the papal name Pope Julius II.

1503.event: Edict Against Violence to Indigenous Peoples
1503.summary: Queen Isabella I of Spain issues an edict prohibiting violence against indigenous peoples in the New World.
Spanish forces under Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba defeat a French–Italian mercenary army in the Battle of Garigliano.

1503.event: Marriage of James IV and Margaret Tudor
1503.summary: King James IV of Scotland marries Margaret Tudor, daughter of King Henry VII of England, at Holyrood Abbey.
Pope Alexander VI dies after a reign of 11 years, prompting a papal conclave.

1504.summary: Michelangelo's sculpture of David is unveiled, showcasing the pinnacle of Renaissance art.
France cedes Naples to Ferdinand II of Aragon, marking a significant territorial change.
Columbus uses knowledge of a lunar eclipse to obtain supplies from indigenous Jamaicans.
King James IV of Scotland opens the Scottish Parliament for the first time since 1496, promoting governance.
A significant battle is fought in Ireland, highlighting the ongoing conflicts in the region.
The Pope issues an order reforming the official coinage of the Papal States, impacting trade and economy.

1504.event: Queen Isabella and King Ferdinand's warrant
1504.summary: A Royal Warrant for the construction of Capilla Real is issued, symbolizing royal patronage of the arts.
A treaty is signed between key European powers, influencing the political landscape of the continent.
A water diversion project in Florence fails, leading to artistic and engineering implications.
Columbus returns from his explorations, bringing new knowledge and influence to Spain and Europe.

1505.summary: Pope Julius II issues a reform in the Roman Catholic Church to prohibit simony.
Pope Julius II sets the line of demarcation in the New World between Spain's and Portugal's territory.

1505.event: First recorded use of tennis rackets
1505.summary: Philip the Handsome plays tennis at Windsor Castle, marking the first recorded use of rackets.
Dom Francisco de Almeida departs from Portugal with an armada as the new Viceroy of Portuguese India.
King Alexander Jagiellon agrees to support a law prohibiting the king from issuing laws without consent.
A mass execution takes place in Sweden after a judgment of treason against city leaders.

1505.event: Foundation of the Portuguese State of India
1505.summary: The Portuguese establish control over territory in what is now Kerala, India.

1505.event: Construction of Fortaleza de Santo Ângelo begins
1505.summary: The King of Cannanore grants permission for Francisco de Almeida to build a fortress.
Érard de La Marck is elected as the prince-bishop of Liège.
Peter Henlein makes the earliest known pocket watch in Germany.

1506.summary: The classical statue of Laocoön and His Sons is unearthed in Rome and placed on public display in the Vatican.

1506.event: Foundation stone of St. Peter's Basilica
1506.summary: Pope Julius II lays the foundation stone of the new St. Peter's Basilica in Rome.
The Lisbon Massacre begins in Portugal, resulting in the torture and killing of thousands of Jews by Catholics.
The Treaty of Villafáfila is signed between Austria and Spain.
Philip the Fair becomes the ruler of the Spanish Kingdom of Castile but dies two months later.

1506.event: Sigismund I the Old becomes King
1506.summary: Sigismund I the Old succeeds his brother as king of Poland.
In Córdoba, members of the nobility and the public revolt against the Spanish inquisitor and liberate incarcerated people.

1506.event: Pope Julius II excommunicates Giovanni II Bentivoglio
1506.summary: Pope Julius II issues a bull excommunicating Giovanni II Bentivoglio from the Roman Catholic Church.
Pope Julius II leads his troops into Bologna, retaking the city from Giovanni II Bentivoglio.
Charles II, the son of King Philip of Castile, inherits his father's title of Duke of Burgundy.

1507.summary: Martin Waldseemüller publishes his Cosmographiae Introductio and accompanying wall map, the first to show the Americas as a separate continent, naming them in honour of Amerigo Vespucci.
Sigismund I the Old is formally crowned King of Poland, at a ceremony in Kraków.
The crew of the Portuguese ship Cirne, commanded by Diogo Fernandes Pereira, become the first Europeans to sight the Indian ocean island of Réunion.
German monk Martin Luther is ordained by the suffragan bishop Johann Bonemilch as a priest of the Catholic Church.
The revolutionary council of the Republic of Genoa declares a war against French invaders.
King James IV grants a patent for the first printing press in Scotland, allowing the printing of books within the realm.
The Kingdom of Portugal conquers the island of Ormuz in the Persian Gulf.
A fleet of 11 ships from the Portuguese Navy's 8th Armada arrives in India and rescues the Portuguese defenders of Fort Saint Angelo from attack.
Pope Julius II issues a damnatio memoriae forcing the members of the House of Borgia out of control of the Papal States.
Princess Mary of England, the 11-year-old daughter of King Henry VII, is betrothed to the 7-year-old Duke of Burgundy.

1508.summary: Maximilian, King of the Romans, proclaims himself Holy Roman Emperor at the Italian city of Trento after being blocked by Venice from traveling to Rome to be crowned.
La Cassaria by Ludovico Ariosto, the first Italian language comedy, is premiered at Ferrara.

1508.event: Contract to paint the Sistine Chapel
1508.summary: Michelangelo signs a contract with the Vatican to paint the Sistine Chapel ceiling, in return for a promised fee of 3,000 gold ducats.

1508.event: Start of the Sistine Chapel ceiling painting
1508.summary: Michelangelo begins painting the Sistine Chapel ceiling in the Holy See of Rome, on a commission by Pope Julius II.

1508.event: Formation of the League of Cambrai
1508.summary: The League of Cambrai is formed as an alliance against the Republic of Venice, including major European powers like Pope Julius II, Louis XII, and Maximilian I.

1508.event: Death of Cardinal Galeotto Franciotti della Rovere
1508.summary: England is left without a Roman Catholic Cardinal protector when Cardinal Galeotto Franciotti della Rovere dies suddenly.
The Emperor of Ethiopia, Na'od, dies in battle, leading to his son Lebna Dengel becoming the new emperor.
At the age of 16, Prince Wolfgang becomes the new ruler of the German principality of Anhalt-Köthen upon the death of his father.
Ferdinand II of Aragon appoints Florentine merchant Amerigo Vespucci to the post of Chief Navigator of Spain.
The Republic of Venice defeats Maximilian I in the Battle of Cadore, marking a significant military confrontation.

1509.summary: The Portuguese defeat a coalition of Indians, Muslims and Italians.

1509.event: Henry VIII becomes King of England
1509.summary: Henry VIII ascends to the throne following the death of his father, Henry VII.

1509.event: Marriage of Henry VIII and Catherine of Aragon
1509.summary: Henry VIII marries Catherine of Aragon, marking a significant political alliance.
French forces defeat the Venetians, leading to the occupation of Venice's mainland territories.
The siege ends with Venetian victory, causing a retreat of Holy Roman Empire and French forces.
Luca Pacioli's work on the golden ratio is published in Venice, illustrated by Leonardo da Vinci.

1509.event: Erasmus writes In Praise of Folly
1509.summary: Erasmus composes his most famous work, influencing humanist thought and culture.
Brasenose College at Oxford is established, contributing to the advancement of education in England.
Krishnadevaraya becomes the ruler of the Vijayanagara Empire, affecting cultural developments in the region.
The earthquake destroys numerous mosques and results in significant loss of life.

1510.summary: Sunflowers are brought to Europe by Spaniards.
Indigenous ǃUriǁʼaekua decisively defeat sailors of the Portuguese Empire in South Africa.
Afonso de Albuquerque of Portugal conquers Goa.
The Royal Dano-Norwegian Navy is founded when Henrich Krummedige is appointed chief captain of all those who are at sea.
Zhu Zhifan, Prince of Anhua, kills all the officials invited to a banquet and declares his intent on ousting the powerful Ming dynasty eunuch Liu Jin.
Sir Thomas More becomes undersheriff of the City of London.
Shah Ismail I defeats the Uzbek forces of Shaybani Khan in Khorasan.
Mingyi Nyo declares independence from the Ava Kingdom by establishing the Toungoo dynasty.
Catherine of Aragon gives birth to her first child, a stillborn daughter.

1510.event: The Grand Prince of Moscow conquers Pskov
1510.summary: The Grand Prince of Moscow Vasili III conquers Pskov.

1511.summary: The 1511 Idrija earthquake occurs, affecting a large territory between Carinthia, Friuli, present-day Slovenia and Croatia.
St John's College, Cambridge, England, founded by Lady Margaret Beaufort, receives its charter.
Henry VIII of England's flagship, the Mary Rose, is launched at Portsmouth.
Afonso de Albuquerque of Portugal conquers Malacca, gaining control over the Strait of Malacca.
Pope Julius II proclaims a Holy League against French dominance in Italy.
James IV of Scotland's great ship, the Michael, is launched at Newhaven, Edinburgh, becoming the largest ship afloat.
The Treaty of Westminster creates an alliance between Henry VIII of England and Ferdinand II of Aragon against France.

1511.event: Sinking of Frol de la Mar
1511.summary: The vessel Frol de la Mar, transporting Afonso de Albuquerque, sinks en route to Goa.

1511.event: Publication of The Praise of Folly
1511.summary: Erasmus publishes his most famous work, The Praise of Folly, contributing to the Renaissance humanism.
The indigenous Taíno people revolt against the Spanish in southwestern Puerto Rico near Guánica.

1512.summary: Eric Trolle is elected as the new Regent of Sweden but is soon ousted in favor of Sten Sture the Younger.
The French carry out the Sack of Brescia during the War of the League of Cambrai.
The French army defeats the Spanish in the Battle of Ravenna but suffers the death of Gaston of Foix.
The Fifth Council of the Lateran convenes to address various church reforms.
Selim I becomes the Sultan of the Ottoman Empire, marking a significant shift in power.
The English navy defeats the French-Breton fleet at the Battle of Saint-Mathieu, showcasing naval warfare advancements.

1512.event: Martin Luther becomes a Doctor of Theology
1512.summary: Martin Luther earns his doctorate in theology, marking the beginning of significant religious reform.

1512.event: Ceiling of the Sistine Chapel exhibited
1512.summary: Michelangelo's celebrated ceiling of the Sistine Chapel is displayed to the public for the first time.
The Spanish Crown issues the Laws of Burgos governing settlers' conduct towards native Indians in the New World.
The dismantling of the Florentine Republic begins, leading to the return of the Medici family to power.

1513.event: Pope Leo X succeeds Pope Julius II
1513.summary: Pope Leo X, Giovanni di Lorenzo de' Medici, becomes the 217th pope amidst challenges from Italian cardinals.

1513.event: Juan Ponce de León sights Florida
1513.summary: Juan Ponce de León becomes the first European to sight Florida, mistaking it for another island.
Juan Ponce de León and his expedition become the first Europeans known to visit Florida.
Swiss mercenaries defeat the French, forcing them to abandon Milan and Italy during the Italian Wars.
Christian II ascends to the throne as King of Denmark and Norway.
King James IV of Scotland is defeated and killed in battle against the English army.

1513.event: Vasco Núñez de Balboa sees the Pacific Ocean
1513.summary: Vasco Núñez de Balboa becomes the first European to see the Pacific Ocean from the Isthmus of Darién.
Spanish troops decisively defeat the Republic of Venice in the War of the League of Cambrai.
Appenzell becomes a member of the Swiss Confederacy, indicating a shift in political alliances.

1513.event: Peace between Louis XII and the Pope
1513.summary: Louis XII of France makes peace with the Pope, attempting to resolve conflicts with Spain as well.

1514.summary: Albrecht Dürer creates a significant engraving that influences art and culture.
A major fire breaks out in the Rialto district of Venice, causing significant destruction.
An exotic embassy from King Manuel I of Portugal arrives in Rome, including an Indian elephant.

1514.event: Peace Agreement between France and Holy Roman Empire
1514.summary: Louis XII of France makes peace with Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor, impacting European diplomacy.
The Poor Conrad peasant revolt against Duke Ulrich in Beutelsbach begins, affecting social dynamics.
The earliest printed edition of Saxo Grammaticus' history is published, contributing to the preservation of cultural heritage.

1514.event: Dedication of Henry Grace à Dieu
1514.summary: The largest warship at the time, Henry Grace à Dieu, is dedicated in England, highlighting naval advancements.
King Christian II is crowned King of Norway, marking a significant event in Norwegian history.

1514.event: Peace Treaty between England and France
1514.summary: King Henry VIII of England concludes a peace treaty with France, impacting relations in Europe.
In a major battle, Polish and Lithuanian forces defeat the Grand Duchy of Moscow, influencing regional power balances.

1515.summary: Louis XII of France dies leading to the ascension of Francis, Dauphin of France.
Francis I of France is crowned King of France in the Cathedral of Reims.

1515.event: Marriage of Mary Tudor and Charles Brandon
1515.summary: Mary Tudor, Queen of France, marries Charles Brandon, 1st Duke of Suffolk, at Greenwich.
The army of Ottoman sultan Selim I defeats the beylik of Dulkadir under Bozkurt of Dulkadir.
Manchester Grammar School is endowed by Hugh Oldham as the first free grammar school in England.
A double wedding at the First Congress of Vienna cements agreements between royal families.
Francis I of France's army defeats Swiss mercenaries, restoring French control of Milan.
Thomas Wolsey is invested as a Cardinal, increasing his influence in England.
Cardinal Wolsey orders the construction of what will become Henry VIII's summer residence, Hampton Court Palace.
Bartolomé de las Casas urges Ferdinand II of Aragon to end Amerindian slavery.

1516.event: Death of Ferdinand II of Aragon
1516.summary: With the death of Ferdinand II of Aragon, his grandson, Charles of Ghent, becomes King of Spain.
Desiderius Erasmus publishes a new Greek edition of the New Testament in Basel.
The Venetian Ghetto is instituted in the Republic of Venice.
The Reinheitsgebot is instituted in Ingolstadt, Bavaria, regulating the purity of beer.
Selim I of the Ottoman Empire declares war on the Mamluk Sultanate of Egypt and invades Syria.
The Treaty of Noyon is signed, with Francis I recognizing Charles I's claim to Naples.
King Francis I of France and Pope Leo X sign the Concordat of Bologna, agreeing on church and state relations.
The Ottoman Sultan Selim I defeats the Mamluk forces at the Battle of Marj Dabiq.
Ottoman forces under Grand Vizier Sinan Pasha defeat the Mamluks near Gaza.
Thomas More's most famous work, Utopia, is completed and published in Leuven.

1517.summary: The Holy Ottoman army defeats the Mamluk army in Egypt
Cairo is captured by the Ottoman Empire after a three day battle
Portuguese merchant Fernão Pires de Andrade meets Ming Dynasty officials in China
Martin Luther publishes his 95 Theses, marking the Reformation

1517.event: Fifth Council of the Lateran ends
1517.summary: The Fifth Council of the Lateran concludes its sessions
Xenophobic riots break out in London
The Mamluk Sultanate falls after the Ottoman conquest
Grand Prince Vasili III of Muscovy conquers Ryazan
A third outbreak of sweating sickness hits Oxford and Cambridge
The Abbasid Caliphate of Cairo falls to the Ottomans

1518.event: Marriage of Sigismund I the Old
1518.summary: Sigismund I the Old marries Milanese noblewoman Bona Sforza and she is crowned as Queen consort of Poland.
A transit of Venus occurs, capturing the interest of astronomers and scientists across Europe.
A case of dancing mania breaks out in Strasbourg, leading to numerous deaths from constant dancing.
The construction of Manchester Grammar School is completed in England, enhancing education opportunities.
The Treaty of London is signed, temporarily ensuring peace in Western Europe.
Deccan sultanates in southern India declare their independence from the Bahmani Sultanate.
The Rajput Mewar Kingdom achieves a major victory over Sultan Ibrahim Lodi of Delhi.
Johann Froben publishes Erasmus's work Colloquies, an unauthorized edition that impacts literature and education.

1518.event: Publication of Ayn neu Kunstlich Buech
1518.summary: Henricus Grammateus publishes Ayn neu Kunstlich Buech, which features the earliest printed use of plus and minus signs.

1518.event: Caliphate title handed over to Ottomans
1518.summary: The Abbasid Caliphate hands over the title of caliph to the Ottoman Empire, marking a significant political shift.

1519.summary: Martin Luther joins the debate regarding papal authority, against Johann Eck at Leipzig

1519.event: Charles I becomes Holy Roman Emperor
1519.summary: Charles I of Spain becomes Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, ruling until 1556
Hernán Cortés enters Tenochtitlan, the court of Aztec ruler Moctezuma
Ferdinand Magellan departs from Spain with a fleet of five ships to sail to the Spice Islands
Cacao comes to Europe, potentially impacting food and culture

1519.event: Pandemic spreads in the New World
1519.summary: A large pandemic spreads from the Greater Antilles into Central America, killing much of the indigenous population
The Prince of Ning rebellion begins, trying to capture Nanjing
Panama City is founded, marking an important event in colonial expansion
Wang Yangming defeats Zhu Chenhao, using advanced weaponry in the process

1519.event: First recorded fatal gun accident in England
1519.summary: The first recorded fatal accident involving a gun occurs at Welton, East Riding of Yorkshire

1520.summary: King Christian II of Denmark and Norway defeats the Swedes, leading to a significant shift in power dynamics in Scandinavia
Citizens of Toledo rise up against Charles V's rule, illustrating growing unrest in Castile
Moctezuma II is declared deposed during the Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire, marking a key moment in colonial tensions

1520.event: Meeting at Field of the Cloth of Gold
1520.summary: King Henry VIII of England meets King Francis I of France in a lavish display of diplomacy and power
1520.city: Field of the Cloth of Gold

1520.summary: Pope Leo X issues a bull threatening Martin Luther with excommunication, highlighting tensions within the Catholic Church
Cuitláhuac's forces win a significant battle against Hernán Cortés, marking a turning point in the Aztec resistance

1520.event: Christian II's Triumphant Entry into Stockholm
1520.summary: Christian II enters Stockholm after its surrender, cementing his power in Sweden
Suleiman I succeeds as Sultan of the Ottoman Empire, indicating a new era of Ottoman expansion
Christian II is crowned king of Sweden, further establishing his rule over the region
82 nobles and clergymen are executed for their resistance against Danish rule, causing outrage and unrest

1521.event: Pope Leo X excommunicates Martin Luther
1521.summary: Pope Leo X excommunicates Martin Luther, marking a significant moment in the Protestant Reformation
Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, opens the Diet of Worms, a crucial event in the conflict between Catholicism and Protestantism
Martin Luther is examined before Emperor Charles V and refuses to recant his writings, asserting his beliefs
Charles V declares Martin Luther an outlaw and bans his literature, escalating tensions in Europe
Suleiman the Magnificent begins the siege of Belgrade, showcasing the territorial ambitions of the Ottoman Empire
Ferdinand Magellan is killed in the Philippines during a conflict with local warriors
The surrender of Cuauhtémoc to Cortés leads to the incorporation of the Aztec Empire into the Spanish Empire
French forces are defeated by the Spanish, blocking their attempt to recover the Kingdom of Navarre
The uprising against the Spanish crown is decisively defeated
The oldest surviving document written in Romanian is produced, highlighting emerging national identity

1522.summary: The papal conclave concludes with the election of Adriaan Florensz Boeyens, marking the last non-Italian pope for the next 450 years.
The Revolt of the Comuneros is re-ignited in Castile after King Carlos V reneges on promised amnesty, leading to significant unrest.
The co-rulers Duke Wilhelm IV and Duke Ludwig X agree to reform the Roman Catholic Church within Bavaria, initiating the Counter-Reformation.
Pastor Huldrych Zwingli publicly challenges food restrictions of Lent, sparking the Reformation in Zurich.
Charles V visits King Henry VIII of England, signing the Treaty of Windsor to pledge a joint invasion of France.

1522.event: Publication of Martin Luther's New Testament
1522.summary: Martin Luther's translation of the New Testament into Early New High German is published, achieving rapid sales.
A devastating earthquake strikes Almeria, killing over 2,500 people and destroying the city.
A significant earthquake kills more than 4,000 people on the Azores Islands, marking a catastrophic event in the region's history.

1522.event: Surrender of the Knights in Rhodes
1522.summary: The Ottomans capture Rhodes after fierce resistance from the Knights of St. John, marking a pivotal moment in the Ottoman expansion.

1522.event: Publication of Erasmus's Greek Textus Receptus
1522.summary: The third edition of Erasmus's Greek Textus Receptus of the New Testament is published, influencing biblical scholarship.

1523.summary: Christian II is forced to abdicate as King of Denmark and Norway after nobles renounce allegiance in favor of Frederick, Duke of Holstein
Construction of Fort Kastela completed by Portuguese invaders in the Spice Islands, claiming the region for Portugal
Portuguese troops sack the capital Al-Shihr on the Arabian Peninsula after a day-long battle
Martin Luther's supporter rescues nuns from a convent in Germany, influencing the Reformation
Charles V brings the Spanish Inquisition to the Netherlands by appointing an inquisitor general
Gustav Vasa is elected king of Sweden, marking the end of the Kalmar Union and the establishment of modern Sweden
Martin Luther's German translation of the Pentateuch is published, impacting religious and cultural life
Death of Pope Adrian VI marks the end of Dutch papacy, leading to a long succession of Italian popes
Cardinal Giulio de' Medici is elected Pope Clement VII, beginning a reign of consecutive Italian Popes
Pedro de Alvarado begins the Spanish conquest of Guatemala, contributing to European expansion

1524.event: Verrazzano's Expedition Makes Landfall at Cape Fear
1524.summary: Verrazzano's expedition makes landfall at Cape Fear at what is later the U.S. state of North Carolina.

1524.event: First European Entry into New York Bay
1524.summary: Verrazzano's expedition makes the first European entry into New York Bay, and sights the island of Manhattan.
Spanish forces under Charles de Lannoy defeat the French army in Italy, leading to the French withdrawal from the Italian Peninsula.

1524.event: Coronation of Frederick I of Denmark
1524.summary: Frederick I is elected King of Norway and later crowned in Copenhagen.
The French city of Marseille is besieged by Holy Roman Empire forces and lasts until September.
By the Treaty of Malmö, Sweden withdraws from the Kalmar Union with Denmark.
Spanish conquistadors set off on the first expedition to conquer Peru, taking 80 men and 40 horses.
John Fleming, Lord Chancellor of Scotland, is assassinated by John Tweedie and others.
The Bundesbrief is adopted by the members of the Three Leagues of Switzerland as a common constitution.
Francisco Hernandez de Cordoba founds the city of Granada, Nicaragua, the oldest Hispanic city in mainland America.

1525.summary: The Anabaptist Movement is born when Conrad Grebel and others baptize each other in Zürich, breaking a thousand-year tradition.
German and Spanish forces defeat the French army, capturing Francis I of France, which influences European power dynamics.
The first human rights related document is published in Memmingen, highlighting the plight of the peasantry.

1525.event: German Peasants' War - Battle of Frankenhausen
1525.summary: Insurgent peasants led by Thomas Müntzer are defeated, leading to his execution and the end of significant peasant uprisings.
Martin Luther marries Katharina von Bora, marking a significant personal and social transformation in the Reformation.
A large part of the book collection in Zurich is burned as part of the Swiss Reformation, affecting culture and knowledge.
Charles V issues an edict ordering the expulsion or conversion of Muslims in the Crown of Aragon, impacting citizens and community dynamics.

1525.event: First edition of Tyndale's New Testament
1525.summary: The printing of William Tyndale's New Testament translation into English is disrupted by anti-Lutheran forces, reflecting the religious turmoil.
A peace treaty between Scotland and England is agreed, impacting the stability of the region.
The printing of Huldrych Zwingli's New Testament translation into German begins, contributing to religious reform and literacy.

1526.summary: Peace is declared between Francis I of France and Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, leading to significant territorial changes.

1526.event: Formation of the League of Torgau
1526.summary: German princes form an alliance to oppose the 1521 Edict of Worms, impacting the political landscape in Germany.
Babur invades northern India and captures Delhi, establishing the Mughal Empire, which influences regional politics and culture.
The Sultan of the Ottoman Empire agrees to a military alliance with France, affecting European power dynamics.

1526.event: Repudiation of the Treaty of Madrid
1526.summary: Francis I repudiates the Treaty of Madrid and forms the League of Cognac against Charles, changing the balance of power in Europe.
The Ottoman army defeats the Hungarian army, leading to significant changes in Hungarian leadership and territory.

1526.event: First complete printed translation of the New Testament into English
1526.summary: William Tyndale's translation arrives in England, impacting literacy and religious practices.

1526.event: Foundation of San Miguel de Gualdape
1526.summary: Lucas Vázquez de Ayllón establishes the first European settlement in South Carolina, marking a significant moment in colonization.
Mughal Emperor Babur and Crown Prince Humayun order the execution of Afghan prisoners, showcasing the brutality of the era.

1526.event: Issuance of Proclamation against Tyndale's New Testament
1526.summary: Cuthbert Tunstall directs followers to destroy copies of Tyndale's translation, reflecting tensions in religious reforms.

1527.summary: Ferdinand of the House of Habsburg is formally crowned as King of Bohemia
Spanish and German troops led by the Duke of Bourbon sack Rome, forcing Pope Clement VII to make peace with Charles V, marking the end of the High Renaissance
The Riksdag of the Estates in Västerås adopts Lutheranism as the state religion, marking a significant religious shift and suppression of Catholic property

1527.event: Crowning of Ferdinand as King of Hungary
1527.summary: Archduke Ferdinand of Austria is formally crowned as the King of Hungary at the Basilica of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary
Mughal Emperor Babur defeats Rajput ruler Rana Sanga, leading to Mughal dominance in northern India
The Érdy Codex, the largest collection of Hungarian legends and literature, is completed by an unidentified monk
King Frederick I declares religious tolerance for Lutherans, significantly impacting the Lutheran community

1527.event: Formation of the Republic of Florence
1527.summary: The Piagnon drive out the Medici, re-establishing the Republic of Florence until 1530
The Narváez expedition to conquer Florida sets sail from Spain, initiating exploration of the region
Jovan Nenad, a self-proclaimed Emperor of the Serbs, is assassinated following his defeat at the Battle of Sződfalva

1528.summary: Gustav I of Sweden is crowned king of Sweden, having already reigned since his election in June 1523
Poland's King Stanisław II Augustus establishes the zloty as the Kingdom's official currency as part of an extensive monetary reform
The Battle of Szina is fought in the Kingdom of Hungary between the rival kings, with Zápolya being defeated by Habsburg mercenaries
The French Army, under Marshal Odet of Foix, begins a siege of Melfi, leading to a massacre of more than 3,000 defenders
The French fleet crushes the Spanish squadron trying to run the blockade of Naples
King James V of Scotland escapes from Edinburgh to Stirling after more than two years of captivity
The fourth major outbreak of the sweating sickness is recorded, causing panic and fear across London
The Peace of St. Ambrose is signed in Milan, ending civil strife in the region
Askia Muhammad I, ruler of the Songhai Empire, is forced to abdicate by his son

1528.event: Defeat of French forces at Naples
1528.summary: The Siege of Naples fails, leading to the elimination of French forces and the establishment of Imperial control

1529.event: Basarab VI becomes Prince of Wallachia
1529.summary: Basarab VI is installed as the new Prince of Wallachia shortly after the assassination of Voivode Radu of Afumați.

1529.event: Zhang Qijie becomes powerful in Ming China
1529.summary: Zhang Qijie becomes the most powerful woman in the Ming dynasty as the primary wife of the Jiajing Emperor.
The Örebro Synod provides the theological foundation for the Swedish Reformation.
The Battle of Shimbra Kure is fought with Imam Ahmad defeating a much larger army using firearms.
A group of rulers protest the reinstatement of the Edict of Worms, beginning the Protestant movement.
The Treaty of Zaragoza divides the eastern hemisphere between the Spanish and Portuguese empires.
French forces are decisively defeated by Spain in the Battle of Landriano during the War of the League of Cognac.
Charles V and Francis I sign the Treaty of Cambrai, impacting power dynamics in Italy.
Vienna is besieged by the Ottoman Turks, marking a significant confrontation in European history.
Cardinal Wolsey falls from power due to his failure to secure an annulment for King Henry VIII.

1530.summary: The Augsburg Confession is presented to Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, representing a significant moment in the Protestant Reformation.
Charles V is crowned emperor in Bologna, solidifying his power and influence across Europe.
King François of France marries Eleanor of Austria, strengthening political ties between France and Austria.
Tangaxuan II, the last cazonci of the Purépecha Empire, is executed, marking the end of the empire's independence.
The Knights of Malta are formally established when the Knights Hospitaller are granted Malta by Charles V.
Spanish troops capture Florence during the Battle of Gavinana, restoring the Medici power in the city.
A significant flood engulfs Rome, causing widespread damage in the city.
An agreement is reached involving a tribute to Charles V for the governance of Tripoli and Malta.
Purépecha Empire is ended as Tangaxuan II is executed, leading to Spanish dominance in the region.
Members of the Imperial Diet meet in Augsburg to prepare the Augsburg Confession, marking a key event in the Protestant Reformation.

1531.summary: More than 30,000 people are killed in Portugal in an earthquake and subsequent tsunami
Lutheran princes in the Holy Roman Empire form an alliance known as the Schmalkaldic League
Emperor Askiya Musa of the Songhai Empire is assassinated by his brothers
The city of Puebla, Mexico, is founded
The Moldavians are defeated by Polish forces under Jan Tarnowski
The first Parliament of Ireland in more than nine years is opened at Kilkea Castle
The forces of Zürich are defeated by the Catholic cantons and Huldrych Zwingli is killed

1531.event: Arrival of Christian II in Oslo
1531.summary: Christian II's invasion force arrives in Oslo

1531.event: Appearance of the Virgin of Guadalupe
1531.summary: The Virgin of Guadalupe first appears to Juan Diego at Tepeyac

1532.summary: São Vicente is established as the first permanent Portuguese settlement in Brazil.

1532.event: Abolishment of the Republic of Florence
1532.summary: The democratic government of the Republic of Florence is abolished to establish a hereditary monarchy under Pope Clement VII.
The Nuremberg Religious Peace is granted, allowing religious liberty to members of the Schmalkaldic League.
The Duchy of Brittany is absorbed into the Kingdom of France.
The siege of Güns begins as the Ottoman army attempts to capture the city, facing a significantly smaller defending force.
Francisco Pizarro and his men capture Inca emperor Atahualpa at Cajamarca, offering a ransom of approximately $50 million in gold.
A fire strikes the cathedral in Chambéry, damaging the Shroud of Turin, which is later repaired by nuns.
The Prince is published, five years after the death of author Niccolò Machiavelli.
Pantagruel is published by François Rabelais.
Henry VIII grants a Royal Charter to the Thorne brothers to found Bristol Grammar School.

1533.event: Marriage of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn
1533.summary: King Henry VIII of England formally but secretly marries Anne Boleyn, who becomes his second queen consort.
Henry VIII is excommunicated by Pope Clement VII, as is Archbishop Cranmer.
The Statute in Restraint of Appeals in England declares the king to be the supreme sovereign and forbids judicial appeals to the papacy.
King Henry VIII of England's marriage with Catherine of Aragon is declared annulled by Archbishop Cranmer.
Anne Boleyn, the second wife of King Henry VIII, gives birth to a daughter who will become Elizabeth I of England.
A treaty is established between the Ottoman Empire and the Archduchy of Austria, affecting territorial claims in Hungary.
Sapa Inca Atahualpa is executed by garotte in Cajamarca at the orders of Francisco Pizarro.

1533.event: Marriage of Henry, Duke of Orléans and Catherine de' Medici
1533.summary: The marriage ceremony of 14-year old Henry, Duke of Orléans and Catherine de' Medici takes place in Marseille.
Cranmer crowns Anne Boleyn as queen consort of England in Westminster Abbey.
Ivan IV succeeds his father as Grand Prince of Muscovy at the age of three and will rule until 1584.

1534.summary: The Parliament of England passes the Act Respecting the Oath to the Succession, recognising the marriage of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn, and their children as the legitimate heirs to the throne.
Ignatius of Loyola and six others take the vows that lead to the establishment of the Jesuits (the Society of Jesus), in Montmartre, near Paris.
Cambridge University Press is given a Royal Charter by Henry VIII of England, and becomes the first of the privileged presses.
Martin Luther's translation of the complete Christian Bible into German is offered for sale for the first time, adding the Old Testament and the Apocrypha.
Cardinal Alessandro Farnese is elected as the 220th pope of the Roman Catholic Church and takes the name Pope Paul III.

1534.event: Completion and distribution of Luthern Bible
1534.summary: The first complete Christian Bible translated into German by Martin Luther is printed and sold, greatly influencing literacy and access to religious texts.
The Ottoman army under Suleiman the Magnificent captures the city of Baghdad from the Safavids, beginning almost 400 years of Ottoman rule.
Over 200 Spanish settlers, led by conquistador Sebastián de Belalcázar, found what becomes Quito, Ecuador.
Huguenots post placards all over France attacking the Catholic Mass, provoking a violent sectarian reaction known as the Affair of the Placards.
The English Reformation Parliament passes the Act of Supremacy, establishing Henry VIII as supreme head of the Church of England.

1535.summary: Lima is founded by Francisco Pizarro, establishing a significant city in Peru.
French Protestant leaders are burned to death in front of the Cathedral of Notre-Dame, witnessed by King François.
Fray Tomás de Berlanga discovers the Galápagos Islands while en route to Peru.
Go-Nara is formally installed as the 105th Emperor of Japan.
Sir Thomas More is executed for refusing to recognize King Henry VIII as head of the English Church.

1535.event: Publication of the First Complete English Bible
1535.summary: The first complete English-language Bible is printed in Antwerp, translating works by William Tyndale and Myles Coverdale.

1535.event: Papal Bull by Pope Paul III
1535.summary: Pope Paul III issues a papal bull to reform the city of Rome and the Roman Curia.
The Conquest of Tunis begins with the destruction of Barbarossa's fleet by Charles V.

1535.event: Claim of the Duchy of Milan
1535.summary: Charles V claims the Duchy of Milan as his inheritance, leading to a dispute with King François of France.

1535.event: Appointment of the First Viceroy of New Spain
1535.summary: Antonio de Mendoza is appointed as the first Viceroy of New Spain, overseeing a vast colonial territory.

1536.event: Establishment of Colegio de Santa Cruz de Tlatelolco
1536.summary: The Colegio de Santa Cruz de Tlatelolco, the oldest European school of higher learning in the Americas, is established by Franciscans.
Tyrolean Anabaptist leader Jacob Hutter is burned at the stake for heresy in Innsbruck.
King Henry VIII of England is seriously injured in a jousting tournament after falling from his horse.
A Franco-Ottoman alliance is established which exempts French merchants from Ottoman law.
The first edition of John Calvin's Institutes of the Christian Religion is published in Basel, impacting Protestant theology.
The Reformation Parliament in England passes an Act for the Dissolution of the Monasteries under Henry VIII.
Anne Boleyn, second queen of Henry VIII, is arrested and later beheaded on charges of incest, adultery, and treason.
The Inquisition is implemented in Portugal, affecting religious practices and freedoms.

1536.event: Marriage of Henry VIII to Jane Seymour
1536.summary: Henry VIII marries Jane Seymour shortly after the execution of Anne Boleyn, marking a significant political shift.
The Pilgrimage of Grace, a rebellion against Henry VIII's church reforms, begins, spreading across England.

1537.event: Marriage of Princess Madeleine of Valois
1537.summary: The marriage of Princess Madeleine of Valois to King James V of Scotland takes place at Notre-Dame de Paris
Alessandro de' Medici, Duke of Florence, is assassinated by Lorenzino de' Medici
An uprising led by Francis Bigod against Henry VIII begins with an attempt to seize Scarborough Castle
Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada conquers Bacatá, the main settlement of the Muisca Confederation

1537.event: Pope Paul III publishes Sublimis Deus
1537.summary: Pope Paul III declares that the natives of the New World are rational beings with souls
Christian III is crowned King of Denmark and King of Norway in Copenhagen
The city of Asunción is founded by Juan de Salazar de Espinosa

1537.event: First election in the New World
1537.summary: King Carlos I of Spain issues a decree for the first election in the New World
King François I signs a law requiring authors to submit copies of their work to the government
Myles Coverdale's complete Bible translation is published in England for the first time

1538.summary: Peace is declared between Emperor Charles V and Francis I of France.
Peace is declared between Ferdinand I and the Ottoman Empire, recognizing John Zápolya as King of Hungary.

1538.event: Dissolution of the Monasteries in England
1538.summary: The newly founded Bisham Abbey is dissolved, part of a larger religious reform in England.

1538.event: Foundation of the Universidad Santo Tomás de Aquino
1538.summary: The first university of the New World is founded on the island of Hispaniola.
The Ottoman fleet defeats the Holy League's naval forces in a significant battle.
The city of Guayaquil is founded by Spanish conqueror Francisco de Orellana.
Garcia de Noronha is appointed as the new Governor-General of Portuguese India.

1538.event: Michelangelo begins work on the Piazza del Campidoglio
1538.summary: Michelangelo starts work on significant architectural project in Rome.
Pope Paul III confirms the excommunication of Henry VIII from the Roman Catholic church.
The city of Bogotá is founded by Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada.

1539.summary: Charles V and Francis I agree to make no further alliances with England after Henry VIII's split with Rome.
A truce is agreed between Charles V and Protestant states, halting violent actions for 15 months.
The inaugural declaration of the Protestant Reformation takes place with Martin Luther present.
King Francis I makes French the official language of legal discourse in France.
The Ottoman Empire's siege ends with a significant defeat for the Spanish defenders.
Joachim II Hector becomes the second Prince-Elector to adopt Lutheranism in Germany.
Several abbeys in England fall prey to the dissolution, impacting religious and cultural institutions.

1539.event: First printing press in North America
1539.summary: The first printing press is set up in Mexico City, facilitating the spread of literature and ideas.
The first edition of the Calvinist Genevan Psalter is published, influencing music composition.

1539.event: Introduction of Middle Eastern languages to Europe
1539.summary: Teseo Ambrogio publishes works introducing several Middle Eastern languages.

1540.event: Marriage of Henry VIII and Anne of Cleves
1540.summary: King Henry VIII marries Anne of Cleves, his fourth Queen consort; the marriage lasts six months.
Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, enters Ghent without resistance, and executes rebels, ending the Revolt of Ghent.
Waltham Abbey is the last to be closed as part of Henry VIII's dissolution of the monasteries.
Printing of the first translation of the New Testament into the Icelandic language is completed.
Battle of Kannauj: Sher Shah Suri defeats and deposes Mughal Emperor Humayan, establishing the Sur Empire.
Thomas Cromwell is executed for treason on the orders of king Henry VIII of England.
Gibraltar is sacked by Ali Hamet's fleet, leading to construction of the defensive Charles V Wall.

1540.event: Approval of the Society of Jesus
1540.summary: The Society of Jesus (Jesuits) is approved by Pope Paul III in his bull Regimini militantis Ecclesiae.
A Habsburg Spanish fleet destroys an Ottoman fleet commanded by Ali Hamet off Alborán Island in the Mediterranean.
Georg Joachim Rheticus publishes De libris revolutionum Copernici narratio prima, the first printed publication of Copernican heliocentrism.

1541.event: Doge of the Republic of Genoa Elected
1541.summary: Leonardo Cattaneo della Volta is elected to a two-year term as the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa.
The Siege of Koriyama ends with a defeat of the Amago clan, sustaining heavy losses.
Pedro de Valdivia founds Santiago del Nuevo Extremo, which will become the capital of Chile.
Petru Rareș becomes the Prince of Moldavia for a second time, overthrowing the Voivode Alexandru Cornea.
The Portuguese Empire's fortress at Agadir falls to the Moroccan general Mohammed al-Shaykh after a siege.
Francisco Pizarro, the Spanish conqueror of the Inca Empire, is assassinated at Lima.

1541.event: Return of John Calvin to Geneva
1541.summary: After three years of exile, John Calvin returns to Geneva to reform the church under Calvinism.
The expedition against the Regency of Algiers fails as heavy storms force European forces to retreat.
Thomas Culpeper and Francis Dereham are executed for treason in committing adultery with Queen Catherine.

1541.event: Introduction of Lutheran Faith in Iceland
1541.summary: Iceland adopts the Lutheran faith, marking a significant religious shift.

1542.summary: The Spanish colonists create a new town in Yucatan.
Catherine Howard, former Queen consort of England, is executed.
Antoine Escalin des Aimars negotiates an alliance with the Ottoman Empire.
The Parliament of Ireland passes an act reestablishing the Kingdom of Ireland.
Pope Paul III establishes the Holy Office with jurisdiction over the Inquisition.
Citizens of Hildesheim profess Lutheran teachings, aligning with the Reformation.
Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo claims San Miguel for the Spanish Empire in San Diego Bay.
The earliest recorded Preston Guild Court is held in Lancashire, England.

1542.event: Contact of Japan with the West
1542.summary: The first contact of Japan with the West occurs when a Portuguese ship lands in Japan.

1542.event: Death of James V of Scotland
1542.summary: King James V of Scotland dies, and Mary, Queen of Scots, becomes queen regnant.

1543.event: Election of Regent for Mary Queen of Scots
1543.summary: James Hamilton, 2nd Earl of Arran, is elected by the Scottish Parliament as the Regent for the infant Mary Queen of Scots.
De revolutionibus orbium coelestium is printed, offering mathematical arguments for the heliocentric universe.
Nicolaus Copernicus passes away shortly after being presented with his groundbreaking book on astronomy.
The Treaty of Greenwich is signed between England and Scotland, aiming to unify the two nations.
The Siege of Nice by the Ottoman Empire and French forces begins, involving a prolonged bombardment.
The first Europeans, led by Portuguese traders, arrive in Japan and introduce firearms.
The city of Esztergom surrenders to the Ottomans, marking a significant expansion of Ottoman rule.
Suleiman the Magnificent completes his campaign to bring Hungary under Ottoman rule.
The Laws in Wales Act 1542 is given royal assent, establishing counties and regularizing parliamentary representation in Wales.
The Confederation of Shan States begins an invasion of the Toungoo Empire in upper Myanmar.

1544.summary: Dutch mathematician Gemma Frisius makes the first recorded use of a camera obscura to observe a solar eclipse
The estates of Sweden swear loyalty to King Gustav Vasa, ending traditional electoral monarchy
French forces defeat the Holy Roman Empire in the Battle of Ceresole near Turin
Blasco Núñez Vela takes office as the first Spanish Governor of the Viceroyalty of Peru
The Treaty of Speyer is signed between the Holy Roman Empire and the Kingdom of Denmark
Ottoman raiders sack the Italian town of Agropoli and take 100 people prisoner
The University of Königsberg is inaugurated in Prussia
King Henry VIII of England begins the siege of Boulogne in northern France
Peace is declared between Charles V and Francis I of France
Rüstem Opuković Pasha is appointed as the new Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire

1545.event: King Francis I issues the Arrêt de Mérindol
1545.summary: King Francis I of France issues the Arrêt de Mérindol to destroy the Protestant Waldensians of Provence.
The Scots are victorious over numerically superior English forces at the Battle of Ancrum Moor.
The Battle of the Solent begins between the English and French navies.
The Royal Navy's flagship, the Mary Rose, is sunk along with 365 of its 400 crew before the Battle of the Solent ends inconclusively.
The elaborate Tomb of Sher Shah Suri is completed in Sasaram, three months after Sher Shah's death.

1545.event: Creation of the Duchy of Parma
1545.summary: The Duchy of Parma and Piacenza is created in Italy by order of Pope Paul III.
The New Laws of the Indies for the Good Treatment and Preservation of the Indians are repealed in Spain.

1545.event: Truce between Holy Roman Empire and Ottoman Empire
1545.summary: A truce is signed between the Holy Roman Empire and the Ottoman Empire following the Siege of Nice.

1545.event: Opening of the Council of Trent
1545.summary: The Council of Trent officially opens in northern Italy, addressing key issues of the Catholic Church.
Italian mathematician Gerolamo Cardano publishes Ars Magna, containing the first published algebraic solutions to cubic and quartic equations.

1546.summary: Ashikaga Yoshifushi ascends to the position of Shōgun, marking a significant change in Japan's military leadership.

1546.event: Creation of Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mexico
1546.summary: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mexico is established, significantly impacting the Catholic community in Mexico and influencing religious practices.
Scottish Protestant reformer George Wishart is burned at the stake, highlighting the religious tensions of the period.
The Council of Trent issues a decree recognizing the Vulgate Bible as the official scripture, shaping Catholic doctrine.

1546.event: Creation of the Keeper of the King's Ports and Galleys
1546.summary: The first government body to oversee England's Royal Navy is established, marking an important development in naval administration.
The Treaty of Ardres is signed, resulting in peace between England and France and influencing European alliances.
Lutheran leaders meet to defend against Catholic forces, indicating the growing power of Protestant reformers.

1546.event: First Protestant Huguenot church in France established
1546.summary: The first Huguenot church in France is seized, reflecting the increasing tension between Protestant and Catholic factions.

1546.event: Siege of Diu ends with Portuguese victory
1546.summary: After a long siege, the Portuguese reclaim Diu, underlining the ongoing colonial conflicts in India.
Trinity College is founded by Henry VIII, contributing to the advancement of education and culture in England.

1547.summary: The first Lithuanian-language book, a Catechism, is published in Königsberg by Martynas Mažvydas.

1547.event: Ivan IV crowned Tsar of Russia
1547.summary: Grand Prince Ivan IV is crowned as Tsar of all Russia at the Dormition Cathedral, marking the start of the Tsardom of Russia.
King Henry VIII of England dies in London, succeeded by his 9-year-old son Edward VI.
Edward VI of England is crowned at Westminster Abbey, beginning his reign as a child monarch.
King Francis I of France dies at the Château de Rambouillet, succeeded by his son Henry II.
Emperor Charles V defeats the Lutheran forces of the Schmalkaldic League at the Battle of Mühlberg.
The Protestant Schmalkaldic League defeats the Catholic Army of the Holy Roman Empire at the Battle of Drakenburg.
Henri II is crowned as King of France at the Reims Cathedral, solidifying his rule.
An English army defeats a Scottish army, seizing Edinburgh in a significant military victory.
Catherine Parr, former Queen consort of England, publishes her book The Lamentation of a Sinner.

1548.summary: Firearms are used for the first time on the battlefield in Japan, influencing military tactics.
The Diet of Augsburg approves a decree directing German Protestants to resume the Roman Catholic doctrine, impacting religious practices.

1548.event: Marriage Treaty between Scotland and France
1548.summary: A marriage treaty is signed to betroth Mary, Queen of Scots, to Francis II, furthering political alliances.
Mary, Queen of Scots, leaves for France, significant for cultural and political ties between nations.
King João III of Portugal creates a colonial government in Brazil to organize trade and governance, affecting colonial policies.
The Ottoman Navy recaptures Aden, strengthening Ottoman power in the region.
Regent Si Sudachan murders her son, leading to a counter-coup and influencing the political landscape.
Archduke Maximilian and Princess Maria become co-regents of Spain, influencing governance during Charles V's absence.
Suleiman the Magnificent begins an invasion of Safavid Iran, shaping Ottoman-Safavid relations.
John Dee begins his studies at the Old University of Leuven, impacting future intellectual developments.

1549.summary: The Act of Uniformity 1548 is passed by the Parliament of England, establishing the 1549 version of the Book of Common Prayer as the sole legal prayer book in England.
King Tabinshwehti of Burma begins his invasion of the Ayutthaya Kingdom in the Burmese–Siamese War, which ends in retreat.
In the Battle of Eguchi in Japan, General Miyoshi Nagayoshi defies the Governor, resulting in the death of his cousin and several high-ranking generals.

1549.event: Introduction of the Book of Common Prayer
1549.summary: The Book of Common Prayer is introduced in English churches, leading to the Prayer Book Rebellion against it.
Kett's Rebellion breaks out in East Anglia, opposing injustices related to landownership and religious changes.
Portuguese Jesuit missionary Francis Xavier departs from Goa with the mission to bring Christian ministry to Japan.
At the Battle of Dussindale in England, Kett's Rebellion is ended by a Royal Army.
The Council of Trent is prorogued indefinitely, impacting the Catholic reformation efforts.

1549.event: Papal Conclave for Pope Paul III
1549.summary: The papal conclave to decide on a successor to Pope Paul III goes into session, marking a significant event in the Catholic Church.
Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent abandons his campaign against Safavid Iran after 21 months, highlighting the political struggles of the time.

1550.summary: Spanish Captain Hernando de Santana founds the city of Valledupar in modern-day Colombia.
Giovanni Maria Ciocchi del Monte is elected as Pope Julius III after a lengthy conclave.
Spanish and indigenous troops defeat an army of 60,000 Mapuche in Chile during the Arauco War.
England and France sign the Treaty of Boulogne, ending England's involvement in Boulogne.
The Valladolid debate on the rights and treatment of indigenous peoples by Spanish conquerors begins.
King Tabinshwehti of Burma is assassinated, leading to a civil war.
The Ottoman Empire plunders the Spanish city of Cullera and sells its inhabitants into slavery.
The city of Helsinki is founded by King Gustav I of Sweden.
Spanish troops capture the Tunisian fortress of Mahdia from the Ottoman Empire after heavy fighting.
Daði Guðmundsson defeats Catholic Bishop Jón Arason, resulting in Iceland becoming fully Protestant.

1551.summary: Luca Spinola is elected to a two-year term as the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa, succeeding Gaspare Grimaldi Bracelli.
Macarius, Metropolitan of Moscow, and Tsar Ivan IV of Russia preside over the reforming Stoglavy Synod, introducing a calendar of saints and ecclesiastical law.
French mechanical engineer Aubin Olivier becomes the director of the new Royal Mint after mastering uniform milled coinage in Germany.
The Council of Trent reconvenes by order of Pope Julius III after being adjourned in 1549.

1551.event: Foundation of National University of San Marcos
1551.summary: The National University of San Marcos is founded in Lima, becoming the first officially established university in the Americas.
During the Italian War, a defensive alliance placing the Duchy of Parma under French protection is signed.
Ilie II Rareș is forced by the Ottoman Empire to abdicate as Ruler of Moldavia.
The Edict of Châteaubriant is promulgated in France, intensifying measures against Protestants.
The Treaty of Weissenburg goes into effect, marking the abdication of John Sigismund Zápolya and changes in the Hungarian throne.

1551.event: Foundation of Royal and Pontifical University of Mexico
1551.summary: The Royal and Pontifical University of Mexico is founded in Mexico City, marking the establishment of the second university in the Americas.

1552.summary: Bartolomeo Eustachi completes his studies on the structure of the inner ear and heart, influencing future scientific and medical understanding.
Henry II of France and Maurice, Elector of Saxony, sign the Treaty of Chambord, affecting power dynamics in Europe.
The Act of Uniformity is given royal assent, mandating the Protestant Book of Common Prayer in England.
Delegates of the Council of Trent adjourn for two years, impacting the Catholic Church's reform efforts.
The city of Temesvar is captured by Ottoman forces, altering the control of territory in Hungary.
The Peace of Passau revokes the Augsburg Interim and grants religious freedom to Protestant princes, reshaping religious policy in the Holy Roman Empire.
The Khanate of Kazan falls to troops of Ivan IV, marking a significant military achievement for Russia.
Simeon Sulaka arrives in Rome to request the appointment of the Patriarch of the Church of the East, impacting the Christian community.
Archbishop Thomas Cranmer presents the proposed Forty-two Articles to the Privy Council, outlining doctrinal positions in the Church of England.

1552.event: Establishment of grammar schools by Edward VI
1552.summary: King Edward VI founds 35 grammar schools by royal charter, improving education access in England.

1553.summary: The siege of Metz in France is lifted after 75 days. Charles V loses two-thirds of his forces.
Lady Jane Grey marries Lord Guildford Dudley, arranged by the Duke of Northumberland.
The first Battle of Kawanakajima commences in Japan, marking the beginning of significant conflicts during the Sengoku period.
King Edward VI of England dies at the age of 15 after a reign of only six years.
After a change of allegiance by the Privy Council, Mary I is proclaimed the rightful Queen of England.

1553.event: Trade opened between England and Russia
1553.summary: Explorer Richard Chancellor enters the White Sea and opens up trade between England and Russia.

1553.event: Lady Jane Grey convicted of high treason
1553.summary: Lady Jane Grey is convicted of high treason after a trial and sentenced to death.
Şehzade Mustafa, the oldest son of Suleiman the Magnificent, is executed by his father in Konya.
Michael Servetus is burned at the stake as a heretic by Geneva's governing council.

1553.event: First complete translation of classical work
1553.summary: The first complete translation of any major work of classical antiquity into English is published.

1554.summary: A great fire breaks out in Eindhoven, causing significant destruction.
Bayinnaung is crowned king of the Burmese Taungoo Dynasty, marking a significant political shift.
Wyatt's rebellion begins in England, driven by opposition to Queen Mary's marriage.
Lady Jane Grey is beheaded for treason, reflecting the political turmoil in England.
Princess Elizabeth is imprisoned in the Tower of London on charges of conspiracy.
Mary of Guise is appointed Regent of Scotland, influencing the political landscape.
Queen Mary I marries King Prince Philip, uniting England and Spain.
Italian General Piero Strozzi successfully defends the Republic of Siena, preserving local autonomy.

1554.event: Ending of Francisco Hernández Girón's Rebellion
1554.summary: An 11-month rebellion in Peru is ended by a decisive battle, stabilizing colonial governance.

1554.event: First English trade venture to Guinea
1554.summary: Captain John Lok's expedition departs for Guinea, marking the beginning of trade expansion.

1555.summary: John Rogers is burned at the stake, marking the start of a campaign against Protestantism in England.
The Muscovy Company is chartered in England to trade with the Tsardom of Russia, enhancing trade relations.
Giovanni Pietro Carafa is elected as Pope Paul IV after a conclave, impacting the Catholic Church's direction.
A significant treaty is signed between Charles V and the Lutheran Schmalkaldic League, establishing religious autonomy in the Holy Roman Empire.
Pope Paul IV establishes the first Jewish ghetto in Rome, influencing Jewish heritage and society.
St John's College is founded in Oxford, England, contributing to Catholic education during the Reformation.
Trinity College is established in Oxford for Catholic theology, furthering religious education.
Charles V abdicates as Holy Roman Emperor, leading to changes in European political power.
The collapse of the Adal Sultanate in the Horn of Africa signals major shifts in regional power dynamics.

1555.event: Publication of Orlande de Lassus' Madrigals
1555.summary: Orlande de Lassus publishes his first book of madrigals, contributing to the development of Renaissance music.

1556.summary: Charles V resigns the throne of the Spanish Empire and retires to a monastery
The deadliest earthquake in history occurs, killing approximately 830,000 people
Mughal Emperor Humayun dies from a fatal injury after tripping down the stairs
Akbar the Great ascends the throne of the Mughal Empire at age 13
Thomas Cranmer is burned at the stake for treason as chief bishop of the Anglican Church
The Battle of Delhi is fought between the forces of the Sur Empire and the Mughal Empire
A Mughal army defeats the forces of Hemu and recaptures Delhi, securing Akbar's rule
Work begins on the Peresopnytsia Gospel at the Monastery of the Holy Trinity
The Steter Kriegsrat is founded as a War Council in the Holy Roman Empire

1556.event: Introduction of the printing press in India
1556.summary: The first printing press in India is introduced by Jesuits at Saint Paul's College

1557.summary: Pietro Giovanni Chiavica Cibo becomes the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa for a term of 2 years as the term of the Doge Agostino Pinelli Ardimenti comes to an end.
Bayinnaung, King of Burma, conquers two Shan States and continues the conquest with the fall of Mong Kawng.
The Spanish settlement of Cuenca, Ecuador, is founded.
The Stationers' Company is granted a royal charter and a monopoly on the English publishing industry.
The New Testament of the Geneva Bible, a Protestant Bible translation into English, is published in Geneva.
Mass executions by burning at the stake resume in England for Protestants convicted of heresy under the law of Queen Mary.
French forces are decisively defeated by the Spanish and English at the Battle of St. Quentin.
The Colloquy of Worms convenes in Germany for dialogue on religious issues between Catholic and Lutheran clerics.
Mohammed al-Shaykh, Sultan of Morocco, is assassinated by Ottoman soldiers, leading to his son's succession.
Spain declares bankruptcy, causing turmoil in German banking houses.

1558.summary: French troops take Calais, the last continental possession of England.
The University of Jena is founded in Thuringia, Germany.

1558.event: Mary, Queen of Scots, marries Francis
1558.summary: Mary, Queen of Scots, marries Francis, Dauphin of France, at Notre Dame de Paris.

1558.event: Recognition of Ferdinand as Holy Roman Emperor
1558.summary: The Imperial Diet gives recognition to Ferdinand as Holy Roman Emperor.
Ottoman ships attack the city of Sorrento in Italy.
France recovers the fortress of Thionville after a successful siege.
Ottoman Empire besieges the Spanish garrison at Ciutadella, leading to the town's fall.
Five individuals are burned at the stake for heresy in England.
Queen Mary of England dies and is succeeded by Elizabeth, marking the end of her reign.
Elizabeth I summons the English Parliament to restore laws from the Reformation.

1559.summary: Elizabeth I of England is crowned in Westminster Abbey.

1559.event: Establishment of the Church of England
1559.summary: Queen Elizabeth I establishes the Church of England with the Act of Uniformity and the Act of Supremacy.
France makes peace with England and Spain, ending the Italian War.
John Knox returns to Scotland to lead the Scottish Reformation.

1559.event: Jousting Accident of King Henry II
1559.summary: King Henry II of France is fatally injured in a jousting tournament.

1559.event: Marriage of King Philip II and Elisabeth of Valois
1559.summary: King Philip II of Spain marries 14-year-old Elisabeth of Valois.
Francis II of France is crowned, with significant disputes over control of the kingdom.
Gorkha state is established, leading to the current country of Nepal.
The papal conclave to elect a new pope opens following the death of Pope Paul IV.
Giovanni Angelo Medici is elected as the 224th pope, taking the name Pope Pius IV.

1560.summary: Terms are agreed upon with the Lords of the Congregation in Scotland, for forces of the Kingdom of England to enter Scotland, to expel French troops defending the Regency of Mary of Guise.
The Ottoman fleet, commanded by Piali Pasha, overwhelms a large joint European fleet, sinking about half its ships.
Signed between England, France, and Scotland, ending the Siege of Leith, and largely marking the end of the Auld Alliance between the two countries.
Adopts a Protestant confession of faith and rejects papal authority, beginning the Scottish Reformation and disestablishing Roman Catholicism in Scotland.
A total eclipse of the sun is observable in Europe, inspiring Tycho Brahe's interest in astronomy.
Queen Elizabeth notifies that existing coins will be replaced and those in circulation devalued, marking a significant change in currency.
Queen Elizabeth directs the minting of the first machine produced coins in the Kingdom, replacing hammered coinage.
Eloy Mestrelle is given authority to commence the production of new English coinage on machines, enabling mass production.
Charles IX succeeds his brother Francis as King of France after his brother's death at a young age.

1560.event: Founding of the Academia Secretorum Naturae
1560.summary: The first scientific society, the Academia Secretorum Naturae, is founded in Naples.

1561.summary: Paolo Battista Giudice Calvi is elected as the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa but serves for only eight months before dying.
The Ordinance of Orléans suspends the persecution of the Protestant Huguenots in Kingdom of France.
Lope de Aguirre begins a rebellion against the Spanish Crown aimed at taking over Spanish South America.
Philip II declares Madrid as the capital of Spain.
Saint Basil's Cathedral in Moscow is completed.
Citizens of Nuremberg witness what appears to be an aerial battle followed by a large crash.
The Treaty of Vilnius is concluded, aligning the Livonian Confederation with the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
Mary, Queen of Scots' entry into Edinburgh is marred by religious controversy, reflecting the tensions of the Reformation.
King Afonso II Mpemba a Nzinga of the Kingdom of Kongo is overthrown by his brother shortly after becoming king.
Merchant Taylors' School is founded in the City of London, marking an advance in educational opportunities.

1562.summary: Huguenots are recognized under the Edict of Saint-Germain
Gorboduc, the first known English tragedy, is performed before Queen Elizabeth I
A massacre of Huguenots by the Duke of Guise triggers the First War of Religion in France
Civil war breaks out as Louis I, Prince of Condé, declares war against French Catholic rulers
A treaty is signed between Queen Elizabeth I and Huguenot leader Louis, Prince of Condé
A bloody battle between Huguenot and Catholic forces, narrowly won by the Catholics
A storm sinks twenty-five ships off the coast of Spain, resulting in a massive loss of life
The Portuguese army is defeated at the Battle of Mulleriyawa in Sri Lanka
An explosion in an arsenal in Paris causes widespread destruction and casualties
Emperor Akbar of the Mughal Empire marries Mariam-uz-Zamani

1563.summary: The Church of England begins the agreement on the Thirty-nine Articles, which influences religious practices.

1563.event: Foundation of Instituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino
1563.summary: A significant financial institution is established, impacting banking and finance in Europe.

1563.event: Sarsa Dengel becomes Emperor of Ethiopia
1563.summary: A new young ruler ascends to the Ethiopian throne, influencing regional politics and culture.
The Edict accords toleration to the Huguenots, impacting the French Wars of Religion.
Queen Elizabeth I gives approval to key laws affecting society, including concerning witchcraft and poor relief.
The cornerstone is laid for the royal palace in Spain, a monumental architectural endeavor.
A significant battle takes place in Japan, altering the power dynamics within the country.
A college is established in Guernsey by order of Queen Elizabeth I, promoting education.
Denmark–Norway declares war against Sweden, affecting trade and security in northern Europe.
The closure reinforces Roman Catholic doctrines and marriage laws, impacting religious and social structures.

1564.summary: A Lithuanian surprise attack results in a decisive defeat of the numerically superior Russian forces.
The Burmese–Siamese War ends with the surrender of King Maha Chakkraphat of Ayutthaya to King Bayinnaung of Burma.
French explorer René Goulaine de Laudonnière and a group of Huguenot Protestants depart from Le Havre to colonize what is now Florida.
The Swedish warship Mars catches fire and sinks during a naval battle against Denmark, resulting in the loss of 800 lives.
French settlers abandon Charlesfort and establish Fort Caroline in Florida with the help of a relief force.
Mughal Emperor Akbar defeats the rebellious governor of Malwa, Abdullah Khan Uzbeg.
The first recorded report is made of a rat king.
The Duchy of Savoy signs the Treaty of Lausanne with the Swiss canton of Bern.
Ivan the Terrible sends his government a letter of abdication due to alleged embezzlement and treason.

1564.event: Publication of the First Scottish Psalter
1564.summary: The first Scottish Psalter is published, marking a significant moment in Scottish musical and religious history.

1565.summary: The city of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, is founded as São Sebastião do Rio de Janeiro by Estácio de Sá.
Cebu City is established as San Miguel by López de Legazpi, becoming the first Spanish settlement in the Philippines.
Ottoman troops land on the island of Malta, beginning the Great Siege of Malta.
The Treaty of Cebu is signed, effectively creating Spanish suzerainty over Cebu.
Mary, Queen of Scots, marries her half-cousin Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley, at Holyrood Palace in Edinburgh.
The Spanish fleet of Pedro Menéndez de Avilés first sights land in Florida.
St. Augustine, Florida, is established by Pedro Menéndez de Avilés, becoming the oldest surviving European settlement in the modern-day United States.

1565.event: Lifting of the Great Siege of Malta
1565.summary: The Knights of Malta lift the Great Siege of Malta after four months.
The first recorded naval battle between Japan and a European nation occurs when ships from the Matsura clan fail to capture a Portuguese trading carrack.
The army of Burma, under King Bayinnaung, conquers Chiang Mai, capital of the Siamese Kingdom of Lan Na.

1566.summary: Cardinal Michele Ghislieri is elected as the new Pope, taking the regnal name Pope Pius V.
The foundation stone of Valletta, which will become Malta's capital city, is laid by Jean Parisot de Valette.

1566.event: Launch of the Adler von Lübeck
1566.summary: The Hanseatic city of Lübeck launches the galleon Adler von Lübeck, probably the largest ship in the world at this time.
The Compromise of Nobles is presented to Margaret of Parma, delaying the beginning of the Eighty Years' War.

1566.event: Issuance of the Augsburg Imperial Coin Edict
1566.summary: The Augsburg Imperial Coin Edict issues from the Holy Roman Empire, authorizing a new coin, the thaler.
The siege of Szigetvár is begun by Suleiman the Magnificent, marking the Ottomans at their greatest extent.
Suleiman the Magnificent dies in his tent of natural causes, leading to Selim II becoming Sultan of the Ottoman Empire.

1566.event: End of the siege of Szigetvár
1566.summary: The siege ends with the annihilation of Hungarian and Croatian defenders, significantly impacting the region.
The Beeldenstorm, a widespread destruction of religious art, begins among Protestant Calvinists in the Netherlands.
The Duke of Prussia has three town councilors beheaded on charges of causing political and religious disputes.

1567.summary: Portuguese forces under the command of Estácio de Sá definitively drive the French out of Rio de Janeiro.
After 45 years' reign, the Jiajing Emperor, Zhu Houcong, dies in the Forbidden City of China.
Prince Zhu Zaiji, son of the Jiajing Emperor, becomes the ascends the throne of Ming Dynasty China as the Longqing Emperor.
Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley, husband of Mary, Queen of Scots, is murdered at the Provost's House in Kirk o' Field, Edinburgh.
A Spanish mercenary army surprises and kills a band of rebels near Antwerp, marking the start of the Eighty Years' War.
The Mughal Emperor Akbar wins a victory over more than 7,000 warriors of the Sanyasi Hindu sect in India.
The Earl of Bothwell is acquitted on charges of murder in the killing of Lord Darnley, making plans to marry Mary, Queen of Scots.
Mary, Queen of Scots, is defeated by Scottish nobles at the Battle of Carberry Hill and imprisoned in Lochleven Castle.

1567.event: Establishment of Santiago de León de Caracas
1567.summary: The city of Santiago de León de Caracas is founded by Diego de Losada.
The New Testament is first published in Welsh, in William Salesbury's translation from the Greek.

1568.summary: Europe's first declaration of religious freedom is adopted by the Kingdom of Hungary.
Forces of Mary, Queen of Scots, are defeated by Scottish Protestants under James Stewart.
The Habsburgs agree to pay tribute to the Ottomans.
French Huguenots begin the siege but fail to take the city.
Ends the Second War of Religion in France with concessions to the Huguenots.
Spanish army of the Duke of Alba defeats Louis of Nassau's invading army.

1568.event: Beginning of the Third War of Religion
1568.summary: The war begins in France after an unsuccessful capture attempt of Huguenot leaders.

1568.event: Battle of San Juan de Ulúa
1568.summary: Spanish fleet forces English privateers to end their campaign in the Gulf of Mexico.

1568.event: Installation of Ashikaga Yoshiaki as Shōgun
1568.summary: Begins the Azuchi–Momoyama period in Japan.
Revolt against King Philip II of Spain begins with Aben Humeya proclaimed as king of Granadan rebels.

1569.summary: The first recorded lottery in England begins at St Paul's Cathedral, using proceeds for public works.
Pope Pius V issues a papal bull expelling all Jews from Italian and French territories.
Royalist troops defeat the Huguenots at the Battle of Jarnac, capturing and murdering the Prince of Condé.
The Kingdom of Poland and the Grand Duchy of Lithuania unite into the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.

1569.event: First complete printed Bible in Spanish
1569.summary: The first complete printed Bible in a Spanish translation is published in Basel.
Royalist forces defeat Huguenots at the Battle of Moncontour, resulting in significant casualties.
The siege of Varberg Castle by Denmark ends after heavy shelling of the Swedish defenders.

1569.event: Maha Thammarachathirat installed as vassal king
1569.summary: Maha Thammarachathirat is installed by the Burmese Army as the vassal king of Ayutthaya.
The Mercator projection is first used in Gerardus Mercator's world map.
Akbar founds Fatehpur Sikri, honoring the Muslim holy man Shaikh Salim Chisti.
