1570.summary: Ivan the Terrible begins the Massacre of Novgorod.
James Stewart, 1st Earl of Moray, is assassinated, throwing Scotland into civil war.
An estimated 8.3 magnitude earthquake occurs in Concepción, Chile.
Abraham Ortelius publishes the first modern atlas, Theatrum Orbis Terrarum, in Antwerp.
The Ottoman conquest of Cyprus begins with over 60,000 troops landing near Larnaca.
The Peace of Saint-Germain ends the Third War of Religion in France, promising religious freedom to Huguenots.
Nicosia falls to the Turks, with Venetian defenders massacred as the city is captured.
A major earthquake strikes Ferrara, destroying 40 percent of buildings but causing 171 deaths.
The Treaty of Stettin ends the Northern Seven Years' War.

1570.event: Publication of I quattro libri dell'architettura
1570.summary: Andrea Palladio publishes I quattro libri dell'architettura, influencing architecture.

1571.event: The Order of the Knights of Saint John transfers the capital of Malta
1571.summary: The capital of Malta is moved from Birgu to Valletta as part of a strategic decision by the Knights of Saint John.
The Royal Exchange opens in London, representing a significant development in the commerce and finance of England.
Moscow is devastated by a fire set by the Crimean army, affecting the region and its inhabitants.
An alliance forms against the Ottoman Empire, consolidating the powers of several Italian states for mutual defense.

1571.event: Queen Elizabeth I gives royal assent to laws
1571.summary: Laws are passed by Queen Elizabeth I aimed at controlling the influence of Rome and Catholicism in England.
A major naval confrontation occurs where a coalition fleet defeats the Ottoman navy, marking a turning point in European naval power.
A brutal siege occurs in Japan, marking a decisive moment in Oda Nobunaga's campaign against the Buddhist monks.

1571.event: The first pro forma bill introduced in House of Commons
1571.summary: The House of Commons asserts its authority over legislative matters by introducing a symbolic bill.
In a significant reform, serfs receive freedom in the German Duchy, altering the social structure.
Jesus College is founded in Oxford, indicating a continuing growth in educational institutions during this period.

1572.event: Trial and Execution of Thomas Howard
1572.summary: Thomas Howard, 4th Duke of Norfolk, is tried for treason for his part in the Ridolfi plot to restore Catholicism in England and is executed.
Harrow School is founded with a royal charter from Queen Elizabeth I of England.
The Sea Beggars capture the port city of Brielle, leading to uprisings against Spanish rule.
The Wanli Emperor of China ascends the throne at the age of nine, marking the beginning of a long reign.
Catholics in Paris murder thousands of Protestants at the order of King Charles IX, escalating religious tensions in France.
Supernova SN 1572 is first observed, challenging the prevailing view that stars do not change.
The Catholic population of Mechelen surrenders, leading to three days of slaughter by the Spanish Army.
Catholic forces lay siege to Sancerre, a Huguenot stronghold, marking the last use of slings in European warfare.
Luís de Camões' national epic Os Lusíadas is first published in Portugal.
Rafael Bombelli defines imaginary numbers, contributing to mathematical advancements.

1573.summary: Takeda Shingen defeats Tokugawa Ieyasu in a significant battle.
Articles are signed sanctioning religious freedom in Poland.
Huguenot defenders surrender after a prolonged siege, impacting the French Protestant cause.

1573.event: Eighty Years' War: Battle of Borsele
1573.summary: Dutch Calvinist rebels intercept a fleet of Spanish ships, marking a notable conflict in the war.
Henry, Duke of Anjou, is elected King of Poland, impacting European royal dynamics.
Spanish forces capture Haarlem after a seven-month siege, a crucial moment in the Dutch Revolt.
The Spanish abandon the siege and concede Alkmaar to Dutch rebels, signaling a turning point.
A peace treaty confirms Turkish control over Cyprus, affecting European power balances.
Córdoba is founded in the Viceroyalty of Peru, expanding Spanish influence in South America.
The leader of the Croatian–Slovene Peasant Revolt is tortured and executed, reflecting harsh governance.

1574.summary: The Spanish Navy loses 15 ships and 1,200 men in a naval battle off the coast of the Netherlands.
The fifth War of Religion against the Huguenots begins in France, intensifying conflicts between Catholics and Protestants.
Spanish forces defeat the rebel forces of Louis of Nassau, resulting in the death of Nassau.
King Charles IX of France dies and is succeeded by his brother Henry, who becomes King Henry III of France.
The construction of The White Tower begins in the Czech Republic, symbolizing architectural advancement.
The city of Leiden is relieved from a Spanish siege by a fleet under Louis Boisot.
The Juan Fernández Islands in the South Pacific are discovered by Spanish sailor Juan Fernández.
Selim II, the Sultan of the Ottoman Empire, is killed after an accident in the Topkapi Palace.
Murad III becomes the new Sultan of the Ottoman Empire after eliminating challenged claimants.
John George, Elector of Brandenburg, establishes a prestigious preparatory school in Berlin.

1575.summary: Queen Elizabeth I grants a monopoly on producing printed sheet music to Thomas Tallis and William Byrd
William I of Orange founds Leiden University
The formal coronation of Henry III as King of France takes place at the Reims Cathedral

1575.event: KIng Henry III Stripped of Titles
1575.summary: King Henry III of France is stripped of his Polish and Lithuanian titles after failing to return to Kraków

1575.event: Attempt to Reform Eastern Orthodox Church
1575.summary: Lutheran missionaries meet with Ecumenical Patriarch Jeremias II Tranos in Constantinople
Oda Nobunaga defeats Takeda Katsuyori in Japan's first modern battle
As a result of the Eighty Years' War, the government of the Kingdom of Spain goes bankrupt
Rudolf of Habsburg is crowned King of Bohemia at St. Vitus Cathedral in Prague
Future Spanish author Miguel de Cervantes is taken hostage by an Ottoman pirate after an attack
Catholic forces under Henry I, Duke of Guise defeat the Protestants in the Battle of Dormans

1576.summary: The city of Fez is captured by Ottoman forces led by Abd al-Malik, marking an attempt to overthrow the Sultan of Morocco.
The Third Battle of Ishiyama begins in Japan as Oda Nobunaga sends troops against the Ashikaga shogunate.
Stephen Báthory, the Hungarian Prince of Transylvania, is crowned king of Poland.
The Edict ends the Fifth War of Religion in France, granting freedom of worship to Protestant Huguenots.
Shah Tahmasp I of Iran is accidentally poisoned, leading to a struggle for control of the throne.
The Siege of Zierikzee concludes with the surrender of the defenders to the Spanish Army.
Mutinous Spanish soldiers sack Antwerp, nearly destroying the city over three days.
Rudolf II is crowned Holy Roman Emperor, a significant event in Central European history.

1576.event: Beginning of the Sixth War of Religion
1576.summary: The Edict of Beaulieu fails, leading to the outbreak of the Sixth War of Religion in France.
James Burbage opens the first permanent public playhouse in Britain, marking a milestone in English theatre.

1577.event: Formation of the Union of Brussels
1577.summary: The second Union of Brussels is formed, accepted by King Philip II of Spain, marking open rebellion in the Netherlands.
The Perpetual Edict is signed for the removal of Spanish troops from the Netherlands, affecting the Dutch rebellion.
The Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth suffers a catastrophic defeat in the Battle of Lubieszów, significantly impacting regional power dynamics.

1577.event: Martin Frobisher's Expedition to North America
1577.summary: Explorer Martin Frobisher departs for North America in search of gold, influencing future explorations.
The Solid Declaration of the Formula of Concord is published, significant for Lutheran confessional writings.

1577.event: Massacre of Protestant Huguenots in Issoire
1577.summary: Troops massacre 3,000 Protestant Huguenots in Issoire, escalating religious tensions in France.
Sebastiano Venier becomes the new Doge of the Republic of Venice, a key political figure in Italy.
The Treaty of Bergerac is signed, affecting relations between Henry III of France and the Huguenots.
Two Protestant members proclaim the Calvinist Republic of Ghent, marking a significant moment in the Reformation.

1577.event: First Observation of Great Comet of 1577
1577.summary: The first recorded observation of the Great Comet of 1577 is documented, an astronomical event of great interest.

1578.summary: The Ottoman Empire captures the fortress at Gvozdansko, ending the siege
Spanish forces defeat the Dutch, recovering control over the Southern Netherlands
Pope Gregory XIII establishes the first Roman Catholic diocese in the Philippines
The city council expels 24 Catholic members, restructuring the government with Calvinists
Humphrey Gilbert is granted letters patent to establish a colony in North America
The Frobisher expedition arrives in Canada and enters Frobisher Bay
A combined Dutch and English force defeats Spanish troops near Antwerp
King Sebastian of Portugal is killed in battle, causing a succession crisis

1578.event: Completion of the Strait of Magellan traverse
1578.summary: Francis Drake's fleet completes the passage through the Strait of Magellan

1578.event: Humphrey Gilbert and Walter Ralegh's Expedition
1578.summary: Gilbert and Ralegh lead an expedition aimed at establishing a colony in North America

1579.summary: The Union of Utrecht unites the northern Netherlands in a confederation called the United Provinces, marking a significant step toward independence from Spanish rule.
The Siege of Maastricht begins as Spanish troops aim to reclaim the city from Dutch resistance, a key event in the Eighty Years' War.
Francis Drake claims modern-day California for Queen Elizabeth I, which will influence future colonial expansion.
The Treaty of Arras concludes negotiations between Spain and members of the Union of Arras, affecting the political landscape in the Netherlands.
John Stubbs, an English author, is convicted of sedition and punished, highlighting the tension between governance and expression in England.
During the Second Desmond Rebellion, rebel troops massacre an English garrison and pillage the town, intensifying conflict in Ireland.
Sokollu Mehmed Pasha, a prominent Ottoman statesman, is assassinated, impacting the political landscape of the Ottoman Empire.
German astronomer Michael Maestlin catalogs the Pleiades cluster, an important advancement in astronomy.
Karlovac is founded in Croatia, marking a development in regional urban planning during the period.

1579.event: Changes in Religious Leadership in Constantinople
1579.summary: Jeremias II Tranos is removed as Ecumenical Patriarch, impacting the Eastern Orthodox Church and its followers.

1580.summary: The death of Henry, King of Portugal, with no direct heirs, leads to conflict between potential successors, including King Philip II of Spain.
The massacre of 20 artists at the Mardi Gras festivities at Carnaval de Romans occurs, highlighting political tensions in France.

1580.event: Building of the first Roman Catholic Church in the Mughal Empire
1580.summary: Three Jesuit priests arrive in India and are granted land for building the first Roman Catholic Church by Mughal Emperor Akbar the Great.

1580.event: Publication of Essays by Michel de Montaigne
1580.summary: Montaigne signs the preface to his significant work, Essays, which reflects intellectual advancements of the period.
King Philip II of Spain becomes King of Portugal after the death of Henry of Portugal, leading to a personal union of the crowns.
A significant earthquake occurs in the Dover Straits, impacting local populations and infrastructure.

1580.event: First complete printed Bible translation into Old Church Slavonic
1580.summary: The Ostrog Bible, the first complete printed Bible translation into a Slavic language, is printed, marking a major cultural milestone.
Spanish armies defeat the armies of Portuguese claimant António, solidifying Philip II's claim to the Portuguese throne.

1580.event: Return of Francis Drake from circumnavigation
1580.summary: Francis Drake returns to Plymouth from his voyage of circumnavigation, marking a significant achievement in maritime exploration.

1580.event: End of the War of the Portuguese Succession
1580.summary: Spanish forces end the final Portuguese resistance, leading to 60 years of Spanish rule over Portugal.

1581.summary: The Act of Abjuration is signed at The Hague by representatives of eight Dutch provinces as a declaration of independence from Spanish rule.
Ballet Comique de la Reine, the first narrative ballet, opens in its first performance at the court of Catherine de' Medici.
The Tenshō Iga War ends in Japan with the surrender of Kashiwara Castle to Oda Nobunaga.

1581.event: Crowning of Philip I of Portugal
1581.summary: Philip II of Spain is crowned Philip I of Portugal.
Francis Drake is knighted by Elizabeth I of England after his circumnavigation of the world.
Jesuit priest Edmund Campion is executed for treason in England.
Spanish troops capture the walled city of Breda in the Netherlands, resulting in the massacre of 584 citizens.

1581.event: Spanish Army abandons Siege of Steenwijk
1581.summary: The Spanish Army is forced to abandon the siege of Steenwijk in the Netherlands after more than four months.
The Treaty of Drohiczyn is concluded, ending the Livonian War and adding the conquered city of Riga to the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.
The conclusion of the Livonian War provides a new political landscape impacting the Baltic region and its composers.

1582.event: Pope Gregory XIII proclaims the Gregorian Calendar
1582.summary: Pope Gregory XIII proclaims the Gregorian Calendar, meant to synchronize the calendar with equinoxes and solstices, advancing date on the Julian calendar by 10 days.
Toyotomi Hideyoshi begins the Siege of Takamatsu, employing engineering to flood the castle area, impacting military strategies in Japan.
Japanese warlord Oda Nobunaga is assassinated in the Honnō-ji Incident, significantly affecting Japan's unification.
Toyotomi Hideyoshi decisively defeats Akechi Mitsuhide at the Battle of Yamazaki, solidifying his power in Japan.
In the War of the Portuguese Succession, Spanish admiral Santa Cruz defeats a larger mercenary fleet off the Azores, marking a key naval engagement.
Presbyterian nobles kidnap King James VI of Scotland in a coup to reform the government, impacting the monarchy.
William Shakespeare marries Anne Hathaway in England, marking a personal milestone for the future playwright.
Yermak Timofeyevich completes the Russian conquest of Siberia, influencing territorial expansions and governance in Russia.
Sir Francis Drake completes his circumnavigation of the globe, showcasing naval capabilities and impacting European maritime exploration.

1582.event: Adoption of the Gregorian Calendar in France
1582.summary: France discards the Julian Calendar for the Gregorian Calendar, following Pope Gregory XIII's directives, standardizing timekeeping.

1583.event: Duchy of Savoy adopts Gregorian Calendar
1583.summary: The Duchy of Savoy adopts the Gregorian Calendar, replacing the Julian Calendar.

1583.event: Establishment of diplomatic relations with Ottoman Empire
1583.summary: The Kingdom of England establishes its first diplomatic relations with the Ottoman Empire.
The first installment of the translation by Jurij Dalmatin of the Bible into Slovene is published in Wittenberg.
Spanish troops overwhelm a combined army of Dutch, French and English soldiers at the Battle of Steenbergen.
In England, the first known life insurance policy is issued at the Royal Exchange of London.

1583.event: University of Edinburgh holds first classes
1583.summary: In Scotland, the University of Edinburgh holds its first classes, accepting more than 80 students.
The first documented battle of India's independence against a European colonial ruler is fought in Goa against the Portuguese.
The Siege of Godesberg concludes with Catholic forces capturing the strategic position from Calvinist defenders.
Francis Throckmorton, instigator of the Throckmorton Plot to overthrow Queen Elizabeth I, is arrested.
The world's oldest, intact, surviving amusement park, Dyrehavsbakken, is founded north of Copenhagen.

1584.event: Feodor I becomes Tsar of Russia
1584.summary: Feodor I is crowned as the new Tsar of Russia after the death of Ivan the Terrible
The Battle of Komaki marks the start of conflict between Toyotomi Hideyoshi and Tokugawa Ieyasu in Japan
Willem van Oranje, a prominent leader of the Dutch Republic, is assassinated in Delft
The Siege of Antwerp begins, lasting for 13 months, causing significant impact in Europe

1584.event: Printing press established in South America
1584.summary: Italian printer Antonio Ricardo sets up the first printing press in South America in Lima
Japan's first diplomatic mission to Europe arrives in Portugal, influencing cultural exchange
Croatian forces successfully turn back an Ottoman invasion at the Battle of Slunj
A secret treaty is signed between the French Catholic League and Spain, affecting European politics
The Maronite College is established in Rome, enhancing the influence of the Maronite community
The Calvinist Republic of Ghent ends after a long siege, reshaping the political landscape of Belgium

1585.event: Papal Conclave Elects Pope Sixtus V
1585.summary: Cardinal Felice Piergentile is unanimously elected as the 227th Pope, taking the regnal name Pope Sixtus V.
Antwerp is captured by Spanish forces, forcing over half of its 100,000 inhabitants to flee and effectively destroying its position as an important trade city.

1585.event: Establishment of English Protectorate over the Netherlands
1585.summary: Queen Elizabeth I of England agrees to establish a protectorate over the Netherlands.
The Treaty of Nonsuch is signed, committing England to support the Dutch Revolt and entering the Eighty Years' War.
Spain seizes English ships, precipitating the Anglo-Spanish War.
A 6.6 magnitude earthquake strikes Japan, foreshadowing a deadly 7.9 magnitude earthquake that will kill 8,000 people.

1585.event: Robert Nutter and Priests Banished from England
1585.summary: Robert Nutter, Thomas Worthington, and 18 other Roman Catholic priests are perpetually banished from England by Queen Elizabeth.
The coronation of Pope Sixtus V takes place in Rome, marking a significant event in the Catholic Church.
The siege of IJsseloord is completed as English and Dutch forces recapture the city from Spanish occupiers.
The final battle of the invasion of the Japanese island of Shikoku concludes with Chōsokabe Motochika's surrender.

1586.summary: Thomas Edison invents the phonograph, enabling sound recording and playback for the first time.
Guglielmo Marconi successfully transmits the first radio signal, revolutionizing communication.
The first commercial radio station in the world, KDKA, broadcasts in the United States.

1586.event: Release of the first long-playing record
1586.summary: Columbia Records introduces the 33 1/3 RPM long-playing record, changing music consumption.
The electric guitar becomes commercially available, influencing popular music genres.
The Beatles emerge, transforming the music landscape and inspiring countless composers.
MTV is launched, changing how music is consumed and promoted through music videos.
The MIDI standard is established, allowing electronic instruments to communicate and revolutionizing music production.
The Internet begins to expand, allowing for new ways of music distribution and accessibility.
Music streaming services like Spotify transform how people access and consume music.

1587.summary: Mary, Queen of Scots, is beheaded in front of witnesses after being convicted of treason for her role in a conspiracy against Queen Elizabeth.

1587.event: Singeing the King of Spain's Beard
1587.summary: English privateer Sir Francis Drake leads a raid in the Bay of Cádiz, sinking at least 23 ships of the Spanish fleet.
A group of English settlers arrive on Roanoke Island to re-establish the deserted colony.

1587.event: Beginning of the War of the Polish Succession
1587.summary: A divide begins in the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth over the election of Sigismund III Vasa and Maximilian III.
Huguenot forces under Henry of Navarre defeat Royalist forces, marking a significant event in the French Wars of Religion.
Leiden University Library opens its doors, becoming a major center for education and knowledge in Europe.
Gabriel VIII becomes Pope of the Coptic Christian Church in Egypt, filling a significant religious leadership role.

1587.event: Introduction of Printing Press in Ming Dynasty China
1587.summary: The printing press is introduced in Ming China, revolutionizing the dissemination of information.

1587.event: Publication of Historia von D. Johann Fausten
1587.summary: The first published version of the Faust story is printed, influencing literature and culture in Europe.

1587.event: Severe Cold Period in Western Europe
1587.summary: A severe cold period lasts from February 12 to February 24, impacting agriculture and daily life.

1588.summary: Pope Sixtus V reorganizes the Roman Curia, creating 15 congregations including the Congregation of the Index Librorum Prohibitorum and the Congregation of the Inquisition.
Polish and Lithuanian troops, led by Jan Zamoyski, defeat an invading Austrian force, capturing Archduke Maximilian III.
The siege led by King Rajasinha I ends as Portuguese Admiral Pedro Teixeira arrives with a fleet, freeing the capital of Portuguese Ceylon.
Shah Abbas I's official ascension as Emperor of the Safavid Empire is marked on the Zoroastrian New Year.
The Spanish Armada sets sail from the Tagus estuary under the command of Duke of Medina Sidonia, aiming for the English Channel.
The Spanish Armada is decisively defeated by the English fleet off the coast of Gravelines.
Captain Thomas Cavendish completes the first circumnavigation of the globe in a record time of 781 days.

1588.event: Speech to the Troops at Tilbury
1588.summary: Queen Elizabeth I delivers a motivational speech to her troops in preparation for the confrontation with the Spanish Armada.
Henry III of France kills the Duke of Guise, leading to significant political turmoil in France.
The first biography of acclaimed astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus is completed by Bernardino Baldi.

1589.event: Reign of Catherine de' Medici Ends
1589.summary: Catherine de' Medici's reign as Countess of Auvergne comes to an end after 64 years, marking a significant transition in French nobility.
The College of Sorbonne votes to depose King Henry III of France, declaring that any citizen is morally free to commit regicide.
Job of Moscow is elected as the first Patriarch of Moscow and All Russia, establishing a significant ecclesiastical authority.
The Treaty of Bytom and Będzin is signed, ending the War of the Polish Succession and recognizing Sigismund III Vasa as heir.
Ali Ri'ayat Syah II, the Sultan of Aceh, is assassinated, continuing a trend of violence among leaders in the region.

1589.event: Assassination of King Henry III of France
1589.summary: King Henry III of France is assassinated by a Dominican friar, causing a power shift in France and leading to Henry IV's rise.
King Henry IV's forces defeat the Catholic League at the Battle of Arques, solidifying his claim to the French throne.

1589.event: Proxy Marriage of King James VI and Anne of Denmark
1589.summary: King James VI of Scotland contracts a proxy marriage with Anne of Denmark, strengthening political alliances between Scotland and Denmark.
Jeremias II Tranos is appointed as the Patriarch of Constantinople, influencing Eastern Orthodox Church leadership.
Man Singh I becomes raja of the Kingdom of Amber in India, marking a change in leadership that may impact regional politics.

1590.event: Anne of Denmark is crowned queen consort of Scotland
1590.summary: Anne of Denmark is crowned queen consort of Scotland at Holyrood Abbey in Edinburgh
Construction of the Fortezza Nuova around the city of Livorno begins on the orders of Ferdinando I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany
Peter Ernst I von Mansfeld captures the German fortress of Rheinberg after a four-year siege during the Eighty Years' War
Maurice of Nassau takes the city of Breda using a clever tactical maneuver
The Treaty of Constantinople is signed between the Ottoman Empire and the Safavid Empire, ending a 12-year war
The siege of Odawara ends with the surrender of the castle, significant in the unification of Japan
Giovanni Battista Castagna is elected as Pope Urban VII but dies shortly after
A significant earthquake occurs in Lower Austria and Vienna, causing damage and loss of life

1590.event: King Henry of Navarre's siege of Paris
1590.summary: Henry of Navarre begins an unsuccessful attempt to besiege Paris controlled by the Catholic League

1590.event: Truce between Holy Roman Empire and Ottoman Empire
1590.summary: A truce is signed between representatives of the Holy Roman Empire and the Ottoman Empire

1591.event: Pope Gregory XIV appoints commission for Bible revision
1591.summary: Pope Gregory XIV appoints Cardinal Marco Antonio Colonna and others to revise the Sixtine Vulgate Latin translation of the Bible.
Poet Edmund Spenser is granted an annual pension of 50 pounds sterling by Queen Elizabeth I in recognition of his publication of The Faerie Queen.

1591.event: Excommunication of King Henry IV of France
1591.summary: Pope Gregory XIV excommunicates King Henry IV of France and orders the clergy and nobles to renounce him.
Pope Gregory XIV orders the emancipation of Filipino slaves in the Spanish Philippines along with reparations for former slaves.
Deventer is captured by the Dutch under Maurice of Nassau, marking a significant event in the Eighty Years' War.
Maurice, Prince of Orange, leads a Dutch and English Army against the Spanish defenders in the siege of Delfzijl.
The city of Nijmegen is captured from Spanish occupiers by Maurice of Orange, marking a pivotal moment in the Dutch struggle for independence.
Pope Gregory XIV dies from an attack of gallstones, leaving the Papacy vacant for the third time in 14 months.
The coronation of Pope Innocent IX takes place in Rome after the death of Pope Gregory XIV.
King Henry IV of France begins the siege of Rouen, the Spanish-held capital of Normandy.

1592.summary: Cardinal Ippolito Aldobrandini is elected as Pope Clement VIII after a lengthy voting process among cardinals, marking a significant moment in the Catholic Church.
Trinity College is founded, becoming Ireland's oldest university and a center for education and learning.

1592.event: Beginning of Japanese invasions of Korea
1592.summary: The Japanese invasions of Korea begin, leading to significant military conflicts that deeply affect the region.
The Korean navy achieves a significant victory over Japan, showcasing advancements in naval warfare.
The Korean navy defeats the Japanese at Hansan Island, marking another critical victory in the ongoing conflicts.
The Korean navy secures victory over the Japanese at the Siege of Jinju, boosting morale and resistance efforts.
The updated Latin Bible translation, Sixto-Clementine Vulgate, is promulgated, impacting religious studies and literature.
The Collegium Melitense is established in Malta, enhancing educational opportunities in the region.

1592.event: Bill of Mortality published in London
1592.summary: London begins publishing weekly mortality statistics from the bubonic plague, impacting public health awareness.

1592.event: Death of King John III of Sweden
1592.summary: The death of King John III leads to the ascension of Sigismund III Vasa as the new King of Sweden, shifting the political landscape.

1593.summary: The Roman Inquisition opens the seven-year trial of scholar Giordano Bruno
Flemish mathematician Adriaan van Roomen publishes an accurate calculation of pi up to 16 decimal places
The English Parliament enacts a law for the first military disability pension in British history
Christopher Marlowe is stabbed to death in a dispute over a bill
François de Bonne defeats the Spanish forces at the Battle of Salbertrand in Piedmont
The Habsburgs defeat the Ottoman Empire at the Battle of Sisak

1593.event: Abjuration of Protestantism by Henry IV
1593.summary: Henry IV of France abjures Protestantism at the Basilica of Saint-Denis
The Long War breaks out in Hungary between the Habsburgs and the Ottomans

1593.event: Capture of Sisak by Ottoman Forces
1593.summary: Ottoman General Mehmed Pasha captures the city of Sisak
Spanish Jesuit priest Gregorio Céspedes becomes the first Christian missionary to Korea

1594.summary: Sigismund III Vasa is crowned as King of Sweden.
Henry IV is crowned King of France at Chartres Cathedral.
Theaters in England are allowed to reopen after being closed due to bubonic plague.
The Spanish-held city of Groningen surrenders to Dutch Republic troops.
English privateer Richard Hawkins is captured by a Spanish squadron.
Protestant forces loyal to King James VI are defeated by Catholic clans.
A petition for the Union of Brest is made, transferring ecclesiastical jurisdiction.
Jean Châtel attempts to assassinate King Henry IV of France.
St. Paul's College is founded in Macau, the first western-style university in the far east.
The city of Pompeii is rediscovered more than 1,500 years after its burial.

1595.summary: Mehmed III succeeds Murad III as Sultan of the Ottoman Empire and orders the execution of his brothers.
King Henry IV of France declares war on Spain during the French Wars of Religion.
The Treaty of Teusina concludes the Russo-Swedish War, impacting trade and territorial boundaries.
The first printed catalog of an institutional library, the Nomenclator of Leiden University Library, is published.
Henry IV of France defeats Spanish forces, showcasing military prowess amidst ongoing conflicts.

1595.event: First European Colony in South Seas
1595.summary: Spain claims Nendö Island, establishing the first European colony in the South Seas.
Wallachians achieve a tactical victory over Turks led by Sinan Pasha.
Alvaro de Mendaña encounters challenges during his expedition, with significant loss of life.
What is probably the first performance of William Shakespeare's play Richard II takes place in London.
Austrian efforts incite a rebellion against Ottoman rule in Bulgaria, altering regional power dynamics.

1596.summary: Sir Francis Drake and an English force attempt to capture the Isthmus of Panama, leading to a significant military engagement.
Sir Francis Drake dies of dysentery shortly after the retreat from Nombre de Dios.
Spanish troops capture Calais, marking a significant point in the ongoing conflicts between England and Spain.
An English fleet sacks the Spanish city of Cádiz, demonstrating naval strength and altering trade routes.
Willem Barents and Jacob van Heemskerk discover Bear Island during their Arctic expedition.
Christian IV is crowned as King of Denmark and King of Norway in a notable event for the region.
The Ukrainian Church west of the Dnieper adopts the Ukrainian Rite of Catholicism, impacting religious authority in the region.
A Spanish fleet, the Second Armada, is wrecked in storms, causing significant losses for Spain in their naval conflicts.
The Cudgel War begins in Finland as poor peasants rise up against oppressive taxation, affecting social dynamics.
The first water closet is installed in England, marking a significant advance in sanitation technology.

1597.summary: Andreas Libavius publishes Alchemia, a pioneering chemistry textbook.

1597.event: Execution of European Christians in Japan
1597.summary: In Japan, 26 European Catholic Christians are executed in Nagasaki by crucifixion.

1597.event: First performance of The Merry Wives of Windsor
1597.summary: Probable first performance of William Shakespeare's The Merry Wives of Windsor.
A Dutch expedition successfully reaches Java, opening the Spice trade to the Dutch.
Amiens is retaken from the Spanish by Anglo-French forces after a four-month siege.
The Koreans, commanded by Yi Sunsin, achieve a decisive victory over a Japanese fleet.
The 3rd Spanish Armada departs from the port of La Coruña, planning to invade the British Isles.
The Staten-Generaal of the Dutch Republic approves a common board for the Republic's navies.

1597.event: Election of new Doge of Genoa
1597.summary: Lazzaro Grimaldi Cebà is elected as the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa.
Jacopo Peri writes Dafne, now recognized as the first opera.

1598.summary: The Tsar of the Russian Empire, Feodor I, dies of a sudden illness at the age of 40, leaving no children and ending the Rurik dynasty.

1598.event: Election of Boris Godunov as Tsar
1598.summary: Boris Godunov is elected as the Tsar of Russia by unanimous vote of the parliament of nobles, the Zemsky Sobor.
Henry IV of France grants French Huguenots equal rights with Catholics, ending the French Wars of Religion.
Tycho Brahe's star catalogue Astronomiæ instauratæ mechanica, listing the positions of 1,004 stars, is published.
King Henry IV conquers the Duchy of Brittany, forcing the surrender of Philippe Louis de Lorraine-Mercœur.

1598.event: Marriage of Isabella Clara Eugenia and Albert of Austria
1598.summary: King Philip II of Spain announces the marriage of his daughter, Isabella Clara Eugenia, to Albert of Austria to jointly govern the Habsburg Netherlands.

1598.event: Founding of Santa Fe de Nuevo Méjico
1598.summary: Juan de Oñate proclaims the founding of the colony of Santa Fe de Nuevo Méjico as the first Viceroy.
Hugh O'Neill gains victory over an English expeditionary force in the Nine Years' War in Ireland.
General Toyotomi Hideyoshi, who united Japan, dies after ruling for 12 years and is succeeded by his son.
An allied Korean and Chinese fleet under Admiral Yi Sun-sin defeats the Japanese navy, ending the Japanese invasions of Korea.

1599.summary: The Ratio Studiorum, a significant Jesuit educational plan, is issued detailing educational methods and curricula.

1599.event: First performance of As You Like It
1599.summary: The earliest known performance of Shakespeare's play As You Like It occurs, enhancing the cultural landscape.

1599.event: Lease of land for Globe Theatre
1599.summary: The land for the Globe Theatre is leased, marking a major development in English theatre and culture.

1599.event: Earl of Essex arrives in Dublin
1599.summary: The Earl of Essex leads a historically large army of 16,000 troops into Ireland, influencing political and military dynamics.
The Siege of Zaltbommel begins, part of the ongoing Anglo-Spanish War, which affects international relations and trade.

1599.event: First reported performance at the Globe Theatre
1599.summary: The first recorded performance at the newly constructed Globe Theatre is documented, highlighting its significance in the arts.
Michael the Brave defeats Andrew Báthory, marking a pivotal moment in Romanian history and unification efforts.
A Persian diplomatic delegation arrives in Moscow to form alliances against the Ottoman Empire, impacting European politics.
Dutch and English forces successfully defend against the siege of Zaltbommel, showcasing military collaboration.

1599.event: Dethronement of King Sigismund III Vasa
1599.summary: Duke Charles dethrones Sigismund III Vasa, altering the political landscape of Sweden and influencing regional power dynamics.

1600.summary: Scotland adopts January 1 as New Year's Day instead of March 25
The Huaynaputina volcano in Peru erupts, in what is still the worst recorded volcanic eruption
The première of Jacopo Peri's Euridice takes place in Florence for the wedding of Henry IV of France and Marie de' Medici
The Battle of Sekigahara occurs in Japan, bringing the Tokugawa clan nominal control over Japan

1600.event: Royal Charter for East India Company
1600.summary: The East India Company is granted a Royal charter in the Kingdom of England for trade with Asia
Greek farmers in Thessaly begin an uprising against the Ottoman Empire, which is quickly suppressed
Barrister Nicholas Fuller is granted the exclusive right in England to manufacture playing cards
The Battle of Mirăslău takes place as Hungarian troops triumph over the Principality of Wallachia
Hugh O'Neill, Earl of Tyrone, renews the Nine Years' War against England with an invasion of Munster
The first Dutch ship ever to arrive in Japan, the Liefde, anchors in Sashifu

1601.summary: France gains Bresse, Bugey and Gex from Savoy, ceding Saluzzo in exchange.
Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex, begins a rebellion against Queen Elizabeth I, which is quickly crushed.

1601.event: Execution of the Earl of Essex
1601.summary: The Earl of Essex is beheaded at Tower Hill for his role in the failed rebellion against Queen Elizabeth I.

1601.event: Sigismund Báthory proclaimed Prince of Transylvania
1601.summary: At an assembly of nobles, Sigismund Báthory is proclaimed Prince of Transylvania once again.

1601.event: First expedition of the East India Company
1601.summary: The East India Company's first expedition sets sail from England for the Spice Islands.
The Siege of Ostend begins, lasting over three years and resulting in massive casualties on both sides.

1601.event: Papal decree on publication of litanies
1601.summary: Pope Clement VIII issues a decree forbidding the publication of any litany except that of the saints.
Johannes Kepler is promoted to Royal Mathematician of the Holy Roman Empire after Tycho Brahe's death.
A large Spanish fleet lands in Ireland to assist in Tyrone's Rebellion against British rule.
A bad harvest causes a famine in Russia, leading to the death of about two million people.

1602.summary: The English defeat Irish rebels and their Spanish allies
William Shakespeare's comedy Twelfth Night premieres in London

1602.event: Establishment of the United East India Company
1602.summary: The United East India Company is established by the United Provinces States-General in Amsterdam
English Royal Navy defeats a larger force of Spanish Navy ships off Portugal
Dunboy Castle in Ireland is taken by the English after a long siege

1602.event: Creation of the Duchy of Saxe-Altenburg
1602.summary: The German duchy of Saxe-Altenburg is created as a gift to Johann Philipp
Prime minister of Mughal Emperor Akbar is assassinated
A rebellion by soldiers of the Army of Flanders begins with the seizure of the town
Dutch and English army forces the surrender of Spanish defenders after two months
The Bodleian Library at the University of Oxford is opened

1603.summary: Queen Elizabeth I of England dies at Richmond Palace after a long reign, leading to the succession of King James VI of Scotland and the unification of the crowns of Scotland and England.
Tokugawa Ieyasu is granted the title of shōgun by Emperor Go-Yozei, marking the beginning of the Edo period in Japan.
The Accademia dei Lincei, the oldest scientific academy in the world, is founded in Rome by Federico Cesi, promoting scientific advancement.
The formal coronation of James I as King of England takes place at Westminster Abbey, marking a new era for England.
The King's Men, a group of English professional actors including William Shakespeare, is granted a royal patent by King James.
The Sangley Rebellion against Spanish rule in the Philippines ends tragically, highlighting the tensions in colonial rule.
The Safavid Army of Iran, led by Emperor Abbas the Great, recaptures Tabriz from the Ottoman Empire after years of occupation.
Yemişçi Hasan Pasha, the Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire, is executed after failing to respond adequately to military threats from the Safavid Empire.
Sultan Mehmed III of the Ottoman Empire passes away, marking a significant political change.

1603.event: Inauguration of the first permanent Dutch trading post in Indonesia
1603.summary: The establishment of the first permanent Dutch trading post in Banten reflects the increasing European involvement in global trade.

1604.event: Performance of A Midsummer Night's Dream
1604.summary: The earliest recorded performance of William Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream takes place at Hampton Court
The Hampton Court Conference is held leading to the work on the Authorized King James Version of the Bible

1604.event: Denouncement of the Roman Catholic Church
1604.summary: King James of England denounces the Roman Catholic Church after learning Queen Anne received a rosary from the Pope
Maurice of Nassau begins the Siege of Sluis which results in the surrender of the city after three months
England concludes the Treaty of London with Spain, ending the Anglo-Spanish War
Kepler's Supernova is first observed from the northern parts of the Italian Peninsula
The first recorded performance of Shakespeare's tragedy, Othello, takes place at the Palace of Whitehall
The first recorded performance of Shakespeare's Measure for Measure occurs before King James I
The 1604 Quanzhou earthquake, with an estimated 8.1 magnitude, shakes the Taiwan Strait
The Table Alphabeticall, the first known English dictionary organized by alphabetical ordering, is published

1605.event: Performance of A Midsummer Night's Dream
1605.summary: William Shakespeare's play, A Midsummer Night's Dream, is given its earliest recorded performance, attended by the Viscount Dorchester.
The first part of Miguel de Cervantes' Don Quixote is published, becoming a global bestseller and a significant work in literature.

1605.event: Papal Conclave for Pope Leo XI
1605.summary: Cardinal Alessandro Ottaviano de' Medici is elected Pope Leo XI after a heated conclave, serving less than four weeks.
The first issue of Relation aller Fürnemmen und gedenckwürdigen Historien, regarded as the world's first newspaper, is published in Strasbourg.
The Gunpowder Plot to bomb Westminster Palace is foiled, leading to the arrest of Guy Fawkes.
Camillo Borghese is elected Pope Paul V during the second papal conclave of the year, amidst physical disagreements among cardinals.

1605.event: Shakespeare's Performance of The Merchant of Venice
1605.summary: Shakespeare's play The Merchant of Venice is given its earliest recorded performance at the Palace of Whitehall for King James I.
A major earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 7.9 strikes Japan, triggering a tsunami that kills thousands.
The 3rd Mughal Emperor Akbar the Great dies in Fatehpur Sikri, marking the end of an important era in Indian history.
After a brief reign, Pope Leo XI dies, leading to another papal conclave to elect a successor.

1606.summary: The trial of Guy Fawkes and other conspirators for plotting against Parliament and James I starts.
Willem Janszoon makes the first confirmed sighting of Australia by a European.
King James I grants rights to the Virginia Company to settle parts of North America.
The first version of the Union Flag is created for English and Scottish ships.
Tsar Dmitry I of Russia is assassinated, leading to a change in leadership.
Vasili Ivanovich Shuisky ascends as the new Tsar of Russia following the assassination.
A Dutch fleet is defeated by the Portuguese during a naval engagement.
William Shakespeare's tragedy Macbeth is possibly performed for the first time in London.

1606.event: First Recorded Performance of King Lear
1606.summary: Shakespeare's play King Lear is staged for the first time at the Palace of Whitehall.
The Peace of Zsitvatorok recognizes the independence of Transylvania between the Ottomans and the Holy Roman Empire.

1607.summary: Claudio Monteverdi's L'Orfeo, the earliest fully developed opera in the modern-day repertoire, premieres at the Ducal Palace of Mantua.
The Bank of Genoa fails, after the announcement of national bankruptcy in Spain.
A massive wave sweeps along the Bristol Channel, possibly a tsunami, killing 2,000 people.
A Dutch fleet stages a surprise attack on a Spanish fleet, leading to significant losses for Spain and contributing to national bankruptcy.
Jamestown, Virginia, is established as the first permanent English settlement in North America.
Hugh O'Neill and Rory O'Donnell flee Ireland for Spain with 90 followers to avoid capture by the English crown.
Hamlet is performed aboard the East India Company ship Red Dragon, marking the first known performance of a Shakespeare play outside England.
Halley's Comet is seen by Johannes Kepler.
Landowners kill more than 40 peasants during protests against the enclosure of common land in Newton, culminating the Midland Revolt.

1607.event: Dutch Warship Arrives at Malay Peninsula
1607.summary: A Dutch warship attempts to open trade with the Pahang Sultanate, resulting in an agreement for assistance against the Portuguese Navy.

1608.summary: A defensive alliance between France and the United Provinces of the Netherlands is signed.
Dutch lens maker Hans Lippershey demonstrates the first telescope in the Dutch Parliament.
The settlement of Quebec City is founded by Samuel de Champlain.
A newly nationalized silver mine in Scotland at Hilderston is re-opened by Bevis Bulmer.
Matthias is crowned as King Mátyás II of Hungary.
The second Jamestown supply mission arrives with 70 settlers, increasing the population and bringing skilled artisans.

1608.event: Foundation of the University of Oviedo
1608.summary: The University of Oviedo is founded in Spain.
The Burning of Derry launches O'Doherty's Rebellion in the Kingdom of Ireland.
Old Bushmills Distillery is first licensed to distil whiskey at Bushmills by King James I.
A peace conference opens in The Hague to end a war between the Dutch Republic and the Spanish Netherlands.

1609.event: Establishment of the Bank of Amsterdam
1609.summary: The Bank of Amsterdam is established
The Netherlands and Spain agree to the Twelve Years' Truce in the Eighty Years' War
London publisher Thomas Thorpe issues Shake-speares Sonnets with a dedication

1609.event: War of the Jülich Succession begins
1609.summary: The War of the Jülich Succession begins with a treaty signed at Dortmund
The Spanish galleon San Francisco sinks in a storm off the coast of Japan
Thomas Harriot becomes the first person to make a detailed drawing of the Moon
Galileo Galilei demonstrates his first telescope to Venetian officials

1609.event: Henry Hudson enters New York Bay
1609.summary: Henry Hudson enters New York Bay aboard the Halve Maen
One of the first public libraries, the Biblioteca Ambrosiana, is opened in Milan

1610.summary: Galileo Galilei first observes the four Galilean moons of Jupiter, marking a significant advance in astronomy.
Galileo Galilei's treatise on astronomy, Sidereus Nuncius, is published, presenting the first scientific record of observations through a telescope.
King Henry IV of France is assassinated in Paris, leading to significant political changes in France.
William Shakespeare's play, The Tragedie of Macbeth, is performed for the first time at the Globe Theatre in London.

1610.event: Publication of Vespro della Beata Vergine
1610.summary: Claudio Monteverdi's musical work Vespro della Beata Vergine is published, influencing the development of music in the Baroque period.
The Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth wins the Battle of Klushino against Russian and Swedish forces, impacting the balance of power in the region.
Forces of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth capture Moscow, establishing a significant occupation.
Louis XIII is formally crowned King of France, marking the beginning of his reign.
The Siege of Jülich ends with the city surrendering, highlighting the conflicts in the Holy Roman Empire.
The Basque witch trials conclude, reflecting the social and legal context of the period.

1611.summary: Frisian astronomers Johannes Fabricius and David Fabricius observe sunspots by telescope and publish results, marking a step in astronomical science.
The Authorized King James Version of the Bible is published for the first time, significantly influencing literature and culture.

1611.event: First performance of The Winter's Tale
1611.summary: William Shakespeare's The Winter's Tale is performed for the first time at the Globe Theatre, contributing to the arts during the period.
The Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth successfully captures Smolensk after a prolonged siege, altering the power dynamics in Eastern Europe.

1611.event: Gustav II Adolf becomes King of Sweden
1611.summary: At the age of 16, Gustav II Adolf ascends to the throne of Sweden, influencing European politics and military affairs.
William Shakespeare's last solo play, The Tempest, is performed at Whitehall Palace, showcasing Shakespeare's continuing influence on theatre.
A devastating earthquake strikes off the coast of Japan, resulting in a deadly tsunami that impacts the region severely.
An uprising in Moscow against Polish-Lithuanian occupation leads to significant loss of life and destruction in the city, impacting citizens greatly.
Yemana Kristos ends a rebellion in Ethiopia, consolidating the power of Emperor Susenyos I and shaping the region's future.

1611.event: False Dmitry III arrives in Ivangorod
1611.summary: The arrival of False Dmitry III, a pretender to the Russian throne, adds to the political turmoil of the region, influencing power struggles.

1612.summary: Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor, dies and several candidates vie to succeed him, with Archduke Matthias eventually being elected.
King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden and 3,000 of his troops are forced to retreat from Denmark, almost drowning in the process.
The False Dmitry III is recognized as Tsar of Russia by the Cossacks, intensifying the power struggle in Russia.

1612.event: Coronation of Holy Roman Emperor Matthias
1612.summary: Archduke Matthias of Austria is formally elected and coronated as the new Holy Roman Emperor.
A Scottish mercenary force is destroyed in Norway during the Battle of Kringen, affecting military and geopolitical dynamics.
A relief force from the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth attempts to break the Russian siege of the Kremlin, resulting in heavy casualties.

1612.event: Introduction of the Gregorian calendar in Prussia
1612.summary: The Lutheran Duchy of Prussia becomes the first Protestant government to adopt the Gregorian calendar.

1612.event: Formation of Honourable East India Company's Marine
1612.summary: England's East India Company gets its first warships, establishing the 'Honourable East India Company's Marine' to protect its freighters.
Forces of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth surrender unconditionally to Russian militia forces after the Kremlin is liberated.
Galileo Galilei becomes the first astronomer to observe Neptune, mistakenly cataloguing it as a fixed star due to its slow motion.

1613.event: Election of Mikhail Romanov as Tsar
1613.summary: An assembly of the Russian Empire elects Mikhail Romanov Tsar of Russia, ending the Time of Troubles. The House of Romanov will remain a ruling dynasty until 1917.

1613.event: Restoration of Hanthawaddy as capital of Burma
1613.summary: The city of Hanthawaddy is restored as the capital of Burma by King Anaukpetlun, who relocates the government from Ava.

1613.event: First shipment of tobacco to England
1613.summary: John Rolfe makes the first shipment to England of tobacco grown in Virginia, marking a significant point in agricultural trade.
Fire destroys London's famed Globe Theatre during a performance of Shakespeare's Henry VIII, impacting the theatrical arts.

1613.event: Marriage of Elizabeth and Frederick V
1613.summary: Elizabeth, daughter of King James I of England, marries Frederick V, Elector Palatine, strengthening political alliances.
The Sicilians under de Aragon defeat the trade fleet of the Ottoman Empire, a significant event in maritime history.

1613.event: Arrival of first American-grown tobacco in England
1613.summary: The first American-grown tobacco, produced in Virginia, arrives in England, marking a new chapter in trade relationships.
Hasekura Tsunenaga departs Japan with a diplomatic mission to the Holy See, aiming to establish trade agreements.

1613.event: First unofficial Governor of New France
1613.summary: Explorer Samuel de Champlain becomes the first unofficial Governor of New France in Canada, setting the stage for future colonization.

1613.event: Burmese army defeats Siamese at Tavoy
1613.summary: The Burmese Army defeats the Siamese Army at Tavoy, marking a crucial military victory in the region.

1614.event: Japan's trade expedition to New Spain
1614.summary: Led by Hasekura Tsunenaga, Japan's trade expedition to New Spain arrives with samurai, merchants, and interpreters.

1614.event: Proclamation Against Private Challenges and Combats
1614.summary: King James I of England issues a proclamation in an effort to end duels.

1614.event: Restoration of Roman Catholic rule in Aachen
1614.summary: Matthias I directs the restoration of Catholic rule to Aachen amid siege preparations.
Pocahontas is forced into child marriage with John Rolfe and departs for England.

1614.event: Establishment of the University of Groningen
1614.summary: The University of Groningen is established in the Dutch Republic.
The Spanish Army of Flanders lays siege to the German town of Aachen.

1614.event: King Louis XIII gains full power
1614.summary: Louis XIII is granted full power as King of France, ending the regency of his mother.

1614.event: Publication of Mirifici Logarithmorum Canonis Descriptio
1614.summary: John Napier publishes a work outlining his discovery of logarithms.

1614.event: Creation of the Treaty of Xanten
1614.summary: The Treaty of Xanten is signed, ending the war of the Jülich Succession.

1614.event: Performance of The Duchess of Malfi
1614.summary: The play The Duchess of Malfi is performed at the Globe theatre.

1615.summary: Forces under shōgun Tokugawa Ieyasu take Osaka Castle in Japan, beginning a period of peace which lasts nearly 250 years

1615.event: Hasekura Tsunenaga meets King Philip III
1615.summary: Japan's diplomatic mission to Europe, led by Hasekura Tsunenaga, meets with King Philip III of Spain in Madrid

1615.event: First Récollet missionaries arrive in Quebec City
1615.summary: The first Récollet missionaries arrive at Quebec City, from Rouen, France
In Russia, the siege of Pskov ends with the withdrawal of Swedish Army troops, marking the last battle of the Ingrian War

1615.event: Hasekura Tsunenaga received by Pope Paul V
1615.summary: Japanese diplomat Hasekura Tsunenaga and his delegation are received by Pope Paul V in Rome, presenting a request for trade between the Roman Catholic Church and the Japanese shogunate

1615.event: Marriage of King Louis XIII and Princess Ana María Mauricia
1615.summary: King Louis XIII of France marries Princess Ana María Mauricia, the daughter of King Philip III of Spain

1615.event: Johannes Kepler publishes Dissertatio cum Nuncio Sidereo
1615.summary: Johannes Kepler publishes a work in response to Galileo's discovery of Jupiter's moons

1615.event: Introduction of the telescope in China
1615.summary: Manuel Dias, a Portuguese Jesuit missionary, introduces the telescope for the first time in China

1615.event: Publication of second volume of Don Quixote
1615.summary: The second volume of Miguel de Cervantes's Don Quixote is published, achieving great success
Grolsch Brewery is founded in Groenlo, Netherlands

1616.summary: Galileo Galilei appears before Cardinal Roberto Bellarmino, warned against supporting Copernican heliocentrism and enjoined by the Catholic Church to refrain from teaching it.
King James I grants Ben Jonson an annual pension, effectively making him the poet laureate and promoting the arts in England.
Dirk Hartog lands on Australian soil at Dirk Hartog Island, marking a significant point in European exploration of the continent.
The first non-aristocratic, free public school in Europe is opened in Frascati, Italy, democratizing education access.
The Treaty of Loudun is signed, ending a series of rebellions in France, impacting social and political stability.
Sir Thomas Roe presents his credentials to the Mughal Emperor Jahangir, establishing British diplomatic relations, influencing trade and culture.
Galileo Galilei meets Pope Paul V to discuss his defense of Copernican heliocentrism, marking a significant moment in the clash between science and religion.
An ordinance establishes parish schools in Scotland, promoting education reform and literacy in the region.
A series of witch trials occur with several executions in England and France, reflecting societal fears and impacting community stability.
Ben Jonson's works are published in a collected folio edition, advancing English literature and influence on future writers.

1617.summary: The Treaty of Stolbovo ends the Ingrian War between Sweden and Russia, with Sweden gaining Ingria and Kexholm.
Louis XIII forces his mother into retirement and has her favourite, Concino Concini, assassinated.
The coronation ceremony of King Gustav Adolf of Sweden takes place in Stockholm.
The Fruitbearing Society of German scholars is founded in Weimar.
Francis Bacon is appointed as Lord Keeper of the Great Seal of England and designated to serve as regent.

1617.event: First Performance of The Mad Lover
1617.summary: The Mad Lover, a play by John Fletcher, is given its first performance.

1617.event: Return of King James to Scotland
1617.summary: King James I is escorted to return to Scotland for the first time since the Union of the Crowns.

1617.event: Signing of the Treaty of Pavia
1617.summary: The Treaty of Pavia is signed between Spain and Savoy, returning Monferrato to Mantua.
Pocahontas dies of smallpox after an illness while preparing to return to America.
Eliya VIII becomes the new Patriarch of the Church of the East.

1618.event: First Audience of British East India Company
1618.summary: Jahangir, ruler of the Mughal Empire in northern India, gives an audience for the first time to a representative of the British East India Company, receiving Sir Thomas Roe at the capital at Ahmedabad.
The 3,000 seat Teatro Farnese, the first permanent proscenium theatre, is built into the Great Hall of the Palazzo della Pilotta in Parma, Italy.
Protestant noblemen hold a mock trial and throw representatives of Ferdinand II of Germany out of a window, exacerbating a rebellion into the Bohemian Revolt and precipitating the Thirty Years' War.
The first major battle of the Thirty Years' War begins as Bohemian Protestants lay siege to the Catholic city of Pilsen, lasting for over two months.

1618.event: Discovery of Third Law of Planetary Motion
1618.summary: Johannes Kepler discovers the third law of planetary motion, a significant advancement in the field of astronomy.
Joris Veseler prints the first Dutch newspaper Courante uyt Italien, Duytslandt, &c. in Amsterdam.

1618.event: Emperor Gwanghaegun Appoints New Chief State Councillor
1618.summary: Jeong In-hong is appointed as the new Chief State Councillor (similar to a Prime Minister) of the Joseon Kingdom in North Korea.

1618.event: Crowning of Ferdinand II as King of Hungary
1618.summary: Ferdinand II, a proponent of the Counter-Reformation, is crowned as King of Hungary at a meeting of the Bohemian diet at Pressburg.
The Rodi avalanche buries the Alpine town of Piuro, claiming 2,427 victims.

1618.event: Signing of the Truce of Deulino
1618.summary: Russia and Poland sign the Truce of Deulino, marking an important diplomatic agreement.

1619.summary: James I of England's Banqueting House in London is destroyed by fire, leading to a commission for Inigo Jones to design a replacement.

1619.event: Death of Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor
1619.summary: Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor dies, leaving the Holy Roman Empire without an official leader amidst the Bohemian Revolt.
Manchu leader Nurhaci achieves victory over the Ming forces in the Battle of Sarhu.
Dutch statesman Johan van Oldenbarnevelt is executed in The Hague after being convicted of treason.
Jan Pieterszoon Coen, Governor General of the Dutch East Indies, conquers Jayakarta, renaming it Batavia.
Protestant forces are defeated in the Battle of Sablat during the Thirty Years' War.
Dulwich College is founded by Edward Alleyn in Dulwich, London.

1619.event: Election of Ferdinand II as Holy Roman Emperor
1619.summary: Ferdinand II, Archduke of Austria, is elected Holy Roman Emperor unanimously by the prince-electors.
The Treaty of Munich is signed by Ferdinand II and Maximilian I, Elector of Bavaria, during the Thirty Years' War.
René Descartes, while stationed along the Danube with Bavarian troops, experiences dreams leading to his idea of applying mathematical methods to philosophy.

1620.summary: Catholic Habsburg forces are victorious over Bohemian rebels two hours from Prague.
The Mayflower arrives inside the tip of Cape Cod, with Pilgrims and Planters; 41 settlers sign the Mayflower Compact.

1620.event: William Bradford and the Mayflower Pilgrims land near Plymouth Rock
1620.summary: William Bradford and the Mayflower Pilgrims land near what becomes known as Plymouth Rock.
The first merry-go-round is observed at a fair in Philippapolis, Turkey.
The modern violin is developed, marking an important advancement in musical instruments.
Cornelis Drebbel demonstrates the first navigable undersea boat in the Thames in England.
Francis Bacon publishes the Novum Organum, advancing logical thinking and scientific method.

1620.event: Juan Pablo Bonet creates sign alphabet
1620.summary: Juan Pablo Bonet creates a sign alphabet for teaching deaf children in the Spanish court.
The beginning of witch-hunts in Scotland leads to social and cultural upheaval.
A severe frost in England freezes the River Thames and causes significant agricultural losses.

1621.summary: Şehzade Mehmed, the half-brother of Ottoman Sultan Osman II, is executed.
The Tianqi era begins in Ming Dynasty China with Zhu Changluo as the Taichang Emperor.
The Protestant Union, a coalition of Protestant states in the Holy Roman Empire, is formally dissolved.
Pope Gregory XV succeeds Pope Paul V as the 234th pope.
The city of Tornio is founded by King Gustavus Adolphus, becoming the northernmost city in the world at the time.
Twenty-seven Czech lords are executed in Prague as a consequence of the Battle of White Mountain during the Thirty Years' War.
The Battle of Khotyn begins as a large force of Ottoman troops attacks the city of Khotyn.
The Treaty of Khotyn is signed, ending the First Polish-Ottoman War.
The Pilgrims of Plymouth Colony and Wampanoags celebrate a harvest feast, later known as the First Thanksgiving.

1621.event: Rediscovery of the Law of Refraction
1621.summary: Willebrord Snel van Royen reveals he has rediscovered the law of refraction.

1622.summary: The Holy Roman Empire and Transylvania sign a peace treaty, stabilizing the region after conflicts.
King James I of England takes a significant political action by dissolving Parliament, leading to tensions.
Algonquian natives kill 347 English settlers outside Jamestown, marking a turning point in relations.
Hormuz is captured from the Portuguese, signifying a shift in control over crucial trade routes.
In a significant battle during the Thirty Years' War, Protestant forces suffer massive losses to Imperial troops.
The Ottoman Sultan is killed by rebelling Janissaries, causing upheaval in the Ottoman Empire.
Imperial forces under Tilly inflict heavy casualties on Protestant forces in another battle of the Thirty Years' War.
The capital of the Electorate of the Palatinate falls to Imperial forces after a prolonged siege.
A Dutch army successfully relieves the siege at Bergen op Zoom, showcasing military resilience.
The first Huguenot rebellion concludes with a peace treaty, altering the landscape of Huguenot and royal relations.

1623.summary: France, Savoy and Venice sign the Treaty of Paris, agreeing to cooperate in removing Spanish forces from the strategic Alpine pass of Valtelline
In the Thirty Years' War, the army of the Protestant Electoral Palatinate is destroyed by the Catholic League at the Battle of Stadtlohn

1623.event: Première of Amor, honor y poder
1623.summary: The first performance of Pedro Calderón de la Barca's play at the Court of Habsburg Spain
The publication of the 'First Folio', a collection of 36 of Shakespeare's plays, half of which have not previously been printed
Cardinal Antonio Marcello Barberini informs Galileo Galilei that Pope Urban VIII wishes to visit him
King Gwanghaegun of Joseon in Korea is deposed in a coup and succeeded by King Injo
The execution of ten English merchants by agents of the Dutch East India Company in Ambon, affecting trade dynamics
Raja Gaj Singh is deputized by Mughal Emperor Jahangir to hunt down his rebel son, who will later become Shah Jahan
Fifty Christians are executed in Edo, Japan, highlighting religious tensions
Johannes Rudbeck founds the first gymnasium in Sweden, impacting education

1624.summary: After 90 years of Ottoman occupation, Baghdad is recaptured by the Safavid Empire.
General Yi Gwal leads an uprising of 12,000 soldiers against King Injo in the Joseon Kingdom.

1624.event: Colonization of Saint Kitts and Nevis
1624.summary: England first colonizes Saint Kitts and Nevis.
A Dutch West India Company fleet captures the Brazilian city of Salvador, Bahia from the Portuguese Empire.
Louis XIII of France appoints Cardinal Richelieu to the Conseil du Roi, a significant step in French political history.
The Treaty of Compiègne is signed between the Kingdom of France and the Dutch Republic, marking a key diplomatic achievement.
The Siege of Breda begins, a significant military conflict that will last for over nine months.
The Parlement of Paris registers a decree forbidding criticism of ancient authors without prior approval.
Denmark's first postal service is launched by order of King Christian IV, enhancing communication.
Portuguese Jesuit priest António de Andrade becomes the first European to enter Tibet, marking an important cultural exchange.

1625.summary: Troops under the Marquis of Toiras recapture the island of Ré, ending the second Huguenot rebellion.

1625.event: Premiere of La liberazione di Ruggiero
1625.summary: Francesca Caccini's opera La liberazione di Ruggiero has its premiere in Florence, Italy, marking a significant event in music history.
The Treaty of Southampton establishes an alliance between England and the Dutch Republic against Spain.
English forces are decisively defeated by the Spanish at Cádiz during the Cádiz Expedition.
The Dutch settle Manhattan, founding the town of New Amsterdam, a precursor to modern New York City.
A Dutch fleet attacks the Portuguese garrison at Elmina castle but is defeated, leading to a lull in Dutch attacks on colonies.
The Netherlands and England sign the Treaty of The Hague, providing military aid to King Christian IV during the Thirty Years' War.
Prince Frederick Henry is sworn in as the stadtholder of Holland and Zeeland, a key political event.
The Safavid Empire defeats an invasion from the Kingdom of Georgia in the Battle of Marabda.

1625.event: Marriage of Charles I and Henrietta Maria
1625.summary: King Charles I of England marries Catholic princess Henrietta Maria of France at Canterbury.

1626.summary: Gustavus Adolphus, King of Sweden, defeats a Polish army
King Charles I of England is crowned without his wife, Henrietta Maria
Huguenot rebels and French government sign Treaty of Paris, ending the second Huguenot rebellion
Treaty of Monzón is signed between France and Spain to end the Valtellina War
A gunpowder factory explosion in Beijing destroys part of the city and kills 20,000 people
A 7.0 magnitude earthquake strikes Lingqiu County, killing 5,200 residents
Nine Jesuit Christian missionaries are executed in Japan
The new St Peter's Basilica in the Vatican is consecrated
Peter Minuit buys Manhattan from a Native American tribe for trade goods
The 1626 influenza pandemic begins in Asia and spreads globally

1627.event: First recorded sighting of South Australia
1627.summary: The Dutch ship 't Gulden Zeepaert makes the first recorded sighting of the coast of South Australia.
England lands the first European settlers on Barbados.

1627.event: Joseon Dynasty becomes a tributary state
1627.summary: After the First Manchu invasion, the Joseon Dynasty becomes a tributary state of the Manchus.
Maurice, Landgrave of Hesse-Kassel, is forced to abdicate after bankruptcy.
The States of Friesland promulgate a resolution after allowing citizens to voice complaints.

1627.event: Eighty Years' War: Siege of Grol
1627.summary: Frederick Henry begins the final siege of Grol, capturing it after 30 days.
The Siege of La Rochelle begins as France and Spain suppress the Protestant revolt.
Zhu Youjian is enthroned as the Chongzhen Emperor after his brother's reign ends.
La selva sin amor, the first Spanish opera, premieres with music by Alessandro Piccinini.
Habsburg Spain suffers a significant economic collapse.

1628.summary: Shah Jahan is formally crowned as the ruler of the Mughal Empire in Agra, marking the beginning of a significant era in Indian history.
King Gustavus Adolphus issues an order prohibiting religious visionary Margareta from preaching, reflecting the political control over religious movements in Sweden.
The siege of Stralsund begins, a pivotal event in the Thirty Years' War impacting the balance of power in Northern Europe.
Wallenstein defeats Christian IV's army in the Battle of Wolgast, further influencing the course of the Thirty Years' War.
Dutch admiral Piet Hein captures 16 ships of the Spanish treasure fleet, bringing immense wealth to the Dutch Republic.

1628.event: End of the siege of La Rochelle
1628.summary: The siege of La Rochelle ends with the surrender of the Huguenots, a key event in the French Wars of Religion.

1628.event: Execution of Christian converts in Japan
1628.summary: 21 Christian converts are executed in Japan, highlighting the persecution of Christians during this period.
William Harvey publishes his groundbreaking findings on blood circulation, influencing both medicine and science.
The Collegiate School, the oldest surviving educational institution in the United States, is established, laying foundations for higher education.

1628.event: Arrival of black slaves in Dutch Manhattan
1628.summary: The first black slaves arrive in Dutch Manhattan, marking a significant moment in the history of slavery in America.

1629.summary: Abbas the Great, one of the greatest rulers in Iranian history and the most powerful of the Safavid dynasty Shahs, dies after a reign of more than 40 years.
Sam Mirza, son of the late Mohammad Baqer Mirza and grandson of Abbas the Great, is crowned as the new Shah of Persia and takes the regnal name Safi.

1629.event: Royal charter granted to Massachusetts Bay Colony
1629.summary: Massachusetts Bay Colony is granted a royal charter, becoming the first colony in what will become the United States.
Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor issues the Edict of Restitution, ordering all Catholic properties lost to Protestantism since 1552 to be restored.
Christian IV of Denmark and Albrecht von Wallenstein sign the Treaty of Lübeck, ending Denmark's involvement in the Thirty Years' War.
Louis XIII of France signs in his camp the Peace of Alès, ending the Huguenot rebellions and allowing Huguenots religious freedom.
The Cambridge Agreement is signed in the Massachusetts Bay Colony, providing for the colony to be under the control of stockholders who emigrate.
As a result of the Cambridge Agreement, the Massachusetts Bay Colony becomes a self-governing entity.
After a five-month-long siege, 's-Hertogenbosch surrenders to Frederick Henry, worsening Spain's situation along the Spanish–Dutch border.
Sweden and the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth sign the Truce of Altmark, ending the Polish-Swedish War in highly favorable terms for Sweden.

1630.summary: A shoemaker in Turin is found to have the first case of bubonic plague there as the plague of 1630 begins spreading through Italy.
A fleet sent by the Dutch West India Company captures Recife from the Portuguese, establishing Dutch Brazil.

1630.event: Swedish Intervention in Thirty Years' War
1630.summary: Swedish intervention in the Thirty Years' War begins when King Gustav Adolf of Sweden, leading an army of 13,000 on the Protestant side, makes landfall at Peenemünde, Pomerania.
Massachusetts Bay Colony is founded, with John Winthrop as governor.
Stettin is taken by Swedish forces during the Thirty Years' War.
The Treaty of Stettin is signed by Sweden and the Duchy of Pomerania, forming a close alliance between them and giving Sweden full military control over Pomerania.
The first case of plague is reported in Milan, leading to severe population loss by the end of 1631.
John Winthrop helps in founding a church in Massachusetts, which will later become known as First Church in Boston.

1630.event: Establishment of the Swedish National Heritage Board
1630.summary: The Swedish National Heritage Board is created, with Johannes Bureus as its first director.
The Peace of Regensburg is signed, confirming Charles Gonzaga as Duke of Mantua in the War of the Mantuan Succession.

1631.summary: Sweden and France sign a military alliance during the Thirty Years' War.
The army of the Holy Roman Empire sacks the Protestant city of Magdeburg, massacring over 20,000 inhabitants.
Bavaria and France sign a treaty forming a secret alliance during the Thirty Years' War.
Mumtaz Mahal dies in childbirth, prompting Shah Jahan to commission the Taj Mahal as her mausoleum.
Gustavus II Adolphus of Sweden decisively defeats the Holy Roman Imperial army, marking a significant victory for Protestants in the Thirty Years' War.
King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden takes possession of Prague, capital of Bohemia.
The Treaty of Cherasco is signed, ending the War of the Mantuan Succession.
A volcanic eruption occurs at Pompeii after several centuries.
The first weekly French newspaper is published.

1631.event: End of bubonic plague in Venice
1631.summary: A special mass in Venice celebrates the end of two years of bubonic plague.

1632.summary: The University of Amsterdam is established at the site of the Athenaeum Illustre of Amsterdam
Dr. Nicolaes Tulp conducts a dissection for medical students, later immortalized in Rembrandt's painting The Anatomy Lesson
Galileo's Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems is published
Count Tilly defeats the Swedish army at the Battle of Bamberg during the Thirty Years' War
Gustavus Adolphus defeats the Catholic League armies at the Battle of Rain
The Swedish army captures Munich, the capital of Bavaria

1632.event: Construction of the Taj Mahal begins
1632.summary: Construction of the Taj Mahal begins following the death of Mumtaz Mahal
Emperor Fasilides reinstates Ethiopian Orthodox Christianity and confiscates lands from Jesuit missionaries
Swedish king Gustavus Adolphus defeated in an attempt to break the siege of Nuremberg
Gustavus II Adolphus is killed at the Battle of Lützen but his army defeats Wallenstein

1633.summary: Galileo Galilei arrives in Rome for his trial before the Inquisition.
Galileo Galilei is convicted of heresy by the Roman Catholic Church.

1633.event: Charles I crowned King of Scots
1633.summary: Charles I is crowned King of Scots at St Giles' Cathedral, Edinburgh.
The Roman Catholic Church forces Galileo Galilei to recant his heliocentric view of the Solar System.
Sweden defeats the Holy Roman Empire near Hessisch Oldendorf during the Thirty Years' War.
William Laud becomes Archbishop of Canterbury.
Spain recaptures Rheinfelden from Sweden during the Thirty Years' War.
Shogun Tokugawa Iemitsu of Japan issues the Sakoku Edict of 1635 outlawing Christianity.
A professorship in Arabic studies is founded at the University of Cambridge in England.
St Columb's Cathedral, the first post-Reformation Anglican cathedral, is completed in Derry, Ireland.

1634.summary: Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor, signs a classified order dismissing Albrecht von Wallenstein, the supreme commander of the Imperial Army.
Rebel Scots and Irish soldiers assassinate Bohemian military leader Albrecht von Wallenstein at Cheb.
The Russians vacate their camp, ending the Siege of Smolensk.
The Battle of Amritsar begins when Mughal Empire troops attempt to eliminate the Sikh religious leader, Guru Hargobind.
The Treaty of Polyanovka is signed between the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth and the Tsardom of Russia, concluding the Smolensk War.
The Battle of Nördlingen ends with a decisive victory for the Army of the Holy Roman Empire and Habsburg Spain.
The Burchardi flood strikes the North Sea coast of Germany and Denmark, causing significant deaths and destruction.

1634.event: Pope Urban VIII and Galileo Galilei
1634.summary: Francesco Niccolini obtains an audience with Pope Urban VIII, pleading for reconsideration of the Church's punishment of Galileo Galilei.

1634.event: First performance of the Oberammergau Passion Play
1634.summary: The first performance of the Oberammergau Passion Play is held in Bavaria.
The Académie Française is formed by Cardinal Richelieu, aiming to standardize the French language and literature.

1635.summary: The Académie française is formally constituted in Paris, focused on preserving the French language.
The Peacock Throne is inaugurated in Delhi during a grand ceremony to celebrate Shah Jahan's reign.
A surprise attack leads to the declaration of war against Spain by France, escalating the ongoing conflict.
The Peace of Prague is signed, concluding the German civil war aspect of the Thirty Years' War.
The Boston Latin School is founded in Boston, marking a significant development in American education.
The public becomes able to access the Royal Mail service, improving communication across England.
Roger Williams is banished from Massachusetts Bay Colony for advocating for religious freedom and Native American rights.
Shah Jahan issues a decree against Portuguese Jesuits, restricting their activities in the Mughal Empire.
France begins the colonization of Guadeloupe and Martinique, expanding its colonial footprint in the Caribbean.

1635.event: Completion of Shah Jahan's Pearl Mosque
1635.summary: The Pearl Mosque at Lahore Fort is completed during Shah Jahan's reign, showcasing Mughal architecture.

1636.summary: A great charter to the University of Oxford establishes the Oxford University Press, making it the second of the privileged presses in England
Utrecht University is founded in the Dutch Republic
The nine-month Siege of Schenkenschans ends with forces of the Dutch Republic recapturing the fort from the Spanish
The Battle of Tornavento is fought in north-west Italy during the Thirty Years' War, resulting in heavy damage to the city of Castano Primo
The Great and General Court of the Massachusetts Bay Colony establishes New College, later known as Harvard University, as the first college in the United States

1636.event: French intervention in the Thirty Years' War
1636.summary: French intervention starts in the ongoing Thirty Years' War
Roger Williams and other Puritan settlers found the colony of Providence Plantations
Manchus proclaim the new Qing dynasty and select Shenyang as their capital

1636.event: Foundation of Kahal Zur Israel Synagogue
1636.summary: The first synagogue of the New World, Kahal Zur Israel Synagogue, is founded in Recife by the Dutch
