1636.event: Formation of the United States National Guard
1636.summary: The Massachusetts Bay Colony organizes three militia regiments to defend against the Pequot Indians, recognized today as the founding of the United States National Guard

1637.summary: Pierre Corneille's tragicomedy Le Cid is first performed
Tulip mania collapses in the Dutch Republic

1637.event: Opening of the first opera house
1637.summary: The world's first opera house, Teatro San Cassiano, opens with the premiere of L'Andromeda
Chinese encyclopedist Song Yingxing publishes Tiangong Kaiwu, a valuable encyclopedia of classical China

1637.event: Establishment of a trade deal with Persia
1637.summary: Adam Olearius is welcomed by the Safavid ruler at the Persian capital Isfahan
Ferdinand III is coronated as the new Holy Roman Emperor in Vienna

1637.event: Launch of HMS Sovereign of the Seas
1637.summary: HMS Sovereign of the Seas is launched at Woolwich Dockyard, adorned with gilded carvings
The Shimabara Rebellion erupts in Japan with 30,000 peasants revolting
René Descartes promotes intellectual rigour and introduces the Cartesian coordinate system
Pierre de Fermat claims to have proof of what will become known as Fermat's Last Theorem

1638.summary: A Netherlands fleet commanded by Admiral Adam Westerwolt decimates the Portuguese fleet in a naval battle
A treaty is signed between France and Sweden providing funds to Sweden during the Thirty Years' War
Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan and his sons capture the city of Kandahar from the Safavids
The last remnants of the Shimabara Rebellion are defeated, leading to strict enforcement of Christianity suppression in Japan
Spanish troops defeat a much larger Dutch force during the Eighty Years' War near Antwerp

1638.event: First ascent of the Amazon River
1638.summary: A Portuguese expedition led by Pedro Teixeira completes the first ascent of the Amazon River
The Finnish mail service is established, precursor to Posti Group
New Haven is founded, marking the first planned city in America

1638.event: General Assembly of the Church of Scotland
1638.summary: The General Assembly is summoned to Glasgow by King Charles I
Baghdad is captured by the Ottomans under Sultan Murad IV

1639.event: Printing Press in British North America
1639.summary: The first printing press in British North America is started in Cambridge, Massachusetts by Stephen Daye.
Swedish forces inflict a crushing defeat on the Holy Roman Empire, prolonging the Thirty Years' War.
Pope Urban VIII issues a papal bull prohibiting slavery in the New World colonies of Spain and Portugal.

1639.event: First Battle of the Bishops' Wars
1639.summary: The first battle of the Bishops' Wars is fought in Scotland between the English Army and the Scottish Covenanters.

1639.event: Introduction of Line of Battle Tactic
1639.summary: Admiral Maarten Tromp introduces the line of battle tactic in a naval battle in the English Channel.
A Republic of the United Provinces fleet decisively defeats a Spanish fleet in English waters.
Jeremiah Horrocks makes the first successful prediction and observation of a transit of Venus.
The British East India Company buys land for Fort St. George, founding modern-day Chennai in India.

1639.event: Establishment of Roman Catholic Mission in Montreal
1639.summary: Jérôme le Royer de la Dauversière obtains the seigneurial title to the island of Montreal to evangelize indigenous peoples.
Japan enforces Sakoku, an isolationist foreign policy, limiting trade with Europeans.

1640.summary: The Siege of Salses ends with the French surrendering to the Spanish attackers after months of conflict.
A naval battle over control of Brazil concludes as the Dutch drive the Portuguese away from Recife.
Ibrahim I succeeds Murad IV as Sultan of the Ottoman Empire, marking a change in leadership.
Dutch troops take the strategic fortress at Galle from the Portuguese during a significant military engagement.
The Catalan Revolt breaks out in Catalonia, leading to significant social unrest.
The eruption of Mount Komagatake in Japan causes a famine affecting the local population.
The Royal Academy of Turku, the first university in Finland, is inaugurated.
A Scottish Covenanter army invades Northumberland, marking the onset of the Second Bishops' War.
The Siege of Turin ends with a victory for the French and Piedmontese forces, recapturing the city from Spain.
The end of the Iberian Union begins as John IV of Portugal is acclaimed king, ending 60 years of union with Spain.

1641.summary: The stratovolcano Mount Parker in the Philippines has a major eruption.
The Junta de Braços of Catalonia led by Pau Claris proclaims the Catalan Republic under French protection.
King Charles I of England gives his assent to the Triennial Act, committing to parliamentary sessions every three years.
The Earl of Strafford is publicly beheaded in London after being convicted of treason.
The Long Parliament in England passes the Act against Dissolving Parliament without its own Consent.
The Battle of Songjin begins, where the Ming dynasty defeats the Qing rebels in North Korea.
The Treaty of The Hague is signed between the Dutch Republic and the Kingdom of Portugal as a truce and alliance.
The Long Parliament passes the Grand Remonstrance, highlighting objections to King Charles I's absolutist tendencies.
The term 'roundhead' is used for the first time to describe supporters of the English Parliament.
The Militia Ordinance is introduced, proposing to allow Parliament to appoint its own military commanders.

1642.event: First English Civil War - Attempted Arrest of Parliamentarians
1642.summary: King Charles I attempts to arrest five leading members of parliament but they escape

1642.event: First Performance of Il palazzo incantato
1642.summary: The Italian opera by Luigi Rossi receives its first performance
The Irish Confederation starts a siege against English Protestant control in Ireland
A major naval battle takes place between French and Spanish fleets

1642.event: Creation of the Committee of Safety
1642.summary: The English Parliament creates a committee challenging King Charles I's authority
The English Parliament orders the closure of theatres, ending the era of Renaissance theatre

1642.event: First English Civil War - Battle of Edgehill
1642.summary: Royalists and Parliamentarians battle to a draw in the first major battle of the war

1642.event: First English Civil War - Battle of Turnham Green
1642.summary: Royalist forces withdraw after failing to take London from Parliamentarian forces

1642.event: Abel Tasman Discovers Van Diemen's Land
1642.summary: Abel Tasman claims Van Diemen's Land for the Netherlands, becoming the first European to do so

1642.event: Abel Tasman Sightings of New Zealand
1642.summary: Abel Tasman becomes the first recorded European to sight New Zealand, engaging with local Maori

1643.summary: Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan observes the 12th anniversary of his wife's death and opens the Taj Mahal to thousands of mourners

1643.event: Louis XIV becomes King of France
1643.summary: At age 4, Louis XIV succeeds his father as King, beginning a reign that will last 72 years
French forces defeat the Spanish at the Battle of Rocroi during the Thirty Years' War
A strategic Parliamentarian victory over Royalist forces led by King Charles in the First English Civil War
The Shunzhi Emperor of China is crowned at five years old following his father's death
Empress Meishō abdicates the throne and Emperor Go-Kōmyō ascends in Japan
Evangelista Torricelli invents the mercury barometer, advancing scientific measurement

1643.event: First English Civil War: Battle of Alton
1643.summary: Parliamentarians defeat Royalists in the Battle of Alton
Jean Bolland publishes the first two volumes of the Acta Sanctorum, beginning an important scholarly work

1643.event: Miyamoto Musashi begins The Book of Five Rings
1643.summary: Famous swordsman Miyamoto Musashi begins dictating his renowned work on strategy

1644.summary: First assembly of the Royalist Oxford Parliament by King Charles I of England
Parliamentarians defeat Royalists, ending the siege of Nantwich
Crushing defeat of Royalists by Parliamentarians, ending Charles I's control in the North
A popular rebellion leads to the sacking of Beijing and the suicide of the last Ming emperor
The Qing army captures Beijing, marking the start of Manchu rule over China
Sweden defeats the Holy Roman Empire in a key battle during the Thirty Years' War
John Milton publishes an appeal for freedom of speech in London
The opera Ormindo, composed by Francesco Cavalli, has its first performance in Venice
Manchu Qing forces win decisively against Li Zicheng's Shun dynasty
Christina comes of age and is made ruling queen of Sweden

1645.summary: The Parliamentarian Roundheads defeat the Royalist Cavaliers
Archbishop of Canterbury William Laud is executed for treason on Tower Hill, London

1645.event: Foundation of the New Model Army
1645.summary: The New Model Army is officially founded during the English Civil War
The armies of Sweden decisively defeat the forces of the Holy Roman Empire
The House of Lords passes the Self-denying Ordinance, requiring Parliament members to resign military commissions
Scottish Covenanters under Lord Leven begin the Siege of Hereford, a Royalist stronghold
Prince Rupert surrenders the city of Bristol during the English Civil War
The Covenanters defeat Montrose at Selkirk
The Third siege of Basing House by Oliver Cromwell results in its destruction

1645.event: Founding of the Hôtel-Dieu de Montréal
1645.summary: Jeanne Mance founds the first hospital in North America

1646.summary: Oliver Cromwell's New Model Army surprises and routs the Royalist camp of Lord Wentworth.
A decisive Parliamentary victory is gained over the Royalists.
The future Charles II of England escapes from Cornwall into exile across the English Channel.
The Royalist garrison at Oxford surrenders to General Thomas Fairfax's Parliamentary New Model Army, ending the First English Civil War.
The populist political movement called the Levellers appears in England with the publication of a manifesto by Richard Overton and William Walwyn.
The Westminster Assembly of Divines approves a resolution to begin drafting the Westminster Confession of Faith.
France takes Dunkirk from the Spanish Netherlands for the first time.
The Anglican episcopacy is formally abolished by an act of England's Parliament.
Parliament passes an act to sell the bishops' lands across the Commonwealth following the abolition of the episcopacy.
The Covenanters hand over King Charles I of England to the Parliamentarians.

1647.summary: Chinese bandit leader Zhang Xianzhong is killed following a betrayal by one of his officers
Bavaria, Cologne, France and Sweden sign the Truce of Ulm, impacting the Thirty Years' War
The Puritan rulers of England's Long Parliament abolish Christmas and other holidays
A naval battle begins in the Spanish Philippines between Dutch and Spanish forces
The Duke of Ormond concludes a treaty with the English Commonwealth regarding Dublin
Masaniello starts a rebellion against Spanish rule in Naples
Discussions commence among New Model Army officers about new governance following the monarchy's defeat
An Irish confederate force is destroyed by the army of Parliament, killing Alasdair MacColla
King Charles of England promises a church reform, leading to the Second English Civil War
Peter Stuyvesant is appointed Director of New Netherlands by the Dutch West India Company

1648.summary: The Dutch and the Spanish sign the Peace of Münster, ending the Eighty Years' War, recognizing the Dutch Republic as a sovereign state.
France's Royal Council votes to create the Académie royale, which will influence the arts and music in France.

1648.event: End of the Thirty Years' War
1648.summary: Signing of the Treaties of Münster and Osnabrück concludes the Peace of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War, with important implications for religious tolerance.
England's Commonwealth Army massacres 70 Cornish royalists at Penzance, escalating tensions in England.
The Portuguese army defeats the Dutch army in the north of Brazil, marking significant colonial power shifts.
The Khmelnytsky Uprising in Ukraine begins, leading to significant political and social changes in the region.
King Christian IV of Denmark and Norway dies after a long reign, leading to a succession crisis.
The Battle of Prague ends the Thirty Years' War with a Swedish victory, looting the Prague Castle.
The Imam of Oman successfully recaptures Muscat from Portuguese occupiers, affecting trade routes.

1648.event: Giacomo Carissimi composes Historia di Jephte
1648.summary: Giacomo Carissimi composes Historia di Jephte, one of the first significant Latin oratorios, impacting the music scene.

1649.summary: In England, the Rump Parliament passes an ordinance to set up a High Court of Justice, to try Charles I for high treason.
King Charles I of England, Scotland and Ireland is found guilty of high treason and is beheaded outside the Palace of Whitehall.
The Commonwealth of England replaces the monarchy as the form of government, following the execution of Charles I.
The Scottish Parliament declares Prince Charles, son of the executed King Charles I, as King Charles II of Scotland.
Shah Abbas II of the Safavid Empire captures the Afghan city of Kandahar from the Mughal Empire, marking the beginning of a conflict.

1649.event: The Laws of War and Ordinances of the Sea
1649.summary: The first set of rules for England's Parliamentary Navy is adopted, promoting new naval regulations and leadership.

1649.event: Abolishment of the House of Lords
1649.summary: The House of Commons passes an act abolishing the House of Lords, describing it as 'useless and dangerous to the people of England'.
The Maryland Toleration Act is passed, allowing freedom of worship in the American colony.
Oliver Cromwell's New Model Army starts the Siege of Drogheda in Ireland, leading to the execution of Irish Catholic defenders.
The Puritan law enforcers raid the Red Bull Theatre in London, arresting actors and confiscating property for violating performance laws.

1650.event: Death of Louis I, Prince of Anhalt-Köthen
1650.summary: Louis I passes away after a long reign, affecting regional governance in northeastern Germany.

1650.event: Cardinal Mazarin learns of the plot against him
1650.summary: Cardinal Mazarin's knowledge of a plot leads to arrests, triggering parliamentary rebellion in France.
End of 35 years of Portuguese occupation in Oman as Sultan bin Saif forces their expulsion.
The French verse play Andromède, highlighting artistic progress, premieres at the Théâtre Royal de Bourbon.
Harvard Corporation established, marking a significant advancement in academic governance in the Americas.
Parliamentarian forces defeat a Scottish army, influencing the political landscape in Scotland and England.
A significant volcanic eruption occurs in Santorini, impacting the region and potentially affecting trade and safety.
Queen Christina of Sweden has an elaborate coronation, impacting the monarchy's visibility and influence in Europe.

1650.event: Prohibition on trade with rebel colonies
1650.summary: Commonwealth of England forbids trade with colonies sided with Charles II, affecting economic ties and commerce.
The first modern Palio di Siena horserace is held, marking a cultural event significant to Italian heritage.

1651.event: Charles II is crowned King of Scots
1651.summary: Charles II is crowned King of Scots at Scone, marking a significant event in Scottish history.
A first storm tide in the North Sea strikes the coast of Germany, causing massive destruction and loss of life.
A second storm tide in the North Sea strikes the Netherlands, leading to severe flooding in Amsterdam.

1651.event: Shunzhi Emperor's edict to purge corruption
1651.summary: Shunzhi, Emperor of China, announces an important imperial edict to purge corruption from the government.

1651.event: Publication of Leviathan by Thomas Hobbes
1651.summary: Philosopher Thomas Hobbes publishes Leviathan, a major work that influences political thought and discourse.

1651.event: Polish victory at the Battle of Berestechko
1651.summary: The Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth Army achieves a significant victory against the Zaporozhian Cossacks in one of the largest land battles of the century.
The English Parliamentarian New Model Army defeats a Scottish Covenanter army, showcasing the ongoing conflict in the British Isles.
Kösem Sultan is assassinated by her daughter-in-law, a critical event in the Ottoman court's power dynamics.

1651.event: Defeat of Charles II at the Battle of Worcester
1651.summary: Charles II of England, leading a largely-Scottish army, is defeated, marking the end of major conflicts related to the English Civil War.

1651.event: The first coffee house opens in England
1651.summary: The first coffee house is opened in Oxford, reflecting a cultural shift and the growing popularity of coffee in Europe.

1652.summary: Parliamentary commissioners of the Commonwealth of England proclaim the Tender of Union to be in force in Scotland, annexing Scotland with a provision for parliamentary representation.
Oliver Cromwell announces that his Council of Scotland will regulate church affairs, eliminating Presbyterianism as Scotland's state religion.
A total solar eclipse occurs, referred to as Black Monday.
Dutch sailor Jan van Riebeeck establishes a resupply camp for the Dutch East India Company, founding Cape Town.
Rhode Island passes the first law in North America making slavery illegal.
The Commonwealth of England declares war against the Dutch Republic, marking the formal beginning of the First Anglo-Dutch War.

1652.event: Battle of the Faubourg St Antoine
1652.summary: A significant battle is fought east of Paris between French Parliamentarians and the army of King Louis XIV, with no clear victor.
The Great Fire of Glasgow destroys one-third of the city, impacting many lives and properties.
A naval battle occurs in the North Sea where the Dutch are forced to withdraw, shifting naval power dynamics.
A naval battle ends in a Dutch victory over the English Royal Navy, leading to reforms in the Commonwealth's navy.

1653.summary: The gardens surrounding the Taj Mahal mausoleum are completed.
By the Coonan Cross Oath, the Eastern Church in India cuts itself off from colonial Portuguese tutelage.
The Swiss Peasant War begins after magistrates meeting at Lucerne refuse to hear from a group of peasants who have been financially hurt by the devaluation of the currency issued from Bern.
The petite post, a system of postage using prepaid labels and post boxes, is inaugurated in Paris for mailing letters within the city.
The English navy defeats the Dutch fleet in the Battle of the Gabbard after a two-day fight during the First Anglo-Dutch War.
The dissolution of Barebone's Parliament is voted by its members after having passed laws for the Commonwealth of England.
The Instrument of Government in England becomes Britain's first written constitution, marking the start of The First Protectorate.
The Battle of Bordeaux is fought between French and Spanish warships in the Gironde estuary as part of the Franco-Spanish War.
The Krishnanattam, a series of eight dance dramas telling the epic of the Hindu god Krishna, is completed in India.
The Battle of Arronches takes place with the Portuguese Army defeating a larger Spanish force.

1654.summary: The Treaty of Westminster, ending the First Anglo-Dutch War, is signed.
Otto von Guericke demonstrates the power of atmospheric pressure and the effectiveness of his vacuum pump using the Magdeburg hemispheres.
Cromwell's Act of Grace, officially the Act of Pardon and Grace to the People of Scotland, is proclaimed in Edinburgh.
Louis XIV of France is crowned at Reims.
The Battle of Shklow takes place during a total eclipse of the Sun, with Russian troops retreating.
In England, the First Protectorate Parliament assembles.

1654.event: Smolensk falls to the Russian Army
1654.summary: Smolensk falls to the Russian Army after almost three months of siege.
The Delft Explosion in the arsenal devastates the city in the Netherlands, killing more than 100.
Ferdinand Maria, Elector of Bavaria, is crowned and his leadership style influences Germany.

1654.event: Arrival of Sephardic Jews in New Amsterdam
1654.summary: 23 Sephardic Jews arrive as refugees from Brazil, forming the nucleus of a significant Jewish community.

1655.summary: Titan, the largest moon of Saturn, is discovered by Christiaan Huygens.
Emperor Go-Sai ascends to the throne of Japan.
Pope Innocent X, leader of the Roman Catholic Church, dies after more than 10 years of rule.
Admiral Robert Blake's fleet defeats the Barbary pirates in the Battle of Porto Farina, Tunis.
Charles Emmanuel II, Duke of Savoy slaughters 1,500 Waldensians during the Piedmontese Easter Massacre.
Forces of the English Protectorate capture Jamaica from Spain in the Anglo-Spanish War.
The Amsterdam Town Hall, now the Royal Palace, is inaugurated.
Swedish King Karl X Gustav occupies Warsaw during the Russo-Polish War.
Swedish King Karl X Gustav occupies Kraków as part of the ongoing war.
The Whitehall Conference ends with the determination that there is no law preventing Jews from re-entering England.

1656.summary: A civil war in the Confederation of Switzerland between Protestant and Roman Catholic cantons breaks out but is resolved by March 7.
Swedish Empire troops led by King Carl X Gustav defeat troops of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth in the first major engagement of the Swedish Deluge.
Pope Alexander VII issues a decree ending the Chinese Rites controversy, allowing Jesuit interpretations of Chinese customs within Catholicism.
Bertuccio Valier is elected Doge of the Venetian Republic after Francesco Cornaro dies shortly after his election.
The Navy of the Ottoman Empire suffers a major defeat against the navies of Venice and Malta in the Battle of the Dardanelles.
A military alliance is created between Sweden and Brandenburg and Prussia to aid in the Second Northern War.

1656.event: Köprülü Mehmed Pasha Becomes Grand Vizier
1656.summary: Köprülü Mehmed Pasha is appointed Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire, marking a significant change in leadership.
King Prasat Thong's son is overthrown after a brief reign, illustrating the political instability in the Ayutthaya Kingdom.
A Writ of Excommunication is issued against philosopher Baruch Spinoza, impacting the intellectual debates of the time.
The pendulum clock is invented by Christiaan Huygens, revolutionizing timekeeping with enhanced accuracy.

1657.summary: Miles Sindercombe and his group attempt to assassinate Oliver Cromwell by blowing up the Palace of Whitehall in London and are arrested

1657.event: Abolition of Rule of the Major-Generals
1657.summary: The regional military government in England is abolished

1657.event: Resettlement of the Jews in England
1657.summary: Oliver Cromwell assures the right of Jews to remain in England
The Humble Petition and Advice offers Lord Protector Cromwell the crown
A devastating fire destroys most of Edo, Japan, killing an estimated 100,000 people
France and England form an alliance against Spain during the Anglo-Spanish War
King Frederick III of Denmark signs a manifesto declaring war on Sweden

1657.event: First Quaker Settlers in New Amsterdam
1657.summary: The first eleven Quaker settlers arrive in New Amsterdam and are allowed to practice their faith

1657.event: Opening of England's First Chocolate House
1657.summary: England's first chocolate house is opened in London, marking a culinary advancement
Christiaan Huygens writes the first book on probability theory, impacting mathematical understanding

1658.summary: Peace between Sweden and Denmark-Norway is concluded in Roskilde, with Denmark ceding significant territory to Sweden.
The Battle of Dharmat is fought in India, leading Prince Muhi al-Din Muhammad to victory and closer to capturing the Mughal throne.
Aurangzeb wins the Battle of Samugarh, marking a pivotal moment in his rise to power in the Mughal Empire.
The siege begins as Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth and Austrian troops attempt to recapture Toruń from the Swedish Army.
In the Battle of the Dunes, a Spanish force is defeated by the French and English near Dunkirk, impacting the balance of power in Europe.
Prince Leopold of Habsburg is crowned as the Holy Roman Emperor, influencing European politics.
The Dutch Republic defeats the Swedish Navy at the Battle of the Sound, breaking Sweden's blockade of Copenhagen.

1658.event: Formation of the League of the Rhine
1658.summary: A coalition of 50 German princes forms the League of the Rhine, strengthening their political power along the river.
Oliver Cromwell dies, leading to a significant shift in leadership in England.
The Mexican Inquisition executes 14 men for homosexuality, reflecting the severe religious and social policies of the time.

1659.event: Battle of the Lines of Elvas
1659.summary: The Spanish Army suffers heavy casualties against Portuguese forces in a significant battle during the Portuguese Restoration War
Pierre Corneille's play Oedipe premieres in Paris, impacting literature and theatre.
The first known cheque of 400 pounds is written, marking an important development in banking.
The Kingdom of France, the Commonwealth of England, and the Dutch Republic sign agreements regarding the Second Northern War.
Richard Cromwell resigns as Lord Protector of England, leading to significant political changes.
Polish Cossacks defeat Russian armies in a decisive battle during the Russo-Polish War.
A royalist revolt against the military government in England begins, affecting political stability.
The Treaty formally ends the Franco-Spanish War, redistributing territories between France and Spain.
Dara Shikoh, the heir to the Mughal Empire, is betrayed and killed, impacting the Indian subcontinent's history.
Christiaan Huygens publishes his important work on astronomy, influencing scientific thought.

1660.summary: The return of the monarchy to England is initiated as Colonel George Monck leads troops to London, marking the end of military rule.
The Parliament of England declares Charles Stuart as King Charles II, concluding his years in exile and restoring the monarchy.
Under pressure from General Monck, the Rump Parliament votes to reassemble all surviving members to prepare for new elections.
King Charles II signs the Declaration of Breda, promising amnesty and freedom of conscience as part of the restoration process.
The Convention Parliament is established as a freely elected body to oversee the restoration of the monarchy.
A catastrophic fire engulfs two-thirds of Constantinople, leading to significant loss of life and property.
The first known English actress appears on stage in a non-singing role, marking a significant development in theater.
Notable men including Christopher Wren meet to establish the Royal Society for the Promotion of Experimental Learning.
The Indemnity and Oblivion Act is passed, granting a general pardon for crimes committed during the Civil War.

1660.event: End of the Anglo-Scottish Military Rule
1660.summary: Colonel Monck's forces advance through Scotland to effectively end military governance and restore monarchy control.

1661.summary: King Charles II of England, Scotland, and Ireland is crowned in Westminster Abbey

1661.event: Opening of Lincoln's Inn Fields Theatre
1661.summary: Lincoln's Inn Fields Theatre opens in London featuring the first system for interchangeable scenery on a stage in the British Isles
The Cavalier Parliament, the longest serving Parliament in British history, is opened following the first parliamentary elections since the restoration of the monarchy

1661.event: Marriage Treaty between England and Portugal
1661.summary: The Marriage Treaty is signed, providing a military alliance between King Charles II of England and King João IV of Portugal

1661.event: Death of Shunzhi Emperor of China
1661.summary: The Shunzhi Emperor of the Chinese Qing Dynasty dies, and is succeeded by his 7-year-old son the Kangxi Emperor
The Marquess of Argyll is beheaded in Edinburgh for his role in the regicide of King Charles I
General Zheng Chenggong of China takes control of most of Taiwan from the Dutch East India Company and proclaims the Kingdom of Tungning
Prince Murad Bakhsh, younger brother of the Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb, is executed at Gwailor Fort on order of his brother
The first modern bank notes are issued in Stockholm
Portugal and the Dutch Republic sign the Treaty of The Hague, selling the South American colony of Nieuw-Holland to Portugal

1662.summary: Chinese general Koxinga captures the Dutch East India Company's settlement at Fort Zeelandia after a nine-month siege, ending the company's rule on the island and establishing the Kingdom of Tungning.

1662.event: First public bus system in Paris
1662.summary: A short-lived experiment of the first public bus system begins in Paris with horse-drawn wagons holding eight passengers, introducing a new form of public transportation.
The Royal Society, founded by King Charles II of England and Scotland, receives an official charter, marking a significant advance in scientific and intellectual pursuits.

1662.event: Act of Uniformity goes into effect
1662.summary: The Act of Uniformity makes mandatory in the Church of England the forms of worship prescribed in the new edition of the Book of Common Prayer, leading to the resignation of thousands of clergy.
Princess Catherine of Braganza marries Charles II of England, with Portugal ceding Bombay and Tangier as part of her dowry, influencing trade routes and colonial power dynamics.
Molière's play, The School for Wives, is given its première in Paris, contributing to the landscape of European theatre and influencing musical composition for performances.
The hearth tax is introduced in England and Wales, becoming a significant form of taxation and affecting daily life for citizens.
Three former members of the English Parliament, who signed the death warrant for Charles I, are hanged and drawn, marking a significant moment in the political landscape of England.
The Sangley Massacre is ordered by the Spanish Governor-General of the Philippines, representing a dark chapter in colonial history and ethnic tensions.

1662.event: First recorded Punch and Judy show
1662.summary: Samuel Pepys witnesses a Punch and Judy show in London, marking a notable cultural moment in entertainment history.

1663.event: Royal Charter for the Royal African Company
1663.summary: The Royal African Company is granted a Royal Charter by Charles II of England
The Treaty of Ghilajharighat is signed in India, ending Mughal occupation of Ahom capital
An earthquake estimated at least 7.3 magnitude strikes Canada's Quebec Province
The King's Theatre, now known as Drury Lane, opens in London
The Ottoman Empire declares war against Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor, beginning the Austro-Turkish War
The English Parliament passes the second Navigation Act, requiring goods bound for American colonies to be sent in English ships
The Farnley Wood Plot, a conspiracy to overthrow the monarchy, fails
Petar Zrinski defeats a much larger force of Ottoman soldiers in the Battle at Jurjeve Stijene
The Kingdom of Sweden adopts a law creating the current national flag

1663.event: Establishment of Prix de Rome scholarship
1663.summary: The Prix de Rome scholarship is established in France for students of the arts

1664.summary: Chhatrapati Shivaji defeats the Mughal Army and sacks Surat
France and the Papal States sign a treaty to end the Corsican Guard Affair
A peace treaty ends the War of the Banished between the Duchy of Savoy and the Waldensians

1664.event: Royal charter for New York territory
1664.summary: King Charles II grants a land patent to his brother James in North America
The original version of Tartuffe by Molière is performed at the Palace of Versailles
Gazzetta di Mantova publishes its first issue in Mantua
The Ottoman Empire is defeated by a Habsburg army, leading to peace

1664.event: Foundation of French East India Company
1664.summary: The French East India Company is established
Peter Stuyvesant surrenders New Amsterdam to England, renaming it New York
The Duke of York and Albany's maritime regiment of foot is formed in London

1665.summary: The Journal des sçavans begins publication of the first scientific journal in France.
Molière's comedy Dom Juan ou le Festin de pierre premieres in Paris.
Dr. Richard Lower performs the first blood transfusion between animals in England.
The Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London begins publication, becoming the first scientific journal in English.
The burial of Margaret Porteous is recorded as the first known death during the Great Plague of London.
The Great Plague forces the closure of the University of Cambridge, leading Isaac Newton to make groundbreaking discoveries.
Molière's L'Amour médecin is first presented at the Palace of Versailles, featuring music by Jean-Baptiste Lully.
Robert Hooke's Micrographia is published in London, introducing the term 'cell' to plant tissue.
Kiel University is founded in the Duchy of Holstein, marking a significant advancement in education.
The Royal Netherlands Marine Corps is founded by Michiel de Ruyter, enhancing naval capabilities.

1666.summary: The Chair of Saint Peter designed by Bernini is set above the altar in St. Peter's Basilica, marking a significant moment in religious art and architecture.
Molière's comedy of manners The Misanthrope is premièred at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris.
The Great Fire of London begins, destroying over 13,000 buildings and leading to significant changes in property surveying and urban planning.
The Cestui Que Vie Act is passed by the Parliament of England, establishing legal frameworks for the property of missing persons.

1666.event: Establishment of the French Academy of Sciences
1666.summary: The French Academy of Sciences, founded by Louis XIV, holds its first meeting, influencing scientific research and advancements.
Robert Hubert is executed after falsely confessing to starting the Great Fire of London, reflecting the chaos of the time.
Isaac Newton uses a prism to split sunlight into colors, contributing to the understanding of light and developing differential calculus.
Abbas II, the Shah of Iran, dies without a designated successor, leading to a power transition in the Safavid dynasty.
The Battle of Rullion Green occurs in Scotland, reflecting political tensions and conflicts in the region.
The first printed Bible translation into Armenian is published in Amsterdam, marking a significant literary and cultural achievement.

1667.summary: The 2,000 seat Opernhaus am Taschenberg opens with its first production, Pietro Ziani's opera Il teseo.

1667.event: John Milton seals contract for Paradise Lost
1667.summary: The blind, impoverished John Milton seals a contract for publication of Paradise Lost with London printer Samuel Simmons.
The first human blood transfusion is administered by Dr. Jean-Baptiste Denys, transfusing the blood of a sheep to a 15-year-old boy.
The War of Devolution begins between France and Spain after King Philip IV of Spain reneges on payment of a large dowry.
The Treaty of Breda ends the Second Anglo-Dutch War, with territorial adjustments for England, the Dutch Republic, and France.
Xuanye, the Kangxi Emperor, participates in an ascension ceremony to take full power to rule China.
The Dreadful Hurricane of 1667 ravages southeast Virginia, causing extensive damage to plantations.
The city of Paris enacts its first building code limiting the height of new construction to prevent blocking light.
Giulio Rospigliosi is elected the new Pope, taking the regnal name Pope Clement IX.
A Dutch fleet raids the Medway in England, capturing the royal flagship The Royal Charles.

1668.summary: The Triple Alliance of 1668 is formed between England, Sweden and the United Provinces of the Netherlands
A peace treaty is established between Afonso VI of Portugal and Carlos II of Spain, recognizing Portuguese legitimacy
The Republic of Venice navy defeats an Ottoman naval force in the Cretan War
The English Parliament and bishops seek to suppress Thomas Hobbes' treatise Leviathan

1668.event: Charles II Signs Agreement with East India Company
1668.summary: King Charles II signs an agreement to lease the Indian city of Bombay to the East India Company
The Treaty of Breda, ending the Second Anglo-Dutch War, goes into effect
The first Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle ends the War of Devolution
John Dryden's play An Evening's Love premieres at the Theatre Royal in London
Molière's comedy The Miser is first performed in Paris
Isaac Newton builds the first reflecting telescope

1669.event: First performance of Ballet de Flore
1669.summary: The first performance of the Ballet de Flore, a joint collaboration of Jean-Baptiste Lully and Isaac de Benserade, is premiered at the Palais du Louvre, financed by King Louis XIV who even performs as a dancer.

1669.event: Description of reflecting telescope by Isaac Newton
1669.summary: Isaac Newton writes his first description of his new invention, the reflecting telescope, which would later influence the field of astronomy.
Mount Etna erupts, causing significant destruction to the Sicilian town of Nicolosi.
Moliere's comedy ballet Monsieur de Pourceaugnac, with music by Jean-Baptiste Lully, is performed for the first time at the Château of Chambord.
Dutch painter Rembrandt van Rijn dies at the age of 63, leaving a significant legacy in the art world.

1669.event: Foundation of the University of Innsbruck
1669.summary: The University of Innsbruck is chartered in Austria by Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor, marking an important advancement in education.
Jean Racine's five-act tragic play Britannicus has its first performance at the Hôtel de Bourgogne in Paris.

1669.event: Formation of the Hudson's Bay Company
1669.summary: The English ship Nonsuch returns to London with the first products from trade around Canada's Hudson Bay, prompting interest in the Hudson's Bay Company.
The Hanseatic League holds its last official meeting in Lübeck after 400 years of operation as an economic alliance.

1669.event: Papal conclave to select new pope
1669.summary: A papal conclave that will last four months begins in Rome to select a successor to Pope Clement IX, who died recently.

1670.summary: Raphael Levy, a Jewish resident of Metz, is burned at the stake after being accused of ritual murder, leading to an attempt to expel Jewish families from Metz.
Emperor Aurangzeb orders the destruction of all Hindu temples and schools in the Mughal Empire, affecting the cultural landscape of India.
The Maratha Empire captures the Kondhana Fortress from the Mughal Empire, a significant military victory.
Christian V becomes the king of Denmark-Norway, highlighting changes in European leadership.
Cardinal Emilio Albieri is elected as Pope Clement X, becoming the oldest pope in history.
Charles II of England and Louis XIV of France sign a treaty that will have long-lasting effects on England's religious and political landscape.
The Parliament of France enacts a uniform criminal code, marking a significant advance in legal structure.

1670.event: First performance of Le Bourgeois gentilhomme
1670.summary: Molière's comedy and ballet is performed before King Louis XIV, affecting the cultural landscape of France.
The Army of Portugal attempts to annex the independent BaKongo kingdom, encountering fierce resistance.
Louis XIV of France inaugurates construction of a veterans' hospital, an important social and architectural development.

1671.summary: The first attempt at a uniform code of criminal procedure in France goes into effect.
The Maratha Army defeats a larger Mughal force in India, signaling a shift in power.
The ballet with music by Jean-Baptiste Lully premieres before the royal court of King Louis XIV.
Henry Morgan's expedition leads to the destruction of the city of Panamá, a significant event in colonial history.
Considered the first French opera, Pomone is performed successfully, impacting future operatic works.

1671.event: Founding of the Danish West India Company
1671.summary: This company is established and becomes involved in the human trafficking of African slaves.
The coronation ceremony of Christian V of Denmark-Norway takes place, a significant political event.
A tornado kills more than 600 people in Cadiz, marking a tragic natural disaster.
Giovanni Domenico Cassini discovers Iapetus, expanding knowledge of Saturn's moons.
Established by Louis XIV in Paris, this is the world's first school of architecture.

1672.event: Death of Cornelis and Johan de Witt
1672.summary: Cornelis and Johan de Witt are killed by a mob in The Hague

1672.event: Isaac Newton elected to Royal Society
1672.summary: The Royal Society of London elects Isaac Newton as a member and demonstrates his reflecting telescope to King Charles II
The Theatre Royal in London burns down, leading to the construction of a new venue
Isaac Newton sends a paper regarding his experiments on the refraction of light and identifies primary colors
The Kingdom of England declares war on the Dutch Republic

1672.event: France declares war on the Dutch Republic

1672.summary: Münster and Cologne begin their invasion of the Dutch Republic, marking the year as the disaster year
An indecisive sea battle occurs between the Dutch Republic and the joined forces of England and France
French astronomer Giovanni Domenico Cassini discovers the satellite Rhea of Saturn
Troops of the Dutch Republic reclaim Coevorden, boosting morale in the disaster year

1673.summary: Molière's comédie-ballet The Imaginary Invalid premieres in Paris, and he collapses on stage during the performance.
The first opera written by Jean-Baptiste Lully, Cadmus et Hermione, premières at the Paris Opera in France.
Dutch Republic fleet defeats the allied Anglo-French fleet in the First Battle of Schooneveld off the Netherlands coast.
The Dutch fleet again defeats the joint Anglo-French fleet in the Second Battle of Schooneveld.
Edmund Halley enters The Queen's College, Oxford, as an undergraduate.
Polish and Lithuanian military units defeat the Turkish army in the Battle of Khotyn, during which rockets are successfully used.
Dutch forces under Admiral Cornelis Evertsen recapture New York from the English, naming it New Orange.
The Dutch fleet defeats the English and French fleet at the Battle of Texel, an important naval engagement.
King Louis XIV of France issues a decree recognizing the legitimacy of his three children by his mistress, granting them royal titles.

1673.event: Revolt of the Three Feudatories begins
1673.summary: General Wu Sangui begins a rebellion against the Ming dynasty in China, starting the Revolt of the Three Feudatories.

1674.summary: The tragic opera Alceste, by Jean-Baptiste Lully, is performed for the first time, presented by the Paris Opera company at the Theatre du Palais-Royal.
England and the Netherlands sign the Treaty of Westminster, ending the Third Anglo-Dutch War.
The English Royal Navy captures the Dutch East India Company ship Wapen van Rotterdam in Shetland during the Third Anglo-Dutch War.
Chamaguriya Khamjang Konwar is installed as the figurehead King of Ahom but is poisoned by the Chief Minister.
Shivaji Maharaj is crowned as Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj of the Maratha Empire at Raigad Fort.
A large fleet from the Dutch Republic arrives at Martinique in an unsuccessful invasion attempt against French colonists.
The Battle of Entzheim takes place, with French defenders winning a strategic victory despite an inconclusive outcome.
The Torsåker witch trials begin in Sweden, leading to mass beheadings of the accused.
The town of Grave surrenders to a Dutch army after a difficult siege.
The Dutch Republic cedes its colony of New Netherland to England, which is renamed New York.

1675.summary: The French defeat Austria and Brandenburg.

1675.event: Premiere of La divisione del mondo
1675.summary: The Italian opera La divisione del mondo, by Giovanni Legrenzi, is performed for the first time in Venice.
John Flamsteed is appointed as England's first Astronomer Royal by King Charles II.

1675.event: Foundation of the Royal Greenwich Observatory
1675.summary: King Charles II places the foundation stone of the Royal Greenwich Observatory near London.
Christiaan Huygens files drawings of his invention of the balance spring, improving clock accuracy.
Guru Teg Bahadur is executed by Mughal rulers for upholding Hindu rights.

1675.event: First use of long s symbol
1675.summary: Gottfried Leibniz makes the first use of the long s as a symbol of the integral in calculus.

1675.event: Beginning of the 1675–1676 Malta plague epidemic
1675.summary: The Malta plague epidemic begins, affecting local populations significantly.
John Sassamon's alleged murderers are executed in Plymouth, escalating tensions.
King Philip's War breaks out as the Wampanoags attack Swansea, marking a significant conflict.

1676.event: Feodor III becomes Tsar of Russia
1676.summary: Feodor III assumes the throne, marking a significant political change in Russia.

1676.event: Universidad de San Carlos de Guatemala founded
1676.summary: The oldest educational institution in Central America is established, influencing education access.
Colonist Mary Rowlandson is freed from captivity, highlighting the human cost of conflicts.
A brutal assault results in the death of hundreds, raising awareness of the ongoing conflict.
A decisive naval battle affects regional power dynamics in Northern Europe.
Nathaniel Bacon leads a rebellion against colonial authority, shaking the foundations of governance in Virginia.
The death of Metacomet ends a significant conflict in New England, affecting the lives of many.
This conflict begins, impacting European politics and security.
An important treaty alters the balance of power between the Ottoman Empire and the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.

1676.event: Ole Rømer measures speed of light
1676.summary: The first quantitative measurement of the speed of light is made, a major scientific breakthrough.

1677.summary: Jean Racine's tragedy Phèdre is first performed in Paris.
The first medical publication in America, a pamphlet on smallpox, is produced in Boston.

1677.event: Arrest of Lords in Cavalier Parliament
1677.summary: Four members of the English House of Lords embarrass King Charles II by refusing to recognize the legitimacy of the Parliament session and are subsequently arrested.
During the Franco-Dutch War, the Siege of Valenciennes begins and ends with the surrender to the French Army.
A French force under Philippe I defeats a combined Dutch-Spanish force in French Flanders during the Franco-Dutch War.
Henry Purcell is appointed a musician to the court of Charles II of England.
Swedish troops successfully repel a 12,000-man invasion force from Denmark during the Scanian War.
After almost five months, Sweden surrenders the city of Stettin to Prussia.
Father Louis Hennepin becomes the earliest known European to discover Niagara Falls and reports its existence.

1677.event: End of Dutch military power in the Antilles
1677.summary: The French Navy ends Dutch military power in the Antilles by capturing a fort in Tobago during the Franco-Dutch War.

1678.summary: England and the Dutch Republic sign a mutual defense treaty in order to fight against France.
The first fire engine company in North America goes into service in Boston.
The first part of John Bunyan's Christian allegory The Pilgrim's Progress is published in London.
Rebel general Wu Sangui takes the imperial crown in southern China, declaring himself monarch.
The Spanish Netherlands city of Ypres falls after a seven-day siege by the French Army.
Polish astronomer Johannes Hevelius discovers the nova V529 Orionis.
Elena Lucrezia Cornaro Piscopia becomes the first woman to be awarded a university degree.
The Treaties of Nijmegen end the Franco-Dutch War, leading to significant territorial changes.
England's House of Commons votes to begin impeachment proceedings against five Roman Catholic members accused in the Popish Plot.
The Test Act mandates that members of both Houses must swear an anti-Catholic oath before taking office.

1679.summary: The Parliament of England passes the Habeas Corpus Act for the better securing the liberty of the subject.

1679.event: First European Expedition to Upper Mississippi River
1679.summary: French explorers set off on the first European expedition to explore the upper Mississippi River.
The Treaty of Celle is signed, confirming Sweden's sovereignty over Bremen-Verden.
Royal forces defeat Scottish Covenanters at Battle of Bothwell Bridge.
An 8.0 Mw magnitude earthquake devastates Beijing and Hebei.
A landslide in Piedmont causes the village of Bosia to sink, killing 200 inhabitants.
Catherine Deshayes Monvoisin, a suspected poisoner, is arrested in Paris.
King Charles II dissolves the Cavalier Parliament after nearly 18 years.
Aurangazeb decrees the imposition of jizya tax on non-Muslims in the Mughal Empire.
French explorer Daniel Greysolon explores the Saint Louis River, leading to the future city of Duluth.

1680.summary: Catherine Deshayes Monvoisin, a fortune teller who organized a ring of killers in the Affair of the Poisons, is burned at the stake after being convicted of witchcraft.
Comédie-Française is founded by decree of Louis XIV of France as La maison de Molière in Paris.
The first documented tornado in America kills a servant at Cambridge, Massachusetts.
The Great Comet of 1680 is first sighted by Gottfried Kirch, the first comet discovered by telescope.

1680.event: Founding of the Davenant Foundation School
1680.summary: Rev. Ralph Davenant's will provides for the foundation of the Davenant Foundation School for poor boys in Whitechapel, in the East End of London.

1680.event: Establishment of the London Penny Post
1680.summary: The London Penny Post delivery service begins operations, delivering letters across London for one penny.
Sambhaji Bhosle captures Raigad, becomes the new Emperor of the Maratha Empire, and deposes his brother Rajaram I.

1680.event: First French Huguenots in the New World
1680.summary: The first French Huguenots in the New World arrive at Charleston, South Carolina, sent by King Charles II of England.
A massive 9.0 magnitude earthquake destroys part of Málaga and other cities in the province of the same name.
The Riksdag in Sweden enacts the Great Reduction, returning fiefs to the Crown and establishing an absolute monarchy under King Charles XI.

1681.summary: Prince Muhammad Akbar declares himself the new Mughal Emperor in India, initiating a civil war against his father.
A treaty is signed between the Ottoman vassal Crimean Khanate and the Russian Empire.
King Charles II dissolves the Exclusion Bill Parliament and summons the Oxford Parliament, which meets but is dissolved shortly after.
The Canal du Midi in France is officially opened, improving waterway transportation.
Oliver Plunkett, the last Catholic martyr in England, is executed in London.
France annexes the city of Strasbourg, expanding its territory.
Sir John Child becomes the new Governor of Bombay province, expanding British control in India.
Don Melchor de Navarra arrives in Lima to become the new Viceroy of Peru after a long voyage.
The species Dodo becomes extinct, marking a significant loss in biodiversity.
King Charles II signs a warrant for the construction of the Royal Hospital Chelsea for wounded soldiers.

1682.summary: The Republic of Genoa lifts a ban on unauthorized printing of newspapers and newssheets after three months.
The Opéra du Quai au Foin, the first public theater in Brussels, is opened.
Work begins on the construction of the Royal Hospital Chelsea for old soldiers in London.
The Moscow Uprising of 1682 occurs as a mob invades the Kremlin, leading to the crowning of Ivan V and Peter I as co-rulers of Russia.

1682.event: Crowning of Ivan V and Peter I
1682.summary: Ivan V and Peter I are crowned as joint Tsars of Russia, with their sister Sophia exercising actual power for the next seven years.
The Ottoman Empire declares war on the Holy Roman Empire, planning to attack Vienna.
Comet Halley is observed from various locations on Earth, marking a significant astronomical event.
The city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, is founded by William Penn.
Nearly 1,000 houses are destroyed in a fire in Wapping, London.
Vesuvius begins a period of volcanic activity lasting for 10 days.

1683.summary: The tragic opera Phaëton, written by Jean-Baptiste Lully and Philippe Quinault, is premiered at the Palace of Versailles.
The opera Giustino by Giovanni Legrenzi and about the life of the Byzantine Emperor Justin, premieres in Venice.
A 173,000-man Ottoman force arrives at Vienna, and starts to besiege the city.

The Ottoman siege of the city is broken with the arrival of a force of 70,000 Poles, Austrians and Germans under Polish–Lithuanian king Jan III Sobieski, marking a turning point for the Ottoman Empire.
Kara Mustafa Pasha, Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire, is executed after being blamed for the loss at the Battle of Vienna.
Germantown, Philadelphia is founded as the first permanent German settlement in North America.
Algernon Sidney, opponent of King Charles II, is beheaded after being found guilty of treason.

1683.event: Subdividing the Province of New York
1683.summary: The Province of New York is subdivided into 12 counties, marking significant governance changes.
Turhan, the Valide sultan of the Ottoman Empire, dies, ending an important era in Ottoman history.
The Ashmolean Museum opens in Oxford as the world's first university museum, influencing education and culture.

1684.event: Foundation of the University of Tokyo
1684.summary: The earliest form of what is now the University of Tokyo is established.
The Great Frost in Britain, during which the Thames was frozen, ends, allowing normalcy to return.
The Republic of Venice captures the Ottoman island fortress of Santa Maura during the Morean War.

1684.event: Issuance of edicts by Shōgun Tokugawa Tsunayoshi
1684.summary: The assassination of the Chief Minister leads to impractical edicts by the shōgun, causing hardships.
The French Navy bombards Genoa, using new explosive technology, significantly damaging the city.
Edmond Halley reads Isaac Newton's paper on Kepler's laws at the Royal Society.
Pope Innocent XI forms a Holy League with several powers to end Ottoman rule in Europe.
A treaty is signed allowing German colonists to build a fort on the Gold Coast.

1684.event: Creation of Maison royale de Saint-Louis
1684.summary: Foundation of a boarding school for girls by Louis XIV at Saint-Cyr.
The war ends with a treaty that respects Ladakh's sovereignty.

1685.summary: Catholic James Stuart, Duke of York, becomes King James II of England and Ireland, and King James VII of Scotland, in succession to his brother Charles II.
Louis XIV of France passes the Code Noir, allowing the full use of slaves in the French colonies.
The coronation of King James II of England and his Queen Consort, Mary of Modena, takes place at Westminster Abbey.
James Scott, 1st Duke of Monmouth, lands at Lyme Regis with an invasion force to challenge his uncle, James II, for the Crown of England.
In the Battle of Sedgemoor, the last pitched battle fought on English soil, the armies of King James II defeat rebel forces led by James Scott, who is captured afterward.
The Bloody Assizes begin in Winchester as Lord Chief Justice George Jeffreys tries over 1000 of Monmouth's rebels, condemning many to death or transportation.
Louis XIV of France issues the Edict of Fontainebleau, revoking the Edict of Nantes and declaring Protestantism illegal.
In response to France's Edict of Fontainebleau, the Edict of Potsdam is issued, welcoming Protestant Huguenots to resettle in Brandenburg.
The 49-day Siege of Coron ends with the surrender and massacre of its garrison by the Venetians during the Morean War.
The first organised street lighting is introduced in London, improving safety and visibility for citizens.

1686.summary: King Louis XIV reports the success of the Edict of Fontainebleau, leading to a mass exodus of the Huguenot population from France.
The Swedish Council of State endorses reforms to the Swedish Church Law, confirming the rights of the Lutheran Church and mandating education for children.
The Treaty of Perpetual Peace is signed between the Tsardom of Russia and the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, impacting territorial control in Eastern Europe.
The Valdesi rebellion ends with thousands massacred or forcibly converted following a failed resistance against the Duke of Savoy's edicts.
The Grand Alliance is established in response to Louis XIV's claims on the Palatinate, altering military alliances across Europe.
Imperial forces liberate Buda from Ottoman Turkish rule, which leads to the eventual end of Ottoman control in Hungary.
The Siege of Pécs ends with Austrian troops capturing the Ottoman-held city, furthering Austrian control in Hungary.
Szeged is liberated from Turkish Ottoman rule as part of the Austro-Ottoman conflicts in Hungary.
The Treaty of Whitehall is signed, pledging peace between French and English colonies in America amidst their conflict in Europe.
The Dominion of New England is formed, reshaping governance in the northeastern colonies of America under Edmund Andros.

1687.summary: Victor Amadeus III permits the emigration of Protestants who were forced to convert to Catholicism, marking a significant event for religious freedom.
Richard Talbot is appointed last Lord Deputy of Ireland, an effort to include more Roman Catholics in administration during political turmoil.
In a sensational case, midwife Mary Hobry is convicted of murder after killing her abusive husband, raising discussions around domestic violence.
King James VII issues the Declaration of Indulgence, allowing more religious freedom, impacting Roman Catholics and nonconformists.
Isaac Newton's work is published, detailing universal gravitation and mechanics, significantly influencing science and music composition.
The Habsburg army defeats the Ottomans, allowing Austria to conquer significant territories, affecting European power dynamics.
The capture of Golconda marks a significant expansion of the Mughal Empire in India, altering regional power and trade.
Mortar shells fired in battle cause severe damage to the Parthenon in Athens, a blow to cultural heritage.

1687.event: Earthquake off the coast of Peru
1687.summary: An 8.7 magnitude earthquake results in a tsunami and significant devastation, affecting the colonial cities.
Suleiman II becomes the new Ottoman Emperor, leading to shifts in the empire's policies and influence in Europe.

1688.summary: Pirates Charles Swan and William Dampier become the first Englishmen to set foot on the continent of Australia
Ilona Zrínyi surrenders Palanok Castle in Hungary to General Antonio Caraffa
The French opera David et Jonathas by Marc-Antoine Charpentier is performed for the first time
The Germantown Quaker Protest Against Slavery is drafted by four Germantown Quakers
A 7.0 magnitude earthquake strikes southern Italy, killing at least 10,000 people in the Kingdom of Naples

1688.event: Birth of James Francis Edward Stuart
1688.summary: James Francis Edward Stuart, son of King James II of England, is born at St James's Palace in London
King Narai of Ayutthaya is arrested, leading to a coup d'état
The Nine Years' War begins in Europe after Louis XIV attacks Philippsburg in the Holy Roman Empire
William of Orange lands in Torbay, England, beginning the Glorious Revolution
The gates of Derry are shut in front of the Jacobite Earl of Antrim, initiating the siege during the Williamite War in Ireland

1689.summary: The Convention Parliament convenes to determine if King James II vacated the throne when he fled to France.
The first performance of the opera Henrico Leone composed by Agostino Steffani takes place in Hannover to inaugurate the new royal theatre.
William III and Mary II are proclaimed co-rulers of England, Scotland and Ireland.
The Siege of Derry begins as former King James II arrives at the gates of Derry during the Williamite War in Ireland.
The Act of Toleration is passed, protecting Protestants but excluding Roman Catholics.
Scottish supporters of William III are defeated by Jacobite supporters of James II in the First Jacobite rising.
A papal conclave in Rome elects Pietro Vito Ottoboni as the new Pope, taking the name Alexander VIII.

1689.event: Construction of the Great Siberian Road
1689.summary: Peter the Great decrees the construction of the Great Siberian Road to facilitate trade with China.

1689.event: Bill of Rights receives royal assent
1689.summary: The Bill of Rights establishes constitutional monarchy in England, restricting Roman Catholics from the throne.

1689.event: First documented performance of Dido and Aeneas
1689.summary: The first documented performance of the opera Dido and Aeneas by Henry Purcell takes place at a girls' school in London.

1690.summary: The Anglo-Dutch navy is defeated by the French, raising fears of a Jacobite invasion of England.
The opera Orphée by Louis Lully receives its first performance at the Académie Royale de Musique.

1690.event: First Performance of Énée et Lavinie
1690.summary: The opera Énée et Lavinie by Pascal Collasse receives its first performance at the Académie Royale de Musique.
The planet Uranus is first sighted and recorded by John Flamsteed, mistakenly cataloged as a star.
Christiaan Huygens publishes his book Treatise on Light, a pioneering work in physics.
The construction of Fort Longueuil is completed in Quebec, resembling European castles.
The fort and trading settlement of Sutanuti is founded by the English East India Company.

1690.event: General Court of Massachusetts Issues Paper Money
1690.summary: The first authorized paper money issued by any government in the Western World is created.
King William III of England defeats deposed James II, who returns to exile in France.
An earthquake with strength 5.2 occurs in Caernarfon, Wales, felt as far away as London.

1691.summary: The Massachusetts Bay Colony issues the first paper money in North America, marking a significant financial development.
The first performance of the semi-opera King Arthur with music by Henry Purcell takes place.
The Spanish Inquisition condemns and forcibly baptizes 219 Xuetas in Majorca during a time of intense religious conflict.
Protestant Williamite forces decisively defeat Jacobites in the Battle of Aughrim during the Williamite War in Ireland.
The Treaty of Limerick is signed, ending the Williamite War and guaranteeing civil rights to Roman Catholics in Ireland.

1691.event: Formation of the New York Supreme Court
1691.summary: The Province of New York establishes the New York Supreme Court, marking an important development in American legal history.
The Battle of Slankamen sees significant casualties for the Ottoman Empire, impacting European power dynamics.
Pope Innocent XII becomes the 242nd pope, succeeding Pope Alexander VIII.
Michel Rolle invents Rolle's theorem, contributing significantly to the field of mathematics.
A fire at the Palace of Whitehall in London destroys its Stone Gallery, impacting royal heritage.

1692.summary: At least 75 residents of what is now York, Maine are killed in the Candlemas Massacre by French soldiers and indigenous allies during King William's War
The forces of Robert Campbell slaughter around 40 members of the Clan MacDonald of Glencoe for delaying to sign an oath of allegiance to King William III
The Salem witch trials begin with the charging of 3 women with witchcraft, sparking a series of trials and executions
The Kangxi Emperor issues an edict recognizing the Roman Catholic Church and legalizing missions in China
The first performance of the semi-opera The Fairy-Queen by Henry Purcell takes place, influenced by Shakespeare's work
The Anglo-Dutch fleet defeats the French and foils plans to invade England during the Nine Years' War
An earthquake and tsunami destroy Port Royal, killing an estimated 2,000 and impacting trade in the region
The siege of Namur concludes as Dutch General capitulates to King Louis XIV, furthering French power

1692.event: Last hangings of Salem witch trials
1692.summary: The last of those convicted of witchcraft in the Salem witch trials are hanged, ending a tragic chapter of hysteria
Nahum Tate is named as the new Poet Laureate of the United Kingdom, influencing the literary scene for the next 22 years

1693.summary: The Mount Etna volcano erupts in Italy, causing a devastating earthquake that kills 60,000 people in Sicily and Malta.
The publication of the first women's magazine, titled The Ladies' Mercury, takes place in London.
Anne Palles becomes the last accused witch to be executed for witchcraft in Denmark.

1693.event: Foundation of Order of Saint Louis
1693.summary: The Order of Saint Louis, the first medal awarded in France to non-noble military personnel, is created by King Louis XIV.
The first performance of the opera Didon by French composer Henri Desmarets takes place at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris.
William III of England is defeated by the French at the Battle of Landen during the Nine Years' War.
France begins the siege of the Spanish Netherlands fort of Charleroi.
The Great Storm changes the course of rivers and alters the coastline from Virginia to Long Island in America.
Dimitrie Cantemir presents his Kitâbu 'İlmi'l-Mûsiki alâ Vechi'l-Hurûfât to Sultan Ahmed II, which deals with Ottoman music structure.
The Academia Operosorum Labacensium is established in Ljubljana, Slovenia.

1694.summary: Francesco Morosini, the Doge of Venice since 1688, dies after ruling the Republic for more than five years.

1694.event: First performance of Pirro e Demetrio
1694.summary: Pirro e Demetrio, an opera by Alessandro Scarlatti, is given its first performance at the Teatro San Bartolomeo in Naples.
The largest volcanic eruption of Mount Vesuvius since 1631 takes place, with lava flows and ash affecting nearby regions.

1694.event: Foundation of the Bank of England
1694.summary: The Bank of England is founded through Royal charter by Parliament to raise capital for the war effort against France.

1694.event: Presentation of the Dictionnaire de l'Académie française
1694.summary: The first official dictionary of the French language is presented to King Louis XIV by the Académie française.
Sultan Husayn of the Safavid dynasty is coronated as the Shah of Persia in Isfahan.
The Army of Algeria captures Tunis after a three-month siege, ending the Tunisian–Algerian War.
Thomas Tenison is appointed Archbishop of Canterbury.
The Parliament of England passes the Triennial Act, requiring general elections every three years.

1694.event: Formation of Casa da Moeda do Brasil
1694.summary: The Casa da Moeda do Brasil is formed by Peter II of Portugal.

1695.summary: The United Kingdom's last joint monarchy ends with the death of Queen Mary II, impacting the political landscape and royal succession.
The destruction of Milan's Court Theater by fire limits cultural venues available for music composers and performances.
Queen Mary's funeral features music composed by Henry Purcell, highlighting the significance of music in royal events.
The House of Commons of England decides not to renew the Licensing Order, encouraging a more open society and allowing for the expansion of print, benefiting music composers.
A devastating earthquake in Shanxi Province kills over 50,000 people, highlighting the impact of natural disasters on societies.
The Siege of Namur begins amidst the Nine Years' War, influencing military and political dynamics in Europe.
France surrenders Namur to the Grand Alliance, altering the balance of power in the region during the Nine Years' War.
The capture of HMS Berkeley Castle by the French Navy marks a significant naval engagement during ongoing conflicts.
King William III opens a new Parliament amidst a backdrop of political scandal, impacting governance in England.
A total eclipse of the sun is visible across the Middle East and western Asia, inspiring awe and potentially affecting cultural expressions.

1696.summary: The Recoinage Act is passed by the Parliament of England to pull counterfeit silver coins out of circulation.

1696.event: Peter the Great becomes sole Tsar
1696.summary: Peter the Great becomes the sole Tsar of Russia following the death of his half-brother Ivan V.
The second Pueblo Revolt occurs in Santa Fe de Nuevo México, resulting in violence against Spanish settlers.
The Dutch bombard Givet during the ongoing Nine Years' War.

1696.event: Foundation of the Imperial Russian Navy
1696.summary: The Imperial Russian Navy is founded on the recommendation of Tsar Peter the Great.
King Louis XIV of France and Victor Amadeus sign the Treaty of Turin, ending Savoy's participation in the Nine Years' War.
The Parliament of Scotland passes the Education Act 1696 to establish locally funded schools in parishes.
John Vanbrugh's play The Relapse is first performed in London, contributing to theatrical culture.

1696.event: House of Lords approves attainder for Sir John Fenwick
1696.summary: The House of Lords approves the bill for the conviction of Sir John Fenwick for high treason.

1696.event: Bank of Scotland issues paper currency
1696.summary: The Bank of Scotland becomes the first bank in Europe to successfully issue paper currency.

1697.summary: Thomas Aikenhead is hanged outside Edinburgh, becoming the last person in Great Britain to be executed for blasphemy.
French writer Charles Perrault releases the book Histoires ou contes du temps passé in Paris, a collection of popular fairy tales.
The Siege of Barcelona ends in Spain after 52 days as Louis Joseph, Duke of Vendôme obtains the surrender of the city.

1697.event: First Performance of Vénus et Adonis
1697.summary: The opera Vénus et Adonis, composed by Henri Desmarets, receives its first performance at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris.
The Treaty of Ryswick is signed by France and the Grand Alliance to end the Nine Years' War and King William's War.
The first opéra-ballet, L'Europe galante, combining elements of both mediums, is performed at the Salle du Palais-Royal in Paris.
The Nine Years' War comes to an end with the signing of the last pacts of the Peace of Ryswick in the city of Rijswijk.
Prince Eugene of Savoy purchases land in Vienna for the construction of the Belvedere Palace.

1697.event: Final Service at St Paul's Cathedral
1697.summary: The first service is held in St Paul's Cathedral since rebuilding work after the Great Fire of London began.

1697.event: Coronation of King Charles XII of Sweden
1697.summary: The coronation ceremony takes place for King Charles XII of Sweden.

1698.summary: A significant treaty is signed between the Dutch Republic, England, and France, shaping European diplomatic relations.

1698.event: Foundation of the Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge
1698.summary: An Anglican mission organization is established in London to promote Christian knowledge.
English engineer Thomas Savery patents a steam pump, marking a key advancement in engineering and technology.
The execution of 57 leaders involved in the Streltsy uprising begins, reflecting the political climate in Russia.
The British Royal Navy launches the HMS Hastings, a significant naval vessel.
The Palace of Whitehall in London is destroyed by fire, impacting the English government.

1698.event: A Short View of the Immorality and Profaneness of the English Stage
1698.summary: Bishop Jeremy Collier publishes a pamphlet criticizing the morals of contemporary English playwrights.
Scottish settlers leave for Panama as part of the Darien scheme, an attempt to establish a colony.
A powerful earthquake devastates the region around Ambato, resulting in significant casualties and destruction.
King William III issues a proclamation granting pardon to certain pirates in the East Indies, changing the dynamics of piracy.

1699.summary: The Republic of Venice, Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth and Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Karlowitz with the Ottoman Empire, marking an end to the major phase of the Ottoman–Habsburg wars.

1699.event: First performance of Amadis de Grèce
1699.summary: The first performance of Amadis de Grèce, an opera by French composer André Cardinal Destouches, takes place at the Académie Royale de Musique, Paris.
England, France and the Dutch Republic agree on the terms of the Treaty of London for Spain.
Thomas Savery demonstrates his first steam pump to the Royal Society of London.
A total solar eclipse is visible in the northern hemisphere across Europe, the Middle East and north India.
The Liverpool Merchant, the first slave ship to depart from the Port of Liverpool, sets sail for West Africa to embark hundreds of African slaves.
The opera Marthésie, première reine des Amazones, composed by André Cardinal Destouches, is performed for the first time at Fontainebleau near Paris.
An edict by King Louis XIV establishes an office of police magistrate in almost every village in France.

1699.event: Change of Russian New Year date
1699.summary: Peter the Great orders the Russian New Year changed from September 1 to January 1.
A violent earthquake damages the city of Batavia on the Indonesian island of Java, killing at least 28 people.

1700.summary: Protestant nations in Western Europe adopt the Gregorian calendar, aligning their civil timekeeping with Catholic nations.
A major earthquake strikes the Pacific Northwest causing a tsunami that affects Japan, highlighting the geographical challenges of natural disasters.
The Great Northern War starts as Denmark and Poland invade Swedish territory, leading to significant military conflict in the region.

1700.event: Performance of The Way of the World
1700.summary: William Congreve's acclaimed comedy is first performed in London, marking a significant moment in English theatre.

1700.event: Founding of the Prussian Academy of Sciences
1700.summary: The Prussian Academy of Sciences is established with Gottfried Leibniz as president, promoting advancements in various scientific fields.
Edmond Halley returns and publishes findings on terrestrial magnetism after a long voyage, contributing to the understanding of earth sciences.

1700.event: Death of Charles II of Spain
1700.summary: Charles II dies, leading to a war of succession and impacting the balance of power in Europe.
The formal coronation of Pope Clement XI takes place, marking a significant transition in the Catholic Church leadership.
Swedish forces achieve a decisive victory against Russia at the Battle of Narva, influencing the course of the Great Northern War.

1700.event: First documentary evidence of the piano
1700.summary: An inventory for the House of Medici provides the first documentation of a piano, indicating advancements in musical instruments.

1701.summary: Parts of the Netherlands adopt the Gregorian calendar

1701.event: Creation of the Kingdom of Prussia
1701.summary: Elector Frederick III is proclaimed King Frederick I, making Brandenburg-Prussia the Kingdom of Prussia

1701.event: Assembly of the 5th Parliament of King William III
1701.summary: The 5th Parliament is assembled, with Robert Walpole entering as a significant political figure
The Act is passed to ensure a Protestant succession in the British monarchy
The first skirmish of the War of the Spanish Succession takes place in Italy
The treaty is signed, ending war between the Iroquois Confederacy and New France
The Collegiate School of Connecticut is chartered, later becoming Yale University
English agriculturalist Jethro Tull invents a drill for planting seeds in rows
The Philharmonic Society is established in Ljubljana, Slovenia

1701.event: Death of James II of England
1701.summary: Deposed King James II dies in exile, impacting Jacobite support for his son

1702.summary: A total solar eclipse is visible from the southern Pacific Ocean.
The Duc de Villeroy is taken as a prisoner of war by the Austrian Army during the Battle of Cremona.
King William III of England is fatally injured in a horse riding accident and dies 16 days later.
An earthquake in the middle of the Calore valley in Italy kills 400 people.
Princess Anne Stuart ascends the English, Scottish and Irish thrones following the death of King William III.
The first regular English-language national newspaper, The Daily Courant, begins publication covering foreign news.

1702.event: War of the Spanish Succession Declared
1702.summary: War is declared on France by the Grand Alliance including England, Dutch Republic, and Holy Roman Empire.

1702.event: First Performance of L'Offendere per amore
1702.summary: The premiere of the opera L'Offendere per amore overo la Telesilla by Johann Joseph Fux takes place in Vienna.
Charles XII of Sweden defeats the Polish-Lithuanian-Saxon army in the Great Northern War.
The first performance of the opera Tancrède by André Campra takes place at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris.

1703.summary: The Jamaican town of Port Royal, a center of trade, is destroyed by a fire, leading to significant economic loss.
A series of devastating earthquakes in Central Italy result in a high death toll and widespread destruction.
Forty-seven rōnin assassinate daimyō Kira Yoshinaka as an act of revenge.
The city of Saint Petersburg is founded, becoming a significant cultural center.
French forces capture the fortress of Kehl during the War of the Spanish Succession.
The English government enacts a law for the forcible enlistment of able-bodied unemployed men into the army and navy.
The French defeat a German relief army in the War of the Spanish Succession, securing control over Landau.
A devastating cyclone strikes the British Isles, causing widespread destruction and loss of life.
Isaac Newton is elected president of the Royal Society in London, a significant achievement for science.
Portugal and England sign the Methuen Treaty, favoring Portuguese wines in England.

1704.summary: A partial solar eclipse is visible in Antarctica.

1704.event: Establishment of the first school for African-Americans
1704.summary: Elias Neau establishes the first school open to African-Americans in New York City.

1704.event: Publication of the first regular newspaper in North America
1704.summary: The Boston News-Letter is published, marking a significant development in journalism.
Allied troops defeat the Franco-Bavarian army in a significant battle during the War of the Spanish Succession.
Gibraltar is captured from Spain by English and Dutch forces.
The newly built Kastelskirken is inaugurated in Copenhagen, marking a cultural milestone.

1704.event: War of the Spanish Succession - Twelfth Siege of Gibraltar
1704.summary: The siege by French and Spanish troops begins, showcasing the ongoing military conflicts of the time.
A total lunar eclipse occurs, capturing the attention of astronomers and the public alike.
The fall of a meteorite in Barcelona is interpreted as a divine sign, affecting public interest and beliefs.
The siege of the French-held German town of Landau begins, highlighting ongoing conflicts and military strategies.

1705.summary: George Frideric Handel's first opera Almira is premiered in Hamburg
George Frideric Handel's opera Nero premieres in Hamburg
