The Queen's Theatre opens in Westminster to serve as an opera house, premiering with Gli amori di ergasto
Queen Anne honors Isaac Newton with a Knight Bachelor
The Twelfth Siege of Gibraltar ends with a decisive naval battle, impacting European power dynamics
Anne, Queen of England dissolves the English House of Commons that had been elected in 1702
In the War of the Spanish Succession, an exhausted English force defeats French troops
Construction begins on Blenheim Palace in Oxfordshire
The Dublin Gazette of Ireland publishes its first edition
The Hungarian army achieves a victory in the Battle of Saint Gotthard

1706.summary: Swedish victory over Russian troops concludes the Battle of Grodno, impacting the balance of power in Northern Europe.
A French and Spanish army retakes control of Barcelona after a 14-day siege, altering the dynamics of the War of the Spanish Succession.
A total eclipse of the Sun is visible in most of Europe, inspiring awe and influencing cultural expressions.
Troops led by John Churchill defeat Franco-Bavarian forces in the Low Countries, marking a significant victory in the War of the Spanish Succession.
Flemish Jesuit missionary François Noël discusses Confucian rites with the Kangxi Emperor, showcasing cultural exchanges.
The Treaty of Union between Scotland and England paves the way for the formation of the Kingdom of Great Britain.
Spanish Bourbon armies retake Madrid from Portuguese and Habsburg forces, impacting the Spanish Civil War

1706.event: King Louis XIV's last visit to Paris
1706.summary: Louis XIV makes his final visit to Paris, updating on a significant veterans' hospital project he commissioned.
Elector Augustus II signs the Treaty of Altranstädt, renouncing claims to the Polish throne, ending conflict with Sweden.

1706.event: Election of new King of Portugal
1706.summary: João V becomes the new King of Portugal, starting a reign of 43 years that will influence Portuguese politics.

1707.summary: The Act of Union with Scotland is ratified by the Parliament of England, leading to the formal unification of Scotland and England as Great Britain.
In a decisive battle during the War of the Spanish Succession, the Bourbon army defeats the allied forces, significantly impacting the political landscape of Europe.
After a month-long siege, the city of Játiva falls to Castilian and French troops, leading to widespread destruction and deportation of residents.
Bahadur Shah I is crowned as the new Emperor of India in Delhi, marking a significant change in Indian leadership.

1707.event: Establishment of the Kingdom of Great Britain
1707.summary: The Kingdom of England and the Kingdom of Scotland unite to form the Kingdom of Great Britain, merging their parliaments.

1707.event: First meeting of the Parliament of Great Britain
1707.summary: The newly formed Parliament of Great Britain holds its first meeting in London, marking a new political era.
Emperor Aurangzeb dies in Ahmednagar, leading to significant shifts in the Mughal Empire's power dynamics.
The volcanic eruption in the Santorini caldera begins, impacting the region’s geography and climate.
Four British Royal Navy ships run aground due to navigation errors, resulting in the deaths of Admiral Sir Cloudesley Shovell and over 1,400 sailors.
The Hōei earthquake strikes Japan, causing massive destruction and loss of life, marking one of the most powerful earthquakes in Japan's history.

1708.summary: Charles XII of Sweden invades Russia, by crossing the frozen Vistula River with 40000 men
The first performance of George Frideric Handel's oratorio La resurrezione takes place in Rome
Allied forces under John Churchill defeat the French in the War of the Spanish Succession
British forces capture Lille after a two-month siege during the War of the Spanish Succession

1708.event: Topping out of St Paul's Cathedral
1708.summary: Topping out of new St Paul's Cathedral in London
The première of Electre by Prosper Jolyot de Crébillon takes place in Paris
Johann Sebastian Bach is appointed as chamber musician and organist, at the court in Weimar
Calcareous hard-paste porcelain is produced for the first time in Europe, at Dresden by Ehrenfried Walther von Tschirnhaus

1708.event: Formation of Honourable East India Company
1708.summary: The Company of Merchants of London Trading merges with the East Indies to form the Honourable East India Company
James Francis Edward Stuart unsuccessfully tries to land from a French fleet in Scotland

1709.summary: The coldest period in 500 years begins, causing crop failures and significant loss of life in France

1709.event: Production of Cast Iron using Coke
1709.summary: Abraham Darby I successfully produces cast iron using coke fuel

1709.event: First Production of Hard-Paste Porcelain in Europe
1709.summary: Johann Friedrich Böttger reports the first production of hard-paste porcelain
Peter the Great leads Russian forces to a decisive victory over Sweden

1709.event: Production of Eau de Cologne Begun
1709.summary: Johann Maria Farina begins the production of Eau de Cologne
The first performance of the opera Agrippina by George Frideric Handel takes place

1709.event: First Modern Edition of Shakespeare's Plays
1709.summary: The first modern edition of William Shakespeare's plays is published
The first piano is exhibited in Florence by Bartolomeo Cristofori
The hot air balloon of Bartolomeu de Gusmão flies in Portugal
Troops of the Dutch Republic and partners drive the French from the field

1710.summary: Cölln is merged with Alt-Berlin by Frederick I to form Berlin
Danish invaders are decisively defeated by a Swedish army
Britain's Statute of Anne becomes effective
Sikh rebels defeat Mughal Empire troops near Sirhind
British Royal Navy ship HMS Vanguard is relaunched
A total eclipse of the sun is visible
Swedish garrison in Riga surrenders, ending Swedish rule in Latvia
French surrender at the Siege of Port Royal, marking British control of Nova Scotia
Swedish garrison in Reval surrenders, ending Swedish rule in Estonia

1710.event: Invention of the three-color printing process
1710.summary: Jacob Christoph Le Blon invents a precursor of modern CMYK printing

1711.summary: The first performance of Francesco Gasparini's most famous opera Tamerlano takes place at the Teatro San Cassiano in Venice.
Rinaldo by George Frideric Handel, the first Italian opera written for the London stage, premieres at the Queen's Theatre, Haymarket.

1711.event: Publication of An Essay on Criticism
1711.summary: Alexander Pope publishes the poem An Essay on Criticism in London.
A total lunar eclipse occurs on February 3.
The Treaty of the Pruth is signed between the Ottoman Empire and Russia, ending the Pruth River Campaign.

1711.event: King Louis XIV becomes longest-reigning monarch
1711.summary: King Louis XIV becomes the longest-reigning monarch in the world, surpassing the previous record.

1711.event: Academy of Sciences of the Institute of Bologna
1711.summary: A constitution is approved for the Academy of Sciences of the Institute of Bologna.
The rebuilding of St Paul's Cathedral in London to a design by Sir Christopher Wren is declared complete.
The Immaculate Conception Cathedral, one of the oldest cathedrals in Central America, is inaugurated.

1711.event: Construction of the Académie Royale des Beaux-Arts
1711.summary: Académie Royale des Beaux-Arts is established in Brussels.

1712.summary: A total eclipse of the sun is visible from the southern hemisphere.
The opera Idoménée by André Campra premieres at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris.
A military engineering school is established in Moscow, which will become the A.F. Mozhaysky Military-Space Academy.
The Old Pummerin bell, weighing over 18,000 kg, is rung for the first time in St. Stephen's Cathedral, Vienna.
Peter the Great moves the capital of Russia from Moscow to Saint Petersburg.
The French defeat a combined Dutch-Austrian force in the Battle of Denain.
Composer George Frideric Handel relocates to London with the support of his patron.
The first performance of Handel's opera Il pastor fido takes place at the Queen's Theatre in London.

1712.event: Establishment of Biblioteca Nacional de España
1712.summary: King Philip V of Spain establishes the Biblioteca Nacional de España as the Palace Public Library in Madrid.
Thomas Newcomen builds the first known working steam engine, making practical use of steam power.

1713.event: First performance of Cato, a Tragedy
1713.summary: Joseph Addison's libertarian play Cato is performed for the first time in London, influencing political thought across the Atlantic.
Charles VI issues the Pragmatic Sanction to allow one of his daughters to inherit the Habsburg lands, impacting European dynastic politics.
Antonio Vivaldi's first opera, Ottone in villa, is performed for the first time at the Teatro delle Grazie in Vicenza.
The treaty ends the War of the Spanish Succession, altering territorial claims and shaping European power dynamics.
Great Britain and Spain sign a treaty to establish commerce and navigation terms as part of the peace settlement.
Russia and Brandenburg-Prussia sign a treaty, affecting territorial control in the Baltic region after the Great Northern War.
A significant battle occurs in Finland, marking ongoing conflicts in the Great Northern War.

1713.event: King Philip V changes Spanish throne succession
1713.summary: The Spanish throne succession is changed to allow a female descendant from the House of Bourbon to rule.
A riot breaks out during the contested Irish General Election, highlighting social tensions in Ireland.

1713.event: Spanish Crown agrees Asiento de Negros
1713.summary: The Spanish Crown grants a 30-year monopoly on African slave supply to British interests in colonial Spanish America.

1714.summary: Russia's Tsar Peter the Great issues a decree requiring compulsory education in mathematics for children of government officials and nobility, applying to children between the ages of 10 and 15 years old.
The Treaty of Rastatt is signed between Austria and France, concluding the War of the Spanish Succession.
Johann Sebastian Bach leads the first performance of his cantata for Pentecost, Erschallet, ihr Lieder, BWV 172, at the chapel of Schloss Weimar.
The Parliament of Great Britain votes to offer a reward for the discovery of a method to determine a ship's longitude.
The coronation of George I of Great Britain and Ireland takes place in Westminster Abbey, following his accession to the throne.

1714.event: End of War of the Spanish Succession
1714.summary: France signs separate treaties with multiple countries to end hostilities in the War of the Spanish Succession following the negotiations of the Peace of Utrecht.

1714.event: First Victory of the Imperial Russian Navy
1714.summary: The Imperial Russian Navy gains its first important victory against the Swedish Navy in the Battle of Gangut.
King Philip V of Spain issues a decree reorganizing the Spanish government to create four ministries, with the Secretary of State being the chief minister.
Barcelona is taken after a year's siege, and Catalonia surrenders to Spanish and French Bourbon armies during the War of the Spanish Succession.
Thomas Tenison establishes the world's earliest surviving mixed gender school in Croydon, England.

1715.summary: A devastating fire in London destroys more than 100 houses, described as the worst since the Great Fire of London.
Voting concludes for the British House of Commons, resulting in a major victory for the liberal Whig Party.
Danish Navy defeats Swedish forces in a decisive battle during the Great Northern War, capturing multiple ships.
A total solar eclipse is observed across southern England, prompting interest from astronomers, including Edmond Halley.
King Philip unifies the Kingdom of Castile and the Kingdom of Aragon into a centralized Kingdom of Spain.
King Louis XIV of France dies after 72 years on the throne, leading to political changes in France.
The first major Jacobite rising occurs in Scotland with the Earl of Mar raising the standard of James Edward Stuart.
A treaty is signed between Russia and Hanover, with territorial agreements affecting Sweden's duchies.
A significant yet indecisive battle occurs during the Jacobite rising in Scotland, halting the advance of Jacobite forces.
Baron Onslow resigns as Chancellor of the Exchequer, paving the way for Robert Walpole's future leadership.

1716.summary: The application of the Nueva Planta decrees to Catalonia concludes the unification of Spain under Philip V, abolishing its political entity.
The 1716 Algiers earthquake sequence begins with a mainshock of Mw 7.0, causing severe damage and killing 20,000 people.
Jacobite leaders James Radclyffe and William Gordon are executed in London following the failed Jacobite rising of 1715.
An aurora borealis is observed throughout Europe, from Ireland to Italy, capturing public attention and wonder.
Austrian troops led by Prince Eugene of Savoy defeat the Ottoman Turks, marking a significant victory in the ongoing conflict.
During the war between the Habsburg Empire and the Ottoman Empire, the fortified city of Temeşvar is surrendered to the Austrians, altering the territorial control in Hungary.

1716.event: Disarming Act and Treason Act Amendments
1716.summary: New laws in the Highlands of Scotland are enacted to prevent Jacobite threats, requiring government authorization for firearms and permitting treason trials in any English court.
John Law establishes the Banque Générale Privée in Paris, significantly impacting the financial landscape of France.
Tokugawa Yoshimune assumes control as the new Tokugawa Shogun in Japan, marking the beginning of a new era in governance.
Maria, an African slave leading a rebellion in Curaçao, is executed after a revolt against plantation oppression, highlighting issues of slavery.

1717.summary: The kingdoms of Great Britain, France, and the Dutch Republic sign the Triple Alliance to maintain the Treaty of Utrecht
The Silent Sejm in the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth marks the beginning of the Russian Empire's increasing influence
Dancer John Weaver performs the first ballet in Britain, The Loves of Mars and Venus
Water Music by George Frederick Handel is first performed on a Thames barge in London
The Premier Grand Lodge of England, the first Free-Masonic Grand Lodge, is founded in London
Spain creates the Viceroyalty of New Granada in South America from the northern section of the Viceroyalty of Peru
Antonio Vivaldi's opera Tieteberga is performed for the first time at the Teatro San Moisè in Venice
A disastrous flood hits the North Sea coast, causing thousands of deaths and destruction
A 7.4 magnitude earthquake strikes Antigua Guatemala, leading to significant destruction
The first known Druid revival ceremony is held by John Toland at Primrose Hill in London

1718.summary: Edward Wortley Montagu becomes the first British person inoculated with the smallpox vaccine at the age of four, marking a significant advancement in medical practice.
The British Royal Navy defeats a Spanish fleet, a significant military victory contributing to British naval dominance.
New Orleans is founded, establishing a crucial cultural and economic center in North America that would influence music development.

1718.event: Death of Pedro IV of Kongo
1718.summary: The death of King Pedro IV leads to Manuel II becoming monarch, impacting regional politics in Africa.
The signing of the Treaty of Baden ends the Toggenburg War, reshaping political alliances in Europe.
Notorious pirate Stede Bonnet is executed in Charleston, marking a significant event in pirate history.
Voltaire's first play, Oedipus, premieres in Paris, influencing French literature and the arts.

1718.event: Start of War of the Quadruple Alliance
1718.summary: The declaration of war by several European powers against Spain initiates the War of the Quadruple Alliance, affecting European politics and society.
The Mughal Emperor Farrukhsiyar restores Mir Jumla III to his position, impacting the Mughal administration.
Construction of Kadriorg Palace begins in Tallinn at the behest of Tsar Peter the Great, symbolizing Russian influence in the region.

1719.summary: A catastrophic retreat by a largely-Finnish Swedish-Carolean army results in about 3,700 deaths and severe injuries to many others.
The Principality of Liechtenstein is officially established within the Holy Roman Empire.
Ulrika Eleonora is crowned as the Queen of Sweden after a new constitution is signed.
A serious earthquake causes significant destruction, including buildings and churches.
The first Treaty of Stockholm is signed, marking a significant diplomatic development.
Daniel Defoe releases his famous novel Robinson Crusoe, influencing literature and culture.
British forces achieve victory over Jacobite and Spanish allies in a key battle.
Crown Prince Frederick I leads a successful defense of Stockholm against the Russian fleet.
The Opernhaus am Zwinger, one of the largest opera houses, opens with a staging of an opera.
Muhammad Shah is crowned as the 12th Mughal Emperor of India, significant for its impact on the subcontinent.

1720.summary: Sweden and Prussia sign a treaty, affecting the dynamics of the Great Northern War.
Edmond Halley is appointed as the Astronomer Royal for England, advancing astronomical studies.
The Treaty ends the War of the Quadruple Alliance, altering territorial claims in Europe.
Queen Ulrika abdicates in favor of her husband Frederick I, impacting Swedish monarchy and governance.

1720.event: Coronation of Frederick I of Sweden
1720.summary: Frederick I is crowned King of Sweden, marking a new era in Swedish rule.
The British Parliament enacts the Bubble Act, regulating joint-stock companies amidst economic turmoil.
The South Sea Company stock peaks, leading to economic speculation and subsequent crashes.
The Mississippi Company shares peak sharply in France, precipitating a financial collapse.

1720.event: Founding of the Royal Cork Yacht Club
1720.summary: The world's first yacht club is established in Ireland, influencing maritime culture.

1720.event: Publication of Il teatro alla moda
1720.summary: Benedetto Marcello's satirical pamphlet, significant in cultural critique, is published in Venice.

1721.summary: Johann Sebastian Bach's Brandenburg concertos are completed and dedicated to Christian Ludwig of Brandenburg-Schwedt.

1721.event: First Prime Minister of Great Britain
1721.summary: Robert Walpole becomes the first Prime Minister of Great Britain, a term that denotes his prominent political role.
The deadliest outbreak of smallpox in Boston begins with an arrival of sailors from a smallpox epidemic, leading to thousands of cases.
Dr. Zabdiel Boylston begins the first public inoculation campaign in Boston to combat the smallpox epidemic.
The Treaty of Nystad is signed, officially ending the Great Northern War and reshaping the balance of power in Northern Europe.
Peter I is proclaimed the first Emperor of All the Russias, marking the transition from the Tsardom of Russia to the Russian Empire.

1721.event: Creation of the Universidad Real y Pontificia de Caracas
1721.summary: Philip V of Spain signs a Royal Decree transforming the Seminary of Saint Rose of Lima in Caracas into a university.
The Sack of Shamakhi occurs, a significant military event in the Persian Safavid Empire.
The Kelantan Sultanate is established in modern-day Kelantan Darul Naim, Malaysia.
Regular mail service between London and New England is established, enhancing communication across the Atlantic.

1722.summary: Daniel Defoe's novel Moll Flanders is published anonymously in London
The Royal Navy ends the piracy of Bartholomew Roberts off the coast of West Africa
Nasir-ud-Din Muḥammad Shah names Nizam-ul-Mulk as his Grand Vizier in the Mughal Empire
The Pashtun people decisively defeat the Safavid forces in Persia
Peter the Great issues an order to establish the Caspian Flotilla to control the Caspian Sea
The Safavid capital Isfahan capitulates to Afghan rebels, leading to a change in leadership

1722.event: Establishment of public theatre in Denmark
1722.summary: The first public theatre, Lille Grønnegade Theatre, is founded in Copenhagen
Jean-Philippe Rameau publishes Traité de l'harmonie, defining modern music theory
Johann Sebastian Bach composes The Well-Tempered Clavier
The capital of Louisiana Territory, New Orleans, is struck by a devastating hurricane

1723.summary: The Kangxi Era ends in Qing dynasty China, and the Yongzheng Era begins with the coronation of Yinzhen, the Yongzheng Emperor
King Louis XV of France attains his majority on his 13th birthday, bringing an end to the regency of Philippe II
The Mapuche Uprising begins in Chile as the indigenous Mapuche people lead an attack against the city of Tucapel
Johann Sebastian Bach assumed the office of Thomaskantor in Leipzig, presenting his first new cantata in the St. Nicholas Church
During the Russo-Persian War, Baku surrenders to the Russians
Philippe II, Duke of Orléans is appointed Prime Minister of France by King Louis XV
The Peterhof Palace is opened in a formal ceremony just outside Saint Petersburg
The Treaty of Saint Petersburg is signed in Russia, ending the Russo-Persian War
Bach leads the first performance of his first Christmas Cantata composed for Leipzig

1724.summary: King Philip V of Spain abdicates the throne in favour of his 16-year-old son Louis I.

1724.event: Establishment of Saint Petersburg State University
1724.summary: Saint Petersburg State University is established in Russia.
The premiere of Giulio Cesare, an Italian opera by George Frideric Handel, takes place in London.

1724.event: First performance of St John Passion
1724.summary: Bach leads the first performance of his St John Passion on Good Friday.

1724.event: First performance of cantata Erfreut euch, ihr Herzen
1724.summary: Bach leads the first performance of his cantata Erfreut euch, ihr Herzen, BWV 66, his first cantata composed for Easter.

1724.event: Signing of the Treaty of Constantinople
1724.summary: The Treaty of Constantinople is signed, partitioning Persia between the Ottoman Empire and Russia.
The Hyderabad State is created in India, rewarding Mir Qamar-ud-din Khan.

1724.event: Construction of Teatro Nuovo opera house
1724.summary: The historic Teatro Nuovo opera house is inaugurated in Naples with the premiere of a comic opera.
George Frideric Handel's opera Tamerlano is performed for the first time, premiering in London.
Highwayman Jack Sheppard is hanged in London.

1725.event: Catherine I becomes Empress of Russia
1725.summary: Catherine I is proclaimed Empress of Russia following the death of her husband, Peter the Great

1725.event: First performance of Bach's chorale cantata
1725.summary: Bach's chorale cantata Wie schön leuchtet der Morgenstern, BWV 1, is first performed
Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor, and King Philip V of Spain sign the Treaty of Vienna
Riots commence in Scotland after the increase in the price of beer and scotch whiskey
Freemasonry is introduced in France, influencing social and cultural dynamics

1725.event: Publication of Four Seasons by Vivaldi
1725.summary: Antonio Vivaldi's famous set of violin concertos, The Four Seasons, is published
Johann Joseph Fux publishes Gradus ad Parnassum, an influential work on music counterpoint
James Figg hosts the first documented international boxing match in London
British astronomers set up a telescope leading to the pioneering discovery of the aberration of light

1725.event: First newspaper in the Province of New York
1725.summary: The New-York Gazette is established as the first weekly newspaper in the Province of New York

1726.summary: The Conventicle Act is adopted in Sweden, outlawing all non-Lutheran religious meetings outside of church services.
The First Treaty of Vienna is signed creating the Austro-Spanish Alliance in advance of a war against Great Britain.

1726.event: The establishment of the Supreme Privy Council
1726.summary: The Supreme Privy Council is established in Russia.
The Parliament of Negrete brings an end to the Mapuche uprising of 1723–26.
The Dutch East India Company frigate Aagtekerke departs from the Dutch Cape Colony on its voyage to the Dutch East Indies and is never seen again.
Louis Henri, Duke of Bourbon, is dismissed as Prime Minister of France and replaced by André-Hercule de Fleury.
Jonathan Swift's satirical novel Gulliver's Travels is first published in London, selling out within a week.

1726.event: The explosion of the Santa Rosa
1726.summary: An explosion on the Portuguese Navy galleon HMFMS Santa Rosa kills all but seven of the 700 passengers and crew.
Pope Benedict XIII extends permission to celebrate the feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel to the entire Roman Catholic Church.
The settlement of Montevideo is founded by the Spaniards in the Viceroyalty of Peru.

1727.summary: Spain's ambassador to Great Britain demands the return of Gibraltar, leading to the Thirteenth Siege.
Charité Hospital is established in Berlin for research and aiding the poor.
Johann Sebastian Bach's solo cantata Ich habe genug BWV 82 premieres in Leipzig.
Bach's St Matthew Passion BWV 244b premieres at St. Thomas Church in Leipzig.
George, Prince of Wales, becomes King George II of Great Britain after his father's death.
Spain ceases hostilities against Britain after failing to recapture Gibraltar; a truce is signed.
George II of Great Britain is crowned, and Handel composes Coronation Anthems for the event.
The Netherlands signs the Treaty of Seville.
A significant earthquake in Tabriz, Persia kills 77,000 people.
The Royal Bank of Scotland issues its first pound note since the union of England and Scotland.

1728.event: Founding of the Real y Pontificia Universidad de San Gerónimo de la Habana
1728.summary: The oldest university in Cuba is founded in Havana

1728.event: Coronation of Peter II as Tsar
1728.summary: The coronation of Peter II as the Tsar of the Russian Empire takes place
The most popular theatrical production of the 18th century is performed for the first time at Lincoln's Inn Fields Theatre
The Treaty is signed between Russia and China, recognizing territorial agreements
Persian physician completes an important treatise on health preservation for travelers to Persia
Led by Vitus Bering, the expedition sails from the Kamchatka Peninsula northward
The largest fire in the history of Copenhagen occurs
The Maratha Empire invades the Mughal Empire's Malwa province, leading to significant conflict

1728.event: James Bradley observes nutation of the Earth's axis
1728.summary: English astronomer uses stellar aberration to calculate the speed of light and observe Earth's axis nutation

1728.event: End of Voltaire's exile in England
1728.summary: Voltaire returns from his exile in England, impacting the literary and philosophical scene

1729.summary: Frederick, the eldest son of King George II of Great Britain, is made Prince of Wales at the age of 21.

1729.event: Marriages of Joseph and Mariana Victoria
1729.summary: Joseph, Prince of Brazil, is married to the 10-year-old Princess Mariana Victoria of Spain.
Russian and Afghani leaders sign a peace treaty in the city of Resht in Persia.
James Oglethorpe begins service as the Chairman of the Gaols Committee to investigate conditions of Britain's jails.
Bach's First Köthen Funeral music and funeral cantata premiere at St. Jakob, Köthen.
Bach's St Matthew Passion, BWV 244b is performed again at St. Thomas Church, Leipzig.
Caroline, Queen Consort, becomes the first person to rule Great Britain as regent under the Regency Acts.
The Treaty of Seville is signed between Great Britain, France, Spain and the Dutch Republic.
George Frideric Handel's famous opera Lotario is given its first performance at the King's Theatre in London.

1730.summary: Emperor Peter II of Russia dies of smallpox, aged 14
Anna of Russia becomes reigning Empress of Russia following the death of her cousin Emperor Peter II

1730.event: Completion of the First Kamchatka Expedition
1730.summary: Vitus Bering returns to Saint Petersburg after completing the First Kamchatka expedition
The 1730 papal conclave to elect a new Pope begins with 30 Cardinals
General Nader Khan of Persia opens the first campaign of the Ottoman–Persian War
The coronation of Anna of Russia as Empress takes place in Saint Petersburg
An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 9.1 strikes Valparaíso in modern-day Chile
The papal conclave selects Cardinal Lorenzo Corsini as the successor to Pope Benedict XIII
Maria Madlener becomes the last person to be executed after the Galgeninsel witch trials
Construction of the Ladoga Canal, linking the Neva and Svir Rivers, is completed

1731.summary: An avalanche from Skafjell mountain causes a massive wave in Storfjorden, sinking boats and resulting in casualties.
A fire in Brussels at Coudenberg Palace destroys the building and state records.
The Treaty of Vienna is signed between several European powers, reshaping political alliances.
Benjamin Franklin and others establish the Library Company of Philadelphia, promoting access to literature.
The Pacific Fleet of the Russian Navy is established, impacting naval power in the region.
A fire at Ashburnham House destroys 114 manuscripts, affecting historical literature.
Leonhard Euler announces the use of the number e for the natural logarithm, influencing mathematics.
Laura Bassi becomes the first official female university teacher, breaking barriers in academia.
The octant is developed by John Hadley, enhancing navigation techniques.

1731.event: Building of the Royal Theatre of Mantua
1731.summary: The Royal Theatre of Mantua is constructed, contributing to the cultural landscape of Italy.

1732.summary: Russia and Persia sign an agreement, stopping Russian claims over Persian territories
The Swedish East India Company starts its profitable first expedition to China
Henry Fielding's comedy The Modern Husband premieres in London
King Christian VI signs the charter for the Danish Asia Company, granting a 40-year trade monopoly
Shah Tahmasp II is removed from the throne of Iran by Nader Khan, who proclaims himself King
Dirck van Cloon becomes the new Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies

1732.event: Conquest of Oran and Mers El Kébir
1732.summary: Spain completes the conquest of Algerian cities after a 17-day siege
Mikhail Gvozdev makes the first known crossing of the Bering Strait

1732.event: Treaty of the Three Black Eagles
1732.summary: A secret treaty between the Austrian Empire, the Russian Empire, and Prussia against Poland-Lithuania
The original Theatre Royal Covent Garden in London is opened

1733.summary: George Frideric Handel's classic opera Orlando is performed for the first time at the King's Theatre in London, marking a significant cultural event.
The introduction of John Kay's Flying Shuttle revolutionizes the textile industry and marks the beginning of the Industrial Revolution.
English replaces Latin and Law French as the official language of English and Scottish courts, impacting legal communication.

1733.event: The Molasses Act Receives Royal Assent
1733.summary: The Molasses Act is formally approved, which underscores colonial tensions and economic implications for American colonists.

1733.event: Stanislas Leszczynski Returns to Polish Throne
1733.summary: Stanislas Leszczynski is restored to the throne of Poland, amidst political tensions involving Russia and Austria.
The election of Augustus III as King of Poland triggers the War of the Polish Succession, altering European political landscapes.
The first Freemasons lodge, the Grand Lodge of Massachusetts, opens in what will become the United States, highlighting the spread of new ideas.
The Molasses Act goes into full effect, impacting trade and colonial economics significantly.
Prince Frederick of Prussia marries Duchess Elisabeth Christine, aligning royal interests with significant implications for Prussia.

1733.event: Danish West India Company Purchases Saint Croix
1733.summary: The Danish West India Company buys the island of Saint Croix from France, expanding colonial interests in the Caribbean.

1734.summary: Salzburgers, Lutherans expelled by the Roman Catholic Bishop of Salzburg, set sail for the British Colony of Georgia in America
The Ostend Company ceases business as part of the agreement by Austria in the Second Treaty of Vienna
Spanish forces defeat the Austrian forces, completing the conquest of the Kingdom of Naples
The Whigs lose 85 seats but retain their majority after the British general election
The Siege of the Austrian fortress of Philippsburg by the French Army ends after eight weeks as its Austrian defenders surrender
The armies of Spain and France storm the city of Gaeta in Naples, ending a four-month siege
Chief Tomochichi of the Yamacraw band ends a successful visit to Great Britain after signing the cession of Savannah, Georgia
The Dzików Confederation is created in Poland
A fire destroys the Royal Alcázar of Madrid, damaging numerous valuable artworks and documents
Anton Wilhelm Amo becomes the first African to receive a doctorate in Europe and begins teaching at the University of Halle

1735.event: Publication of Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot
1735.summary: Alexander Pope's poem Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot is published in London.
George Frideric Handel's opera Ariodante is premièred at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, London.
The Engraving Copyright Act 1734 takes effect in Great Britain, marking the first copyright protection laws.

1735.event: Ceasefire in War of the Polish Succession
1735.summary: An agreement between European powers brings a ceasefire in the War of the Polish Succession.
The largest bell in the world, the Tsar Kolokol, is successfully cast in Moscow within the Kremlin.
Qianlong succeeds his father, Yongzheng, as Emperor of China, beginning a long reign.
The Netherlands announces a prohibition against citizens joining the Freemasons.
Claudius Aymand performs the second successful appendectomy at St George's Hospital in London.
Emperor Sakuramachi accedes to the throne of Japan.

1735.event: Introduction of card money in Louisiana
1735.summary: The Kingdom of France approves the issuance of card money in its Louisiana territory.

1736.summary: Sweden passes a comprehensive Civil Code, influencing legal frameworks in Europe.
The marriage of Francis I and Maria Theresa strengthens the Habsburg Empire.
Nader Shah is crowned as Shah of Iran, marking a significant political shift in the region.
Bellevue Hospital is established in New York, becoming a key institution in healthcare.
Riots erupt in Edinburgh after the execution of a smuggler, causing civil unrest.
The Witchcraft Act comes into effect in Great Britain, ending witch trials.
French scientists begin crucial measurements at the Equator to calculate the Earth's circumference.
A massive fire in Saint Petersburg destroys thousands of buildings, impacting the city profoundly.
The brief reign of King Theodore on Corsica ends, bringing the island back under French control.
Benjamin Franklin establishes the first volunteer fire company in Philadelphia, enhancing community safety.

1737.summary: Spain and the Holy Roman Empire sign instruments of cession, with the Empire gaining control of Tuscany and the Grand Duchy of Parma in return for recognition of Don Carlos as King of Naples and Sicily.
Austria and Russia enter into a secret military alliance resulting in Austria's entrance into the Russo-Turkish War.
French scientists publish a study correlating past weather conditions with tree ring examination, marking a significant advance in climate science.
The Theatrical Licensing Act in Britain requires plays to be submitted for censorship, impacting the freedom of artistic expression.
Persian shah Nader Shah begins an extensive siege in Afghanistan, altering power dynamics in the region.
The oldest existing English language newspaper, The News Letter, is founded in Belfast, representing a significant advancement in journalism.
A tropical cyclone kills at least 300,000 people in India and Bangladesh, highlighting the dangers of natural disasters in the region.

1737.event: Inauguration of Teatro di San Carlo
1737.summary: The Teatro di San Carlo, the oldest working opera house in Europe, is inaugurated in Naples, enriching the cultural landscape of music and opera.
Religious reformer John Wesley returns to England, influencing the religious and social landscape.
An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 9.3 off Kamchatka creates tsunamis, showcasing the devastating power of natural events.

1738.event: First performance of Handel's opera Faramondo
1738.summary: George Frideric Handel's opera Faramondo is given its first performance.
Jacques de Vaucanson stages the first demonstration of an early automaton, The Flute Player, in Paris.
Serse, an Italian opera by George Frideric Handel, premieres in London.

1738.event: Establishment of Spain's Royal Academy of History
1738.summary: Spain's Royal Academy of History is established by decree of King Philip V of Spain.

1738.event: Foundation of the Imperial Theatrical School
1738.summary: The Imperial Theatrical School, known as Vaganova Academy of Russian Ballet, is founded.
British inventor Lewis Paul receives a patent for roller cotton-spinning machinery.
English metallurgist William Champion is granted a patent for his process of extracting zinc.
The excavation of Herculaneum, a Roman city, begins near Resina on orders from King Charles III of Spain.

1738.event: Ratification of the Treaty of Vienna
1738.summary: The Treaty of Vienna is ratified, ending the War of the Polish Succession.

1738.event: Publication confirming Newton's view of Earth
1738.summary: Pierre Louis Maupertuis publishes Sur la figure de la terre, confirming Newton's view that the earth is an oblate spheroid.

1739.summary: Bouvet Island is discovered by French explorer Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier in the South Atlantic Ocean.
A 7.6 earthquake shakes the Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region in China killing 50,000 people.
The army of Iranian ruler Nader Shah defeats the forces of the Mughal emperor of India, Muhammad Shah.
Nader Shah occupies Delhi, India and sacks the city, stealing the jewels of the Peacock Throne, including the Koh-i-Noor.

1739.event: Foundation of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences
1739.summary: The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences is founded in Stockholm, Sweden.
The British East India Company signs a treaty with the Maratha Empire to gain the right of free trade within the territory.
The Ottoman Empire retakes Belgrade from Austria's Habsburg monarchy after winning the Battle of Grocka.

1739.event: Re-establishment of the Viceroyalty of New Granada
1739.summary: The Viceroyalty of New Granada is re-established by the royal cedula of King Philip V of Spain, adding the territory of Panama.
The Treaty of Belgrade brings the Austro-Russian–Turkish War (1735–39) to an end.

1739.event: Beginning of the Irish Famine of 1740
1739.summary: Months of unseasonably cold weather begin in Ireland, precipitating the Irish Famine of 1740, leading to starvation for at least 13% of the population.

1740.summary: All 237 crewmen on the Dutch East India Company ship Rooswijk are drowned when it strikes the shoals of Goodwin Sands off the coast of England.
Construction begins on Bethesda Orphanage for boys near Savannah, Georgia, founded by George Whitefield.
The Royal Navy captures the Spanish ship of the line Princesa off Cape Finisterre as part of the War of the Austrian Succession.
Frederick II becomes King in Prussia upon the death of his father, Frederick William I.
The Plantation Act or Naturalization Act allows Protestant alien immigrants in American colonies to receive British nationality.
The Pour le Mérite is first awarded in Prussia as a military honour.
The song Rule, Britannia! is first performed at Cliveden, the country home of Frederick, Prince of Wales, in England.
Troops of the Dutch East India Company massacre 5,000-10,000 Chinese Indonesians in Batavia.
Maria Theresa inherits the hereditary dominions of the Habsburg monarchy upon the death of her father, Charles VI.
Samuel Richardson's influential epistolary novel, Pamela; or, Virtue Rewarded, is published anonymously in London.

1741.event: Adoption of the term 'balance of power'
1741.summary: Sir Robert Walpole popularizes the term balance of power in a speech in Parliament, shaping political discourse.
Charles Macklin debuts in London as Shylock, introducing a more psychologically realistic portrayal in theater.
Prussian troops defeat an Austrian army, marking an important event in the War of the Austrian Succession.
Vitus Bering sets out to map the coasts of Siberia and Alaska, contributing to geographical knowledge.
Spain's defenders defeat a British naval force, impacting British colonial ambitions in the Caribbean.
Maria Theresa is crowned Queen Regnant of Hungary, significantly impacting the Habsburg monarchy.
Raja Marthanda Varma defeats the Dutch East India Company, marking a pivotal moment against colonial rule in India.

1741.event: Eruption leading to the Kampo Tsunami
1741.summary: A volcanic eruption generates the Kampo Tsunami, causing significant loss of life in Japan.
Anders Celsius develops the Centigrade thermometer scale, laying the groundwork for modern temperature measurement.
Elizabeth rises to power in Russia after a palace coup, influencing European geopolitics.

1742.summary: George Frideric Handel's oratorio The Messiah is first performed in Dublin, Ireland in aid of local charities.
Frederick the Great's army defeats the Austrians in the Battle of Chotusitz.
Austria cedes Silesia to Prussia following the Peace of Breslau.
Christian Goldbach first describes Goldbach's conjecture in a letter to Leonhard Euler.
Construction starts on the Foundling Hospital in London.
French forces defeat the Austrians in the Battle of Sahay during the War of the Austrian Succession.
Voltaire's controversial play Fanatacism, or Mahomet the Prophet, is performed in Paris.
The Swedish-Russian War effectively ends with the surrender of 17,000 Swedish troops in Finland.
Robert Walpole resigns as Prime Minister of Great Britain, ending the longest single term for Prime Minister.
Henry Fielding publishes his picaresque novel Joseph Andrews anonymously in London.

1743.summary: George Frideric Handel's oratorio, Samson, premieres in London.
British forces defeat a French army under the duc de Noailles, the last British king to lead troops in battle.
Russia and Sweden sign the Treaty of Åbo, marking the end of the Russo-Swedish War.
The Verendrye brothers make the first contact between Europeans and the Sioux Indians.
Pope Benedict XIV issues a new bull barring agreements by spouses not to appeal annulments of marriages.

1743.event: Inauguration of Public Schools in Georgia
1743.summary: The trustees of the English Province of Georgia vote to inaugurate public schools in the corporate territory.
Louis Maria Colons is executed for attempting to persuade the Pueblo Indians to rise up against the Spanish colonial government.

1743.event: Discovery of the Great Comet of 1744
1743.summary: Dutch astronomer Dirk Klinkenberg becomes the first to observe the Great Comet of 1744.
Benjamin Franklin's view of a lunar eclipse from Philadelphia is spoiled by a rainstorm.

1744.summary: The British fleet is defeated by a joint Franco-Spanish fleet
One of the brightest comets ever seen reaches perihelion
A joint French and Spanish force defeats Britain and Sardinia
Articles of union are signed between Prussia, Hesse-Kassel and the Rhineland Palatinate

1744.event: Attack on British settlement at Canso
1744.summary: The French Army attacks and forces the surrender of the British settlement at Fort William Augustus
Anson's voyage around the world ends with his return to England
France defeats the Kingdom of Sardinia
HMS Victory sinks in a storm, killing 1,100 sailors and officers
Linnaeus is selected as president of the Royal Swedish Academy of Science
The Prussian Army begins bombardment of Prague

1745.summary: Austrian Army makes a surprise attack at Amberg, scattering Bavarian troops and capturing Munich.

1745.event: Death of Holy Roman Emperor Karl VII Albrecht
1745.summary: The ruler of Bavaria dies at the age of 47, leaving the duchy without an adult to lead it.
Pierre Bouguer delivers a report on the Earth's circumference, contributing to the development of the metric system.
French forces defeat an Anglo-Dutch-Hanoverian army, marking a significant victory in the war.

1745.event: Election of Holy Roman Emperor Francis I
1745.summary: Francis I is elected Holy Roman Emperor, marking a shift in power dynamics within the Empire.
Jacobite forces defeat British Government troops in Scotland during the Jacobite rising.
Pope Benedict XIV issues an encyclical condemning usury, impacting financial practices of the time.
Ewald Georg von Kleist invents the first electrical capacitor, marking a significant leap in electrical science.
Charles Edward Stuart leads the Jacobite army into England, causing panic in London.
The Treaty of Dresden grants Prussia full possession of Silesia, reshaping territorial control.

1746.summary: The final pitched battle fought on British soil, bringing an end to the Jacobite rising of 1745.
Samuel Johnson is contracted to write A Dictionary of the English Language.

1746.event: King Philip V of Spain dies
1746.summary: The death of King Philip V after a reign of more than 45 years, leading to the succession of his son, King Ferdinand VI.
Prince William, Duke of Cumberland, issues a proclamation offering amnesty to participants in the Jacobite rebellion.
Zakariya Khan Bahadur orders the massacre of Lahore's Sikh population.
The Earl of Kilmarnock and Lord Balmerino are beheaded in the Tower of London after being imprisoned for treason.
An earthquake demolishes Lima and Callao, causing significant destruction in Peru.

1746.event: Founding of College of New Jersey
1746.summary: The College of New Jersey is founded in Princetown, which will later be renamed Princeton University.

1746.event: Rise against Austrian troops in Genoa
1746.summary: Citizens of the Republic of Genoa rise up against Austrian occupying troops and are initially successful.

1746.event: Publication of Les beaux-arts réduits à un même principe
1746.summary: Charles Batteux's significant work proposing the idea of 'les beaux arts': the fine arts, is published in Paris.

1747.summary: The Scottish Jacobite Lord Lovat is beheaded at Tower Hill, London, for high treason.
The British Navy defeats a French fleet at the First battle of Cape Finisterre during the War of the Austrian Succession.
Emperor Momozono ascends to the throne of Japan, succeeding Emperor Sakuramachi.
The British Navy again defeats a French fleet at the Second battle of Cape Finisterre during the War of the Austrian Succession.
The first venereal diseases clinic opens at London Lock Hospital, marking a significant advance in medical care.
Rioters in Boston protest impressment into the British Royal Navy, reflecting tensions over military conscription.
Benjamin Franklin forms the Pennsylvania Associators, the first militia in Pennsylvania, highlighting shifts in military organization.
A hurricane in the Caribbean Sea sinks several British ships, illustrating the dangers of maritime travel.

1747.event: End of the Second Stadtholderless period
1747.summary: Prince William IV of Orange becomes stadtholder of all the United Provinces, marking a political shift in the region.
James Lind's experiment begins to prove that citrus fruits prevent scurvy, contributing to advances in naval health.

1748.summary: A fire at the prison and barracks at Kinsale kills 54 prisoners of war.
The Siege of the Dutch fortress of Maastricht begins, leading to its fall.
A fire in the City of London causes over £1,000,000 in damages.
A fire in Moscow kills 482 people and destroys 5,000 buildings.
A British squadron engages a Spanish squadron near Havana in the War of Jenkins' Ear.
The Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle is signed, ending the War of the Austrian Succession.
Leonhard Euler publishes Introductio in analysin infinitorum, introducing analytical mathematics.
The ruins of Pompeii are rediscovered.
Eva Ekeblad becomes the first female member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.

1749.summary: Benning Wentworth issues the first of the New Hampshire Grants, leading to the establishment of Vermont.
The first issue of Berlingske, Denmark's oldest continually operating newspaper, is published.
The Teatro Filarmonico, the main opera theater in Verona, Italy, is destroyed by fire.
At London's Covent Garden, composer George Frideric Handel conducts the first performance of his new oratorio, Solomon.

1749.event: First performance of Music for the Royal Fireworks
1749.summary: The first official performance of Handel's Music for the Royal Fireworks in London finishes early, due to the outbreak of fire.
A census is conducted in Finland.
French composer Jean-Philippe Rameau premieres his new opera, Zoroastre, at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris.

1749.event: Missionary work of Father Junípero Serra
1749.summary: Father Junípero Serra begins his missionary work in the New World after arriving in Mexico.

1749.event: Beggars ordinance by King Louis XV
1749.summary: In response to the increasing number of starving people in Paris, King Louis XV issues an ordinance to arrest beggars and vagabonds.
The Conspiracy of the Slaves, which was to have taken place on June 29, is revealed in Malta.

1750.summary: The Treaty of Madrid between Spain and Portugal authorizes a larger Brazil than had the Treaty of Tordesillas of 1494.
A fire in Istanbul destroys 10,000 homes, significantly impacting the local population.
The Murray-Kean Company gives the first performance of a play announced in advance in a newspaper, presenting Richard III in New York City.
Parliament passes Britain's Iron Act, designed to restrict American manufactured goods and impacting colonial economies.
Rioting breaks out in Paris following police actions, leading to a significant urban upheaval and subsequent police reforms.
The Louvre Museum is created in Paris, allowing public access to the royal art collection for the first time.

1750.event: The first documented presentation of a musical in New York
1750.summary: A resident company of actors stages The Beggar's Opera, marking a significant event in the evolution of musical theater in America.
An act removes the ban on slavery in the Province of Georgia, altering the social landscape in the Americas.
Two physicians fight a fatal duel over a disagreement, highlighting the tensions in medical practices of the time.
Westminster Bridge is officially opened in London, enhancing transportation and trade in the area.

1751.summary: The University of Pennsylvania holds its first classes as an institution designed to provide non-denominational higher education, marking a significant development in American education.

1751.event: Introduction of the Gregorian Calendar in Great Britain
1751.summary: Royal assent is given to the Calendar Act, adopting the Gregorian calendar and establishing January 1 as New Year's Day, correcting dating discrepancies.
Thomas Gray publishes Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard, which becomes one of the most notable poems in English literature.
The Pennsylvania Hospital is chartered as the first hospital in the American colonies, a significant advance in healthcare.

1751.event: Death of King Frederick I of Sweden
1751.summary: King Frederick I of Sweden dies, ending a reign of 31 years and leading to a change in the Swedish monarchy.

1751.event: Formation of New Prince of Wales
1751.summary: Prince George William Frederick is formally invested as the new Prince of Wales, setting the stage for future leadership.

1751.event: Start of Cricket in American Colonies
1751.summary: Cricket is played for the first time in the American colonies, introducing a new sport that will become popular.
The first volume of Denis Diderot's Encyclopédie is published, significantly influencing the spread of knowledge and ideas in Europe.

1751.event: Coronation of Adolf Frederick of Sweden
1751.summary: Adolf Frederick is formally crowned as the King of Sweden, symbolizing a new era in Swedish governance.
A significant battle during the Second Carnatic War where a British-led force defeats a larger Franco-Indian army, impacting colonial power dynamics.

1752.event: Adoption of the Gregorian calendar in the British Empire
1752.summary: The British Empire adopts the Gregorian calendar, marking the first day of the year as January 1.
French astronomer Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille discovers the Southern Pinwheel Galaxy, the first cataloged outside the Local Group.
Alaungpaya founds the Konbaung Dynasty in Upper Burma, unifying the country over the next eight years.

1752.event: Establishment of the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando
1752.summary: Spain's Royal Academy of the Fine Arts is formally established, marking a significant step in modernizing Spain during the Spanish Enlightenment.
Thomas-François Dalibard successfully conducts the kite experiment, demonstrating the connection between lightning and electricity.
A fire destroys 13,000 houses in Moscow, causing significant destruction to the city.

1752.event: Signing of the Treaty of Logstown
1752.summary: The Treaty of Logstown is signed, granting control over lands south and east of the Ohio River to the English.
The first of the Kronstadt canals, connecting two harbors in Russia, is completed and opened.

1752.event: Transition to the Gregorian calendar in Great Britain
1752.summary: Great Britain officially transitions from the Julian to the Gregorian calendar, impacting the reckoning of dates.

1752.event: First presentation of The Merchant of Venice in America
1752.summary: The first staging of a Shakespearean play in America occurs in Williamsburg, Virginia.

1753.summary: The concept of electrical telegraphy is first published, suggesting the use of static electricity to send signals across wires, influencing future communication methods.
Sweden adopts the Gregorian calendar by skipping 11 days, aligning with the rest of Europe, affecting record-keeping and cultural events.
The Jewish Naturalisation Act is passed by Britain's House of Lords, allowing Jewish immigrants to become naturalized citizens, impacting social integration.
The British Museum is established by Act of Parliament, becoming a major cultural institution and influencing art and education.
Georg Richmann becomes the first person to be electrocuted while conducting experiments, highlighting the dangers of electricity in scientific work.
King Fernando VI issues regulations for theatrical performances, impacting cultural expression and the arts in Spain.
The Russian Academy of Sciences announces a competition for the best explanation of electricity, fostering research and discovery in the field.
The Marriage Act is passed to prevent clandestine marriages, influencing societal norms and legal frameworks regarding marriage.
Species Plantarum is published, marking the start date for the scientific classification of plants, impacting botany and ecology.
Lieutenant Governor Dinwiddie commissions George Washington to dissuade French encroachment in the Ohio Country, a pivotal moment in colonial relations.

1754.summary: Horace Walpole coins the word serendipity in a letter.
Indigenous Guarani people attack a Brazilian Portuguese settlement, marking the start of the Guarani War.
Thomas Pelham-Holles, 1st Duke of Newcastle, forms a government as the new Prime Minister of Great Britain.
The Clandestine Marriages Act comes into force in England and Wales, establishing statutory marriage.
Guatemalan Sergeant Major Melchor de Mencos y Varón defeats British pirates in the Battle of San Felipe.
George Washington leads an ambush against French forces, marking the onset of the French and Indian War.
Delegates approve the Albany Plan of Union for a common defense policy among the British colonies.
Classes begin at Columbia University, originally founded as King's College by royal charter.
A powerful earthquake strikes Constantinople, causing significant damage and loss of life.
China's Qianlong Emperor reverts a policy preventing subjects from returning if out for over three years.

1755.summary: Moscow University is established, becoming a significant center for education and culture.
A steam engine is used for the first time in the American colonies to pump water out of a mine.
Samuel Johnson publishes A Dictionary of the English Language, which standardizes English and aids writers.
The French commander surrenders Fort Beauséjour to the British, marking a key victory in the French and Indian War.
The decision to deport the Acadians is made, significantly impacting Acadian culture and history.
A massive earthquake strikes Lisbon, killing more than 40,000 people and reshaping ideas about disaster and urban planning.
Delaware Indians attack white settlers in the Penn's Creek massacre, highlighting tensions between colonists and Indigenous peoples.

1755.event: Royal Navy's Victory in North America
1755.summary: British Admiral Boscawen intercepts French ships bound for Canada, showcasing British naval dominance.
Scottish chemist Joseph Black describes carbon dioxide and magnesium, contributing to scientific understanding of gases.
Jean-Marc Vacheron establishes his watch-making company, which becomes the oldest continuously operating watchmaker.

1756.summary: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was born in Salzburg, Austria
The Seven Years' War formally begins when Great Britain declares war on France
The British fleet under John Byng is defeated by the French under Roland-Michel Barrin de La Galissonière
The British garrison in Menorca surrenders to the French after two months' siege
Frederick defeats an Austrian army under Marshal Maximilian Ulysses, Reichsgraf von Browne
The play Douglas is performed for the first time in Edinburgh, gaining overwhelming success despite local opposition
An attempted coup d'état planned by Queen Louisa Ulrika of Sweden is exposed and subdued
The Marine Society is founded in London, becoming the world's oldest seafarers' charity

1756.event: Start of potato cultivation by Frederick II
1756.summary: Frederick II of Prussia forces his country's peasants to grow the unpopular and obscure potato
Leopold Mozart publishes his book on his method for learning to play the violin

1757.summary: The British Army captures Calcutta, India during the Seven Years' War.
Robert-François Damiens makes an unsuccessful assassination attempt on King Louis XV of France.
The Nawab of Bengal and General Clive sign a treaty securing British control over India.
King Frederick V of Denmark issues an order to create a Lutheran mission for African slaves.
Robert François Damiens is executed publicly for his assassination attempt on Louis XV.
The British East India Company defeats the Nawab of Bengal, marking significant British influence in India.
Frederick the Great is defeated by an Austrian army, marking a significant setback for Prussia.
Frederick defeats the French-Imperial army, a significant victory in the Seven Years' War.
Frederick achieves a great tactical victory over the Austrian army, showcasing military innovation.
The works of Galileo are removed from the list of prohibited books by the Roman Catholic Church.

1758.summary: Carl Linnaeus publishes the first volume of Systema Naturae, introducing binomial nomenclature for animals and the term Homo sapiens.
Former slave turned rebel François Mackandal is executed by the French colonial government in Haiti.
Russian troops invade East Prussia and capture the city of Königsberg during the Seven Years' War.
Jonathan Edwards publicly receives a smallpox inoculation, which results in his death from the disease.
James Wolfe's attack at Louisbourg marks a significant moment in the French and Indian War.
Anglo-Hanoverian forces defeat the French at the Battle of Krefeld during the Seven Years' War.
French forces abandon Fort Duquesne to the British, leading to the establishment of Pittsburgh.
Halley's Comet appears for the first time, marking a significant astronomical event.
Austrian forces rout a convoy with supplies for the Prussian army at the Battle of Domstadtl.
J. R. Geigy, which would become Novartis, is founded, marking an advance in the pharmaceutical industry.

1759.summary: The British Museum opens at Montagu House in London after six years of development.
Voltaire's satire Candide is published simultaneously in five countries.
The first vascular surgery in history is performed by a Dr. Hallowell at Newcastle upon Tyne in England.
British troops go ashore on France's North American territory and begin the siege of Quebec City.

1759.event: Battle of the Plains of Abraham
1759.summary: Quebec falls to British forces, following General Wolfe's victory just outside the city.
Smeaton's Tower, John Smeaton’s Eddystone Lighthouse off the coast of South West England, is first illuminated.
The British fleet defeats a French fleet near the coast of Brittany, the decisive naval engagement of the Seven Years' War.
Alamgir II, the Mughal Emperor of India, is assassinated in a conspiracy orchestrated by his Prime Minister.
The Germantown Union School, America's oldest nonsectarian day school, is founded.
The Guinness Brewery is leased by Arthur Guinness in St. James's Gate, Dublin, Ireland, for the brewing of Guinness.

1760.summary: Afghan forces defeat the Marathas in a significant military engagement.
British general Sir Eyre Coote secures a victory over the French in India during the Seven Years' War.
A disastrous fire destroys 349 buildings, marking a notable event in the American colonies.
A significant slave rebellion in Jamaica leads to the death of many residents and rebels.
First use of a mathematical model to study population dynamics of infectious diseases.
A fierce clash between British and French forces around Quebec City in the Seven Years' War.
British troops under Jeffery Amherst capture Montreal, marking a critical point in Canadian history.

1760.event: George II of Great Britain dies
1760.summary: The death of George II leads to the ascension of his grandson, King George III.
Frederick the Great defeats Austrians in a significant battle, furthering his military reputation.

1760.event: Formation of the Institut National de Jeunes Sourds de Paris
1760.summary: The world's first free school for the deaf is established, leading to advancements in education.

1761.summary: In India, the armies of the Durrani Empire led by Ahmad Shah Durrani decisively defeat the Maratha Confederacy, regaining territory for the Mughal Empire.
The British Empire captures Pondichéry from the French colonial empire.
A transit of Venus occurs, observed from 120 locations around the Earth, leading to the discovery of Venus having an atmosphere.
A severe epidemic of influenza breaks out in London, affecting the majority of the population.
The first section of the Bridgewater Canal is opened for transportation of coal from local mines to Manchester.
The Parlement of Paris votes to close all colleges and seminaries associated with the Jesuit Order.

1761.event: Crowning of George III and Charlotte
1761.summary: George III and Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz are crowned, marking a significant moment in British history.
Slavery in Portugal is abolished, reflecting changing attitudes towards human rights and freedom.
The marine chronometer is invented, providing a means to accurately determine longitude at sea.

1761.event: Publication of Ah! vous dirai-je, maman
1761.summary: The music for Ah! vous dirai-je, maman is first published in France, influencing future musical works.

1762.summary: Britain declares war against Spain and Naples following their alliance with France.
Empress Elisabeth of Russia dies, and Peter III, who admires Frederick the Great, succeeds her and opens peace negotiations.
The Treaty of Saint Petersburg ends the war between Russia and Prussia, returning all of Russia's territorial gains to Prussia.
Catherine II becomes empress of Russia after planning the overthrow of her husband, Tsar Peter III.

1762.event: First Performance of Orfeo ed Euridice
1762.summary: Orfeo ed Euridice, composed by Christoph Willibald Gluck, is performed for the first time.
In the Treaty of Fontainebleau, Louis XV of France secretly cedes Louisiana to Charles III of Spain to compensate for territorial losses.
Catherine the Great announces that foreigners are welcome to settle in Russia and waives previous religious requirements.
Louis XV orders the construction of the Petit Trianon in the park of the Palace of Versailles for Madame de Pompadour.
Philosopher Jean-Jacques Rousseau's works, The Social Contract and Emile, are published and face severe censorship in Geneva and Paris.
The Battle of Havana concludes with the surrender of the city by Spain to Great Britain after two months of conflict.

1763.summary: The Treaty of Paris ends the Seven Years' War, France cedes Canada to Great Britain
The Treaty of Hubertusburg ends the war between Prussia and Austria
Théâtre du Palais-Royal, home to Paris Opera, is destroyed in a fire
Chief Pontiac begins Pontiac's War by attacking the British garrison at Fort Detroit
Catherine II endorses plans for a Foundling Home in Moscow
George III issues a proclamation restricting the westward expansion in British North America
The Mozart family grand tour of Europe begins, raising Wolfgang Amadeus's profile
The Berbice Slave Uprising starts in the former Dutch colony of Berbice
Bankruptcies lead to a financial crisis affecting merchants in Amsterdam and beyond

1764.summary: Hundreds of the Székely minority in Transylvania are massacred by the Austrian Army.
French explorer Anquetil Du Perron presents a complete copy of the Zoroastrian sacred text, the Zend Avesta, to the Bibliothèque Royale in Paris.
A treaty is signed between Great Britain and 44 North American Indian nations, ending ongoing hostilities with northern Indian tribes.
Eight-year-old child prodigy Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart performs a private concert before King George III and Queen Charlotte.
A mutual defense treaty between the Russian Empire and the Kingdom of Prussia is signed in Saint Petersburg.
Stanisław August Poniatowski is elected as the King of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
The British East India Company defeats the combined armies of Mir Qasim, Nawab of Bengal, Nawab of Awadh, and Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II.
Catherine the Great establishes the first secondary education school for females in Russia, targeting nobles.
Immanuel Kant publishes Observations on the Feeling of the Beautiful and Sublime, contributing to philosophical discourse.
The Quebec Gazette is established, becoming the oldest surviving newspaper in North America.

1765.event: Marriage of Prince Joseph and Princess Maria Josepha
1765.summary: Prince Joseph of Austria marries Princess Maria Josepha of Bavaria in Vienna

1765.event: Abolition of punishments for unmarried women
1765.summary: Frederick the Great issues a decree abolishing historic punishments against unmarried women in Germany
Judges in Paris posthumously exonerate Jean Calas after public campaign by Voltaire
The Duties in American Colonies Act 1765, known as the Stamp Act, is passed by Great Britain, imposing taxes on the American colonies
The Treaty of Allahabad is signed, marking the beginning of Company rule in India
Bostonians destroy the home of lieutenant governor Thomas Hutchinson in protest of the Stamp Act
James Watt receives inspiration for the development of the steam engine during a walk in Glasgow Green
The auto-da-fé parade is abolished in Lisbon, reducing violence against Jews or Christian heretics

1765.event: Foundation of the first restaurant in Paris
1765.summary: The first true restaurant opens in Paris, offering cooked dishes at an all-night venue

1765.event: Establishment of secondary education for females in Russia
1765.summary: Catherine the Great establishes the Novodevichii Institute for the daughters of commoners

1766.summary: Charles Edward Stuart becomes the new Stuart claimant to the throne of Great Britain, as King Charles III.
Christian VII becomes King of Denmark-Norway.
The siege of Ayutthaya continues as Burmese invaders confront Thai defenders, leading to the eventual fall of the city.
The British Parliament repeals the unpopular Stamp Act, following pressure from the colonies and Benjamin Franklin.
Henry Cavendish describes the production of inflammable air, leading to the eventual naming of hydrogen by Antoine Lavoisier.
The Theatre Royal in Bristol opens its doors, contributing to the cultural landscape of England.
Members of the Sons of Liberty erect a liberty pole in Manhattan as a protest symbol against British authority.
Crown Prince Gustav of Sweden marries Princess Sophia Magdalena of Denmark, leading to his eventual kingship.
Sweden passes a law that abolishes censorship and guarantees freedom of the press, becoming the first country to do so.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart returns home to Salzburg after his family's grand tour of Europe.

1767.summary: The first annual volume of The Nautical Almanac and Astronomical Ephemeris is published, helping navigators find longitude at sea.
Corsican soldiers conquer the island of Capraia after a ten-week campaign.
King Carlos III of Spain issues a decree expelling the Jesuits from the Spanish Empire.
Construction begins on Tryon Palace in New Bern, North Carolina, increasing local taxes and stirring resentment.
British Captain Samuel Wallis becomes the first European to visit Tahiti during HMS Dolphin's circumnavigation.
A fleet from Genoa attempts to retake Capraia but is quickly overwhelmed by the Corsican forces.
Dr. William Watson conducts the first controlled clinical trial at the Foundling Hospital in London.
The King's Council in France repeals several anti-Jewish regulations, improving conditions for Jewish merchants.
The surveying of the Mason-Dixon line is completed, establishing a division between northern and southern states.
Andrew Sprowle establishes the Gosport Shipyard in Virginia, laying the groundwork for future naval activities.

1768.summary: Philip Astley stages the first modern circus, with acrobats on galloping horses, in London

1768.event: Treaty turning Poland into a protectorate
1768.summary: With Russian troops occupying the nation, opposition legislators are deported and Poland signs a treaty turning the Commonwealth into a protectorate of the Russian Empire
A group of Polish nobles establishes the Bar Confederation to defend the independence of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth against Russian influence

1768.event: King Louis XV decrees house numbering
1768.summary: King Louis XV of France requires all cities and towns to post house numbering on residential buildings
John Wilkes is imprisoned for criticizing King George III, provoking protests and resulting in troops firing on a mob
The Liberty Song, the first American patriotic song, is published in the Boston Gazette

1768.event: James Cook departs on first voyage
1768.summary: James Cook departs from Plymouth aboard HMS Endeavour on his first voyage of discovery
The Royal Academy is founded in London, with Joshua Reynolds as its first President
The first weekly numbers of the Encyclopædia Britannica, edited by William Smellie, are published in Edinburgh

1768.event: King Prithvi Narayan Shah unifies kingdoms
1768.summary: King Prithvi Narayan Shah unifies several small kingdoms to establish modern-day Nepal

1769.summary: Pope Clement XIII dies while preparing an order to dissolve the Jesuits
James Watt is granted a British patent for a method of lessening the consumption of steam in steam engines, a key improvement stimulating the Industrial Revolution
A transit of Venus is observed, followed by a total solar eclipse viewed by King George III
A massive explosion in Brescia, Italy, caused by lightning striking a church, destroys a sixth of the city and kills 3000 people

1769.event: James Cook lands in New Zealand
1769.summary: James Cook lands at Poverty Bay, marking significant European exploration in New Zealand
Nicolas-Joseph Cugnot demonstrates a steam-powered artillery tractor in France
David Garrick holds a Shakespeare Jubilee festival at Stratford-upon-Avon

1769.event: End of the Malla dynasty in Nepal
1769.summary: The Gorkhali Army conquers Bhaktapur, marking the end of the Malla dynasty in Nepal
Dartmouth College is established in Hanover, New Hampshire through a charter from King George III
Massive droughts in Bengal lead to a famine resulting in the death of ten million people, one of the worst natural disasters

1770.summary: Eleven American men are shot by British troops, an event contributing to the start of the American Revolutionary War.
Captain Cook's crew becomes the first recorded Europeans to encounter the eastern coastline of Australia.
Joseph Banks discovers 30,000 specimens of plant life in the area during Cook's voyage, including many unknown to European science.
Lexell's Comet makes the closest recorded approach to Earth, influencing scientific observation.
The Russian Empire defeats the Ottoman Empire, affecting regional power dynamics significantly.
Phillis Wheatley becomes the first African American woman to have her work published, impacting literature and civil rights discourse.

1770.event: End of the Townshend Acts embargo
1770.summary: American colonists stop their embargo on British imports following the repeal of the Townshend Acts, facilitating trade.

1770.event: James Bruce discovers the Nile source
1770.summary: James Bruce believes he has found the source of the Nile, significant for exploration and geography.

1770.event: Marie Antoinette arrives at French court
1770.summary: Marie Antoinette's arrival at the French court marks the beginning of her influential yet controversial reign.
King Louis XV dismisses rebellious magistrates, indicating rising tensions within the French political system.

1771.summary: Led by Ubashi Khan, marking a significant population movement under Qing Dynasty rule.
Emperor Go-Momozono ascends the throne of Japan after his aunt's abdication.
Gustav III becomes King of Sweden following his father's death while abroad.
Quarantines initiated in Moscow and Saint Petersburg as a response to the plague epidemic.
Governance issues escalate in North Carolina leading to a decisive clash between Regulators and Governor's forces.

1771.event: Society of Gentlemen Supporters of the Bill of Rights Meeting
1771.summary: Group convenes in London, promoting a reform agenda for British parliamentary reform.
Cook's expedition concludes, promoting maritime exploration and discovery.
Wolfgang Mozart's opera premieres in Milan, showcasing early classical music advancements.
An outbreak of bubonic plague leads to civil unrest in Moscow, resulting in significant fatalities.
Legal proceedings begin against the backdrop of slavery in Great Britain, paving the way for future reforms.

1772.summary: The First Partition of Poland is agreed to by Russia and Prussia, later including Austria.
Lord Mansfield delivers the decision that leads to the end of slavery in England.

1772.event: Coup d'état by King Gustav III
1772.summary: A coup d'état by King Gustav III is completed by adopting a new Constitution, ending half a century of parliamentary rule in Sweden.
American patriots attack and burn the British customs schooner HMS Gaspee off Rhode Island.
Samuel Adams persuades colleagues to create a Committee of Correspondence for dialogue with other American colonies.
Yves-Joseph de Kerguelen-Trémarec discovers the uninhabited Kerguelen Islands in the Southern Indian Ocean.
The second voyage of James Cook departs from Plymouth on HMS Resolution to explore further south.
Scottish scientist Daniel Rutherford discovers nitrogen gas, isolating it from air.
First of two Russian occupations of Beirut during the Russo-Turkish War.
Russian government offices reopen in Moscow and Saint Petersburg after being closed for 15 months due to an epidemic.

1773.summary: The hymn that becomes known as Amazing Grace is first used to accompany a sermon led by curate John Newton.
The first opera performance in the Swedish language, Thetis and Phelée, takes place, marking the establishment of the Royal Swedish Opera.
The Grand Council of Poland meets in Warsaw to respond to the Kingdom's threatened partition between three foreign powers.

1773.event: Establishment of the first education ministry
1773.summary: The Komisja Edukacji Narodowej is formed in the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, considered the world's first ministry of education.
A group of American colonists, dressed as Mohawk Indians, dump tea into Boston Harbor in protest against British tax policies.
America's first insane asylum opens for Persons of Insane and Disordered Minds in Williamsburg, Virginia.
French astronomer Charles Messier discovers the Whirlpool Galaxy, located approximately 31 million light-years away.

1773.event: Founding of Moscow State Academy of Choreography
1773.summary: Moscow State Academy of Choreography is founded, becoming the second ballet school in Russia.
John Harrison wins the Longitude prize for his invention of the marine chronometer.

1773.event: Formation of first comprehensive engineering university
1773.summary: Istanbul Technical University is established as the world's first comprehensive institution of higher learning dedicated to engineering education.

1774.summary: Mustafa III, Sultan of the Ottoman Empire, dies and is succeeded by his brother Abdul Hamid I.
British industrialist John Wilkinson patents a method for boring cannon from the solid, impacting steam engine technology.
The premiere of Iphigénie en Aulide by Christoph Willibald Gluck sparks a huge controversy in Paris.
Russia and the Ottoman Empire sign the Treaty of Küçük Kaynarca, ending the Russo-Turkish War.
The element oxygen is discovered for the third time by Joseph Priestley, contributing to advancements in chemistry.
The First Continental Congress assembles in Philadelphia to coordinate resistance against British rule.
The Continental Congress adopts the Declaration of Rights and Resolves, outlining colonial grievances against Britain.
The First Continental Congress passes the Continental Association, promoting a boycott of British goods.

1774.event: Publication of The Sorrows of Young Werther
1774.summary: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe's novel The Sorrows of Young Werther is published, influencing Romanticism.
Archduchess Maria Theresa signs the General School Ordinance, establishing compulsory education for children.

1775.summary: The American Revolutionary War begins with the first military engagement on April 19. Continental Congress takes significant organizational steps.
James Watt builds a successful prototype of a steam engine, marking a significant advance in technology and industry.

1775.event: Declaration of the Causes and Necessity of Taking Up Arms
1775.summary: The Continental Congress issues a declaration stating the causes of taking up arms against British rule.
British forces are victorious at the Battle of Bunker Hill, suffering severe casualties and demonstrating the resolve of the colonial forces.
The Second Continental Congress meets, raises the Continental Army under George Washington, and authorizes colonies to adopt their own constitutions.
