Edward Jenner develops the smallpox vaccine, an important advancement in public health.
The Independence Hurricane devastates the east coast of North America, killing over 4,000 and affecting many communities.
The Continental Congress orders the establishment of the Continental Navy, crucial for American naval operations in the Revolutionary War.
The coronation of Louis XVI takes place, marking a significant event in the lead-up to the French Revolution.
The city of Kuopio in Finland is founded by King Gustav III of Sweden, contributing to regional development.

1776.event: Publication of The Wealth of Nations
1776.summary: Scottish economist Adam Smith publishes The Wealth of Nations in London, laying the foundations for modern economics.
Thomas Paine publishes his pamphlet Common Sense, advocating for independence from British rule in the Thirteen Colonies.
The Continental Congress ratifies the United States Declaration of Independence from the Kingdom of Great Britain.
Mozart's Serenade No. 7 (the Haffner) is first performed in Salzburg, Austria, showcasing his growing reputation as a composer.
The first Hessian troops land on Staten Island, adding to the British forces during the American Revolutionary War.
Washington's troops surprise and defeat Hessian forces in Trenton, a pivotal victory for the Americans during the Revolutionary War.

1776.event: Foundation of the Phi Beta Kappa Society
1776.summary: The Phi Beta Kappa Society, the oldest academic honor society in the United States, is founded at the College of William & Mary.
Adam Weishaupt founds the Illuminati in Ingolstadt, Bavaria, aiming to promote Enlightenment ideals and rationalism.
The American submersible craft Turtle attempts the world's first submarine attack on British Admiral Richard Howe's flagship.
The Bolshoi Ballet is founded in Moscow, Russia, becoming a significant institution in the world of ballet and performing arts.

1777.summary: American general George Washington's army repulses a British attack in New Jersey.
American general George Washington's army defeats British troops in a key victory.
Vermont declares its independence from New York, becoming an independent country.

1777.event: Maria I becomes Queen of Portugal
1777.summary: King Joseph I of Portugal dies, succeeded by Maria I and Peter III.
The Continental Congress adopts the Stars and Stripes as the flag of the United States.
The second edition of Encyclopædia Britannica begins publication in Edinburgh.
British General John Burgoyne surrenders to American troops, marking a turning point in the war.
The Continental Congress approves the Articles of Confederation after 16 months of debate.
The United States celebrates its first Thanksgiving after the victory at Saratoga.
Kunsthochschule Kassel is founded in Germany as a fine arts academy.

1778.summary: Captain James Cook first views Oʻahu then Kauaʻi in the Hawaiian Islands, naming them the Sandwich Islands.
The United States and France sign treaties signaling French recognition of the new American republic.
Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben arrives at Valley Forge to train American troops during the Revolutionary War.
George Washington's Continental Army battles British general Sir Henry Clinton's army to a draw near Monmouth County, New Jersey.
The La Scala Opera House opens in Milan with the première of Antonio Salieri's Europa riconosciuta.
Louis XVI of France declares war on the Kingdom of Great Britain during the Revolutionary War.
British forces capture the city of Savannah, Georgia during the American Revolutionary War.
British forces and their Iroquois allies attack Cherry Valley, killing both soldiers and civilians.
British and French fleets fight to a standoff in the first Battle of Ushant during the American Revolutionary War.
The Massachusetts Banishment Act, providing punishment for Loyalists, is passed.

1779.event: British troops surrender to the Marathas
1779.summary: British troops surrender to the Marathas in Wadgaon, India, and are forced to return all territories acquired since 1773
Captain James Cook is killed on the Sandwich Islands, on his third voyage
In support of France, Spain declares war on Britain

1779.event: King Charles III of Spain issues declaration of war
1779.summary: King Charles III of Spain issues a declaration of war against Great Britain
The Goshen Militia is destroyed by Joseph Brant's forces in the Battle of Minisink
United States forces, led by General Anthony Wayne, capture Stony Point, New York from British troops
The American ship Bonhomme Richard engages the British ship HMS Serapis and wins
The Treaty of Aynalıkavak is signed between Ottoman Turkey and the Russian Empire regarding the Crimean Khanate
The Iron Bridge is erected across the River Severn, the world's first bridge built entirely of cast iron
Lieutenant Colonel Francisco Bouligny arrives with colonists to establish the city of New Iberia, Louisiana

1780.summary: British Admiral Sir George Rodney defeats a Spanish fleet

1780.event: Formation of the First League of Armed Neutrality
1780.summary: Russia forms an alliance with Denmark and Sweden to protect neutral vessels from British search

1780.event: Foundation of the University of Münster
1780.summary: The University of Münster is founded in Germany

1780.event: Publication of the First Sunday Newspaper
1780.summary: The British Gazette and Sunday Monitor begins publication
An anti-Catholic mob riots, leading to significant casualties and arrests

1780.event: Arrival of French Soldiers in Newport
1780.summary: French soldiers arrive to reinforce American colonists during the Revolutionary War
British forces take control of Charleston, South Carolina
Patriot militia forces defeat Loyalists in South Carolina
Maria Theresa of Austria dies after 40 years of rule, passing her dominions to Joseph II
The Great Hurricane flattens the islands of Barbados, Martinique, and Sint Eustatius

1781.summary: The Iron Bridge opens across the River Severn in England, marking a significant advance in engineering and construction.
Sir William Herschel discovers the planet Uranus, expanding knowledge of the solar system.
Maryland becomes the 13th state to ratify the Articles of Confederation, establishing a formal union.
The American and French troops begin a siege of the British at Yorktown, Virginia, signaling a turning point in the American Revolutionary War.
General Charles Cornwallis surrenders to General George Washington at Yorktown, effectively ending the American Revolutionary War.
A Patent of Toleration is approved in the Habsburg monarchy, allowing limited freedom of worship.
The first bagpipes competition is held in the Masonic Arms, Falkirk, Scotland, celebrating traditional music.
Phillips Exeter Academy is founded in New Hampshire, contributing to educational advancement.
Carl Wilhelm Scheele discovers tungsten, marking an important advancement in chemistry and materials.

1781.event: Immanuel Kant Publishes Critique of Pure Reason
1781.summary: Immanuel Kant publishes his influential work Critique of Pure Reason, impacting philosophy and thought.

1782.summary: The first American commercial bank opens, marking a significant development in the financial system.
Superintendent of Finance Robert Morris recommends the establishment of a national mint and decimal coinage.
A British fleet defeats a French fleet in the West Indies, influencing naval power dynamics.
John Adams secures recognition of the United States as an independent government by the Dutch Republic.

1782.event: Repeal of Act for Securing Dependence of Ireland
1782.summary: The Parliament of Great Britain passes a major reform restoring legislative independence to the Parliament of Ireland.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's opera Die Entführung aus dem Serail premieres at the Burgtheater.
Representatives from the United States and Great Britain sign preliminary peace articles in Paris.
The Montgolfier brothers successfully test fly a hot air balloon in France for the first time.
In Switzerland, Anna Göldi is sentenced to death for witchcraft, marking the last legal witchcraft sentence.

1782.event: Foundation of the first theater in the Baltic
1782.summary: The first theater in the Baltic, the Riga City Theater, is founded, contributing to cultural life.

1783.summary: Treaty between the United States and Great Britain is signed, formally ending the American Revolutionary War and recognizing the independence of the United States

1783.event: Montgolfier brothers' hot air balloon demonstration
1783.summary: The Montgolfier brothers publicly demonstrate their hot air balloon, marking a major advancement in flight technology
Mozart's Great Mass is first performed, showcasing significant progress in musical composition

1783.event: First untethered hot air balloon flight
1783.summary: Jean-François Pilâtre de Rozier and François Laurent make the first untethered flight in a hydrogen-filled balloon
The Great Siege of Gibraltar is abandoned, affecting British naval strategy in the region

1783.event: Declaration of independence of the United States
1783.summary: Great Britain acknowledges the independence of the United States, impacting international relations in Europe

1783.event: End of the American Revolutionary War ratified
1783.summary: Preliminary articles of peace ending the American Revolutionary War are ratified by the Congress of the Confederation

1783.event: First manned flight in a hydrogen balloon
1783.summary: Jacques Charles and Nicolas-Louis Robert make the first manned flight in a hydrogen-filled gas balloon
George Washington resigns his commission as commander-in-chief, solidifying civilian control of the military
A sequence of earthquakes strikes Calabria, Italy, resulting in significant loss of life and impacting the region

1784.summary: The Ottoman Empire agrees to Russia's annexation of the Crimea.
The Congress of the United States ratifies the Treaty of Paris with Great Britain to end the American Revolution.
Henry Cavendish's paper reveals the composition of water.
The Marriage of Figaro premieres at the Comédie-Française in Paris.
Élisabeth Thible becomes the first woman to ascend in a hot-air balloon.
Parliament of Great Britain passes the East India Company's regulatory act.
The Robert brothers fly more than 100 km from Paris, setting a record for distance.
John Michell first posits the phenomenon of black holes in a scientific paper.
A 1-day action occurs where a Dutch ship repels forces of the Holy Roman Empire.
Immanuel Kant's essay Answering the Question: What Is Enlightenment? is published.

1785.summary: The first issue of the Daily Universal Register, later known as The Times, is published in London
Jean-Pierre Blanchard and John Jeffries travel from Dover to Calais in a hydrogen gas balloon, becoming the first to cross the English Channel by air
James Hutton presents his landmark work, Theory of the Earth, to the Royal Society of Edinburgh

1785.event: Establishment of the University of Georgia
1785.summary: The University of Georgia is chartered, marking a significant advance in education
A hot air balloon crashes in Tullamore, Ireland, causing the world's first aviation disaster
The Piper-Heidsieck Champagne house is founded in Reims, marking a major event in beverage production
The first newspaper in British India, the English-language Madras Courier, is published

1785.event: Signing of the Treaty of Hopewell
1785.summary: The Treaty of Hopewell is signed between the United States and the Cherokee Nation

1785.event: Introduction of Coal Gas for Illumination
1785.summary: Coal gas is first used for illumination, initiating a major technological advance
Mozart's 'Haydn' String Quartets are published, showcasing his major contributions to music

1786.summary: The third Treaty of Hopewell is signed, between the United States and the Choctaw.
The outward bound East Indiaman Halsewell is wrecked on the south coast of England in a storm, with only 74 of more than 240 on board surviving.

In a speech before The Asiatic Society in Calcutta, Sir William Jones notes the formal resemblances between Latin, Greek, and Sanskrit, laying the foundation for comparative linguistics and Indo-European studies.
Construction begins in Dublin on the Four Courts Building, with the first stone laid down by the United Kingdom's Viceroy for Ireland.
Mozart's opera The Marriage of Figaro premieres in Vienna.
An earthquake-caused landslide dam on the Dadu River gives way, killing 100,000 in the Sichuan province of China.
The 'Kilmarnock volume' of Robert Burns' Poems, Chiefly in the Scottish Dialect is published in Scotland.
Caroline Herschel discovers a comet, the first discovered by a woman, from England.
The oldest musical organization in the United States, the Stoughton Musical Society, is founded.
Peter Leopold Joseph of Habsburg-Lorraine promulgates a penal reform, making his country the first state to abolish the death penalty.

1787.summary: William Herschel discovers Titania and Oberon, two moons of Uranus.
Mozart's Symphony No. 38 is premièred in Prague.
Delegates begin to convene the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia, intended to amend the Articles of Confederation.
The first of The Federalist Papers is published in New York, calling for ratification of the U.S. Constitution.
The United States Constitution is signed by the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia.
Mozart's opera Don Giovanni premieres in the Estates Theatre in Prague.
The Treaty of Versailles is signed, forming an alliance between France and the future Emperor of Vietnam.
James Rumsey demonstrates his water-jet propelled boat on the Potomac River.
The first secondary education school open to girls in Sweden, Societetsskolan, is founded in Gothenburg.

1787.event: Abolition of the Slave Trade Society founded
1787.summary: Thomas Clarkson and Granville Sharp found the Society for Effecting the Abolition of the Slave Trade in Britain.

1788.summary: The first edition of The Times, previously The Daily Universal Register, is published in London
The British prison colony of New South Wales is established at Sydney Cove, marking the first permanent European settlement in Australia
Isaac Briggs and William Longstreet patent a steamboat
America's first recorded riot, the 'Doctors' Mob', begins in Manhattan

1788.event: Founding of the Royal Dramatic Theatre
1788.summary: Sweden's national drama company, the Royal Dramatic Theatre, is founded
The Day of the Tiles occurs in France, signaling the beginning of the French Revolution

1788.event: Completion of Music Composition by Mozart
1788.summary: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart completes his antepenultimate symphony, Symphony No. 39 in E-flat, in Vienna
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart completes his penultimate symphony, Symphony No. 40 in G Minor, in Vienna
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart completes his final symphony, Symphony No. 41 in C Major, in Vienna

1788.event: King George III's Mental Illness Revealed
1788.summary: The Houses of Parliament receive the first formal report regarding the mental illness of King George III

1789.summary: Citizens of Paris storm the fortress of the Bastille, and free the only seven prisoners held. In rural areas, peasants attack the manors of the nobility.
The 1st United States Congress meets and declares the new United States Constitution to be in effect, replacing the old government system.
George Washington is inaugurated at Federal Hall in New York City, beginning his term as the first president of the United States.
In France, the Estates-General convenes for the first time in 175 years, taken as the start of the French Revolution.

1789.event: Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen
1789.summary: The Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen is proclaimed in France by the Constituent Assembly.

1789.event: Establishment of the United States Bill of Rights
1789.summary: The United States Congress proposes a set of 12 amendments to the U.S. Constitution, which later becomes the Bill of Rights.

1789.event: Adoption of the Union and Security Act
1789.summary: King Gustav III of Sweden enforces the Union and Security Act, ending Sweden's parliamentarian system in favor of an absolute monarchy.
Fletcher Christian leads the mutiny on the British Royal Navy ship HMS Bounty against Captain William Bligh in the Pacific Ocean.
Approximately 7,000 women march from Paris to the royal Palace of Versailles to demand action regarding high bread prices.
The Venetian arsenal on the island of Corfu explodes during a fire, resulting in significant casualties and destruction.

1790.summary: Mozart's opera Così fan tutte premieres in Vienna

1790.event: Establishment of United States patent system
1790.summary: The United States patent system is established

1790.event: Ratification of the United States Constitution by Rhode Island
1790.summary: Rhode Island ratifies the United States Constitution, becoming the last of the original states to do so
Louis XVI of France accepts a constitutional monarchy

1790.event: Completion of the Civil Constitution of the Clergy
1790.summary: The Civil Constitution of the Clergy is passed, completing the destruction of the monastic orders in France
The first United States Census is authorized

1790.event: Creation of the District of Columbia
1790.summary: The U.S. House of Representatives votes to approve creating the District of Columbia

1790.event: Rebellion of freed blacks in Saint-Domingue
1790.summary: Vincent Ogé leads a rebellion of freed blacks in Saint-Domingue, which is suppressed

1790.event: Introduction of Anhui opera to Beijing
1790.summary: The Peking Opera is born when the Four Great Anhui Troupes introduce Anhui opera to Beijing
The Treaty of Värälä ends the Russo-Swedish War

1791.summary: Austrian composer Joseph Haydn arrives in England to perform a series of concerts.

1791.event: Bank of the United States Incorporation
1791.summary: The Bank of the United States is incorporated by the federal government with a 20-year charter.
The abolition of guilds is enacted during the French Revolution.

1791.event: Introduction of the Metric System in France
1791.summary: The National Constituent Assembly accepts the recommendation to adopt the metric system.

1791.event: First Modern Codified Constitution in Europe
1791.summary: The Constitution of May 3, 1791 is proclaimed in the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
The Champ de Mars massacre occurs in Paris during the French Revolution.
John Fitch is granted a patent for the steamboat in the United States.

1791.event: Mozart's La clemenza di Tito Premiere
1791.summary: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's opera, La clemenza di Tito, premières in Prague.
Mozart's singspiel opera The Magic Flute premières in Vienna.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart dies in Vienna at the age of 35.

1792.summary: The Treaty of Jassy ends the Russian Empire's war with the Ottoman Empire over Crimea.
King Gustav III of Sweden is shot at a midnight masquerade and later dies from his wounds.
France declares war against Austria, marking the start of the French Revolutionary Wars.
La Marseillaise, the French national anthem, is composed by Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle.
A Proclamation of the abolition of the monarchy leads to the establishment of the French First Republic.
The French revolutionary army defeats the Prussians after a significant artillery duel.
The cornerstone of the United States Executive Mansion, later known as the White House, is laid.
The trial of Louis XVI of France begins, marking a crucial point in the French Revolution.
George Washington is re-elected as president of the United States in the second presidential election.
Claude Chappe successfully demonstrates the first semaphore line, facilitating long-distance communication.

1793.summary: Citizen Capet, Louis XVI of France, is guillotined in Paris after being found guilty of treason.
The French First Republic declares war on Great Britain, the Dutch Republic, and Spain.

1793.event: Establishment of the Committee of Public Safety
1793.summary: The Committee of Public Safety is established in France, leading to significant political changes.
The Girondins are overthrown in France, marking a major shift in the revolutionary government.
The Louvre in Paris opens to the public as an art museum, signifying a cultural milestone.
Marie Antoinette is guillotined in Paris following her trial, impacting public sentiment in France.

1793.event: Introduction of the French Republican Calendar
1793.summary: The French Republican Calendar is adopted by the National Convention, altering timekeeping in France.
French Republican troops and black slave insurgents defeat Royalist settlers in the Haitian Revolution.

1793.event: Celebration of the Goddess of Reason
1793.summary: The dechristianization of France peaks with the celebration of the Goddess of Reason in Notre Dame.
Niccolò Paganini debuts as a violin virtuoso at age 11, influencing the music scene in Europe.

1794.summary: The National Convention of the French First Republic abolishes slavery

1794.event: Establishment of the Cult of the Supreme Being
1794.summary: Robespierre establishes the Cult of the Supreme Being as the new state religion of the French First Republic

1794.event: First Recorded Meeting of Franklin Literary Society
1794.summary: The first recorded meeting of the Franklin Literary Society is held at Canonsburg Academy
Bowdoin College is founded in Brunswick, Maine
French forces defeat the Austrians and their allies at the Battle of Fleurus, marking the first use of an observation balloon in battle
The United States and Great Britain sign the Jay Treaty to resolve issues from the American Revolutionary War and secure peaceful trade
The Kościuszko Uprising ends in the defeat of Tadeusz Kościuszko and his forces

1794.event: Inauguration of Public Sessions in the U.S. Senate
1794.summary: The U.S. Senate passes a rule ending its policy of closing all of its sessions to the public
Eli Whitney is granted a United States patent for the cotton gin, a significant technological advance in agriculture

1795.summary: Map indicates the political end of the Mogul dynasty in India.
Central England records its coldest ever month, in the CET records dating back to 1659.
The University of North Carolina opens to students at Chapel Hill, becoming the first state university in the United States.
The Batavian Republic is proclaimed in Amsterdam, ending the Dutch Republic.
Ludwig van Beethoven makes his public debut in Vienna performing his Second Piano Concerto under the baton of his teacher Antonio Salieri.
The metric system is adopted in France.
Louis XVII, Prince Royal and titular King of France, dies in captivity in the Temple in Paris.
Construction of the Pontcysyllte Aqueduct in Wales begins.
The signing of the Treaty of Greenville puts an end to the Northwest Indian War.
The Third Partition of Poland is made, dividing the territory of the Commonwealth of Poland between the Habsburg monarchy, Prussia, and the Russian Empire.

1796.summary: The first Dutch elections are held for the National Assembly of the Batavian Republic
The Qianlong Emperor of China abdicates to make way for his son, the Jiaqing Emperor
Ratifications of the Jay Treaty between Great Britain and the United States are officially exchanged
Napoleon Bonaparte gains his first victory as an army commander in the Battle of Montenotte
Napoleon Bonaparte defeats the Austrian rearguard in the Battle of Lodi
Edward Jenner administers the first smallpox vaccination in England
Napoleon fights a pitched battle at La Favorita, leading to the siege of Mantua
Catherine the Great dies and is succeeded by her son Paul I of Russia
French forces under Napoleon defeat the Austrians at the Battle of Arcole
Robert Burns's version of the Scots poem Auld Lang Syne is first published

1797.summary: A peace treaty between the United States and Ottoman Tripolitania is signed.
The parliament of the Cisalpine Republic adopts the Italian green-white-red tricolour as their official flag.
French forces under Napoleon Bonaparte defeat an Austrian army near Rivoli, ending Austria's final attempt to relieve Mantua.

1797.event: Gott erhalte Franz den Kaiser is performed
1797.summary: Joseph Haydn's composition premieres, which will later become the German national anthem.
Napoleon Bonaparte conquers Venice, ending its 1,100 years of independence and opening the Venetian Ghetto.
The first ship of the United States Navy, the frigate USS United States, is commissioned.
André-Jacques Garnerin makes the first parachute descent using a silk parachute from a hot air balloon.
The British Royal Navy defeats the fleet of the Batavian Republic off the coast of Holland.
The Treaty of Campo Formio is signed, ending the War of the First Coalition.
Joseph-Louis Lagrange publishes his treatise on differential calculus, influencing mathematical thought.

1798.summary: The Pope is taken captive and the Papacy is removed from power by French General Louis-Alexandre Berthier.
The Irish Rebellion of 1798 begins with the arrest of the leadership of the Society of United Irishmen, aiming to unify Catholics and Protestants.

1798.event: Establishment of the US Department of the Navy
1798.summary: The United States Department of the Navy is established as a cabinet-level department, marking a significant advancement in naval organization.
The United States Congress rescinds treaties with France, leading to the Quasi-War, impacting international relations significantly.
Napoleon defeats Ottoman forces near the Pyramids, establishing French dominance in Egypt.
Lyrical Ballads is published by Samuel Taylor Coleridge and William Wordsworth, marking the start of the English Romantic movement in literature.
French troops land in County Mayo to assist the Irish Rebellion, showcasing European involvement in Irish affairs.
The Sedition Act of 1798 is signed into law in the United States, making it a federal crime to make false statements about the government.
Edward Jenner publishes his work describing the smallpox vaccine, representing a major advance in medical science.
Alois Senefelder invents lithography, a new printing technology that would impact the production of music and art.

1799.summary: British Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduces an income tax of two shillings to the pound to raise funds for Great Britain's war effort.
The Parthenopean Republic is established in Naples by French General Jean Étienne Championnet, leading to King Ferdinand I's flight.

1799.event: Public Premiere of Haydn's The Creation
1799.summary: The public premiere of Haydn's oratorio The Creation takes place at the Burgtheater in Vienna.
Napoleon captures Jaffa in Palestine from the Ottomans, resulting in the execution of Albanian captives.
Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies is restored to his kingdom following the collapse of the Parthenopean Republic.
Jeanne Geneviève Labrosse becomes the first woman to jump from a balloon with a parachute, marking a significant achievement in aeronautics.
Napoleon overthrows the French Directory in a coup d'état, which effectively ends the French Revolution.

1799.event: Abolishment of the Constitution of the Year III
1799.summary: A remnant of the Council of Ancients abolishes the Constitution of the Year III, establishing the French Consulate.
France adopts the metre as its official unit of length, impacting measurement standards across Europe.
George Washington, the first President of the United States, dies at Mount Vernon, impacting American politics and society.

1800.summary: Infrared radiation is discovered by astronomer Sir William Herschel.
Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No. 1 premieres at the Burgtheater.
Alessandro Volta describes his new invention, the voltaic pile, the first chemical battery.

1800.event: Foundation of the U.S. Library of Congress
1800.summary: The U.S. Library of Congress is founded in Washington, D.C.
The French army is evacuated from Genoa after a siege.
Napoleon defeats the Austrian troops near Marengo, Italy.
The Convention of 1800 is signed between France and the United States, ending the Quasi-War.
King George III gives royal assent to the second Act of Union, uniting Great Britain and Ireland.
The French army defeats Habsburg and Bavarian troops at the Battle of Hohenlinden.

1800.event: First President in the White House
1800.summary: John Adams becomes the first U.S. President to live in the Executive Mansion, later known as the White House.

1801.summary: The legislative union of Great Britain and Ireland is completed, forming the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and abolishing the Parliament of Ireland.
The Treaty ends the War of the Second Coalition, with France annexing German territories and Austria recognizing several republics.
Thomas Jefferson is sworn in as the third President of the United States, marking a significant political transition.
The first census is held, revealing a population of 8.9 million in England and Wales, with significant urbanization.
Tsar Paul I of Russia is murdered and succeeded by his son Alexander I, impacting Russian politics.
Jacquard exhibits a loom that uses punched cards to control weaving, pioneering a significant technical advancement.
The Treaty is signed between the French First Republic and the United Kingdom, laying groundwork for preliminary peace.
Cornish engineers demonstrate the first steam-powered road locomotive, marking a key development in transportation technology.
Carl Friedrich Gauss publishes his groundbreaking work in number theory, influencing mathematics profoundly.
Johann Wilhelm Ritter discovers ultraviolet radiation, opening new fields in science that may influence art and music.

1802.summary: Thomas Bruce, 7th Earl of Elgin, begins removal of the Elgin Marbles from the Parthenon in Athens, claiming they were at risk of destruction.
Ludwig van Beethoven publishes his Piano Sonata No. 14, commonly known as the Moonlight Sonata, in Vienna.
The Rosetta Stone is brought to England by Colonel Tomkyns Hilgrove Turner after being captured from the French.
The Treaty of Amiens is signed, ending the War of the Second Coalition and the French Revolutionary Wars.
The United States Patent and Trademark Office is established within the Department of State.

1802.event: Establishment of French Legion of Honour
1802.summary: Napoleon establishes the French Legion of Honour as a new military honor.
By law, Napoleon reinstates slavery in the French colonies, revoking its abolition from the French Revolution.

1802.event: Beginning of Great Trigonometrical Survey of India
1802.summary: The Great Trigonometrical Survey of India begins with the measurement of a baseline near Madras.
The first account of Thomas Wedgwood's experiments in photography is published in London.

1802.event: Health and Morals of Apprentices Act
1802.summary: The Health and Morals of Apprentices Act comes into effect in the United Kingdom, regulating child labour conditions.

1803.summary: The first edition of the first guide to restaurant cooking is published in Paris.
William Symington demonstrates his Charlotte Dundas, the first practical steamboat, in Scotland.
The Louisiana Purchase is completed as the French prefect formally transfers ownership of land to the United States.
The United Kingdom declares war on France, initiating the Napoleonic Wars.
The Supreme Court of the United States establishes the principle of judicial review in Marbury v. Madison.
The franc germinal is introduced in France, representing a significant monetary reform.
The Convention of Artlenburg agrees on a ceasefire following the French Invasion of Hanover.
The wagonway between Wandsworth and Croydon is opened, being the first public railway line in England.
The Haitian army defeats the French army at the Battle of Vertières, impacting colonial power dynamics.
The Balmis Expedition starts in Spain to vaccinate millions against smallpox in Spanish America.

1804.summary: Haiti gains independence from France, becoming the first black republic with a successful slave revolt.
The First Serbian uprising begins, leading to Serbia proclaiming self-rule from the Ottoman Empire by 1817.
Richard Trevithick's Penydarren steam locomotive operates on rails, marking a significant advancement in transportation.
Napoleon crowns himself as the first Emperor of the French in a thousand years at Notre Dame Cathedral.
Beethoven's Symphony No. 3 in E–flat is premiered in Vienna, showcasing a major work in classical music.
The Napoleonic Code is adopted, establishing a uniform legal framework in France.
The Lewis and Clark Expedition departs to explore the Louisiana Purchase, marking a significant exploration of the American West.
Smithson Tennant announces the discovery of the elements iridium and osmium, contributing to advancements in chemistry.
The Treaty of St. Louis is signed, affecting indigenous alliances and future conflicts in North America.
The global population reaches 1 billion people, a significant milestone in human history.

1805.summary: Beethoven's Symphony No. 3, Eroica, has its public premiere at the Theater an der Wien in Vienna under his baton.
Beethoven's only opera Fidelio, in its original form, is premiered at the Theater an der Wien in Vienna, which is under French military occupation.
The British fleet, led by Admiral Horatio Nelson, defeats a combined French and Spanish fleet off the coast of Spain; however, Admiral Nelson is fatally shot.
Austrian General Mack von Leiberich is forced to surrender his entire army to Napoleon after being surrounded.
Napoleon is crowned King of Italy.
The Peace of Pressburg between France and Austria is signed in the Primate's Palace.
French troops under Napoleon decisively defeat a joint Russo-Austrian force.
The first Trooping the Colour ceremony is held at the Horse Guards Parade in London.
The Harmony Society is officially formed as a Christian community in Harmony, Pennsylvania.

1805.event: Establishment of Public Education in Canada
1805.summary: The New Brunswick Legislature passes a bill to advance literacy in the province, contributing to the creation of public education in Canada.

1806.event: Abolishment of the French Republican Calendar
1806.summary: The French Republican Calendar is abolished.

1806.event: Formation of the Kingdom of Bavaria
1806.summary: The Kingdom of Bavaria is established by Napoleon.
The Dutch Cape Colony capitulates to British forces, becoming a British colony.
The British Royal Navy gains a victory over the French off Santo Domingo.
Washington College is chartered by the Pennsylvania General Assembly.

1806.event: Formation of the Confederation of the Rhine
1806.summary: Sixteen German Imperial States leave the Holy Roman Empire to form the Confederation of the Rhine.
Francis II, the last Holy Roman Emperor, abdicates, ending the Holy Roman Empire.

1806.event: Napoleon's War of the Fourth Coalition
1806.summary: Napoleon begins the War of the Fourth Coalition against Prussia and its allies.
Napoleon declares the Continental Blockade against the British, blocking British goods to Europe.
Ludwig van Beethoven premieres his violin concerto at the Theater an der Wien.

1807.event: British ships prohibited from trading with France
1807.summary: The United Kingdom issues an Order in Council prohibiting British ships from trading with France or its allies
Napoleon fights a hard but inconclusive battle against the Russians at Eylau
The Slave Trade Act is passed in the House of Commons by an overwhelming majority

1807.event: Abolition of slave trade in British Empire
1807.summary: The United Kingdom Slave Trade Act becomes law abolishing the slave trade in most of the British Empire
H. W. Olbers discovers the asteroid Vesta
Napoleon decisively defeats the Russian army at the Battle of Friedland
Robert Fulton inaugurates the first commercial steamboat service with the North River Steamboat

1807.event: Beethoven's Mass in C major premiered
1807.summary: Beethoven's Mass in C major, Op. 86, is premiered, displeasing Prince Esterházy
The Geological Society of London is founded
France issues the Milan Decree which confirms the Continental System, restricting trade with the United Kingdom

1808.event: Slave trade abolished in UK colonies
1808.summary: The slave trade is abolished by the United Kingdom in all of its colonies as the Slave Trade Act 1807 takes effect

1808.event: Transfer of Portuguese court to Brazil
1808.summary: The Portuguese royal court arrives in Rio de Janeiro, making it the centre of the Portuguese Empire
Ludwig van Beethoven conducts and plays piano in a marathon benefit concert, consisting entirely of first public performances of works by him

1808.event: Abolition of slave importation in the US
1808.summary: The importation of slaves into the United States is banned, taking effect on January 1
Banco do Brasil, a major financial group in South America, is founded in Rio de Janeiro

1808.event: Fichte publishes Addresses to the German Nation
1808.summary: Prussian philosopher Johann Gottlieb Fichte publishes his work addressing the German nation

1808.event: Establishment of the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Munich
1808.summary: The Academy of Fine Arts in Munich is given the title of Royal Academy of Fine Arts by King Maximilian I Joseph of Bavaria
A volcano erupts in the western Pacific causing a localized drop in marine air temperatures
Humphry Davy electrochemically isolates potassium from potash
The people of Madrid rise up against the French troops during the Peninsular War

1809.summary: The Siege of Zaragoza ends with the surrender of Jose Palafox; over 60,000 killed
British forces resist French attempts to prevent their embarkation; General Moore killed
Napoleon defeats the Austrians in a significant battle
The famous composer Joseph Haydn dies in Vienna at age 77
Peace of Hamina signed between Russia and Sweden; Finland ceded to Russia
A military coup ousts Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden
French troops arrest Pope Pius VII and take him to Liguria
Sir Arthur Wellesley's army defeats a French force in Spain
At the Diet of Porvoo, Finland pledges allegiance to Alexander I of Russia

1810.event: Napoleon Bonaparte decrees Rome as second capital of French Empire
1810.summary: Napoleon Bonaparte decrees that Rome would become the second capital of the French Empire, impacting political dynamics in Europe.
Beethoven composes his famous piano piece Für Elise, contributing significantly to classical music.
Venezuela achieves home rule as citizens overthrow the local governor, marking a significant moment in South American independence movements.
Armed citizens of Buenos Aires expel the Viceroy and establish a provincial government for Argentina, influencing future political landscapes.
Argentina's new junta publishes the country's first newspaper, the Gazeta de Buenos-Ayres, promoting public discourse.

1810.event: Jean Baptiste Bernadotte elected Crown Prince of Sweden
1810.summary: Jean Baptiste Bernadotte, Marshal of France, is elected Crown Prince of Sweden, altering the royal lineage in Sweden.
Bavarian royalty hosts the first Oktoberfest, fostering cultural traditions that continue to impact society.

1810.event: Declaration of Independence by Mexican priest
1810.summary: Miguel Hidalgo incites the revolt that becomes the Mexican War of Independence, affecting many Latin American regions.

1810.event: Napoleon marries Marie Louise of Austria
1810.summary: Napoleon marries Marie Louise of Austria, further solidifying alliances and affecting European aristocratic relations.

1810.event: Publication of Goethe's Theory of Colours
1810.summary: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe publishes his book Zur Farbenlehre, contributing to advancements in art and science.

1811.summary: A heavily outnumbered Spanish force defeats nearly 100,000 Mexican revolutionaries in a significant conflict during the Mexican War of Independence.
Spain, Portugal and Great Britain achieve a victory against the French forces during the Peninsular War.
The Great Comet of 1811 is discovered, which would influence art and music during this period.
Paraguay declares independence from the Spanish Empire, marking a significant shift in the region's political landscape.
American troops defeat Native American leader Tenskwatawa, shaping U.S. expansion and Native relations.
Workers begin destroying industrial machines in response to technological changes in northern England, impacting labor movements.
John Stevens' boat begins operation, ushering in a new era of transportation and influencing commerce and trade.
The first Constitution of the Republic of Venezuela takes effect after independence from Spain, shaping its governance.
A tragic fire in Virginia kills 72 people, including notable political figures, shocking the public and affecting the local community.
A volcanic eruption briefly creates Sabrina Island in the Azores, a geological event of interest.

1812.event: Allgemeines bürgerliches Gesetzbuch enters into force
1812.summary: The Austrian civil code enters into force in the Austrian Empire.
Napoleon authorizes the usage of Mesures usuelles, forming the basis of the metric system.

1812.event: Creation of the first modern Spanish constitution
1812.summary: The Cortes of Cádiz creates the first modern Spanish constitution.

1812.event: Admittance of Louisiana as a U.S. state
1812.summary: Louisiana is admitted as the 18th U.S. state.
The War of 1812 between the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom begins with a U.S. declaration.
Beethoven and Goethe meet each other in Teplice, Bohemia.
The bloodiest battle of the Napoleonic Wars ends in a tactical victory for Napoleon, with at least 70,000 casualties.
Napoleon's troops enter Moscow, which is deliberately set on fire by Muscovites, as part of the French invasion of Russia.

1812.event: Capture of British warships by American forces
1812.summary: American naval forces capture two British warships, HMS Detroit and HMS Caledonia, during the War of 1812.
Napoleon begins his retreat from Moscow, leading to disastrous results for his army.

1813.summary: The Philharmonic Society, later known as the Royal Philharmonic Society, is founded in London, promoting music culture.
Jane Austen's renowned novel Pride and Prejudice is published anonymously, influencing literature and culture.
Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 is premiered in Vienna, showcasing his influential music.
Napoleon is defeated at the Battle of Leipzig, marking a significant shift in European politics and warfare.

1813.event: Victory at Battle of San Lorenzo
1813.summary: José de San Martín achieves a symbolic victory against Spanish royalists in Argentina, impacting the independence movement.
Wellington's allied forces defeat the French at the Battle of Vitoria, signaling a turning point in the Peninsular War.
Persia and Russia sign the Treaty of Gulistan, which redraws territorial boundaries and impacts regional stability.
A naval engagement occurs between French and British ships, emphasizing the ongoing naval conflicts of the Napoleonic Wars.
Prussia officially declares war against France, escalating the conflict in Europe.
Napoleon secures a victory against the German alliance at the Battle of Bautzen, reaffirming his control.

1814.event: War of the Sixth Coalition - Siege of Cattaro
1814.summary: French garrison surrenders to the British after ten days of bombardment
Frederick VI of Denmark cedes the Kingdom of Norway into personal union with Sweden
Blücher's Allied army defeats the French under Napoleon

1814.event: War of the Sixth Coalition - Treaty of Chaumont
1814.summary: Treaty signed by four Allied powers, deepening their alliance against France
The War of the Sixth Coalition ends, and Napoleon is forced to abdicate unconditionally
Returning France's borders to their 1792 extent, Napoleon is exiled to Elba
Louis XVIII of France issues the Charter, a written constitution
The eruption kills more than 1,200 people and destroys Cagsawa Church
The famous poet passes away, significantly impacting the literary world
American defense inspires Francis Scott Key to write The Star-Spangled Banner

1815.summary: American forces led by Andrew Jackson defeat British forces, marking a significant American victory in the War of 1812.
The War of 1812 officially ends with the ratification of the Treaty of Ghent, restoring relations between the United States and Britain.
Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from Elba and returns to France, igniting a series of events leading to his Hundred Days rule.
Arthur Wellesley defeats Napoleon Bonaparte decisively, marking the end of the Napoleonic Wars.

1815.event: Final Act of the Congress of Vienna
1815.summary: The Congress of Vienna concludes, establishing a new political order in Europe and the neutrality of Switzerland.
Mount Tambora erupts, causing a volcanic winter, crop failures, and widespread famine, known as the Year Without a Summer.
Napoleon is exiled to the remote island of Saint Helena after his defeat.
Sir Humphry Davy announces his invention of the Davy lamp, significantly improving safety in coal mining.
Marshal Ney is executed in Paris, marking a notable event following the Napoleonic Wars.

1815.event: First Performance of the Handel and Haydn Society
1815.summary: The Handel and Haydn Society, an important musical organization, gives its first performance in Boston.

1816.summary: Sir Humphry Davy's Davy lamp is first tested underground as a coal mining safety lamp
Gioachino Rossini's opera buffa The Barber of Seville premières at the Teatro Argentina
The Governorate of Estonia of the Russian Empire emancipates its peasants from serfdom
Divorce is abolished in France by the Chambre introuvable

1816.event: Independence of United Provinces of South America
1816.summary: The United Provinces of South America declares independence from Spain

1816.event: Foundation of the Society for the Promotion of Permanent and Universal Peace
1816.summary: The Society for the Promotion of Permanent and Universal Peace is founded in London

1816.event: Foundation of the University of Warsaw
1816.summary: The University of Warsaw is established

1816.event: Establishment of the American Colonization Society
1816.summary: The American Colonization Society is established to support the emigration of free African Americans to Africa
Robert Stirling patents his Stirling engine, known at the time as Stirling's air engine

1817.summary: Otto von Kotzebue discovers New Year Island while sailing through the Sandwich Islands.
Ram Mohan Roy and David Hare found Hindu College in Calcutta, offering Western education.
The Argentine–Chilean patriotic army defeats the Spanish in a key battle for Chilean independence.
Karl Drais drives his dandy horse, the earliest form of bicycle, in Mannheim.
The frigate HMS Trincomalee is launched in Bombay for the British Royal Navy.

1817.event: Establishment of the University of Ghent
1817.summary: The University of Ghent officially opens its doors for education in Belgium.

1817.event: Foundation of the University of Michigan
1817.summary: The University of Michigan is founded in Detroit, providing higher education in the region.
The U.S. Congress creates the Alabama Territory by splitting the Mississippi Territory.
The first Seminole War begins in Florida, leading to significant conflicts between U.S. forces and Seminole tribes.
Mississippi is admitted as the 20th U.S. state, solidifying its governance and laws.

1818.summary: The Laufmaschine, an early form of the bicycle, is invented by Karl Drais, influencing future personal transportation.
Mary Shelley publishes her influential novel Frankenstein, which will have a lasting impact on literature and culture.
An astronomical event occurs where Venus passes in front of Jupiter, marking a rare celestial phenomenon.
Chile proclaims its independence from Spain, a significant political event in South America.
The British East India Company achieves a decisive victory over the Maratha Empire, solidifying British control in India.

1818.event: Foundation of the Old Vic Theatre
1818.summary: The Old Vic Theatre is founded in London, marking a significant development in the cultural landscape.
The Christmas carol Silent Night is first performed in Oberndorf bei Salzburg, influencing Christmas music traditions worldwide.
The Anglo-Chinese College is founded in Malacca, contributing to education and cultural exchange between East and West.
The Treaty of Mandeswar is signed, ending the Third Anglo-Maratha War and enhancing British power in India.

1818.event: Crowning of Charles XIV of Sweden
1818.summary: Charles XIV is crowned king of Sweden and Norway, marking a significant political transition.

1819.summary: The first major peacetime financial crisis in the United States begins.
Thomas Jefferson founds the University of Virginia.
The Treaty of Singapore founds a British trading settlement in Singapore.
Spain cedes Florida to the United States in exchange for claims on Texas.
U.S. naval vessel USS Columbus is launched.
German dramatist is assassinated by Karl Ludwig Sand in Mannheim.
The SS Savannah begins its voyage as the first steamship to cross the Atlantic.
A crowd of radical protesters is charged by a yeomanry unit in Manchester, leading to deaths and injuries.
The Museo del Prado, one of the world's great art galleries, opens in Madrid.

1819.event: Establishment of Republic of Gran Colombia
1819.summary: The Republic of Gran Colombia is formally established with Simón Bolívar as its first president.

1820.summary: A significant treaty is signed between various sheikhs of the Arabian Peninsula and the United Kingdom, aimed at curbing piracy and promoting maritime safety.
An Imperial Russian Navy expedition becomes the first to sight the Antarctic ice sheet.
A plot to murder the Cabinet of the United Kingdom is exposed, highlighting political unrest in England.
King Ferdinand VII of Spain accepts a new constitution, signifying a shift towards liberal governance.

1820.event: Foundation of the Astronomical Society of London
1820.summary: The Astronomical Society of London is founded, promoting advancements in astronomy that may influence various disciplines including music composition.

1820.event: Discovery of the Venus de Milo
1820.summary: The famous ancient statue is discovered on the Greek island of Milos, sparking interest in classical art and culture.
The ship that would later carry Charles Darwin on his historic voyage is launched, paving the way for scientific discoveries.
The world's longest vehicular suspension bridge at the time opens, enhancing transport and communication across regions.
The canal linking to the London Docks is completed, facilitating trade and transport in the city, impacting economic activities.
Guayaquil declares its independence from Spain, a significant event in the broader context of Latin American independence movements.

1821.event: Start of the Greek War of Independence
1821.summary: The Greek War of Independence begins with a significant symbolic act at the Monastery of Agia Lavra, marking a pivotal moment in Greek history
Napoleon Bonaparte dies in exile on Saint Helena, ending a significant chapter in European history
José de San Martín declares the independence of Peru from the Spanish Empire, a key event in the Latin American independence movements

1821.event: Establishment of the Republic of Gran Colombia
1821.summary: The Republic of Gran Colombia is formed, uniting several South American nations under the leadership of Simón Bolívar

1821.event: Declaration of Independence of Central America
1821.summary: Central American nations including Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica declare independence from Spain
Greek rebels capture Tripolitsa, leading to a tragic massacre that highlights the brutality of the Greek War of Independence

1821.event: Establishment of the Société de géographie
1821.summary: The world's first geographical society is established in Paris, promoting the exploration and understanding of geography
Simón Bolívar achieves a decisive victory at the Battle of Carabobo, securing Venezuela's independence from Spanish rule
Ecumenical Patriarch Gregory V is executed by the Ottoman government, illustrating the severe repression during the Greek War of Independence
Amherst College is founded in Massachusetts, contributing to the growth of higher education in the United States

1822.summary: The Greek Constitution of 1822 is adopted by the First National Assembly at Epidaurus.
Prince Pedro I of Brazil decides to stay in Brazil, beginning the Brazilian independence process.
20,000 Greeks on the island of Chios are slaughtered by Ottoman troops during the Greek War of Independence.
Simón Bolívar secures the independence of Quito.
Charles Babbage publishes a proposal for a difference engine, a precursor of the modern computer.
Brazil officially declares its independence from Portugal.
Jean-François Champollion announces his success in deciphering Egyptian hieroglyphs using the Rosetta Stone.
The American Colonization Society lands in Africa to establish Monrovia, intended for freed American slaves.
An earthquake sequence causes severe damage and at least 20,000 deaths in the northern Ottoman Empire.
Pedro I is crowned as the first Emperor of Brazil.

1823.summary: Gioachino Rossini's opera Semiramide is first performed at La Fenice in Venice
Franz Liszt, 11, gives a concert in Vienna, after which he is personally congratulated by Ludwig van Beethoven
About 110 boys are killed during a stampede at the Convent of the Minori Osservanti in Valletta, Malta
The first worldwide carnival parade takes place in Cologne, Prussia
Pope Pius VII dies after a reign of more than 23 years
Cádiz surrenders to the French and Ferdinand VII of Spain is restored to his throne, repealing the liberal Spanish Constitution of 1812
French infantry capture the fort of Trocadero and turn its guns on Cádiz
An insurrection of 10,000 black slaves begins in British Guiana
Medical journal The Lancet is founded by Thomas Wakley in London
James Monroe introduces the Monroe Doctrine in the State of the Union address

1824.summary: Beethoven's Symphony No. 9, one of the most celebrated compositions, premieres at the Theater am Kärntnertor in Vienna, with the deaf composer witnessing the audience's reaction.

1824.event: Formation of the Royal National Lifeboat Institution
1824.summary: The Royal National Lifeboat Institution is founded in the British Isles to improve maritime safety and assist those in distress at sea.
The First Anglo-Burmese War begins, leading to significant military engagements and territorial changes in Southeast Asia.
Lord Byron, a prominent poet and figure in the Romantic movement, dies in Missolonghi, Greece while supporting the Greek War of Independence.
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute is founded in Troy, New York, marking the establishment of the first technological university in the English-speaking world.

1824.event: First Issue of The Westminster Review Published
1824.summary: The inaugural issue of The Westminster Review, a radical quarterly founded by Jeremy Bentham, is published in London.
The Mechanics' Institution is established in Manchester, England, promoting the education of working men and leading to further academic advancements.
The Anglo-Dutch Treaty of 1824 is signed, impacting colonial territories and trade agreements between Britain and the Netherlands.
Pro-independence forces achieve a decisive victory over Spanish forces in the Battle of Junín, a pivotal moment in the Peruvian War of Independence.
Saint Petersburg experiences its worst flood to date, resulting in significant loss of life and prompting discussions on urban planning and infrastructure.

1825.summary: King Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies dies in Naples and is succeeded by his son, Francis.
After no presidential candidate receives a majority of United States Electoral College votes, the U.S. House of Representatives elects John Quincy Adams President of the United States.
The Coronation of Charles X takes place at the historic site of Reims Cathedral, the last coronation of a French monarch.

1825.event: Opening of Stockton and Darlington Railway
1825.summary: The Stockton and Darlington Railway opens, marking a major advancement in railway technology.
The Erie Canal opens, providing passage from Albany, New York to Buffalo and Lake Erie, enhancing trade and transportation.
The Australian city of Brisbane is founded.
Bolivia gains its independence from Spain as a republic, at the instigation of Simón Bolívar.
The first horse-drawn omnibuses are established in London, revolutionizing public transport.
Some Imperial Russian Army officers stage the Decembrist revolt against Nicholas I's accession, but it is suppressed by the government.
PS Comet II sinks off Gourock with the loss of 62 lives, highlighting the dangers of maritime travel.

1826.summary: The French newspaper Le Figaro begins publication in Paris, initially as a satirical weekly.

1826.event: First printing of The Last of the Mohicans
1826.summary: First printing of James Fenimore Cooper's novel The Last of the Mohicans in Philadelphia.

1826.event: Opening of the Menai Suspension Bridge
1826.summary: The Menai Suspension Bridge, built by engineer Thomas Telford, is opened between the island of Anglesey and the mainland of Wales.
Russian mathematician Nikolai Ivanovich Lobachevsky develops non-Euclidean geometry independently of Janos Bolyai.
University College London is founded, under the name University of London.

1826.event: Invention of the internal combustion engine
1826.summary: Samuel Morey patents an internal combustion engine in the United States.

1826.event: Opening of the Liverpool and Manchester Railway
1826.summary: The Liverpool and Manchester Railway is authorized to become the world's first purpose-built railway operated by steam locomotives.
Nicéphore Niépce makes the first true photograph, View from the Window at Le Gras.

1826.event: Premiere of Beethoven's String Quartet No. 13
1826.summary: Premiere of Ludwig van Beethoven's String Quartet No. 13 in B♭ major, Op. 130, given by the Schuppanzigh Quartet.

1826.event: Opening of the Paris Stock Exchange
1826.summary: The Paris Stock Exchange opens at the Palais de la Bourse.

1827.summary: A Brazilian Imperial Army force is tactically defeated by Argentine–Uruguayan troops.
The first public theatre in Norway, the Christiania Offentlige Theater, is inaugurated in Christiania.
German composer Ludwig van Beethoven dies in Vienna, causing a large public funeral.

1827.event: Establishment of Qasr El Eyni Hospital
1827.summary: The predecessor of Qasr El Eyni Hospital and Cairo University School of Medicine is established in Egypt.
Freedom's Journal, the first African-American owned and published newspaper in the United States, is founded in New York City.
Georg Ohm publishes Die galvanische Kette, the first appearance of Ohm's law.
The British-built paddle steamer Curaçao makes the first transatlantic crossing by steam.
John Walker begins selling his invention, the Lucifer friction match, in England.
British, French and Russian naval forces destroy the Turko-Egyptian fleet in the Greek War of Independence.
Petrache Poenaru receives a French patent for the invention of the first fountain pen.

1828.summary: Persia irrevocably cedes significant territories to Imperial Russia, drastically altering regional boundaries.
The war starts, marking a critical conflict in southeastern Europe and affecting many nations.
René Caillié becomes the first non-Muslim to enter Timbuktu and return alive, expanding European interest in Africa.
The UK's oldest zoo opens, setting a precedent for zoological institutions in Europe.

1828.event: Greek War of Independence London Protocol
1828.summary: The protocol leads to the creation of an autonomous Greek state, impacting European politics and national identities.
Juan Lavalle deposes the governor, reigniting civil conflicts that would shape the country’s future.
Andrew Jackson is elected President of the United States, signaling a shift in American political landscape.
Franz Schubert's song cycle is published posthumously, becoming significant in classical music repertoire.
Wöhler's synthesis of urea challenges vitalism, marking a milestone in organic chemistry.
Jedlik invents the world's first electric motor, paving the way for future technological advancements.

1829.summary: Felix Mendelssohn conducts the first performance of Johann Sebastian Bach's St Matthew Passion since Bach's death, reviving interest in the composer.
Greece receives autonomy from the Ottoman Empire via the London Protocol, marking a significant step in its quest for independence.
The Catholic Relief Act is passed in the UK Parliament, enhancing Catholic emancipation in Britain and Ireland.
George Shillibeer starts the first bus service in London, revolutionizing public transportation.
Gioacchino Rossini's opera William Tell has its first performance in Paris, showcasing a significant musical contribution.
Robert Peel establishes the Metropolitan Police Service in London, the first modern police force.
The Technical University of Denmark opens, contributing to higher education and technical training in the region.
The Chalmers University of Technology is founded in Gothenburg, Sweden, advancing technical education.
Stephenson's Rocket wins the Rainhill Trials, marking a milestone in the development of rail transport.
The original Welland Canal opens for a trial run, enhancing transport connections in Upper Canada.

1830.summary: LaGrange College begins operation, becoming the first publicly chartered college in Alabama
The London Protocol establishes the full independence and sovereignty of Greece from the Ottoman Empire
A fire destroys the Argyll Rooms in London where the Philharmonic Society of London presents concerts, firefighters use steam-powered fire engines
French invasion of Algiers, leading to creation of French Algeria
Barthélemy Thimonnier is granted a French patent for a sewing machine that chains stitches at 200/minute

1830.event: Opening of the Liverpool and Manchester Railway
1830.summary: Opening of the Liverpool and Manchester Railway, the world's first intercity passenger railway operated solely by steam locomotives
The Provisional Government in Brussels declares the creation of the independent state of Belgium
Hector Berlioz's most famous work, Symphonie fantastique, has its world premiere in Paris
The independence of Belgium is recognized by the Great Powers
The Polish November Uprising begins in Warsaw against Russian rule

1831.summary: William Lloyd Garrison begins publishing an anti-slavery newspaper in Boston

1831.event: Founding of the French Foreign Legion
1831.summary: The French Foreign Legion is founded
Victor Hugo's historical romantic Gothic novel is published in Paris
The Belgian Constitution of 1831 is approved by the National Congress
Michael Faraday demonstrates electromagnetic induction at the Royal Society of London
Michael Faraday constructs an early form of dynamo
The November Uprising ends in the defeat of Polish forces
Rebellious silk workers seize Lyon following a bloody battle with the military
Russian imperial officials in Wallachia adopt regulations introducing unprecedented reforms
Global financial services business Assicurazioni Generali is founded in Trieste

1832.event: Founding of the New-England Anti-Slavery Society
1832.summary: William Lloyd Garrison founds the New-England Anti-Slavery Society, promoting abolitionist movements.
A cholera epidemic in London claims at least 3,000 lives and spreads to France and North America.

1832.event: Charles Darwin arrives in South America
1832.summary: Charles Darwin and the crew of HMS Beagle arrive at South America for the first time.

1832.event: Treaty of London creates Kingdom of Greece
1832.summary: The Treaty of London creates an independent Kingdom of Greece with Otto of Bavaria as king.
The June Rebellion breaks out in Paris, led by students protesting against the monarchy.

1832.event: Reform Act becomes law in the UK
1832.summary: The Reform Act is enacted in the UK, expanding voting rights and political representation.
Durham University is founded in England by an act of Parliament with royal assent.
The Siege of Antwerp culminates with French forces attacking the last Dutch stronghold in the aftermath of the Belgian Revolution.
Publication begins of Carl von Clausewitz's influential book on military strategy, On War, posthumously.
The first commutator DC electric motor, capable of turning machinery, is demonstrated by William Sturgeon in London.

1833.summary: The British Slavery Abolition Act 1833 receives royal assent, beginning the process of giving slaves in much of the British Empire their freedom.
The Parliament of the United Kingdom enacts the Factory Acts, limiting child labour.
Carl Friedrich Gauss and Wilhelm Weber obtain permission to build an electromagnetic telegraph in Göttingen.
Ada Lovelace is introduced to Charles Babbage, an important moment in the history of computing.
A spectacular occurrence of the Leonid meteor shower is observed all over North America, inspiring the song Stars Fell on Alabama.
Oberlin College is founded in Oberlin, Ohio, known for its progressive stance on social issues.
An 8.0 earthquake shakes the Chinese province of Yunnan, killing 6,000 people.

1833.event: First Performance of God Save the Tsar!
1833.summary: The national anthem of the Russian Empire, God Save the Tsar!, is first performed.
Three-year-old Isabella II becomes Queen of Spain, beginning the First Carlist War.
Greece recaptures the Acropolis of Athens.

1834.summary: Customs charges are abolished at borders within the Zollverein member states, promoting trade and economic cooperation.

1834.event: End of Slavery in British Empire
1834.summary: Slavery is abolished in the British Empire by the Slavery Abolition Act 1833, impacting millions and promoting human rights.
Cyrus McCormick is granted a patent for his mechanical reaper, revolutionizing agriculture and food production.
The Palace of Westminster is destroyed by fire, leading to significant changes in British political architecture.
The Medical School of Louisiana is founded, enhancing medical education and practice in the region.
The Zollverein institutes the first regular census in Germany, providing vital demographic data.
Charles Babbage begins conceptual design of the Analytical Engine, laying groundwork for modern computing.
Thomas Davenport installs the first American DC electrical motor in a model car, innovating transportation technology.
Spain, France, Portugal, and the UK sign the Quadruple Alliance, impacting European diplomacy.
General Theodoros Kolokotronis is sentenced for treason in Greece, reflecting conflicts in independence movements.

1835.summary: HMS Beagle anchors off the Chonos Archipelago with Charles Darwin onboard as naturalist.

1835.event: Public Debt of the United States
1835.summary: The United States public debt contracts to zero for the only time in history.
A railway is opened between Brussels and Mechelen, marking the first rail transport in continental Europe.
H. Fox Talbot exposes the world's first known photographic negatives in England.
Bertelsmann is founded as a religious printer and publisher in Prussia.
Halley's Comet reaches perihelion, its closest approach to the Sun.

1835.event: Opening of the Bavarian Ludwig Railway
1835.summary: The Bavarian Ludwig Railway opens between Nuremberg and Fürth, marking the first railway in Germany.
The Great Fire of New York destroys 530 buildings, including the New York Stock Exchange.
The Texas Revolution begins as Mexican soldiers attempt to disarm the people of Gonzales, Texas.

1836.summary: Charles Darwin on board HMS Beagle reaches Sydney during its voyage
First section of the London and Greenwich Railway opens, marking a significant advancement in transportation
The Battle of the Alamo begins as American settlers are surrounded by the Mexican Army
Delegates sign the Texas Declaration of Independence, declaring the Republic of Texas
The Battle of the Alamo ends with significant Texan casualties against the Mexican troops

1836.event: Sam Houston's victory at San Jacinto
1836.summary: The Texas Revolution culminates in the Battle of San Jacinto with a decisive Texan victory
Richard Wagner's opera Das Liebesverbot is performed for the first time
The University of London is established by Royal Charter, impacting education in the region
John Ruggles is granted the first numbered patent in the United States for improvements to railroad steam locomotive tires
A devastating fire at the Lehman Theater in Saint Petersburg leads to the deaths of 800 people

1837.summary: The destructive Galilee earthquake causes 6,000–7,000 casualties in Ottoman Syria.

1837.event: Charles Dickens's Oliver Twist begins publication
1837.summary: Charles Dickens's Oliver Twist begins publication in serial form in London.

1837.event: Formation of Congregation of Holy Cross
1837.summary: The Congregation of Holy Cross is formed in Le Mans, France, by the signing of the Fundamental Act of Union.
W. F. Cooke and Charles Wheatstone patent a system of electrical telegraph.

1837.event: Queen Victoria accedes to the throne
1837.summary: Queen Victoria, 18, accedes to the throne of the United Kingdom, on the death of her uncle William IV without legitimate heirs.

1837.event: Samuel Morse files for telegraph patent
1837.summary: Samuel Morse files a caveat for a patent for the telegraph.
The Tsarskoye Selo Railway, the first in the Russian Empire, opens between Saint Petersburg and Zarskoje Selo.
World's leading consumer goods brand, Procter & Gamble is founded in Ohio, United States.
The first electric locomotive built is a miniature battery locomotive constructed by chemist Robert Davidson of Aberdeen in Scotland.
The Slave Compensation Act is signed into law by the government of the United Kingdom.

1838.summary: Samuel Morse, Alfred Vail and Leonard Gale give the first public demonstration of the telegraph
A 7.5 earthquake strikes the Romanian district of Vrancea causing damage and killing 73 people
A combination of rain and melting snow causes the Danube River to overflow, drowning more than 150 people
Isambard Kingdom Brunel's paddle steamer SS Great Western makes the transatlantic crossing to New York in 15 days
The People's Charter is drawn up in the United Kingdom, demanding universal suffrage
28 Indigenous Australians are killed in the Myall Creek massacre
The coronation of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom takes place at Westminster Abbey
The Anti-Corn Law League is established in Britain by Richard Cobden
Most former slaves in the British Empire are released from apprenticeships, gaining full emancipation
Battle of Maella marks a victory for supporters of Infante Carlos, Count of Molina

1839.summary: The first photograph of the Moon is taken by French photographer Louis Daguerre.
The French Academy of Sciences announces the daguerreotype photography process.
The world's first commercial electric telegraph line comes into operation in England.
Prussia imposes The Child Labor Law of 1839, becoming the first nation to place restrictions on child labor.
Louis Daguerre receives a patent for his camera, which will be commercially available.
Chile defeats the Peru–Bolivian Confederation, leading to the restoration of an independent Peru.
Destruction of opium at Humen begins, leading to the First Opium War against Qing Dynasty China.
A railway between Naples and Portici is inaugurated as the first line in the Italian Peninsula.
Giuseppe Verdi's first opera, Oberto, conte di San Bonifacio, opens in Milan.
The Anti-Corn Law League is founded in Manchester, England.

1840.summary: The introduction of the Uniform Penny Post revolutionizes mail delivery in the United Kingdom by standardizing postage rates.

1840.event: First steam transatlantic passenger mail service
1840.summary: The Cunard Line's RMS Britannia departs from Liverpool on the first steam transatlantic passenger mail service, marking a major advancement in transportation.

1840.event: Premiere of La fille du régiment
1840.summary: Gaetano Donizetti's opera La fille du régiment premieres in Paris, showcasing significant progress in operatic composition.
The Treaty of Waitangi is signed, formally establishing British sovereignty in New Zealand, impacting colonial governance.

1840.event: Completion of the Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad
1840.summary: The Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad is completed, becoming the world's longest railroad, enhancing transport and trade.
The Stockport Viaduct, one of the largest brick structures in Europe, is completed, representing an engineering marvel of the time.

1840.event: Ottoman and British bombardment of Beirut
1840.summary: Ottoman and British troops bombard Beirut to pressure Egyptian Muhammad Ali, illustrating the geopolitical tensions of the era.

1840.event: Death of Frederick William III of Prussia
1840.summary: The death of Frederick William III leads to the ascent of his son Frederick William IV, affecting the political landscape in Prussia.
The French frigate Belle-Poule returns with Napoleon's remains, a significant event reflecting national pride in France.
King's College Hospital opens in London, advancing healthcare and medical education in England.

1841.summary: Charles Elliot of the United Kingdom and Qishan of the Qing dynasty agree to the Convention of Chuenpi
Britain occupies Hong Kong, later recording a population of about 7,500 in the first census
The Act of Union, also known as the British North America Act, is proclaimed in Canada
President William Henry Harrison dies of pneumonia, becoming the first U.S. president to die in office
The first national census in the United Kingdom records names and approximate ages of every household member
The ballet Giselle is first presented by the Ballet du Théâtre de l'Académie Royale de Musique in Paris
The First Opium War begins, leading to major conflicts involving British forces and China
The first modern educational institution on the Indian subcontinent, Dhaka College, is established
Queen's University is founded in Kingston, Ontario, by Rev. Thomas Liddell

1841.event: Treaty for the Suppression of the African Slave Trade
1841.summary: The first multilateral treaty for the suppression of the African slave trade is signed in London

1842.event: Establishment of Delft University of Technology
1842.summary: Delft University of Technology is established by William II of the Netherlands, as a Royal Academy for the education of civilian engineers.
Giuseppe Verdi's third opera Nabucco premieres at La Scala in Milan; its success establishes Verdi as one of Italy's foremost operatic composers.

1842.event: First concert of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra
1842.summary: The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, founded by Otto Nicolai, performs its first concert.

1842.event: Establishment of the New York Philharmonic
1842.summary: The New York Philharmonic, founded by Ureli Corelli Hill, performs its first concert.

1842.event: Introduction of the Income Tax Act
1842.summary: The Income Tax Act establishes the first peacetime income tax in the United Kingdom; 7 pence in the pound, for incomes over 150 pounds.
Great fire of Hamburg in Germany destroys around one-third of the city centre and kills 51.
Queen Victoria becomes the first reigning British monarch to travel by train, on the Great Western Railway between Slough and London Paddington station.
The Mines Act 1842 becomes law, prohibiting underground work for all women and boys under 10 years old in the United Kingdom.
Wesleyan University is established in Ohio.
First Anglo-Afghan War - Battle of Jellalabad: British troops are victorious.

1843.summary: Serial publication of Charles Dickens's novel Martin Chuzzlewit begins in London.

1843.event: I Lombardi alla prima crociata premieres
1843.summary: Giuseppe Verdi's opera I Lombardi alla prima crociata premieres at La Scala in Milan.
Isambard Kingdom Brunel's SS Great Britain is launched from Bristol, the first iron-hulled, propeller-driven ship.
Mount Etna erupts in Italy, killing 69 people in the village of Bronte.
The Economist newspaper is first published in London.

1843.event: Founding of Shanghai as trade city
1843.summary: The city of Shanghai opens for trade with foreigners for the first time, welcoming traders from the United Kingdom.
The Danish government re-establishes the Althing in Iceland as an advisory body.
Ada Lovelace translates and expands Menabrea's notes on the Analytical Engine, creating what is regarded as the world's first computer program.
Hawaii is recognized as an independent nation by the United Kingdom and France.
Charles Dickens's novella A Christmas Carol is first published in London, selling out by Christmas Eve.

1844.summary: The first telegraph message is sent, revolutionizing long-distance communication.
Giuseppe Verdi's opera Ernani premieres at Teatro La Fenice, marking a significant event in music history.

1844.event: King Oscar I Ascends to the Throne
1844.summary: King Oscar I becomes the new monarch of Sweden–Norway following the death of his father.
The Althing, Iceland's parliament, is reopened after being closed for 45 years.
Hungarian is officially declared the national language of Hungary.
The first Young Men's Christian Association is established in London, aimed at promoting healthy living.

1844.event: Giuseppe Verdi's Opera I due Foscari Debuts
1844.summary: Giuseppe Verdi's opera I due Foscari has its debut at Teatro Argentina in Rome.
The Bank Charter Act of 1844 is approved, affecting banking operations in Britain.

1844.event: Báb Proclaimed Promised One of Islam
1844.summary: The Báb publicly declares himself as the promised one of Islam, marking a significant religious event.
A major earthquake hits Argentina's Salta Province, causing widespread damage.

1845.event: Reckoning Asian Dates in the Philippines
1845.summary: The Philippines begins reckoning Asian dates by hopping the International Date Line, aligning local calendars with the rest of Asia for trade purposes.
The Raven by Edgar Allan Poe is published for the first time in the New York Evening Mirror.
The United States Congress approves the annexation of Texas, a significant event in American territorial expansion.
The Violin Concerto by Felix Mendelssohn premieres in Leipzig, influencing future compositions.
The Great Fire of Pittsburgh destroys much of the city, impacting local population and infrastructure.

1845.event: First Transatlantic Crossing by Iron Steamship
1845.summary: Isambard Kingdom Brunel's iron steamship Great Britain makes the first transatlantic crossing from Liverpool to New York.
Potato blight breaks out in Ireland, beginning the Great Famine which will have dire societal effects.
Richard Wagner's opera Tannhäuser debuts at the Dresden Royal Court Theater, marking a milestone in opera history.
Anesthesia is used for childbirth for the first time, marking a significant advance in medical practices.
Texas is admitted as the 28th U.S. state, significantly altering the political landscape of the United States.

1846.event: Opening of the Milan–Venice Railway Bridge
1846.summary: The world's longest railway bridge opens, enhancing transportation between major cities.

1846.event: Signing of the Treaty of Lahore
1846.summary: The First Anglo-Sikh War ends, ceding Kashmir to the British East India Company and surrendering the Koh-i-Noor diamond.
