The first United States coast-to-coast long-distance telephone call is made possible by a vacuum tube amplifier, inaugurated by Alexander Graham Bell.
The Ottoman Empire starts deporting Armenians from its armed forces to labor battalions, marking the beginning of a genocide.
RMS Lusitania is sunk by a German U-boat off the south-west coast of Ireland, killing 1,199 civilians.
1915.city: Off the southern coast of Ireland

1915.summary: Germany declares the waters around the British Isles a war zone as part of its U-boat campaign, escalating tensions with neutral nations.
Germany employs poison gas for the first time on the Western Front during the Second Battle of Ypres.

1915.event: British First Use of Poison Gas
1915.summary: British forces encounter poison gas for the first time in battle during the Battle of Loos.
The controversial film The Birth of a Nation premieres in Los Angeles, becoming a significant early cinematic work and a point of contention.
The Zimmerwald Conference, a gathering of socialist groups calling for an end to World War I, begins in Switzerland.
The British Army tests the prototype of the military tank, marking a significant development in warfare technology.

1916.summary: The British Royal Army Medical Corps carries out the first successful blood transfusion, using stored and cooled blood.
Tristan Tzara founds the art movement Dadaism, which influences various art forms including music.

1916.event: First concert of Baltimore Symphony Orchestra
1916.summary: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra presents its first concert in the United States.
The Battle of Verdun, one of the longest battles in WWI, begins in France, greatly impacting European societies.

1916.event: Invention of the toggle light switch
1916.summary: The toggle light switch is invented, marking a significant advance in electrical design.

1916.event: Establishment of the National Park Service
1916.summary: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson signs legislation creating the National Park Service, preserving nature and promoting public enjoyment.

1916.event: Introduction of the tank in warfare
1916.summary: The Battle of Flers–Courcelette sees the first use of the tank in warfare, a significant military technological advancement.

1916.event: Publication of Cours de linguistique générale
1916.summary: Ferdinand de Saussure's Cours de linguistique générale is published posthumously, influencing modern linguistics and semiotics.
Gustav Holst composes his orchestral suite The Planets, which becomes a significant work in the classical repertoire.

1916.event: First audio broadcast of presidential election returns
1916.summary: Radio station 2XG makes the first audio broadcast of U.S. presidential election returns, a technical innovation in communication.

1917.summary: The last substantial Ottoman Army garrison on the Sinai Peninsula is captured by the Egyptian Expeditionary Force's Desert Column.
Germany announces the resumption of unrestricted submarine warfare, rescinding the Sussex Pledge.
The intercepted Zimmermann Telegram reveals Germany's proposal to Mexico to join the war against the United States.
Livery Stable Blues is recorded by the Original Dixieland Jass Band, becoming the first commercially released jazz music.
U.S. President Woodrow Wilson asks Congress for a declaration of war on Germany, marking the U.S. entry into WWI.
The Bolshevik Party, led by Vladimir Lenin, storms the Winter Palace, leading to the establishment of Soviet power in Russia.
The British Foreign Secretary Arthur Balfour announces support for the establishment of a Jewish homeland in Palestine.
Women win the right to vote in New York State, marking a significant advance in the women's suffrage movement in the U.S.
A massive explosion in Halifax Harbour results from a collision of freighters, causing significant casualties and destruction.
The Senate of Finland officially declares the country's independence from Russia.

1918.summary: The Council of Lithuania adopts the Act of Independence of Lithuania, declaring Lithuania's independence from Germany, Russia or any other state.
Representation of the People Act gives most women over 30 in the United Kingdom the right to vote.
The Battle of Belleau Wood begins, marking a significant engagement for American forces in WWI.

1918.event: Formation of the Royal Air Force
1918.summary: The Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service in Britain are merged to form the Royal Air Force, the first autonomous Air Force in the world.
The Armistice of 11 November 1918 officially ends WWI as Germany signs an armistice agreement with the Allies.
Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany abdicates and the German Republic is proclaimed by Philipp Scheidemann in Berlin.
Poland declares its independence from Russia, regaining sovereignty after over a century.
Czechoslovakia declares its independence from Austria-Hungary amid the collapse of empires following WWI.
Poles in Greater Poland rise up against German rule, inspired by a patriotic speech from pianist Ignacy Jan Paderewski.
Giacomo Puccini's comic opera Gianni Schicchi premieres at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City.

1919.summary: The Paris Peace Conference opens in France, with delegates from 27 nations attending for meetings at the Palace of Versailles.

1919.event: First Transatlantic Flight by Navy Curtiss Flying Boat
1919.summary: United States Navy Curtiss flying boat NC-4 makes the first transatlantic flight, from Naval Air Station Rockaway to Lisbon.
The Bauhaus architectural and design movement is founded in Weimar, Germany.
Einstein's theory of general relativity is tested by Arthur Eddington's observation of the bending of light during a total solar eclipse.
The 19th Amendment to the United States Constitution is approved, guaranteeing women's suffrage.
The Treaty of Versailles is signed, formally ending World War I, with significant implications for Europe.

1919.event: Foundation of the International Labour Organization
1919.summary: The International Labour Organization is established as an agency of the League of Nations.
The German Workers' Party, predecessor of the Nazi Party, is formed in Germany.
The Russian Civil War continues with various battles impacting large regions of Eastern Europe.
Estonian forces successfully liberate territories from the Red Army in the Estonian War of Independence.

1920.event: Beginning of Prohibition in the United States
1920.summary: Prohibition begins, banning the sale of alcohol across the U.S., affecting social life and potentially influencing composers.
The Treaty officially ends World War I, impacting European borders and politics, influencing composers and musicians.

1920.event: League of Nations Covenant enters into force
1920.summary: The League of Nations begins operations, aimed at promoting peace and cooperation internationally.
Conflict between Poland and Soviet Russia erupts, influencing regional politics and cultural expressions.

1920.event: Establishment of the South African Air Force
1920.summary: The second autonomous air force in the world is established, marking a significant military development.
The Tartu Peace Treaty is signed, solidifying Estonia's independence and reshaping regional dynamics.

1920.event: Switzerland joins the League of Nations
1920.summary: Switzerland becomes a member of the League, indicating a shift towards international diplomacy.

1920.event: First radio broadcasts in the U.S.
1920.summary: The first commercial radio station begins operations, revolutionizing mass communication and the music industry.

1920.event: First assembly of the League of Nations
1920.summary: The inaugural meeting convenes, marking the beginning of structured international diplomacy.
Joan of Arc is canonized, influencing national identity and cultural expressions in France and beyond.

1921.summary: The Democratic Republic of Georgia is invaded by forces of Bolshevist Russia
The İstiklâl Marşı, the Turkish national anthem, is officially adopted
Charlie Chaplin's full-length silent comedy drama film The Kid is released in the United States
The Kronstadt rebellion is initiated by sailors of the Soviet Navy's Baltic Fleet

1921.event: International Working Union of Socialist Parties founded
1921.summary: A Socialist congress at Vienna ends with the foundation of the International Working Union of Socialist Parties
The Irish War of Independence ends under the terms of a truce between the British Army and the Irish Republican Army
A Massachusetts jury finds Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti guilty of first degree murder, sparking worldwide protests
Chanel No. 5 perfume is launched by Coco Chanel
The Constitution of Liechtenstein is granted by Johann II, making the country a constitutional monarchy
The Anglo-Irish Treaty establishing the Irish Free State is signed in London

1922.summary: Frederick Banting successfully conducts the first treatment of diabetes with insulin.
The United Kingdom issues a unilateral declaration of Egyptian independence, ending its protectorate.
WLW begins broadcasting, marking a significant development in media communication.

1922.event: Establishment of the British Broadcasting Company
1922.summary: The BBC is formed, initiating a new era of radio broadcasting in the UK.
Howard Carter discovers the entrance to the tomb of the Egyptian pharaoh Tutankhamun.
The first issue of the magazine Krestyanka, aimed at women, is published in Russia.

1922.event: Foundation of the Irish Free State
1922.summary: The Irish Free State is officially established, resulting in significant political changes.
T. S. Eliot publishes his influential poem The Waste Land in The Criterion magazine.
Irish Civil War general Michael Collins is assassinated, impacting Irish politics.
The Lincoln Memorial is dedicated in Washington, D.C., representing a notable cultural milestone.

1923.summary: Lithuania begins the Klaipėda Revolt to annex the Klaipėda Region
Troops from France and Belgium occupy the Ruhr area to force Germany to make reparation payments

1923.event: First Flight of Cierva C.4 Autogyro
1923.summary: First flight of the first rotorcraft, Juan de la Cierva's Cierva C.4 autogyro, in Spain
Eskom, the largest electricity producer in Africa, is established in South Africa
The Egyptian Constitution of 1923 is adopted, introducing a parliamentary system of democracy
The original Wembley Stadium in London opens its doors to the public for the first time
William Walton's Façade is performed for the first time, in London
The International Criminal Police Commission, better known as Interpol, is set up
The Great Kantō earthquake devastates Tokyo and Yokohama, killing more than 100,000 people
Adolf Hitler leads the Nazis in an unsuccessful attempt to overthrow the Bavarian government in Munich

1924.summary: The first Winter Olympics open in Chamonix, in the French Alps.
The United Kingdom recognizes the Soviet Union.
The Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company is renamed International Business Machines (IBM).
The 407-year-old Islamic caliphate is abolished in Turkey.

1924.event: World Premiere of Sibelius' Symphony No. 7
1924.summary: Jean Sibelius conducts the world premiere of his Symphony No. 7 in Stockholm.
Fascists win the general election in Italy with a two-thirds majority.
U.S. President Calvin Coolidge signs the Indian Citizenship Act into law, granting citizenship to all Native Americans.

1924.event: First Regular Radio Broadcast in Italy
1924.summary: 1-RO begins regular radio broadcasting services in Italy.
The first Surrealist Manifesto is published, defining the movement as pure psychic automatism.
American astronomer Edwin Hubble announces that Andromeda is another galaxy, expanding the understanding of the universe.

1925.event: First modern performance of Il ritorno d'Ulisse in patria
1925.summary: The first modern performance of Claudio Monteverdi's opera takes place in Paris.
Charles Francis Jenkins achieves the first synchronized transmission of pictures and sound using a mechanical system.
The Schutzstaffel is formally established as a personal bodyguard for Adolf Hitler in Germany.
The Locarno Treaties are signed in London to secure post-war European territorial settlements.
The weekly country music-variety radio program is first broadcast as the WSM Barn Dance in Nashville.
The Bauhaus school closes in Weimar and relocates to a building in Dessau, designed by Walter Gropius.
F. Scott Fitzgerald publishes his acclaimed novel The Great Gatsby in New York.
John Logie Baird successfully transmits the first television pictures with a greyscale image in London.
A 7.0 earthquake shakes the Chinese province of Yunnan, resulting in significant casualties.
The advances in vacuum tube radio technologies enhance audio transmission for music composers and broadcasting.

1926.summary: John Logie Baird demonstrates a mechanical television system which paves the way for future broadcasting innovations.
Robert H. Goddard launches the first liquid-fuel rocket, marking a significant advance in rocket technology.
Warner Brothers' Vitaphone system is showcased in Don Juan, marking a significant innovation in synchronized sound for films.
A general strike initiated in support of coal miners leads to significant civil unrest and changes labor relations.
An assassination attempt on Italian Fascist leader Benito Mussolini raises tensions within Italy.
Lebanon establishes its first constitution, marking a significant political change under the French Mandate.
The Rif War in Morocco concludes with the surrender of Rif rebels, affecting colonial dynamics in the region.

1926.event: First Scheduled Air Route to South Africa
1926.summary: The first commercial air route from the UK to South Africa is established, enhancing international travel.
Francisco Franco becomes a General in Spain, signaling the approach of significant political turmoil.
The death of famous illusionist Harry Houdini captures public attention and affects the entertainment world.

1927.summary: The British Broadcasting Company becomes the British Broadcasting Corporation, when its Royal Charter of incorporation takes effect.
The first transatlantic telephone call is made via radio from New York City to London.
Fritz Lang's futuristic film Metropolis is released in Germany.
Philo Farnsworth of the United States transmits his first experimental electronic television motion pictures.
The Jazz Singer, the first box-office hit sound film, premieres at the Warner Theater in New York City.
The Columbia Phonographic Broadcasting System, later known as CBS, is formed in the United States.
Carving of the sculptures at Mount Rushmore begins.

1927.event: Establishment of the United Kingdom's new title
1927.summary: The Royal and Parliamentary Titles Act 1927 renames the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland as the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

1927.event: First flight of Pan American Airways
1927.summary: The first flight of Pan American Airways takes off from Key West, Florida, bound for Havana, Cuba.
The Holland Tunnel opens to traffic, linking New Jersey with New York City.

1928.summary: British bacteriologist Frederick Griffith reports the results of Griffith's experiment, indirectly demonstrating that DNA is the genetic material.
Scottish-born inventor John Logie Baird broadcasts a transatlantic television signal from London to Hartsdale, New York.

1928.event: First modern Olympic Games for women
1928.summary: The 1928 Summer Olympics are held in Amsterdam, opening with the lighting of the Olympic flame, and women's athletics and gymnastics debut.
The first regular schedule of television programming begins in Schenectady, New York, by General Electric's television station W2XB.
Philo Farnsworth demonstrates the world's first working all-electronic television system in San Francisco.
Scottish-born microbiologist Alexander Fleming accidentally rediscovers the antibiotic which he will call Penicillin.
The Muslim Brotherhood is founded in Egypt by Islamic scholar and schoolteacher Hassan al-Banna.
Mickey Mouse appears in Steamboat Willie, the first sound film and the first such film to be generally distributed.
The one-movement ballet Boléro, music by Maurice Ravel, premières at the Paris Opéra.

1928.event: Foundation of the International Red Cross
1928.summary: The International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement is formally established, with the adoption of the 'Statutes of the International Red Cross'.

1929.summary: King Alexander of the Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes suspends his country's constitution.

1929.event: Publication of All Quiet on the Western Front
1929.summary: All Quiet on the Western Front, by Erich Maria Remarque, is published in book form.
The Kingdom of Italy and the Holy See sign the Lateran Treaty, establishing Vatican City as an independent state within Rome.

1929.event: Opening of the Monaco Grand Prix
1929.summary: The first edition of the Monaco Grand Prix is held.

1929.event: First Commercial Flights by Imperial Airways
1929.summary: Imperial Airways begins operating the first commercial flights between London and Karachi.

1929.event: First Public Demonstration of Color TV
1929.summary: The first public demonstration of color TV is held at Bell Telephone Laboratories.
Fritz von Opel pilots the first rocket-powered aircraft, the Opel RAK.1.
The Wall Street Crash of 1929 leads to the beginning of the Great Depression.
Vladimir Zworykin takes out the first patent for color television.

1929.event: Opening of the Museum of Modern Art
1929.summary: The Museum of Modern Art in New York City opens to the public.

1930.summary: The Moon moves into its nearest point to Earth during its fullest phase, marking the closest distance in recent history.
The Indian National Congress declares this date as Independence Day, advocating for Complete Independence from British rule.
The first patent for a field-effect transistor is granted in the United States, a significant advance in electronics.
Clyde Tombaugh confirms the existence of Pluto, contributing to the field of astronomy.
Mahatma Gandhi informs the British Viceroy of India about the upcoming civil disobedience movement, starting the famous Salt March.
The United Kingdom, Japan, and the United States sign the London Naval Treaty, limiting naval shipbuilding and warfare.
Ellen Church becomes the world's first flight attendant, revolutionizing the aviation industry.
The first FIFA World Cup takes place, marking a significant event in sports history.
The British airship R101 crashes in France on its first overseas flight, resulting in significant loss of life.
Haile Selassie is crowned emperor of Ethiopia, an important event in African history.

1931.summary: Ernest Lawrence invents the cyclotron, used to accelerate particles for nuclear physics studies.
New Delhi becomes the capital of India with official inauguration ceremonies.
The British viceroy of India and Mohandas Gandhi sign a pact aimed at ending civil disobedience.
The Second Spanish Republic is declared in Madrid amid elections favoring republican parties.
The Empire State Building is completed, becoming an iconic skyscraper in New York City.
The bankruptcy of the Creditanstalt triggers a financial crisis across Central Europe.
U.S. President Herbert Hoover announces a moratorium to halt banking crisis effects worldwide.
A staged incident leads to the Japanese invasion of Manchuria, escalating tensions in East Asia.
The Spanish Constituent Cortes approves the new constitution, establishing the Second Spanish Republic.
The discovery of heavy hydrogen, or deuterium, marks significant progress in chemistry.

1932.event: Mahatma Gandhi and Vallabhbhai Patel Arrested
1932.summary: British authorities in India arrest and intern Mahatma Gandhi and Vallabhbhai Patel, which escalates civil unrest in India.
A general World Disarmament Conference begins in Geneva with Germany demanding equal status under international treaties.
Japan declares Manchukuo formally independent from China, impacting relationships in East Asia.
In the 1932 German presidential election, Paul von Hindenburg is re-elected as Reichspräsident, which consolidates conservative power in Germany.
The kidnapping of Charles Lindbergh Jr., son of famed aviator Charles Lindbergh, shocks the United States and has international media coverage.
The July 1932 German federal election sees the Nazis become the largest party in the Reichstag, winning significant political power.
Amelia Earhart makes a groundbreaking flight from the United States to Northern Ireland, solidifying her status as a pioneer of aviation.
Walt Disney's Flowers and Trees, the first animated short to utilize full Technicolor, premieres and influences the animation industry.
The Polish Cipher Bureau successfully breaks the German Enigma cipher, a vital advance in cryptography before World War II.
Heinrich Brüning is dismissed as German chancellor and a political coup leads to instability and the rise of fascism in Germany.

1933.event: Construction of the Golden Gate Bridge begins
1933.summary: Construction of the iconic Golden Gate Bridge, a major engineering achievement, begins.

1933.event: Adolf Hitler appointed Chancellor of Germany
1933.summary: Adolf Hitler is appointed as Chancellor, marking a significant political shift in Germany.
Germany's parliament building is set on fire, leading to drastic civil rights restrictions.

1933.event: Introduction of the first singing telegram
1933.summary: The first singing telegram is introduced, innovating the way messages are delivered.
Roosevelt is sworn in as president, famously asserting the need to overcome fear during the Great Depression.
Dachau, the first Nazi concentration camp, is completed to hold political prisoners.
Karl Jansky's detection of radio waves from the Milky Way is reported, marking the birth of radio astronomy.

1933.event: Prohibition ends in the United States
1933.summary: The ratification of the 21st Amendment repeals Prohibition, impacting social and cultural life significantly.
Air France is formed through the merger of multiple airline companies, enhancing international air travel.
FM radio is patented, revolutionizing broadcasting and music transmission.

1934.event: Establishment of the International Telecommunication Union
1934.summary: The International Telecommunication Union is established as a specialist agency of the League of Nations to manage international telecommunication.
An 8.0 Mw earthquake strikes Nepal and Bihar, killing an estimated 6,000 to 10,700 people.
Greece, Romania, Turkey, and Yugoslavia form the Balkan Pact to bolster regional cooperation and security.
Nazis purge the Sturmabteilung and political adversaries in a series of violent political murders.
The encounter between British and Italian forces in Ethiopian territory escalates tensions leading to the Abyssinia Crisis.

1934.event: Quintette du Hot Club de France performs
1934.summary: The continental jazz group led by Django Reinhardt performs for the first time in Paris, influencing jazz music.
Sergei Prokofiev's orchestral suite Lieutenant Kijé, becomes one of his most recognized works.

1934.event: Adolf Hitler becomes Führer of Germany
1934.summary: Following the death of President Paul von Hindenburg, Hitler consolidates power by becoming Führer of Germany.

1934.event: Death of King Albert I of Belgium
1934.summary: King Leopold III succeeds his father Albert I as the new king of Belgium.

1934.event: First Eastward flight across the Pacific Ocean
1934.summary: Charles Kingsford Smith makes history with the first eastward trans-Pacific flight.

1935.event: First Solo Flight from Hawaii to California
1935.summary: Amelia Earhart becomes the first person to successfully complete a solo flight from Hawaii to California, a distance of 2408 miles.
A plebiscite in the Territory of the Saar Basin shows that 90.3% of those voting wish to join Germany.
The discovery and clinical development of Prontosil, the first broadly effective antibiotic, is published in Germany's pre-eminent medical journal.
Adolf Hitler orders reinstatement of the air force, the Luftwaffe, in violation of the 1919 Treaty of Versailles.
The world's first regular television program is transmitted from the Funkturm in Berlin, Germany.
Joseph Stalin opens the Moscow Metro to the public.
Carlos Gardel, the legendary Franco-Argentine Father of Tango, dies in a plane crash in Medellín, Colombia.
The Government of India Act is passed by the British Parliament, establishing a degree of autonomy in India.
United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs the Social Security Act into law.

1935.event: First Airmail Cargo Across the Pacific
1935.summary: The flying boat China Clipper takes off to deliver the first airmail cargo across the Pacific Ocean.

1936.event: King Edward VIII ascends the throne
1936.summary: The Prince of Wales succeeds to the throne as King Edward VIII, following the death of his father, George V.
Radium E (bismuth-210) becomes the first radioactive element to be synthesized.
Construction of Hoover Dam is completed, marking a significant engineering achievement.
In defiance of the Treaty of Versailles, Nazi Germany reoccupies the Rhineland.
The Spanish Army initiates a coup against the Republican government, starting the Spanish Civil War.

1936.event: First live television coverage of the Olympics
1936.summary: The 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin witness the first live television coverage of an international sporting event.

1936.event: Establishment of the BBC television service
1936.summary: The BBC launches the world's first regular television service in high-definition.
King Edward VIII abdicates the throne, leading to the succession of his brother as King George VI.
In response to a polio outbreak, Chicago Public Schools launches a distance education program using radio broadcasts.
The first filmed Russian opera, Natalka Poltavka, is released in Ukraine.

1937.event: Spanish Civil War: Bombing of Guernica
1937.summary: The Bombing of Guernica is carried out in Spain by the Condor Legion of the Nazi German Luftwaffe, resulting in extensive destruction and loss of life.
The German airship Hindenburg bursts into flames while mooring in Lakehurst, New Jersey, killing 36 people.
Frank Whittle ground-tests the world's first jet engine designed to power an aircraft at Rugby, England, marking a significant advance in aviation technology.

1937.event: Release of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
1937.summary: Walt Disney's Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs premieres, becoming the world's first full-length animated feature film and influencing future animated works.
The new Constitution of Ireland comes into force, changing the name of the Irish Free State to Ireland and establishing Éamon de Valera as the first Taoiseach.

1937.event: Spanish Civil War: Fall of Málaga
1937.summary: Falangist troops take Málaga, a significant victory in the ongoing Spanish Civil War.
Pope Pius XI publishes an encyclical condemning Nazism in Germany, impacting Catholic and political responses to the regime.
The Battle of Nanjing begins during the Second Sino-Japanese War, leading to significant civilian casualties in what is later known as the Nanjing Massacre.

1937.event: Opening of the Golden Gate Bridge
1937.summary: The Golden Gate Bridge opens in San Francisco, becoming an iconic landmark and engineering achievement.

1937.event: First total solar eclipse over 7 minutes
1937.summary: A total solar eclipse lasting over 7 minutes is visible in the Pacific and Peru, a rare astronomical event.

1938.summary: State-owned railway networks are created by merger in France and the Netherlands

1938.event: Release of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
1938.summary: Walt Disney's Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, the first cel-animated feature, is released in the United States

1938.event: First Commercial Oil Discovery in Saudi Arabia
1938.summary: First commercial oil discovery in Saudi Arabia occurs at Dammam No. 7
German troops occupy Austria, which is later annexed by Germany
German, Italian, British, and French leaders agree to German demands regarding annexation of the Sudetenland in Czechoslovakia
DuPont announces a name for its new synthetic yarn, nylon
László Bíró patents the ballpoint pen in Britain

1938.event: Establishment of the Mauthausen Concentration Camp
1938.summary: The Mauthausen concentration camp is built in Austria
In Germany, the Night of Broken Glass begins as Nazi activists loot and burn Jewish businesses
Otto Hahn discovers the nuclear fission of uranium, marking the beginning of the Atomic Age

1939.summary: The Hewlett-Packard technology and scientific instruments manufacturing company is founded by Bill Hewlett and David Packard, marking the start of Silicon Valley.
Otto Hahn's discoveries in the field of nuclear fission are published, paving the way for future advancements in nuclear energy.
French physicist Marguerite Perey identifies francium, the last chemical element first discovered in nature.
The Spanish Civil War comes to an end when the last of the Republican forces surrender, altering the political landscape of Europe.
The Einstein–Szilard letter is signed by Albert Einstein, advising President Franklin D. Roosevelt about the potential use of uranium to construct an atomic bomb.
Germany invades Poland, marking the official beginning of World War II and affecting composers and citizens across Europe.
The United Kingdom and France declare war on Nazi Germany following the invasion of Poland, changing the course of European history.
The Soviet Union invades Poland, occupying eastern territories and signaling further conflict in Europe.
The Nazis storm the University of Prague, murdering students and closing Czech universities as a punishment against protests.
The first Jewish ghetto in Nazi-occupied Europe is proclaimed in Piotrków Trybunalski, marking the beginning of systematic segregation and persecution.

1940.event: Luftwaffe Chief assumes control of German war industries
1940.summary: Hermann Göring takes control of most war industries in Germany for the Four Year Plan
Finnish troops decisively defeat Soviet forces in the Battle of Suomussalmi

1940.event: Food rationing begins in the UK
1940.summary: Food rationing in the United Kingdom starts as a response to WWII
The Soviet Union and Finland sign a peace treaty ending the Winter War with harsh terms for Finland

1940.event: Evacuation of British Expeditionary Force from Dunkirk
1940.summary: The Dunkirk evacuation ends with the rescue of 300,000 troops from France to England
Winston Churchill takes office as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
The Battle of Britain commences as the Luftwaffe starts bombing London
Women's stockings made of nylon are first sold in the United States
The largest Nazi concentration and extermination camp in WWII opens near Oświęcim, Poland
Coventry suffers devastating bombing from the Luftwaffe, leading to massive destruction and loss of life

1941.summary: The Lend-Lease Act is introduced into the United States Congress, allowing the U.S. to supply military aid to Allied nations during WWII.
John Vincent Atanasoff and Clifford Berry describe the workings of the Atanasoff–Berry computer in print, marking a significant advance in computing technology.
Reserve Constable Albert Alexander becomes the first person treated with penicillin intravenously in Oxford, England, indicating a major medical advance.
The Nazi German Chełmno extermination camp opens in occupied Poland, with the first mass gassing of Jews, marking a horrific event in the Holocaust.
Commercial television is authorized in the United States, marking a new era in mass communication and entertainment.
The German battleship Bismarck is sunk in the North Atlantic, killing 2,300, significantly impacting naval warfare.
Walt Disney's animated film Dumbo is released in the United States, contributing to significant cultural developments in cinema.
Nazi Germany invades the Soviet Union in Operation Barbarossa, dramatically impacting the course of WWII and European history.
The attack on Pearl Harbor by Japanese forces leads the United States to enter WWII, dramatically changing the course of the conflict.
The Nazis issue orders leading to mass executions of Jews, marking a significant escalation in the Holocaust.

1942.summary: The Declaration by United Nations is signed by major powers agreeing not to make separate peace with the Axis powers.
The Sikorsky R-4, which will become the first mass-produced helicopter, completes its first flight.
Heinkel test pilot Helmut Schenk becomes the first person to escape from an aircraft with an ejection seat.
Nazis at the Wannsee Conference decide on the Final Solution to the Jewish problem.

1942.event: First American forces arrive in Europe
1942.summary: The first American forces land in Northern Ireland, marking a significant step in U.S. involvement in European conflict.
The United States achieves a decisive victory at the Battle of Midway, halting Japanese expansion in the Pacific.

1942.event: Leningrad première of Shostakovich's Symphony No. 7
1942.summary: Shostakovich's Symphony No. 7 is premiered in Leningrad amidst the siege, boosting morale among the residents.
Enrico Fermi initiates the first self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction at the University of Chicago.
The torpedoing of MV Struma carrying Jewish refugees leads to the drowning of about 791 people.
The American Federation of Musicians goes on strike against major U.S. recording companies over royalty payments.

1943.summary: The German 6th Army surrenders, marking a significant turning point in World War II.
Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's self-illustrated novella, The Little Prince, is published in New York City, becoming an iconic literary work.

1943.event: First flight of the Gloster Meteor
1943.summary: The Gloster Meteor, the first Allied jet fighter, makes its first flight in England, revolutionizing military aviation.
The Nazis liquidate the Kraków Ghetto, resulting in thousands of deaths, a grim reminder of the Holocaust's brutality.
The U.S. Army contracts to develop ENIAC, the first electronic general-purpose computer, which signifies a major leap in computing technology.
The RAF conducts the Dambuster Raid, using innovative bouncing bombs to breach dams, demonstrating advances in military engineering.
Nazi troops enter the Warsaw Ghetto to round up remaining Jews, igniting one of the most significant acts of resistance during the Holocaust.
Leaders Roosevelt, Churchill, and Stalin meet to discuss strategy against Axis powers, shaping post-war Europe.

1943.event: Leonard Bernstein conducts New York Philharmonic
1943.summary: Leonard Bernstein directs the New York Philharmonic, marking a pivotal moment in American classical music broadcasting.
The first Lebanese flag is drawn and signed, marking a significant symbol of Lebanon's national identity.

1944.event: Proposal of Second Bill of Rights
1944.summary: President Franklin D. Roosevelt proposes a Second Bill of Rights for social and economic security.

1944.event: Creation of the Provisional Government of the French Republic
1944.summary: The Provisional Government of the French Republic is established.

1944.event: Destruction of the Abbey of Monte Cassino
1944.summary: The Battle of Monte Cassino leads to the destruction of the monastery atop Monte Cassino by Allied bombing.
Allied forces capture Rome, the first Axis capital to fall.
Allied troops land on the beaches of Normandy, initiating Operation Overlord.
Forces of Free France liberate Paris from German occupation.
The Dumbarton Oaks Conference is held to plan the foundation of the United Nations.
Germany launches the first V-2 rocket attack on London.
Ruben Rausing patents a method for packaging milk in paper, laying the foundation for Tetra Pak.
Arturo Toscanini conducts a concert performance of Beethoven's Fidelio on NBC Radio, promoting its political message.

1945.summary: The Soviet Red Army liberates Auschwitz, a major concentration and extermination camp during the Holocaust, marking a significant moment in WWII.
The 'Big Three': Winston Churchill, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Joseph Stalin meet for the Yalta Conference to discuss post-war plans for Europe.
The United States drops an atomic bomb on Hiroshima, resulting in a devastating loss of life and marking the first use of nuclear weapons in warfare.
Nazi Germany formally surrenders, leading to Victory in Europe (VE) Day celebrations across Europe, marking the end of WWII in Europe.
The United States drops a second atomic bomb on Nagasaki, further influencing Japan's surrender in WWII.
Japan officially surrenders aboard the USS Missouri, signaling the end of World War II.
The United Nations is founded, aiming to promote international cooperation and prevent future conflicts.

1945.event: Liberation of the German-occupied Channel Islands
1945.summary: British forces liberate the Channel Islands from German occupation, restoring British control.

1945.event: Establishment of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam
1945.summary: Ho Chi Minh proclaims the establishment of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam, leading to significant changes in the region.
The Nuremberg Trials commence, bringing Nazi war criminals to justice and establishing precedents for international law.

1946.summary: The first meeting of the United Nations is held at Methodist Central Hall Westminster in London
Project Diana bounces radar waves off the Moon, proving that communication is possible between Earth and outer space
ENIAC, an early general-purpose electronic computer, is unveiled at the University of Pennsylvania
UNESCO is established as a specialized agency of the United Nations

1946.event: Italy votes to become a republic
1946.summary: Italians vote to turn Italy from a monarchy into a republic in a referendum
The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) is founded
The United States detonates the first underwater test of the atomic bomb during Operation Crossroads
The remaining ten Nazi war criminals sentenced at the Nuremberg trials are executed
Viet Minh forces begin a war against French occupying forces in Vietnam

1946.event: First artificial nuclear chain reaction in Europe
1946.summary: The first artificial, self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction in Europe is initiated in the Soviet nuclear reactor F-1

1947.summary: Nigeria gains autonomy from British law and governance, marking a significant step in its path towards independence.

1947.event: Canadian Citizenship Act comes into effect
1947.summary: The Canadian Citizenship Act comes into effect, establishing citizenship separate from British law.
Voice of America begins to transmit radio broadcasts into Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, impacting communication during the Cold War.
Edwin Land demonstrates the first instant camera, revolutionizing photography with the ability to print photos immediately.
The Truman Doctrine is proclaimed to help prevent the spread of Communism, significantly influencing U.S. foreign policy.
Secretary of State George Marshall outlines the Marshall Plan for reconstruction and relief aid to Europe, aiming to stabilize post-war economies.
The first Llangollen International Musical Eisteddfod is held in Wales, promoting cultural exchange through music.
Howard Hughes carries out the one and only flight of the Hughes H-4 Hercules, the largest aircraft ever built, drawing public attention.

1947.event: First use of the word computer
1947.summary: The term 'computer' is first recorded to refer to an electronic digital machine, marking a technological evolution.

1947.event: Founding of the Central Intelligence Agency
1947.summary: The CIA is officially established under the National Security Act of 1947, influencing U.S. intelligence operations.

1948.summary: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is inaugurated, promoting international trade.
Burma gains its independence from the United Kingdom, becoming the Union of Burma.
Indian pacifist and leader Mahatma Gandhi is assassinated in New Delhi.

1948.event: Formation of the Federation of Malaya
1948.summary: The Federation of Malaya is proclaimed, reshaping colonial administration.
Edvard Beneš cedes control of Czechoslovakia to the Communist Party.
United States President Harry S. Truman signs the Marshall Plan, providing aid to Europe.
Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 is played on television for the first time, conducted by Arturo Toscanini.
Israel declares its independence, with David Ben-Gurion as its first prime minister.
Columbia Records introduces its 33+1⁄3 rpm long playing phonograph format, revolutionizing music consumption.
The World Health Organization is established by the United Nations, focusing on public health.

1949.summary: A United Nations-sponsored ceasefire brings an end to the Indo-Pakistani War of 1947, resulting in a stalemate and the division of Kashmir.
The first networked television broadcasts take place as KDKA-TV in Pittsburgh goes on the air, connecting east coast and mid-west programming.
The North Atlantic Treaty is signed, creating the NATO defense alliance.
The first half of Giuseppe Verdi's opera Aida, conducted by Arturo Toscanini, is telecast live by NBC, marking a significant moment in television history.
The B-50 Superfortress Lucky Lady II completes the first non-stop around-the-world airplane flight, refueling in flight.
The Soviet Union lifts the Berlin Blockade, a significant event in post-war Europe.

1949.event: Foundation of the People's Republic of China
1949.summary: The People's Republic of China is officially proclaimed, marking a major shift in Chinese politics.
The de Havilland Comet, the world's first jet-powered airliner, makes its first flight in England.

1949.event: Establishment of the Federal Republic of Germany
1949.summary: The Federal Republic of Germany is officially founded, launching a new phase in German history.
Nereid, a moon of Neptune, is discovered by Gerard Kuiper, contributing to advancements in astronomy.

1950.event: Formation of the European Broadcasting Union
1950.summary: The European Broadcasting Union is founded to facilitate cooperation among public service broadcasters in Europe.
Influential British comic Eagle is launched, marking a significant moment in British children's literature.
The Korean War begins as North Korean forces invade South Korea, significantly impacting global geopolitics.
Robert Schuman presents his proposal for a pan-European organization, laying the groundwork for what would evolve into the European Union.
U.S. President Harry S. Truman orders the development of the hydrogen bomb in response to the Soviet atomic bomb test.

1950.event: First use of Diners Club card
1950.summary: The first payment is made by Diners Club card in New York, marking a significant advancement in payment technology.
Klaus Fuchs is convicted of spying for the Soviet Union, revealing significant security breaches in nuclear research.

1950.event: First Volkswagen Microbus rolls off the assembly line
1950.summary: The first Volkswagen Type 2, also known as the Microbus, is produced, becoming an iconic vehicle.
The first jet-to-jet dogfight in history occurs during the Korean War, marking a technological advancement in aerial combat.
Tenzin Gyatso, 15, is formally enthroned as the 14th Dalai Lama, influencing Tibetan culture and politics.

1951.summary: Mount Lamington in Papua New Guinea erupts catastrophically, killing nearly 3,000 people and causing great devastation in Oro Province.
Remington Rand delivers the first UNIVAC I computer to the United States Census Bureau.
Korean War: Armistice negotiations begin at Kaesong.
The Treaty of Paris is adopted, establishing the European Coal and Steel Community.
King George VI opens the Festival of Britain in London, including the Royal Festival Hall.

1951.event: First Atomic Bomb Tested with Tritium
1951.summary: Operation Greenhouse: The first atomic bomb boosted by the inclusion of tritium is tested in the Marshall Islands.
Gian Carlo Menotti's 45-minute opera, Amahl and the Night Visitors, premieres live on NBC in the United States.

1951.event: Formation of the National Ballet of Canada
1951.summary: The National Ballet of Canada performs for the first time in Eaton Auditorium, Toronto.
LEO runs the world's first commercial computer program, bakery valuations, for J. Lyons and Co.'s tea shops in the U.K.
The first Volkswagen Type 1 rolls off the production line in Uitenhage, South Africa.

1952.summary: Rioters burn Cairo's central business district, targeting British and upper-class Egyptian businesses.
Princess Elizabeth, on a visit to Kenya, learns of her father's death and becomes queen.

1952.event: First mechanical heart used in the US
1952.summary: In the United States, a mechanical heart is used for the first time in a human patient.
Greece and Turkey join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

1952.event: Establishment of the European Coal and Steel Community
1952.summary: The European Coal and Steel Community is established.
C. Walton Lillehei and F. John Lewis perform the first open-heart surgery, at the University of Minnesota.

1952.event: Milestone in aviation with non-stop Atlantic crossing
1952.summary: A British passenger jet makes a return crossing of the Atlantic Ocean in the same day.
Composer John Cage's 4′33″, during which the performer does not play, premieres in Woodstock, New York.
The first successful sex reassignment surgery is performed in Copenhagen on Christine Jorgensen.
The United States successfully detonates the first hydrogen bomb, codenamed 'Mike', at Eniwetok Atoll.

1953.summary: James Watson and Francis Crick announce their discovery of the structure of the DNA molecule, significantly advancing biological science.
Elizabeth II is crowned Queen of the United Kingdom and the Commonwealth realms at Westminster Abbey.
Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay become the first men to reach the summit of Mount Everest.
Jonas Salk announces his polio vaccine, which will significantly impact public health.
The Korean War ends with the signing of the Korean Armistice Agreement, dividing Korea into North and South.

1953.event: U.N. approves UNICEF as a permanent agency
1953.summary: UNICEF is made a permanent specialized agency of the United Nations, enhancing global child welfare initiatives.
The UNIVAC 1103 becomes the first commercial computer to use random-access memory, marking a milestone in computing technology.
Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are executed for espionage in the United States, sparking debates on anti-communism.
Georgi Malenkov announces that the Soviet Union has developed a hydrogen bomb, escalating the arms race.
Conductor Arturo Toscanini performs Beethoven's Eroica with the NBC Symphony Orchestra for the last time.

1954.event: First public demonstration of a machine translation system
1954.summary: The Georgetown–IBM experiment marks the first public demonstration of a machine translation system, showcasing advances in technology.

1954.event: Establishment of the National Negro Network
1954.summary: A new radio network aimed at improving representation and opportunities for African Americans is established in the U.S.
The first nuclear-powered submarine is launched, representing a significant advancement in naval technology.

1954.event: First mass vaccination of children against polio
1954.summary: The first mass vaccination against polio begins in Pittsburgh, marking a major public health initiative.

1954.event: Bill Haley & His Comets record Rock Around the Clock
1954.summary: Bill Haley records a song that will later spark the rock and roll craze, influencing music culture significantly.

1954.event: The world's first atomic power station opens
1954.summary: Obninsk becomes the site of the first operational atomic power station, a major step in the use of nuclear energy.
Elvis Presley's cover of That's All Right is released, marking the beginning of his monumental influence in music.
The Union of European Football Associations, UEFA, is established, which has a lasting impact on football in Europe.

1954.event: Formation of the Asian Football Confederation
1954.summary: The Asian Football Confederation is formed to promote and organize football in Asia.
The release of the first Godzilla film introduces a significant cultural phenomenon in cinema and pop culture.

1955.summary: The first nuclear-powered submarine, USS Nautilus, puts to sea for the first time, showcasing advancements in naval technology.
The Pentagon announces a plan to develop intercontinental ballistic missiles armed with nuclear weapons, marking a significant step in military technology.
The Salk polio vaccine receives full approval by the FDA, offering protection against a disease that has affected countless individuals.
The Broadway musical Peter Pan is presented on television for the first time in its entirety, setting a precedent in televised musical performances.
The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization is established, indicating a shift in international alliances and military cooperation.
The Disneyland theme park opens, marking a significant cultural and entertainment development in the United States.
Little Richard records Tutti Frutti, a groundbreaking track that would significantly influence the music industry and popular culture.
Commercial television begins in the UK with the Independent Television Authority's first franchises, ending a long-standing BBC monopoly.
70-mm film for projection is introduced with the release of the musical film Oklahoma!, enhancing cinematic experiences.
Austria declares its permanent neutrality after the last Allied troops leave, marking a significant political change in Europe.

1956.summary: The first Eurovision Song Contest is broadcast from Lugano, Switzerland, showcasing European music talent.
Elvis Presley enters the United States music charts for the first time with Heartbreak Hotel, marking a significant moment in rock music.
Doris Day records Que Sera, Sera, her most famous song, from the film The Man Who Knew Too Much, contributing to film and music culture.

1956.event: My Fair Lady opens on Broadway
1956.summary: The Broadway musical My Fair Lady opens in New York City, becoming a significant cultural milestone in theatre.
Ampex demonstrates the first practical and commercially successful videotape format at the 1956 NARTB convention in Chicago, revolutionizing television broadcasting.
The world's first industrial-scale commercial nuclear power plant is opened at Calder Hall in England, marking a significant technological advancement.
The Suez Crisis begins with plans for military intervention by the United Kingdom, France, and Israel, impacting global politics and music composers expressing dissent.
The Hungarian Revolution breaks out, challenging the pro-Soviet government and inspiring artists and musicians globally.

1956.event: Elvis Presley performs on Ed Sullivan Show
1956.summary: Elvis Presley appears on The Ed Sullivan Show in the United States for the first time, becoming a cultural phenomenon.
Labour riots in Poznań, Poland, are crushed by Soviet troops, highlighting the struggle against oppression and inspiring composers.

1957.summary: The Saarland becomes part of West Germany, marking a significant political change in post-war Europe.
The Hamilton Watch Company introduces the first electric watch, revolutionizing timekeeping technology.
Harold Macmillan takes office as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, influencing British politics for years to come.
The Treaty of Rome establishes the EEC, paving the way for deeper economic integration in Europe.
IBM sells the first compiler for the Fortran programming language, advancing scientific computing capabilities.
The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 1, marking the start of the Space Age and space exploration.
The Jodrell Bank radio telescope is controlled for the first time, contributing to advancements in astrophysics.
Laika, a dog, becomes the first animal to orbit the Earth aboard Sputnik 2, highlighting advancements in space exploration.
The Boeing 707 airliner flies for the first time, transforming commercial aviation and global travel.
The USS Nautilus logs its 60,000th nautical mile, showcasing advancements in military technology and naval power.

1958.summary: The European Economic Community comes into being
Seven Manchester United footballers are killed in a plane crash
The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 3 into space
Van Cliburn wins the International Tchaikovsky Competition, easing Cold War tensions
Jack Kilby invents the first integrated circuit at Texas Instruments
The first widely offered credit card is launched in the United States

1958.event: Introduction of Color Television in the US
1958.summary: NBC broadcasts the first television show recorded on color videotape
The United States launches SCORE, the world's first communications satellite

1958.event: Rise of the Fifth Republic in France
1958.summary: The new Constitution of France is established, creating the Fifth Republic
British Overseas Airways Corporation becomes the first airline to fly jet passenger services across the Atlantic

1959.summary: Fulgencio Batista flees Havana when the forces of Fidel Castro advance
Soviet lunar probe Luna 1 becomes the first human-made object to attain escape velocity from Earth
Alaska is admitted as the 49th U.S. state
Fidel Castro becomes Premier of Cuba
Vanguard 2, the first weather satellite, is launched to measure cloud cover for the U.S. Navy
A chartered plane carrying musicians Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens, and The Big Bopper crashes, killing all on board
Vanguard 1, the first satellite powered by solar cells, is launched by the United States
The first successful test firing of a Titan intercontinental ballistic missile is accomplished
Lunar probe Pioneer 4 becomes the first American object to escape Earth’s gravity

1959.event: Establishment of the European Court of Human Rights
1959.summary: The European Court of Human Rights is established

1960.summary: Construction of the Aswan Dam begins in Egypt.
The first CERN particle accelerator becomes operational in Geneva, Switzerland.
France tests its first atomic bomb in Algeria.
The United States launches the first weather satellite, TIROS-1.
Arthur Leonard Schawlow and Charles Hard Townes receive the first patent for a laser in the USA.
The USS Triton completes the first underwater circumnavigation of the Earth.
The Belgian Congo receives its independence from Belgium.
A U.S. spy plane is shot down over the Soviet Union, escalating Cold War tensions.
The Bluebell Railway opens in southern England, becoming the world's first standard gauge passenger preserved railway.

1961.summary: United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower announces that the United States has severed diplomatic and consular relations with Cuba
Patrice Lumumba of the Republic of Congo is assassinated
President John F. Kennedy delivers the first live presidential news conference, discussing key issues including a USAF reconnaissance plane shot down

1961.event: Soviet Cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin in Space
1961.summary: Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin becomes the first human to fly in outer space

1961.event: The Beatles Perform at The Cavern Club
1961.summary: The Beatles perform under this name at The Cavern Club for the first time following their return to Liverpool from Hamburg
Element 103, Lawrencium, is first synthesized in Berkeley, California
The 'Ken' doll is introduced in the United States, expanding the Barbie franchise

1961.event: The Federal Republic of Cameroon Formed
1961.summary: The formerly British Southern Cameroons gains independence from the United Kingdom and joins with formerly French Cameroun
Alan Shepard becomes the first American in space aboard Mercury-Redstone 3
United States President John F. Kennedy establishes the Peace Corps

1962.summary: A U-2 flight over Cuba photographs Soviet nuclear weapons being installed, leading to a 12-day standoff that threatens nuclear war.
John Glenn becomes the first American to orbit the Earth three times aboard Friendship 7, marking a significant achievement in the space race.
Algeria gains independence from France as the referendum yields a 99% majority in favor of independence.
AT&T launches Telstar, the world's first commercial communications satellite, revolutionizing global communications.

1962.event: The Beatles Release Their First Single
1962.summary: The Beatles release Love Me Do, marking the start of their influence on music and pop culture.
Marvel Comics introduces the character Hulk, expanding the comic book landscape and influencing future media.
Supporters of Algeria's independence achieve a 99% majority in a referendum.
NASA's Mariner 2 passes by Venus, becoming the first spacecraft to transmit data from another planet.
Spider-Man is introduced by Marvel Comics, influencing future comic book and film narratives.
Armed Cuban exile terrorists fire at a hotel in Havana, highlighting the tension in post-revolutionary Cuba.

1963.summary: France and West Germany sign the Élysée Treaty strengthening cooperation between the two nations.
The European Court of Justice's ruling in Van Gend en Loos v Nederlandse Administratie der Belastingen establishes the principle of direct effect, a key tenet of European Union law.
Dansevise wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1963 for Denmark, impacting music composition across Europe.
The US, UK, and Soviet Union sign the Partial Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, marking a significant step in nuclear disarmament during the Cold War.
Soviet cosmonaut Valentina Tereshkova becomes the first woman in space, a milestone in space exploration.
U.S. President John F. Kennedy is assassinated, a pivotal event that affects global politics and society.
The first instant replay system using videotape is demonstrated during a live sports event, revolutionizing sports broadcasting.
John F. Kennedy delivers his famous speech in West Berlin, reinforcing U.S. commitment to defending West Berlin.
Malaysia is formed through the merging of several territories, a significant political change in Southeast Asia.
A major heist in England where robbers steal a large sum of money, captivating public attention and media coverage.

1964.event: Establishment of the European Space Research Organization
1964.summary: The precursor of the European Space Agency is established per an agreement signed on June 14.
NASA launches Ranger 6 on a mission to carry television cameras and crash-land on the Moon.

1964.event: Establishment of diplomatic relations between France and China
1964.summary: France and the People's Republic of China announce their decision to establish diplomatic relations.

1964.event: First televised images of the Moon
1964.summary: Ranger 7 sends back the first close-up photographs of the Moon, significantly advancing lunar studies.
The Soviet Union launches Voskhod 1, the first spacecraft with a multi-person crew and the first flight without space suits.
The first computer program written in BASIC, a new and accessible programming language, is run, marking a significant step in computing.

1964.event: First Eurovison Song Contest win for Italy
1964.summary: The song Non ho l'età wins the Eurovision Song Contest, shaping future music trends and inspiring composers.

1964.event: Introduction of significant civil rights legislation in the US
1964.summary: The United States authorizes the Twenty-fourth Amendment to outlaw the poll tax, a landmark change that impacts voting rights.

1964.event: First high-speed rail system, Shinkansen, inaugurated
1964.summary: Japan inaugurates the Shinkansen high-speed rail system, pioneering fast, efficient rail travel.
The first Grammy Awards are held, recognizing outstanding achievements in the music industry.

1965.summary: The state funeral of Sir Winston Churchill takes place in London with the largest assembly of dignitaries in the world until the 2005 funeral of Pope John Paul II.
Trofim Lysenko is removed from his post as director of the Institute of Genetics at the Academy of Sciences in the Soviet Union, marking the end of Lysenkoist theories.
The African and Malagasy Common Organization is formed as a successor to the Afro-Malagasy Union for Economic Cooperation.
The Gambia becomes independent from the United Kingdom.
Cosmonaut Alexei Leonov leaves his Voskhod 2 spacecraft for 12 minutes, becoming the first person to walk in space.
Mass in the Catholic Church worldwide is said in local languages instead of Latin for the first time.

1965.event: Winning of Eurovision by France Gall
1965.summary: 'Poupée de cire, poupée de son', sung by France Gall, wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1965 for Luxembourg.
NASA launches the United States' first 2-person crew into Earth orbit aboard Gemini 3.
The Intelsat I communications satellite is launched, which becomes a major step in satellite communications.
The Soviet Union launches the Venera 3 space probe toward Venus, marking the first spacecraft to reach the surface of another planet.

1966.summary: A bloody military coup occurs in Nigeria, resulting in the death of Prime Minister Abubakar Tafawa Balewa and the installation of a military government.
Indira Gandhi is elected as the Prime Minister of India, marking the beginning of her significant political career.

1966.event: First spacecraft lands on the Moon
1966.summary: The unmanned Soviet Luna 9 spacecraft achieves the first controlled rocket-assisted landing on the Moon.

1966.event: Soviet space probe Venera 3 crashes on Venus
1966.summary: The Soviet space probe Venera 3 crashes on Venus, becoming the first spacecraft to land on another planet's surface.
The Soviet Union launches Luna 10, which becomes the first space probe to enter orbit around the Moon.
The British Government announces plans for the decimalisation of the pound sterling, set to be implemented in 1971.
John Lennon of The Beatles claims the band to be more popular than Jesus, sparking controversy and media attention.
NASA spacecraft Gemini 8 conducts the first docking in space with an Agena target vehicle.
The opening of the Parliament of the United Kingdom is televised for the first time.

1966.event: World premiere of Antony and Cleopatra
1966.summary: The Metropolitan Opera House opens at Lincoln Center in New York City with the world premiere of Samuel Barber's opera Antony and Cleopatra.

1967.event: Christiaan Barnard carries out first heart transplant
1967.summary: The world's first heart transplant is successfully performed by Christiaan Barnard at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town.

1967.event: The Velvet Underground's first album is released
1967.summary: The Velvet Underground releases their self-titled debut album, which later gains significant acclaim and influences the music industry.

1967.event: The Beatles' 'All You Need Is Love' is broadcast live
1967.summary: The first live international satellite television production features The Beatles debuting their song 'All You Need Is Love', watched by 400 million viewers.

1967.event: The launch of the first automatic cash machine
1967.summary: The world's first automatic cash machine is installed by Barclays Bank in Enfield, revolutionizing banking.
Montreal's Expo 67 World's Fair opens, attracting over 310,000 visitors on the first day and showcasing technological innovations.

1967.event: First UK color television broadcasts begin
1967.summary: The UK launches its first color television broadcasts on BBC2 during the Wimbledon Championships.

1967.event: Puppet on a String wins Eurovision
1967.summary: Sandie Shaw's song 'Puppet on a String' wins the Eurovision Song Contest, marking a significant moment in music history for the UK.

1967.event: The Jimi Hendrix Experience releases Are You Experienced
1967.summary: The debut album of The Jimi Hendrix Experience, 'Are You Experienced', is released, marking a pivotal moment in rock music.
Lunar Orbiter 3 is launched by NASA in a mission to map the surface of the Moon.
The EEC merges with the European Coal and Steel Community and the European Atomic Community to form the European Communities.

1968.summary: Viet Cong forces launch a series of surprise attacks across South Vietnam, marking a significant escalation in the Vietnam War.
Alexander Dubček is chosen as leader of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia, initiating a period of political liberalization.
The Winter Olympics are held in Grenoble, France, showcasing international athletic competition.
The second and last uncrewed test-flight of the Saturn V launch vehicle takes place, furthering space exploration efforts.

1968.event: Assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.
1968.summary: Civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. is assassinated, sparking riots and widespread mourning across the USA.
Surgeons in Paris perform Europe's first heart transplant, marking a significant advancement in medical technology.
Spain wins the Eurovision Song Contest, highlighting the event's cultural significance in Europe.
The Warsaw Pact invades Czechoslovakia, crushing the Prague Spring reforms and ending attempts at political liberalization.
NASA launches Apollo 7, the first crewed mission that includes live television broadcasts from orbit.

1968.event: Summer Olympics held in Mexico City
1968.summary: The 1968 Summer Olympics take place, highlighting global athletic talent and social issues.

1969.summary: Neil Armstrong becomes the first human to step onto the Moon during the Apollo 11 mission
The Boeing 747 jumbo jet makes its first passenger flight carrying 191 people from Seattle to New York City
The Woodstock Festival is held, featuring top rock musicians and marking a pivotal moment in music history
Apollo 10 is launched as a full rehearsal for the upcoming Moon landing
Experimental research showing that protons were composed of smaller particles, the first evidence of quarks, is published
The first electronic message is sent between two computers, marking a significant development towards the Internet
Apollo 12 is launched, marking the second crewed mission to the Moon
The first test flight of the Concorde occurs in Toulouse, France
Soviet space probes Venera 5 and Venera 6 successfully land on Venus, providing important atmospheric data
A draft lottery for the Vietnam War is held in the United States, affecting many young Americans

1970.summary: Unix time epoch reached at 00:00:00 UTC
A 7.1 Mw earthquake shakes Tonghai County, China, killing between 10,000 and 14,621 and injuring 30,000
Biafra capitulates, ending the Nigerian Civil War
Ohsumi, Japan's first satellite, is launched on a Lambda-4 rocket
The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty goes into effect after ratification by 56 nations
The Expo '70 World's Fair opens in Suita, Osaka
The Soviet Tupolev Tu-144 becomes the first commercial transport to exceed Mach 2
Luna 16 lands on the Moon and returns with samples
The United States Environmental Protection Agency is established

1970.event: Formation of the International Council of Organizations of Folklore Festivals and Folk Arts
1970.summary: Creation of the International Council of Organizations of Folklore Festivals and Folk Arts in Confolens, France

1971.summary: First ever One Day International cricket match is played between Australia and England

1971.event: Release of All in the Family
1971.summary: Landmark United States television sitcom All in the Family debuts on CBS
The Aswan High Dam officially opens in Egypt
Apollo 14 lifts off for the third successful lunar landing mission

1971.event: Decimal Day in UK and Ireland
1971.summary: Both the United Kingdom and Ireland switch to decimal currency
US, UK, USSR and others sign treaty outlawing nuclear weapons on the ocean floor

1971.event: First Public Performance of Stairway to Heaven
1971.summary: Led Zeppelin performs Stairway to Heaven for the first time in Belfast
Apollo 14 successfully lands on the Moon
A significant earthquake strikes the Greater Los Angeles Area
Led Zeppelin releases their fourth studio album which becomes one of the best-selling albums

1972.summary: The introduction of the first scientific hand-held calculator revolutionizes computing and mathematics for professionals and students.
Apollo 16 is launched, continuing the United States' missions to explore the Moon and advancing lunar science.
Somalia officially introduces a standardized alphabet, impacting education and literacy in the country.
The United States launches Landsat 1, marking the beginning of resource monitoring from space.
Pioneer 10 is launched, becoming the first spacecraft to travel through the asteroid belt and to study Jupiter.
The British Army's killing of 14 unarmed civil rights marchers prompts widespread outrage and intensifies the conflict in Northern Ireland.
The signing of the SALT I treaty between the USA and USSR marks a pivotal moment in arms control during the Cold War.
Luxembourg wins the Eurovision Song Contest with Après toi, showcasing European music and culture.
A terrorist attack during the Summer Olympics leads to the deaths of 11 Israeli athletes, shocking the world and impacting future security protocols.
Apollo 17 is launched, the final crewed mission to the Moon, exemplifying the culmination of lunar exploration.

1973.summary: The United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland and Denmark enter the European Economic Community

1973.event: End of U.S. Vietnam War Involvement
1973.summary: U.S. involvement in the Vietnam War ends with the signing of the Paris Peace Accords
The first handheld mobile phone call is made by Martin Cooper of Motorola
Skylab, the United States' first space station, is launched

1973.event: Opening of the Sydney Opera House
1973.summary: The Sydney Opera House is opened by Elizabeth II
The fourth and largest Arab-Israeli conflict begins with the Yom Kippur War
An OPEC oil embargo against several countries supporting Israel triggers the 1973 energy crisis

1973.event: Signing of Cease-fire Accord Between Egypt and Israel
1973.summary: Egypt and Israel sign a United States-sponsored cease-fire accord

1973.event: Launch of the Mariner 10 Space Probe

1974.event: Formation of New Government in Turkey
1974.summary: Bülent Ecevit of CHP forms the new government of Turkey
After a record 84 days in orbit, the crew of Skylab 4 returns to Earth
Turkish Airlines Flight 981 crashes near Paris, killing all 346 aboard.
End of five-month oil embargo by most OPEC nations against the US, Europe, and Japan.
Launch of the Volkswagen Golf in West Germany, expected to replace the iconic Volkswagen Beetle.
Swedish pop group ABBA wins the 1974 Eurovision Song Contest in Brighton, England.
A left-wing military coup in Portugal restores democracy, ending 41 years of dictatorship.
India successfully detonates its first nuclear weapon, becoming the 6th nation to do so.
The 1974 FIFA World Cup Association football tournament begins in West Germany.
The Arecibo Observatory sends an interstellar radio message towards Messier 13.

1975.summary: Jazz pianist Keith Jarrett plays the solo improvisation The Köln Concert at the Cologne Opera, becoming the best-selling piano recording in history.
The Vietnam War concludes with the Fall of Saigon as Communist forces from North Vietnam take over Saigon, resulting in mass evacuation.
The Helsinki Accords, which officially recognize Europe's national borders and respect for human rights, are signed in Finland.
Angola becomes independent from Portugal, leading to civil war.
The first Cricket World Cup is held in England, with West Indies defeating Australia in the final.

1975.event: First colour television broadcasts in Australia
1975.summary: Australian television switches to full-time colour, marking a major shift in broadcasting.
Bill Gates and Paul Allen found Microsoft and release their Altair BASIC interpreter, marking a significant advance in personal computing.
A terrorist attack in downtown Jerusalem kills 15 civilians and wounds 77, highlighting the ongoing conflict in the region.
The Suez Canal opens for the first time since the Six-Day War, affecting global shipping routes.
Mozambique gains independence from Portugal, marking a significant change in the region's political landscape.

1976.event: International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights enters into force
1976.summary: The International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights enters into force, establishing important international standards for human rights and cultural development.
Apple Computer Company is formed by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak in California, marking a significant advancement in personal computer technology.
The Cray-1, the first commercially developed supercomputer, is released, paving the way for advancements in computing and technology.
The Eurovision Song Contest 1976 is won by Brotherhood of Man, representing the United Kingdom, with their song Save Your Kisses for Me, highlighting the significance of music competitions in Europe.

1976.event: Introduction of the first LAGEOS satellite
1976.summary: The first LAGEOS (Laser Geodynamics Satellite) is launched, contributing to advancements in satellite technology and geodesy.
The Viking 1 lander successfully lands on Mars, marking a major milestone in space exploration and sending back valuable data.
The Big Thompson River in northern Colorado floods, destroying over 400 cars and houses and killing 143 people, impacting communities and emergency responses.

1976.event: Formation of Irish rock band U2
1976.summary: Irish rock band U2 is formed after drummer Larry Mullen, Jr. posts a note seeking members for a band, influencing the music landscape significantly.
Czechoslovakia beats West Germany to win Euro 76 on penalties, showcasing the importance of football in European culture.
Patty Hearst is sentenced to seven years in prison for her role in the armed robbery of a San Francisco bank, reflecting significant crime and social issues of the time.

1977.summary: Three bombs explode in Moscow, killing seven, attributed to an Armenian separatist group.
Australia's worst railway disaster at Granville leaves 83 people dead.
Scientists identify a previously unknown bacterium as the cause of Legionnaires' disease.
A collision between KLM and Pan Am Boeing 747s in Tenerife kills 583 people, the deadliest aviation accident.
The Soviet Union launches Soyuz 24 to dock with the Salyut 5 space station.

1977.event: First test flight of Space Shuttle Enterprise
1977.summary: The first test flight of Space Shuttle Enterprise mated to the Boeing 747 Shuttle Carrier Aircraft occurs.
The rings of the planet Uranus are discovered.
Spain holds its first democratic elections after 41 years of Francoist rule.
The last natural smallpox case is discovered in Somalia, marking a success for vaccination efforts.

1977.event: Release of Never Mind the Bollocks
1977.summary: The British punk band Sex Pistols releases their debut album, which enters the UK Album Charts at number one.

1978.summary: A Boeing 747 passenger jet crashes off the coast of Bombay, killing 213.
Soviet satellite Kosmos 954 burns up in Earth's atmosphere, scattering radioactive debris over Canada's Northwest Territories.

1978.event: First broadcast of U.S. Senate proceedings on radio
1978.summary: U.S. Senate proceedings are broadcast on radio for the first time.
The first global positioning satellite, Navstar 1, is launched by the United States.
Izhar Cohen & the Alphabeta win the Eurovision Song Contest 1978 for Israel with their song A-Ba-Ni-Bi.

1978.event: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy radio episode
1978.summary: The first radio episode of The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy is transmitted on BBC Radio 4.
Giuseppe Verdi's opera Otello makes its first appearance on Live from the Met, marking a significant cultural event.
The 'Democratic Republic of Afghanistan' is proclaimed, marking a significant political change.

1978.event: First ascent of Mount Everest without supplemental oxygen
1978.summary: Reinhold Messner and Peter Habeler make the first ascent of Mount Everest without supplemental oxygen.

1978.event: Soviet ban on Aristotelian works lifted
1978.summary: The People's Republic of China lifts a ban on works by Aristotle, William Shakespeare, and Charles Dickens.

1979.summary: The Music for UNICEF Concert is held at the United Nations General Assembly to raise money for UNICEF and promote the Year of the Child, featuring performances from various artists.
Philips demonstrates the compact disc publicly for the first time, marking a major technical advance in audio technology.
The Iranian Revolution ends with the Iranian army withdrawing and power transferred to Ayatollah Khomeini, leading to significant political change and societal impact.
A Soviet biowarfare laboratory accidentally releases airborne anthrax spores, resulting in numerous fatalities and raising international concerns about biological safety.

1979.event: Pope John Paul II Visits Poland
1979.summary: Pope John Paul II arrives in Poland on his first official visit, significantly impacting Polish society and the Solidarity movement against Communism.
The Sony Walkman goes on sale for the first time in Japan, revolutionizing how music is consumed and enjoyed by individuals.
The U.S. Pioneer 11 spacecraft becomes the first to visit Saturn, marking a significant achievement in space exploration.
Hong Kong opens its rapid transit railway system, the MTR, enhancing urban transportation.
Eleven fans are killed during a crowd crush for unreserved seats before The Who rock concert, raising awareness about crowd management at events.
Pink Floyd releases The Wall, a rock opera concept album that becomes one of the best-selling albums of all time, deeply influencing music culture.

1980.summary: U.S. President Jimmy Carter proclaims a grain embargo against the USSR with the support of the European Commission
Global Positioning System time epoch begins at 00:00 UTC
Andrei Sakharov, Soviet scientist and human rights activist, is arrested in Moscow

1980.event: Establishment of diplomatic relations between Israel and Egypt
1980.summary: Israel and Egypt establish diplomatic relations

1980.event: First rock music festival in USSR
1980.summary: The Soviet Union's first rock music festival starts
Iron Maiden's debut self-titled album is released in the U.K.
The first 24-hour news channel, Cable News Network (CNN), is launched
Digital Equipment Corporation, Intel and Xerox introduce the DIX standard for Ethernet
Former Beatles member and peace activist John Lennon is shot dead outside his home in New York
The nationwide independent trade union Solidarity is established in Poland after weeks of strikes

1981.event: Greece joins the European Economic Community
1981.summary: Greece enters the European Economic Community, predecessor of the European Union
The first DeLorean automobile, a stainless steel sports car with gull-wing doors, rolls off the production line
A fire at the Stardust nightclub in Dublin, Ireland, kills 48 young people and injures 214
Space Shuttle Columbia launches on the STS-1 mission, the first time a crewed reusable spacecraft has returned from orbit
Provisional Irish Republican Army member Bobby Sands begins a hunger strike for political status at HM Prison Maze
The first 24-hour video music channel MTV is launched in the United States, airing its first video
The original Model 5150 IBM PC is released in the United States

1981.event: Pope John Paul II assassination attempt
