1981.summary: Pope John Paul II is shot by Mehmet Ali Ağca as he enters St. Peter's Square in Vatican City

1981.event: First female U.S. Supreme Court justice nominated
1981.summary: President Ronald Reagan nominates Sandra Day O'Connor as the first woman to the Supreme Court
Wojciech Jaruzelski declares martial law in Poland to prevent the dismantling of the communist system by Solidarity

1982.summary: The first computer virus, the Elk Cloner, is discovered, infecting Apple II computers via floppy disk.
Senegal and The Gambia form a loose confederation, aiming for greater political and economic cooperation.
Argentine forces invade the Falkland Islands, marking the start of the Falklands War.

1982.event: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
1982.summary: Canada patriates its constitution, gaining full independence and including an entrenched bill of rights.
German singer Nicole wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1982 with the song Ein Bisschen Frieden.
During the Falklands War, HMS Sheffield is struck by an Argentine Exocet missile, resulting in 20 fatalities.
The first compact discs (CDs) are produced in Germany, marking a significant advance in music technology.

1982.event: Death of Princess Grace of Monaco
1982.summary: Princess Grace of Monaco dies in a car crash, leading to significant public mourning.
Michael Jackson releases his sixth studio album Thriller, which will become the best-selling album of all time.
Swedish pop group ABBA makes their final public performance on British television.

1983.summary: The migration of the ARPANET to TCP/IP is officially completed, marking the beginning of the true Internet.
The 3D printer is invented by Chuck Hull, representing a significant advance in technology.
Two research groups independently declare a novel retrovirus may be infecting people with HIV/AIDS, leading to profound social implications.
The Disney Channel launches in the United States, impacting media and entertainment.
The first worldwide mobile telephone, the Motorola DynaTAC, enters the market, changing communication methods.
Simultaneous suicide truck-bombings kill numerous U.S. servicemen and French paratroopers, escalating Middle Eastern tensions.

1983.event: Introduction of the mobile cellular telephone
1983.summary: The world's first commercial mobile cellular telephone call is made in Chicago, marking a tech milestone.
At the 17th General Conference on Weights and Measures, the metre is redefined in terms of the speed of light, affecting scientific standards.
Multi-Tool Word, which later becomes Microsoft Word, is released, impacting how documents are created and edited.

1983.event: The television movie The Day After
1983.summary: ABC aired The Day After, a highly impactful and controversial TV movie focused on nuclear war.

1984.summary: Steve Jobs launches the Macintosh personal computer in the United States.

1984.event: Release of 1984 album by Van Halen
1984.summary: Van Halen releases their sixth studio album 1984, which debuts at number 2 on the Billboard 200 albums chart.
Astronauts Bruce McCandless II and Robert L. Stewart make the first untethered space walk.
The 1984 Summer Olympics are held in Los Angeles, California.
The science fiction action film The Terminator premieres, directed by James Cameron.
A methyl isocyanate leak from a pesticide plant in Bhopal, India kills thousands in the worst industrial disaster in history.
The Soviet Union announces that it will boycott the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles.
The Canadian entertainment company Cirque du Soleil is founded.
TED conference is founded, bringing together technology, entertainment, and design.
Band Aid records the charity single Do They Know It's Christmas? to raise money to combat the famine in Ethiopia.

1985.event: Creation of the Internet's Domain Name System
1985.summary: The Internet's Domain Name System is created.
Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency launches Sakigake, Japan's first interplanetary spacecraft.

1985.event: Formation of the Economic Cooperation Organization
1985.summary: The Economic Cooperation Organization (ECO) is formed in Tehran.
The charity single record 'We Are the World' is recorded by USA for Africa.

1985.event: First patient leaves hospital with artificial heart
1985.summary: William J. Schroeder becomes the first patient with an artificial heart to leave the hospital.
The GNU Manifesto, written by Richard Stallman, is first published.
The Schengen Agreement is signed, creating the Schengen Area.
Live Aid benefit concerts in London and Philadelphia raise over £50 million for famine relief in Ethiopia.
Scientists announce the discovery of the ozone hole.
Microsoft Corporation releases the first U.S. release of Windows 1.0.

1986.event: Spain and Portugal enter the European Community
1986.summary: Spain and Portugal officially join the European Community, marking a significant expansion of the European Union.
The United Kingdom and France announce plans to construct the Channel Tunnel, improving transportation links between the two countries.
The Space Shuttle Challenger disintegrates shortly after launch, killing all seven astronauts on board, including a schoolteacher.
Halley's Comet passes closest to the Sun during its second visit to the solar system in the 20th century.
The Single European Act is signed, aiming to create a single market within the European Community.
The Soviet Union launches the Mir space station, a significant achievement in space exploration.
A catastrophic nuclear accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant releases radioactive material, affecting many countries.

1986.event: People Power Revolution in the Philippines
1986.summary: The People Power Revolution results in the ousting of President Ferdinand Marcos, leading to a democratic government.

1986.event: The Phantom of the Opera opens
1986.summary: The Phantom of the Opera, the longest-running Broadway show in history, premieres in London.
Rutan Voyager completes the first nonstop circumnavigation of the earth by air without refueling.

1987.summary: The first naked-eye supernova since 1604 is observed, significantly impacting astronomical studies and public interest in space.
Stock market levels fall sharply worldwide, leading to economic concerns that affect citizens and investors alike.
Michael Jackson releases his first studio album since Thriller, impacting music culture and trends worldwide.
AZT is approved for use in the treatment of HIV/AIDS, marking a significant advancement in medical science.

1987.event: Completion of the Euro Disney agreement
1987.summary: An agreement to construct Euro Disney Resort is signed, impacting tourism and culture in France.
The world's first conference on artificial life is held, promoting advances in technology and biology.
Canada introduces a one-dollar coin, affecting currency use and public interactions with money.

1987.event: Mass Rapid Transit opens in Singapore
1987.summary: The MRT system opens for passenger service, transforming public transport in Singapore.
The Single European Act is passed, introducing significant changes in the governance of the European Community.

1987.event: Creation of the Vanuatu Labour Party
1987.summary: The Vanuatu Labour Party is founded, indicating political changes in the region.

1988.summary: The Soviet Union starts its program of economic restructuring known as perestroika, initiated by Premier Mikhail Gorbachev.
The 1988 Winter Olympics are held in Calgary, Alberta, Canada, showcasing winter sports on an international stage.
The Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast votes to secede from Azerbaijan, sparking the First Nagorno-Karabakh War.
The Poole explosion causes a significant evacuation and is marked as the largest peacetime evacuation in the UK since World War II.
A mass demonstration in Estonia sees 300,000 people gather to push for independence from the Soviet Union.
A ceasefire effectively ends the long and devastating Iran–Iraq War, marking a significant moment for peace after years of conflict.
The Spitak earthquake strikes Soviet Armenia, killing nearly 25,000 people and causing massive homelessness and destruction.
The first transatlantic telephone cable using optical fibers is completed, improving communication links between America and Europe.
The first World AIDS Day is celebrated, raising awareness on the disease and its global impact.
Benazir Bhutto is sworn in as Prime Minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman to lead a government in an Islamic state.

1989.summary: East Germany opens checkpoints in the Berlin Wall, allowing its citizens to travel freely to West Germany for the first time in decades.
Pro-democracy protesters gather in Tiananmen Square, Beijing, leading to a violent military crackdown.

1989.event: Launch of the World Wide Web proposal
1989.summary: Tim Berners-Lee produces the proposal document that will become the blueprint for the World Wide Web.
The Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM) is adopted, providing a framework for mobile telecommunications.
Cuban troops begin withdrawing from Angola in accordance with international agreements.
Eurosport, a multiple-language sports broadcasting station in Europe, begins broadcasting.
The Polish Government and Solidarity sign an agreement restoring Solidarity to legal status and agreeing to hold democratic elections.
Mass demonstrations in Hungary demand democracy, significantly influencing the political landscape.
Motorola introduces the MicroTAC personal cellular telephone, the world's smallest mobile phone at this time.
The Exxon Valdez oil spill occurs in Alaska, causing significant environmental impact.

1990.event: Abolition of state socialist colonies in Poland
1990.summary: Poland becomes the first country in Eastern Europe to begin abolishing its state socialist colonies.
The comedy television series of Rowan Atkinson's Mr. Bean first aired on ITV in the United Kingdom.
300,000 demonstrate for independence in the Lithuania SSR, marking a critical point in the Singing Revolution.
ADtranz low floor tram world's first completely low-floor tram is introduced in Bremen.
Nelson Mandela is released from Victor Verster Prison, near Cape Town, South Africa, after 27 years of imprisonment.
The Lithuanian SSR declares independence from the Soviet Union with the Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania.
STS-31: The Hubble Space Telescope is launched aboard Space Shuttle Discovery.

1990.event: Signing of Currency and Economic Merger
1990.summary: West Germany and East Germany agree to merge currency and economies, marking a step towards reunification.

1990.event: Launch of the World Wide Web
1990.summary: Tim Berners-Lee begins his work on the World Wide Web, setting the stage for a digital revolution.
The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) is founded to aid Eastern European countries transition to market economies.

1991.summary: Czechoslovakia becomes the second Eastern European country to abandon its command economy
Operation Desert Storm begins with air strikes against Iraq
Soviet forces storm Vilnius to stop Lithuanian independence, killing civilians
Tim Berners-Lee announces the World Wide Web project and software
Estonia declares independence from the Soviet Union
Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president, marking the end of the Soviet Union
South Africa repeals the last legal foundations of apartheid
The UN Security Council passes Resolution 687, calling for Iraqi disarmament
The world's first GSM telephone call is made in Finland

1991.event: First free parliamentary elections in Poland
1991.summary: The first free parliamentary elections in Poland since 1928 are held

1992.summary: The Maastricht Treaty is signed, founding the European Union.
First confirmed detection of exoplanets announced, impacting astronomy and potentially inspiring composers.
Slovenia and Croatia gain independence and international recognition, reshaping the geopolitical landscape.
Officials and rebel leaders sign peace accords in Mexico City, marking the end of a civil war.
U.S. President George H. W. Bush meets with Russian President Boris Yeltsin to declare the Cold War over.
Riots break out in Los Angeles following a controversial verdict, affecting national discourse.
The concert is televised live to over one billion people, raising millions for AIDS research and inspiring musicians.
The Earth Summit is held in Rio de Janeiro, focusing global attention on environmental issues.
In a landmark referendum, white South Africans vote in favor of reforms ending apartheid.
The Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina proclaims independence from Yugoslavia, sparking conflict.

1993.summary: Czechoslovakia ceases to exist, as the Czech Republic and Slovakia separate.
The European Economic Community eliminates trade barriers, creating a European single market.
Presidents George H. W. Bush and Boris Yeltsin sign the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty in Moscow.
The Chemical Weapons Convention is signed, aiming to eliminate chemical weapons globally.
A van bomb explodes at the World Trade Center in New York City, killing six people and injuring over one thousand.

1993.event: Bill Clinton sworn in as President
1993.summary: Bill Clinton is sworn in as the 42nd President of the United States.

1993.event: March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom
1993.summary: Prominent civil rights activists march in Washington D.C. advocating for jobs, justice, and civil rights.
Eritrea gains independence from Ethiopia, verified by the United Nations.

1993.event: National Geographic announces increase in human population
1993.summary: National Geographic reports the human population exceeds 5 billion, raising concerns about resources.
The Maastricht Treaty takes effect, formally establishing the European Union.

1994.summary: The North American Free Trade Agreement is established, facilitating trade between the U.S., Canada, and Mexico.
The Irish government announces the end of a 15-year broadcasting ban on Sinn Féin, potentially impacting media and political discourse.
The first photo of Pluto and its moon Charon is revealed, sparking interest in space exploration.
The Linux kernel version 1.0.0 is released, marking a significant milestone in open-source software development.
The Church of England ordains its first female priests, marking a major change in the religious landscape.
The Rwandan genocide begins, leading to a massive humanitarian crisis and international ramifications.
Nelson Mandela is inaugurated as South Africa's first black president, signifying the end of apartheid.
South Africa holds its first fully multiracial elections, transitioning to a democratic government.
The Channel Tunnel officially opens, enhancing transportation connections between England and France.
American rapper Nas releases the influential album Illmatic, which shapes the hip-hop genre.

1995.summary: The World Trade Organization is established to replace the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
The 6.9 Great Hanshin earthquake strikes Japan causing significant casualties and displacement

1995.event: AFC Ajax Wins UEFA Champions League
1995.summary: AFC Ajax wins the UEFA Champions League by defeating A.C. Milan
A car bomb explodes outside a Federal building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people
More than 170 countries agree to extend the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty indefinitely
Sony enters the North American video game market with the release of the PlayStation

1995.event: Discovery of Extrasolar Planet 51 Pegasi b
1995.summary: Michel Mayor and Didier Queloz announce the discovery of 51 Pegasi b, the first confirmed extrasolar planet
The Dayton Agreement to end the Bosnian War is reached
Units of the Army of Republika Srpska enter Srebrenica, committing mass atrocities
Russian paramilitary troops begin a massacre of at least 250 civilians in Samashki, Chechnya

1996.summary: A Zairean cargo plane crashes into a crowded market, resulting in approximately 300 deaths.
Yasser Arafat is re-elected as president of the Palestinian Authority, impacting the Middle East peace process.
An amateur astronomer discovers Comet Hyakutake, which is set to pass close to Earth, influencing astronomical studies and cultural interest.
France conducts its last nuclear weapons test, marking a significant moment in global nuclear policy.
Cuban fighter jets shoot down two American aircraft, escalating tensions between the US and Cuba.
China begins military exercises near Taiwan, causing international concern.
Dolly the sheep becomes the first mammal cloned from an adult cell, leading to advances in genetic research.

1996.event: Introduction of the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty
1996.summary: The Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty is signed, aiming to prohibit all nuclear explosions.
The element copernicium is created, contributing to advances in chemistry and material science.

1996.event: First direct elections for Taiwanese president
1996.summary: Taiwan holds its first direct elections for president, marking a significant step in its democratic processes.

1997.summary: The Emergency Alert System is introduced in the United States.
IBM's Deep Blue defeats Garry Kasparov, marking the first time a computer beats a chess World champion in a match.
Astronauts from the Space Shuttle Discovery start tune-up and repair work on the Hubble Space Telescope.
The first genetically modified three-parent baby is born.
The 13-kilometer Confederation Bridge, the world's longest bridge spanning ice-covered waters, opens in Canada.

1997.event: First Color Photograph on NY Times
1997.summary: The first color photograph appears on the front page of The New York Times.
Katrina and the Waves win the Eurovision Song Contest 1997 for the United Kingdom with Love Shine a Light.
Scientists report their DNA analysis findings from a Neanderthal skeleton, supporting the out of Africa theory of human evolution.
NASA launches the Cassini-Huygens probe to Saturn.
The Kyoto Protocol is adopted by a United Nations committee.

1998.summary: The Lunar Prospector spacecraft is launched into orbit around the Moon, and later finds evidence for frozen water in permanently shadowed craters near the Moon's poles.
NASA announces that the Clementine probe orbiting the Moon has found enough water in polar craters to support a human colony and rocket fueling station.
An hour after the end of the talks deadline, the Belfast Agreement is signed between the Irish and British governments and most Northern Ireland political parties.
The first euro coins are minted in Pessac, France, setting the stage for a major change in European currency.
An Intercity-Express high-speed train derails in Germany, causing 101 deaths.

1998.event: Start of the Second Congo War
1998.summary: The Second Congo War begins, which will lead to millions of deaths and drastically affect the region.
Google, Inc. is founded, eventually becoming one of the most influential technology companies in the world.
Voyager 1 overtakes Pioneer 10 as the most distant man-made object from the Solar System.
A Russian Proton rocket is launched carrying the first segment of the International Space Station, marking a significant advancement in space exploration.
Valve Corporation releases their first-person shooter video game Half-Life, which will influence future video game design.

1999.summary: The euro currency is established and the European Central Bank assumes its full powers.
Napster, a music downloading service, is created and inspires file-sharing sites.
NATO launches air strikes against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, marking the first attack by NATO on a sovereign state.
A U.S. Lockheed F-117 Nighthawk is shot down by Yugoslav forces during the Kosovo War.
The 71st Academy Awards are held, with Shakespeare in Love winning Best Picture.
Nunavut, an Inuit homeland, is created from the eastern portion of the Northwest Territories.
NATO bombers hit the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, killing three Chinese workers.
The first shuttle mission to dock with the International Space Station is launched.
Yugoslavia and NATO sign a peace treaty to end the Kosovo War hostilities.
East Timor votes for independence from Indonesia in a referendum.
